DOC.HEAD: Accounting System Rapped
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force lacks an accurate accounting system, similar to those in private industry, that could forecast problems in its billions of dollars of weapons purchases, according to a draft report by congressional investigators. The Washington Post said in Thursday editions that an early draft of the report said the Air Force had ``grossly understated'' the cost of major weapons systems by tens of billions of dollars over the past decade. It said costs of frontline warplanes were understated by $27 billion from 1975 to 1988, and $18 billion in unneeded equipment was purchased. The Air Force is now spending about $14 billion a year buying aircraft of all kinds. A source at the General Accounting Office, whose analysts prepared the report, said the severely critical comments of the draft obtained by the newspaper might have been toned down somewhat in later drafts. In comments included in the report, the Air Force largely concurs with the overall assessment by the GAO investigators _ that its system has problems, the GAO source said, speaking on condition on anonymity. The newspaper quoted an Air Force statement as saying the report ``creates a faulty impression of waste and mismanagement.'' The GAO source said the document should not be taken to ``mean they don't have any (financial) control over systems (purchases).'' The report makes more than 20 recommendations to improve Air Force accounting. Charles Bowsher, comptroller general and head of the General Accounting Office, has been worried that the government's accounting systems are out of date. He chose to examine the Air Force system on the grounds that it is the best in the Defense Department, the GAO source said. The report had been planned for transmittal to the Senate Government Operations Committee, chaired by Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio., on March 1.

DOC.HEAD: Bonnie Raitt Leads Grammys With Four Awards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with record of the year, producer of the year; picks up 10th graf pvs: `Bolton, who ...; SUBS 21st graf, `Bobby Brown ..., to UPDATE with Anita Baker as top female R&B vocalist; DELETES grafs 22-24, `Living Color ..., to tighten; should stand for AMs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA14,15,17,22,26,27, LaserColor LA29
DOC.TEXT: Rock survivor Bonnie Raitt, who has toiled in the vineyards of obscurity since the 1960s, won four Grammy awards Wednesday, including album of the year, for her critically acclaimed ``Nick of Time'' album. ``Wind Beneath My Wings,'' a ballad performed by two-time Grammy winner Bette Midler, written Larry Henley and Jeff Silbar, won record of the year and song of the year. ``This record's my first No. 1,'' gushed Midler to the audience at the 32nd annual Grammy Awards show. ``I had to wait 17 years for it. I hope I don't have to wait another 17.'' ``I can only take so much of this,'' said Raitt, accepting her fourth award, female pop vocalist. ``Wake me up when this is over.'' Raitt also won female rock vocalist and shared the traditional blues award with John Lee Hooker for ``I'm in the Mood'' on Hooker's ``The Healer'' album. ``This means so much for the kind of music I do, and means those of us who do rhythm and blues are going to get a chance again,'' said Raitt, 40, a four-time nominee. It was a night for survivors. Don Henley, formerly of the Eagles, won male rock vocalist for his lyrical, melancholy ``The End of the Innocence.'' Henley, co-wrote the album's title track with Bruce Hornsby. It was his sixth career Grammy. ``Great. You sing a song, you win an award,'' a smiling Henley said, accepting his award moments after performing the tune with Hornsby. Blue-eyed soul balladeer Michael Bolton won best male pop vocalist Grammy for ``How Am I Supposed to Live Without You.'' Linda Ronstadt and Aaron Neville won pop duo honors for their love duet ``Don't Know Much.'' Their producer, Peter Asher, who began his career in the '60s as half of the Peter & Gordon duo, was named producer of the year. Bolton, who has been recording since the '70s, acknowledged his ``overnight success'' and thanked ``Ray Charles for blessing us all and opening his mouth and singing.'' Ronstadt thanked Neville's mother: ``She gave us not only Aaron, but all the Neville Brothers and that's a pretty great musical contribution.'' Neville had his first Top 10 hit in 1966 with ``Tell It Like It Is.'' Ronstadt first made the charts with the Stone Poneys in ``Different Drum'' in 1968. The first televised Grammy award in the rap music category went to Young MC for the single ``Bust a Move.'' Last year the miniature gramophone trophy for rap was presented off-camera and some rappers boycotted the ceremony. Lyle Lovett won male country vocal honors for ``Lyle Lovett and His Large Band'' album; k.d. lang won country music's female vocalist award for ``Absolute Torch and Twang.'' Milli Vanilli, the Munich-based, dredlocked pop duo of Fab Morvan and Rob Pilatus, won best new artist honors despite the ``hip-hopping radio fodder'' label given them by Rolling Stone magazine. Slick rhythm and blues group Soul II Soul, legendary jazz artist Miles Davis and jazz composer-arranger Dave Grusin were early multiple winners in pre-broadcast ceremonies at the Shrine Auditorium. Soul II Soul won the rhythm and blues group performance for the single ``Back to Life,'' and the R&B instrumental Grammy for the ``African Dance'' track from their ``Keep on Movin' '' album. Davis, already recipient of a lifetime achievement award from the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, won best jazz solo instrumental for ``Aura'' and won for the same album in the big band jazz instrumental category. Grusin won three Grammys, for the background score of the movie ``The Fabulous Baker Boys,'' instrumental arrangement for the suite from ``The Milagro Beanfield War'' and arrangement with vocals for the ``My Funny Valentine'' track from ```Baker Boys.'' The all-star collaboration of The Traveling Wilburys won the rock vocal group Grammy, ending the Rolling Stones' latest bid for a first Grammy. Brother and sister Michael and Janet Jackson won back-to-back music video trophies. Michael won the short form Grammy for his ``Leave Me Alone'' and Janet claimed the long form category for ``Rhythm Nation 1814.'' Bobby Brown won as best rhythm and blues male vocalist for his ``Every Little Step'' single; and female R&B vocalist honors went to Anita Baker for ``Giving You the Best That I've Got.'' In the classical categories, Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic won best orchestral performance for ``Mahler: Symphony No. 3 in D Minor,'' and cellist Yo-Yo Ma won the instrumental soloist award for ``Barber: Cello Concerto, Op. 22-Britten Symphony for Cello and Orchestra, Op. 68.'' The late Gilda Radner won the best spoken word Grammy for her album ``It's Always Something.'' ``After All This Time'' was named best country song, earning a Grammy for singer-songwriter Rodney Crowell. Former Beatle Paul McCartney and Davis were chosen for the Academy's Lifetime Achievement Award, and Dick Clark received a Trustees Award, for achievements in the non-performing side of the industry.

The Academy also gave two posthumous Lifetime Achievement Awards to singer Nat ``King'' Cole and pianist Vladimir Horowitz. The achievement awards recognize performers who have made contributions of outstanding artistic significance. Earlier recipients have included the Rolling Stones, Elvis Presley, Bing Crosby, Frank Sinatra and Arturo Toscanini. Grammy winners are chosen by the nearly 6,000 active members of the academy, a non-profit organization formed to represent all segments of the recording industry. The Grammy Awards began in 1958 with 28 categories, since increased to nearly 80.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Says Alaska Oil-Spill Cleanup to Begin May 1
With AM-Hazelwood Trial
DOC.TEXT: Starting May 1, Exxon will resume its cleanup of oil remaining in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska from the nation's largest oil spill, company officials said Wednesday. Exxon suspended its cleanup in September because of the onset of severe winter weather, but had declined to set a date for further work. ``We know now that some additional work is going to be needed,'' spokesman Joe Tucker said. ``Additional cleanup as required will begin around May 1, weather permitting.'' Exxon officials said survey teams found oil at a depth of 28 inches in one site. But at most problem areas the depth was about 4 to 6 inches, said Hann Jahns, an Exxon scientist. The company found serious problems along about 10 of the 90 miles of shoreline its crews surveyed, Jahns said. The extent of the remaining work will not be determined until April, Tucker said. But he predicted the 1990 cleanup would be ``substantially smaller'' than efforts carried out last year. The tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground March 24 on Bligh Reef south of Valdez, spewing nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude. Hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline were covered with oil and countless birds and sea mammals died. Following a meeting of 70 oil-spill officials in Anchorage on Tuesday, Coast Guard Rear Adm. David Ciancaglini announced that Exxon would resume the cleanup. Ciancaglini said Exxon was not ordered to return. ``Exxon will return because they are needed to do so,'' he said. Exxon, federal and state officials have agreed on a basic schedule for the spring cleanup, Tucker said. The company will submit a general cleanup plan to Ciancaglini by March 15. Ciancaglini, the federal on-scene coordinator for the cleanup, said he will have to approve Exxon's plan before it is put into effect. Exxon, the Coast Guard and state and federal agencies will develop the best strategy and decide on the appropriate methods to remove the remaining oil, Ciancaglini said. The agencies and Exxon have been working for weeks to assess how much oil has been removed by waves, rain and other natural processes. Though they disagree on the exact amounts, all say winter has had a major cleansing effect on the sound. But they say some of the more protected areas are still in trouble. Ciancaglini said survey crews from Exxon, the state Department of Environmental Conservation and other agencies would spend most of April surveying the shores. They will meet in late April to develop clean-up strategies. He praised Exxon's cooperation in assessing the cleanup needs with state and federal officials. But he said he would not hesitate to order a federal takeover of the cleanup if Exxon refused to carry out the work.

DOC.HEAD: Prolific Author of Books for Youngsters Dies
DOC.TEXT: _ Harold Leland Goodwin, a prolific author who wrote science adventure books for youngsters and books about space exploration for general readers, has died. He was 75. Goodwin, who wrote under the pseudonym John Blaine, died of cardiac arrest at his Bethesda, Md., home Sunday. Goodwin worked at various times for NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. His largest enterprise was the 26-volume ``Rick Brant Science Adventure Series'' for youngsters. The first book, ``Rocket's Shadow,'' was published in 1947 and the most recent, ``The Magic Talisman,'' came out this year.

DOC.HEAD: `Cosby Show' in Top 10 Twice
DOC.TEXT: ``The Cosby Show'' finished in the top 10 twice in the A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings, while more people watched ``The Color Purple'' than the first part of ``The Kennedys of Massachusetts'' miniseries. NBC won the ratings race for the week ended Feb. 18 with an average of 15.7, followed by ABC with 12.6 and CBS with 12.1, according to figures released Tuesday. A ratings point represents the percentage of the nation's 92.1 million television shows tuned into a show. Here are the Top 10 shows, their networks and ratings: ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 23.9; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 23.3; (tie) ``Movie of the Week _ Blind Faith Part 2,'' NBC, 23.3; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 21.9; ``The Cosby Show Special,'' NBC, 21.6; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 21.2; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 20.5; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 20.4; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 19.9; ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC, 19.4 NBC scored strongly on Monday night by using a special airing of the ``Cosby'' show, ``The Golden Girls,'' ``Dear John'' and ``Empty Nest.'' The network claimed a 10 percent gain above its normal Monday average. Also Monday, CBS' ``The Love Boat: A Valentine Voyage'' was 38th in the ratings, while ABC's broadcast of ``Jewel of the Nile'' was 41st. NBC won all the nights of the week except Friday against ABC's lineup and Sunday, when it offered ``The Death of the Incredible Hulk'' against CBS' broadcast of the theatrical movie ``The Color Purple'' and ABC's first installment of ``The Kennedys'' miniseries. ``The Color Purple'' took 18th place with a 17.1 rating, followed by ``The Kennedys'' tied at 20th with a 15.8 rating and the ``Hulk'' movie tied for No. 24 with a 14.6 rating. ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' was in 6th place on ABC with a 21.2 rating, but ``Elvis,'' the midseason show following it Sunday night was at No. 43. The half-hour series about the life of the rock legend had a 12.5 rating. Up against ``Elvis'' was the cartoon family from Fox, ``The Simpsons,'' which tied for 24th place with two other shows and was the ``fourth network's'' highest-rated show during the week. Another new show for the midseason, CBS' ``The Bradys,'' was 61st. NBC's new series ``Grand'' was ranked 17th, but its 17.2 rating was more than six points below that for ``Cheers,'' its lead-in. The NBC comedy special, ``Bob Hope Lampoons Show Business'' on Saturday night, ranked 30th for the week. For the season to date, NBC leads the averages with 14.8, followed by ABC with 13.0 and CBS with 12.3. For the evening news shows, ABC led with a weekly average of 11.3, followed by NBC with 10.1 and CBS with 9.9. The five bottom-ranked network shows were ``Tour of Duty,'' CBS, 7.9; ``Saturday Night With Connie Chung,'' CBS, 7.8; ``Grand Slam,'' CBS, 7.5; ``48 Hours,'' CBS, 7.3, and ``Mission Impossible,'' ABC, 6.2.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europe's Challenge
Part IV: U.S. Companies Proceed With Caution in Last Economic Frontier
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: When Sybron Corp. negotiated a joint venture in Budapest, talks stalled while attorneys for the Hungarian partners grappled to translate ``profit.'' ``It was difficult to put the word profit in the contract in Hungarian so we wrote it in German,'' said Donald Rackl, chief financial officer for the Milwaukee manufacturer. Sybron weathered that and other problems starting its first business in Eastern Europe. The company expects to dance around bigger business potholes when its microscope-slide plant starts production this year. Even a veteran like Pepsico Inc., after years of operating in the region, has altered the way it does business to cope with problems alien to the West. Pepsi plants in Czechoslovakia sometimes run out of bottles due to late shipments. In the Ukraine, state officials waylay delivery trucks to haul harvested wheat, said Richard Norton, Pepsico vice president for Eastern Europe. Such inconveniences are a way of life in countries still shaking off the dust of communist rule. Less easily overcome are structural and economic problems: rapid inflation, huge foreign debt and inconvertible currencies that make it difficult to turn profits into dollars. In many respects, the revolution in Eastern Europe remains only a promise. Several countries have no laws on foreign ownership and joint ventures. They lack legal systems and courts, leaving Western businesses vulnerable if, for example, suppliers don't deliver and customers don't pay. Yet for all the problems, Eastern Europe may represent the greatest commercial and financial opportunity since the rebuilding of Western Europe after World War II. The region's 136 million consumers crave everything from french fries to shoe polish, telephones to computer disks. For companies with global aspirations and patience for profits, Eastern Europe is ``a pot of gold,'' said Marvin Zonis, a University of Chicago business professor. ``There are real possibilities out there and they ought to be pursued.'' The Commerce Department's own analysts say firms dealing in agriculture, health care, telecommunications, energy, tourism and housing may have the best chance of gaining entry and prospering in East European markets. There are plenty of reasons for American companies to invest. Cheap labor is one of the biggest. The average hourly manufacturing wage in Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia in 1988 was $1.35 to $1.71, said PlanEcon Inc., a Washington research concern specializing in Eastern Europe. Wages could even fall in dollar terms because of an expected decline in exchange rates. Moreover, East European workers are relatively well-educated and highly trained compared with Third World counterparts. Low productivity may be a concern, but some economists say that can be corrected. ``Workers get lazy and depressed when they get stuck with guys who are doing a bad job of running things,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Perhaps the biggest incentive for U.S. corporations is global competition. American giants like General Electric, International Business Machines and General Motors are already there, but so are rivals Suzuki; Siemens, West Germany's giant electronics company; Ferruzzi Finanziara, Italy's leading chemical and agribusiness company; and British Telecom. Others are on the way. Eugene Theroux, an attorney in the Washington office of the international law firm Baker & McKenzie, said it's a mistake for American businesses to sit back and watch. ``They should make at least a minimum of time, effort and expense necessary to examine the alternatives,'' said Theroux, who advises companies doing business in communist countries. Many companies are doing just that. The Commerce Department and Chamber of Commerce say they're getting 10 times as many inquiries as last year from American companies _ on everything from investment laws to opportunities and licensing. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher opened an information office on Eastern Europe in January to handle all the calls. Lawyers, travel agents and public relations firms are leading the way, establishing offices and advertising for Western clients. ``Cautious optimism has been replaced by opportunism,'' said Richard W. Edelman, president of New York-based Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, which has opened offices in Hungary and is scouting elsewhere. But American executives already experienced in Eastern Europe warn newcomers to calculate the risks. Many early joint ventures in the Soviet Union failed for lack of careful business plans. Those who decide to go should be prepared to stay awhile. ``This is an investment that will have long-term rewards instead of a short-term immediate impact,'' said Andrew B. Somers Jr., general counsel for American Express Corp., which has offices in several East European countries. ``This is not something you dabble in.'' Companies in the vanguard also must be prepared to sacrifice time and resources to gain a foothold, as McDonald's discovered opening its first restaurant in Moscow. The opening took McDonald's 14 years, $50 million and its own supply system that bypasses the deadly Soviet bureacracy. While the Soviet Union is considered more treacherous for enterprising Westerners, economists say Eastern Europe is similar. ``Right now if I were an American company I would think the prospects were very risky given the political and economic transition,'' said Georgetown University professor Stewart Brown. Congress has authorized $300 million in aid for private enterprise in Poland and Hungary. The federal Export-Import Bank will guarantee loans up to $200 million to Hungary and Yugoslavia. But U.S. companies will have to rely largely on their own resources to establish outposts in Eastern Europe. ``Anyone not prepared to suffer losses should not go in,'' Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: Marriott Overcomes Odds to Open Eastern Europe's First Western Hotel
With PM-EUR--US Prospects
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Opening a hotel is never easy, but launching the first Western-managed hotel in Poland taxed the creativity of veteran Marriott Corp. executives. Reaching a joint-venture agreement for the Warsaw Marriott was just the start. Next was the problem of furnishing and equipping the 41-story, 520-room hotel, built in the shell of a dormant Warsaw skyscraper. ``Just about everything was imported,'' said Marriott spokesman Gordon Lambourne. Then there was the matter of finding local employees with the proper attitude. ``The sense of hospitality, the sense of private enterprise doesn't exist,'' said William R. Tiefel, president of Marriott's hotels division. ``There's not much incentive to be very creative in a job.'' The most difficult task was securing a reliable supply of food and drink for the hotel's 11 restaurants and bars. You don't shop for prime rib and fine wine in a country where shoppers queue for bread and potatoes. Marriott's problems reflect the difficulties inherent in cultivating capitalism in old state-run economies. It's not a matter of adding a little water and fertilizer. You have to plant the very seeds. Marriott took the challenge literally. It signed contracts with Polish farmers, fishermen and a brewery to ensure a more-or-less steady stream of local provisions ranging from beer to lettuce. It even imported the seed used by the farmers so the produce would be up to its standards. In addition, Marriott built a freezing and canning plant to ensure a year-round supply, along with huge food lockers and storage areas to hold a month's worth of goods, much of it imported. The hotel opened in October, and the company is pleased enough that it's considering outposts in other major East bloc cities, including Budapest, Prague and Moscow. Marriott is no stranger to opening hotels in non-Western countries; it had to negotiate similar food procurement contracts in the Middle East and Barbados, Tiefel said. But the Warsaw hotel posed the most difficult problems the company ever faced, he said. The idea for the hotel, the first U.S.-Polish joint venture since the end of American economic sanctions against Poland in 1987, began four years ago when Marriott was contacted by partners in its Vienna hotel, Tiefel said. The parters _ Ilbau, the Austrian construction company that built the hotel, and Girozentrale, the bank that financed it _ joined with LOT, the Polish government-owned airline, in proposing the Warsaw hotel. They wanted Marriott to run it. Under the joint venture, Marriott holds an approximate 25 percent interest in ownership and operation of the hotel and the office space that occupies 20 of the building's floors. It also gets an undisclosed percentage of profits. The hotel's rooms are rented for foreign currency only, and the Polish government gets a cut. The restaurants and bars accept zlotys, the Polish currency, which are used to pay most hotel expenses. As for staffing, Tiefel said, ``There was not a work force to draw on that had experience in the lodging business.'' So the criteria changed. ``The bigger the smile, the quicker we hired them,'' he said. Marriott brought in 25 managers to school the staff. In addition, it trained 22 Polish workers in the United States and brought in several dozen housekeepers, bartenders and other employees from its Western hotels to work alongside their Polish counterparts, Tiefel said. Samir Daqqaq, the hotel's marketing director, said Western managers in Poland need ``a very deep well of patience. You don't train just once, it is an ongoing process.'' The employees are given two meals daily, partly to reduce food theft, in addition to wages slightly above what they would get elsewhere in Poland. The pay is adjusted monthly for the nation's runaway inflation, Marriott said. But perhaps the most prized perks are the hotel uniforms. ``One bellman _ we have these really nice bellman's uniforms _ he postponed his wedding so he could wear it on his wedding day,'' Lambourne said.

DOC.HEAD: Decaying Whale Carcass Lies On Beach While Officials Decide Who'll Remove It
DOC.TEXT: More than a week after it was discovered, the body of a 15-ton whale that washed ashore still lay on the beach while officials decided which province would remove it. The whale washed ashore about nine days ago at el-Omeid about 55 miles west of this Mediterranean city but had not been removed by Tuesday because officials in Alexandria claimed the half-buried carcass was not in their province but in that of Mersa Matruh. Mersa Matruh is unequipped to deal with the body of such a large animal, which rarely appears in Egypt's Mediterranean waters. The last time a dead whale was washed ashore in Egypt was in 1936, said Sherif Ramadan at the Oceanography Institute. An official at Alexandria's fire department said that if Mersa Matruh asked for help, it would send firefighters with cranes along with butchers to cut up the whale's body, which was so disintegrated it could not be lifted whole.

DOC.HEAD: Pittston Coal Contract Highlights
With PM-Coal Strike, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are key provisions of the contract approved by United Mine Workers in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky who have been on strike since April 5 against the Pittston Coal Group: _ Term: 4 years. _ Wages: top scale of $17.52 an hour in selected positions, a raise of $1.20 an hour. _ Health benefits: 100 percent medical coverage for employees, pensioners and their families. _ Retirement: pension benefits identical to the 1988 agreement between the UMW and the Bituminous Coal Operators Association. _ Job security: Pittston can hire contract workers for transportation and equipment repair and maintenance if no union miners are laid off. Laid-off union miners must be hired for the first four of every five job openings at Pittston's non-union mines and providers of contract workers must agree to offer the first 19 of every 20 jobs to laid-off union miners. _ Working hours: flexible schedules, including four-day weeks of 10 hours each and 28-day shift rotations, which would allow almost round-the-clock operation of mines.

DOC.HEAD: Pittston Coal Strike Chronology
With PM-Coal Strike, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of significant events in the strike between the United Mine Workers union and Pittston Coal Group Inc.: May 19, 1987: Pittston said it would leave the Bituminous Coal Operators Association and negotiate independently with the UMW beginning for a contract to replace the national contract expiring Jan. 31, 1988. April 5, 1989: UMW called a strike against Pittston in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky for alleged unfair labor practices after union members worked 14 months without a contract. April 12: UMW members arrested for throwing rocks at company trucks in Dickenson County, the first of hundreds of violent acts designed to disrupt coal shipments and intimidate replacement workers. April 27: More than 1,000 UMW members and supporters blocked two mines in a sit-down demonstration, the beginning of a civil disobedience campaign that led to more than 2,000 arrests in the first three months of the strike. May 8: Negotiations began through the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. May 16: Russell County Circuit Judge Donald McGlothlin fined the UMW $642,000 for violating his order limiting strike activities and prohibiting the disruption of Pittston operations. McGlothlin's fines eventually totalled $64.5 million. June 5: U.S. District Judge Glenn Williams threw UMW strike coordinators Marty Hudson and Jackie Stump in jail for contempt of court. They were released two weeks later. June 7: The union withdrew from federally mediated negotiations, accusing Pittston of bargaining in bad faith. June 10: Pittston declared an impasse in negotiations and implemented its final contract offer, essentially saying take it or leave it. June 11: UMW President Richard Trumka promised to widen the strike. The next day, a series of wildcat strikes began that spread to the Midwest and eventually had more than 46,000 miners off the job in sympathy with the Pittston strikers. June 19: Union members and supporters, including wildcat strikers from other states, began bumper-to-bumper convoys of several hundred cars and trucks to slow coal shipments. The tactic ended a few weeks later after Williams fined the union nearly $1 million and began throwing drivers in jail for contempt of court. July 8: The National Labor Relations Board issued an unfair labor practices complaint against Pittston. July 18: UMW and Pittston agreed to resume federally mediated contract talks but could not agree to meet in the same room and negotiations failed to progress. Aug. 23: Trumka, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland and 19 officials representing a dozen other unions arrested in a sit-down demonstration at the Russell County, Va., courthouse. Sept. 17: Ninety-eight striking miners and union officials launched an unarmed invasion of Pittston's main processing and shipping plant in Russell County and occupied it for four days while as many as 3,000 supporters rallied outside. Oct. 11: International labor leaders, including representatives of the Polish Solidarity, attended a rally of Pittston strikers and took the strikers' case to Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole the next day in Washington. Oct. 13: Dole visited striking miners and Pittston workers and announced she would meet with Trumka and Pittston Co. Chairman Paul Douglas for the two sides' first face-to-face meeting since June. Two weeks later, Dole appointed former Labor Secretary William Usery to mediate. Nov. 9: Contract talks resumed with Trumka and Douglas at the table. Jan. 1: Dole, Trumka and Douglas announced a tentative settlement and agreed to withhold a vote on it until all strike-related litigation was dissolved. Feb. 12: McGlothlin refused to drop the $64 million in fines. Two days later, Judge Williams agreed to reduce his fines against the union from $960,000 to $228,000. Feb. 19: The rank-and-file voted 1,247 to 734 in favor of the contract.

DOC.HEAD: `Supermediator' Claims Another Big Settlement
With PM-Coal Strike, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When W.J. Usery entered the bitter Pittston Coal strike he was called a ``supermediator,'' a term that seems particularly appropriate with both labor and management praising the agreement he helped to forge. ``I've seen so much malice and hate across the table,'' Usery said, ``but if they really listen to each other, they find they're not quite as far apart as they thought. Some people say, `You just wear 'em down,' but I don't think that's all true.'' Maybe so. But the former labor secretary readily concedes using marathon bargaining sessions in his effort to bring parties to agreement. Those who've worked with Usery in various negotiations say he sets an unrelenting, sometimes round-the-clock pace at the bargaining table. In the Pittston talks, Usery kept negotiators at the table for 96 hours straight in a failed bid to reach an accord by Christmas. He nearly succeeded. The agreement approved by miners Monday had been reached New Year's Eve. ``When you're on a nine-month strike, sometimes there's a tendency to say, `What's another day? What's another week?,'' Usery said, cautioning that ``if you recess for a few days, then you have to start all over again when you get back.'' When Usery was tapped by Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole to intervene in the Pittston strike in late October, he hesitated at first to enter the fray because of the acrimony between the two sides. At that point, management and labor hadn't bargained directly with one another since the walkout began in April. Instead, they were sending messages back and forth through a federal mediator. Usery was at the AFL-CIO's winter meeting in Bal Harbour, Fla., when the United Mine Workers announced Tuesday that Pittston workers had ratified the contract and would soon be back to work. ``It was a very difficult time. I confess I pushed very hard, long hours. I think today it's worth it,'' Usery told miners in Castlewood, Va., on a conference call as the results of the vote were announced. For his efforts, the Labor Department will pay his firm $250 an hour for days in which he worked less than six hours and $2,750 for days in which he worked more. Expenses will be paid separately. Usery has not submitted a bill. Part of his success, Usery said in an interview, lies in his ability to persuade negotiators to set emotions aside and listen to their counterparts. ``People in a strike sometimes just think about themselves. But it's not just, as in this case, the miners and their families who are losing money. Management loses, all the general stores, the schools, tax base. ... The churches don't get the same offerings,'' said the 66-year-old Usery. He said that the contract approval represented a huge victory for organized labor and that it showed that two sides, no matter how far apart they are in the bargaining process, can ultimately find a resolution. Jim Kennedy of the Railway Labor Executive Association said Usery has won acclaim for bringing two sides together when it appears they are ``locked into their positions and nothing can dynamite them out.'' ``I've seen him push and cajole and bully and charm. He'll use any technique,'' Kennedy said. Longtime aide Herb Fishgold says Usery's own success story _ rising from being a shipyard welder to President Ford's labor secretary _ helps explain his mediating style, which often appeals to negotiators' patriotism. ``He tries to pay back the country by promoting it,'' Fishgold said. ``I've watched people at these things and you can just tell they're thinking, `Here we go, another speech about mom and apple pie.' But when it's all over, they're saying, `How did he do that?''' Usery himself says: ``I've been accused of waving the flag, of using the flag. But the world is so different now; there's a global economy, international concerns. ... We can't afford the luxury of long, lenthy disputes.'' Bob Healey, who was president of the Chicago Teachers Union when Usery helped settle a three-week strike there in 1983, goodnaturedly divulged that Usery sometimes would disappear for three or four hours during negotiations. ``We thought he was in trying to sell it to the school board, but we learned later he sneaks up and takes naps while nobody's looking.'' Usery grew up in Hardwick, Ga., and began his working career as a shipyard welder in World War II before joining the Navy and serving in the Pacific. After his discharge, he worked for the Armstrong Cork Co., where he helped organize a Machinists union local. Former President Nixon brought Usery to Washington in 1969 as an assistant secretary of labor. Usery immediately won praise for helping resolve complicated railroad and airline disputes without Congress having to step in. He was named director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in 1973. In 1976 Ford appointed him secretary of labor. Since going into private business, Usery has helped mediate disputes involving Chicago public school teachers, the United Auto Workers and General Motors and Toyota, and pro football players.

DOC.HEAD: Education Administrator Wins Seat Held by Councilman Killed by Mail Bomb
DOC.TEXT: An education administrator defeated a dentist in a runoff election Tuesday for the City Council seat held by a lawyer who died in December in a spate of Southeastern mail bombings. Clifford Hardwick, assistant dean for the Coastal Georgia Center for Continuing Education, received 1,467 votes to 1,127 for dentist Phyllis Mack, in the race to succeed Robert Robinson. The 2,594 voters represented a turnout of 29.4 percent in the council district. Hardwick, 62, led a field of eight candidates in the first election Jan. 30, but didn't get the 50 percent minimum needed to take the race, forcing a runoff. Robinson represented the city's 5th District, a predominantly black area which runs through Savannah's historic Victorian District. He was killed by a mail bomb Dec. 18 following the mail-bomb assassination of federal appeals Judge Robert Vance in Mountain Brook, Ala. Bombs were also sent to a federal courthouse in Atlanta and the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, but were safely removed.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles in Charleston for Business Conference
LaserPhoto Upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Great Britain's Prince Charles told business leaders from around the globe Tuesday that the world needs a ``new deal'' where capitalism takes on a more humane face. ``The crucial factor is whether such an approach can be commercial. And yet, surely, it must be good business in the long run,'' the Prince of Wales told about 100 corporate executives gathered for an international business conference. The prince arrived in Charleston around noon and was warmly cheered by a crowd of about 200 people as he entered the Old Exchange Building, where South Carolinians ratified the U.S. Constitution in 1788. About 100 chief executive officers and top business officials are attending a two-day meeting of Business in the Community, a London-based group founded by the prince which brings corporate leaders together to discuss the roles and responsibilities of business. ``Business is at a crossroads,'' Charles told the conference. ``Does it enter new markets like the cowboys of the new frontier or does it take a rather more sophisticated approach which leads to continued, rather than short-term profit?'' He suggested business leaders can neither take a short-term approach in search of quick profits nor leave the larger problems of the environment and education only to the government. ``There is no better illustration of this than the greatly increased concern by consumers about the impact of business processes and products upon the environment,'' he said. ``These are no longer frontier days when businesses can afford to make short-term decisions.'' The prince, who will be in Charleston through Wednesday, is making his second visit to the city once known as Charles Towne. He last visited in 1977. During a lunch with the business leaders, the prince praised Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. for the mayor's efforts to build the antebellum tourist city into an international asset. ``Charleston has ridden out disaster and setbacks over many years, not just the terrifying recent effects and loss caused by Hurricane Hugo,'' he said, referring to the Sept. 21 storm that left 29 dead and $5.9 billion in damage in South Carolina. Riley said the prince's visit would focus attention on the fact that Charleston has bounced back after the hurricane. Tuesday night the prince and about 400 people attended a black-tie gala to benefit hurricane victims. About 100 people looked on as business leaders and a who's who of Charleston society entered the brightly lit Hibernian Hall for an evening of dancing. Guests were asked to donate $100 each to the hurricane relief effort. The prince is expected to attend several more conference sessions Wednesday, and visit a public housing complex. He plans to leave Thursday for Washington for a meeting with President Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Genetically Engineered Trees Important Step Toward `Energy Plantations'
DOC.TEXT: Development of the first genetically engineered trees is an important step toward creation of energy plantations on which forests would be grown for fuel, researchers say. The trees, engineered from a species of poplar, were altered to make them resistant to a widely used herbicide, says Bruce E. Haissig of the U.S. Forest Service laboratory in Rhinelander, Wis. Haissig reported on his work at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science on Tuesday. A mutant gene from a species of bacteria called salmonella, which commonly causes food poisoning, was introduced into the trees, making the trees resistant to glyphosate, a herbicide marketed as Roundup. Growing poplars on plantations has been difficult because the young trees can be crowded out and killed by weeds. Herbicides that are used to kill the weeds often kill or damage the poplars, Haissig said. The genetically engineered trees offer the hope of plantations in which a herbicide like Roundup can be used to kill the weeds without harming the trees, Haissig said. That would lower the cost of producing the trees, which grow rapidly and could be burned to provide energy or converted into ethanol to run automobiles, he said. The research has been partly supported by the U.S. Department of Energy, Haissig said. Scientists in Minnesota are working on the feasibility of the energy plantations. ``That blows hot and cold depending upon what the price of oil is,'' he said. Poplars are now grown as ornamental trees, Haissig said. ``They're a fast screen,'' he said. ``People grow them until they can get conifers behind them.'' In addition to their fast growth, poplars have another characteristic that makes them ideal for genetic engineering: They can be grown from bits of poplar tissue in laboratory culture dishes. When Haissig and colleagues at the University of Wisconsin and Calgene in Davis, Calif., inserted the salmonella gene into the poplars, the trees produced an enzyme that allowed them to survive after being sprayed with Roundup. In the first experiments, the genetically altered trees were unable to withstand levels of the herbicide used in the field. ``We had a scientific success, but not a commercial success,'' Haissig said. A second round of experiments improved the trees' resistance to the herbicide, he said. Because poplar trees do not flower for 15 years, the researchers have not determined whether the herbicide resistance will be inherited by the trees' offspring. The trees must flower before they can be bred through conventional means. Experiments are under way with jack pine, which flowers in two years, to see whether genetically engineered herbicide resistance is permanent. The genetic engineering of trees is limited because most trees cannot be regenerated from tree tissue grown in laboratory dishes _ a necessary step with present methods of genetic engineering. ``The most commercially important species are the most difficult to regenerate,'' Haissig said. That might be overcome, however, with a new technique in which a gun is used to fire gene-carrying microscopic particles into plant cells, he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Other Woman' In Trump Split Hires Lawyer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to UPDATE with Trump spokesman denying report about photos; SUBS penultimate graf with 2 grafs to UPDATE with details; picks up last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Model Marla Maples, fighting back after a week of portrayals as the Trump Tower home-wrecker, hired a lawyer Tuesday to stop the media from splashing her face and figure across the front page and the TV screen. ``We're retaining counsel,'' said her publicist, Chuck Jones. ``We plan an active pursuit of litigation against people wrongfully selling photos and videotape or making libelous statements against Marla.'' Jones did not say specifically who might be targeted in the model's fight-back campaign. Meanwhile, a newspaper reported that Donald Trump had ordered all pictures of his wife, Ivana, removed from their Florida estate, and that the operation took two days. A Trump spokesman denied the report. Miss Maples, who has not surfaced publicly since the Trump divorce story began last week, has been featured in front-page tabloid photos and in home video on television programs. Jones asserted some of this material was used without his client's approval. ``These people are making money off Marla's misfortune,'' said Jones. ``It's going to stop.'' The Trumps announced last week they were separating after nearly 13 years of marriage. Despite repeated denials, Miss Maples has been prominently mentioned as ``the other woman'' who lured Trump from his wife. Trump defended Miss Maples in an interview with the New York Post. ``Marla is an unfortunate victim of all this. She is really a very nice person who is really a friend,'' said Trump, who spent the weekend with his wife and their three children at the couple's Florida mansion. While stories about the couple's split continued to make the front page, neither side appeared any closer to filing divorce papers. Trump again mentioned the possibility of a reconciliation to the Daily News. ``I don't know what will happen. We'll have to see. ... I haven't discussed it with her, but I suppose anything is possible,'' Trump said. Mrs. Trump was in her office at the Plaza Hotel on Tuesday, said her spokesman, John Scanlon. ``She goes to work every day just like the rest of us,'' he said. ``She's OK, she's a strong woman, but she's obviously pained,'' said Scanlon. While Miss Maples was hiring an attorney, Mrs. Trump was attacking one. Her attorney, Michael Kennedy, said his client felt threatened by a report in Monday's New York Post that Trump attorney Jay Goldberg said, ``I'm a killer. I can rip skin off a body.'' ``Mrs. Trump ... has instructed my firm and other colleagues representing her and her children to have no further negotiations nor anything else to do with you,'' Kennedy said in a letter to Goldberg. ``This is an instruction we will scrupulously follow.'' Goldberg responded with a letter stating he would ``have no further contact'' with Kennedy. He also wrote: ``At no time and to no one have I ever said that the reason I was retained was to inflict any harm, physical or otherwise, on your client.'' Both letters were released to the media. The letters further confuse whether there will be a settlement between the Trumps, who have a prenuptial agreement which would reportedly give Mrs. Trump $25 million, a Connecticut estate and custody of their three children. Goldberg and partner Stanford Lotwin represent Trump in the case. New York Post gossip columnist Cindy Adams, to whom Goldberg made the ``killer'' comment, called The Associated Press to further clarify the statement. ``At no point did Goldberg say he was going to rip the skin off Ivana ... The thought of taking the flesh off this beautiful, lovely blonde is absolutely not what this man said to me,'' Ms. Adams said. During his Florida visit, The Palm Beach Post reported Tuesday, Trump ordered that all pictures of Mrs. Trump be removed from the estate, named Mar-a-Lago. ``It took them two days,'' an unidentified Palm Beach socialite told the newspaper. Trump, the paper reported, had been planning to stay at Mar-a-Lago with a friend this weekend. But Mrs. Trump decided to come to the mansion with the couple's three children: Donald Jr., 12, Ivancka, 8, and Eric, 6. A spokesman for Trump, Howard Rubenstein, denied the report about the pictures and denied that Trump had planned to spend the weekend with a friend. Mrs. Trump and the children arrived Friday night. Trump joined his family Sunday and left Monday after a ``wonderful trip,'' the spokesman said. One socialite who knows the Trumps told The Palm Beach Post that about 25 guests attended a birthday celebration for Mrs. Trump, at which the Trump children sang tunes, including Ivancka crooning ``Edelweiss.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Coalition Could Be Fractured by Defeat _ Or Victory
LaserPhoto NY5
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: An opposition coalition glued together from an atomized, fractious array of parties is posing the strongest challenge to the Sandinistas' rule since they took power more than a decade ago. The United National Opposition, called UNO, now consists of 14 parties or party factions, all backing opposition newspaper publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, a living symbol of the fight for democracy. `Uno' is Spanish for one, but the Nicaraguan political tradition of uniting in the face of a common enemy seldom lasts long after defeat _ or victory. President Daniel Ortega, seeking re-election, has tried to drive a wedge into the opposition coalition by mocking the wide variety of parties comprising UNO _ they range from the Communist Party to ideological opposites in the Conservative Party. ``This is such a mish-mash, it can give you indigestion,'' Ortega told delighted supporters at one rally. ``Let (President) Bush eat it.'' Can UNO hold together and govern through 1996, should it win Sunday's general elections? ``Yes. We have matured,'' Alfredo Cesar, an adviser to Mrs. Chamorro, said in an interview. He said one reason is ``we have a unanimously agreed-to government program. ``Dona Violeta is the second reason. Everyone in the coalition trusts she will comply with her commitment and put the program into place.'' At least for now, everyone has something to gain by sticking together and everything to lose if they let mutual suspicions drive them apart. But when the hoped-for spoils were being divided, at least one party was not happy. The secretary-general of People's Social Christian Party stayed within UNO while its president joined a Social Christian alliance running separately. The official reason was irreconcilable differences; the widely believed rumor was that the party president, Mauricio Diaz, did not think his party had been granted enough candidates for the 90 National Assembly seats at stake. Nicaragua's political cast is full of splinter parties. Besides Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro, there are eight other presidential candidates. UNO's vice-presidential candidate, Virgilio Godoy of the Independent Liberal Party, has been criticized within the coalition as arrogant and abrasive. The power struggle won't be settled by the voters, because each party will be able to claim it was a major drawing card for Mrs. Chamorro's ticket. Nicaragua's past doesn't offer much of a model for stability, said Jorge Eduardo Arellano, a history professor. ``There's no history here; there's only a caricature,'' Arellano said. Despite the idea of the Liberals and Conservatives traditionally dominating Nicaraguan politics, up to 10 factions existed at the turn of the century; six in the 1940s, he said. The Somozas, who ran Nicaragua from the time of the death of Augusto Cesar Sandino in 1934 until they were toppled by Sandino's heirs in 1979, were able to use the internal dynamics of coalitions to divide and rule. The Sandinistas themselves have displayed a party discipline that has proven their biggest strength. ``That's the really amazing thing, that the nine comandantes (top party leaders) have hung together for 10 years,'' a Western diplomat said. Nevertheless, during their years as a guerrilla group, the Sandinistas split into three factions. One advocated a prolonged guerrilla war; another favored educating the masses on Marxist theory and slowly building up urban discontent, the third was intent on seizing the first opportunity to push a mass insurrection. The third faction was able to forge tactical alliances with angry Nicaraguans of all social classes to knock down Somoza in July 1979. Despite that, the Sandinistas united to rule, although there have been rumored disagreements, notably over ending a cease-fire last November with the U.S.-backed Contra rebels. The assassination of Mrs. Chamorro's husband, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, was the spark that lit the Sandinista revolution, and the winners initially forged a junta that included non-Sandinistas, including Mrs. Chamorro. The non-Sandinistas didn't last long, though. Since then, the Sandinistas have faced several opposition coalitions, including the Democratic Coordinating Board, which eventually dropped out of the 1984 elections. This time, despite internal bickering, fraying at the edges and gaping differences in background and thinking, the main opposition coalition has managed to hang together, at least through the campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Advice for Smokers on Smoke-Free Airlines: Take a Nap
DOC.TEXT: Smokers on smoke-free airliners would be well-advised to do breathing exercises, doodle or take a nap, say groups who pushed for the 99 percent ban that takes effect Sunday. The American heart and lung associations and the American Cancer Society said Tuesday they are offering free advice to air travelers who will have to do without cigarettes on all but about 28 of the 17,000 daily domestic flights. Only flights of more than six hours to Alaska or Hawaii will have smoking sections beginning Sunday. A wallet-sized tip card printed by the Coalition on Smoking or Health advises smokers to take along low-calorie snacks and to focus on positive thoughts of ``clean air and a clear head.'' It suggests: ``Hold your breath while you count to four, and exhale slowly letting out all the air from your lungs. Slowly repeat these steps five times.'' It also offers doodling or doing crossword puzzles as a means of keeping fingertips busy and proposes, ``As a last resort, lean back and sleep.'' The coalition unveiled its campaign to help smokers cope at a news conference with congressional sponsors of the new law and the Association of Flight Attendants, which pushed for the change. ``Chronic lung inflammation, respiratory and sinus problems, dizziness, nausea and severe headaches will no longer plague our members, their colleagues or the passengers who share their environment,'' said Juliette D. Lenoir, representing flight attendants. Increased cancer risk, estimated in a Transportation Department study released last week, also would be eliminated, Ms. Lenoir said. Rep. Dick Durbin, D-Ill., said he would move to ban smoking on trains and buses. He said although a majority of Amtrak passengers say they like the railroad's rules separating smoking passengers by car, some complain that they have to pass through the smoking areas on their way to the dining car. Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., said the smoking ban should be an incentive for smokers to ``kick the habit.'' ``I think smoking ought to be done in the privacy of one's home or one's business where it doesn't affect others,'' he said. Lautenberg and Durbin issued a summary of the government study which concluded that cigarette smoke in airline cabins could kill between 12 and 15 cabin crew members out of every 100,000 over the next 20 years, assuming they fly about 960 hours a year. Frequent fliers also would be exposed to an increased risk if smoking had continued, said the study, which was commissioned before the smoking ban on airliners.

DOC.HEAD: From Giant Octopus to 1,272 Lice, Smithsonian Has it All
DOC.TEXT: Last year the Smithsonian Institution acquired an old Pullman railroad car spittoon, Ray Bolger's scarecrow costume from ``The Wizard of Oz,'' a giant Pacific octopus, 14 condom vending machines (with 108 condoms), 50 parking meters and 1,272 dry-mounted specimens of lice. These and more than 700,000 other objects joined the vast collections of the Smithsonian, a sort of large national cigar box where Americans stuff their odds and ends, mostly odd. Also carted into the Smithsonian's complex of museums and art galleries in 1989 were a sculpture made of grapevine roots, an Air Force C-130A Hercules cargo plane, a satin Chinese hanging scroll from the Ming dynasty and several thousand world's fair souvenirs dating to 1850. The list includes 75 original paving bricks from the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, the original propeller nose cone removed from Charles Lindbergh's ``Spirit of St. Louis'' airplane because of a crack, and 2,500 fossils containing imprints of ferns, crabs and trilobites which lived in a northern Illinois swamp more than 300 million years ago. Officials said the Smithsonian's holdings grew to nearly 138 million objects with last year's acquisitions, many of which came from private collectors like Clifford Krainik of Alexandria, Va., whose passion was ballooning. The National Air and Space Museum bought Krainik's 400-item collection of balloon memorabilia, including Matthew Brady photographs of Civil War balloons, a balloon-shaped perfume bottle and valentines, greeting cards, handbills and sheet music about balloons. The biggest recipient was the National Museum of Natural History. Its 674,817 new items included a pair of stuffed passenger pigeons from Colorado, a flying lizard from the Philippines, a football-sized Brazilian quartz crystal containing golden needles, 8,152 mounted specimens of wasps, 30 garments and household objects used by Tibetan nomads and a piece of petrified timber from Cyprus that has turned into copper. Only a tiny fraction of the Smithsonian's vast collections are on display at its 14 museums and galleries in Washington and New York, plus the National Zoo. The bulk of its nearly 138 million objects are specimens housed in the Natural History Museum and used for scientific research. The giant octopus, by the way, was captured off the coast of Washington state near Seattle and shipped to the National Zoo, which also acquired a Sumatran tiger from Indonesia and a three-ton Asian elephant named ``Toni'' from Scranton, Pa.

DOC.HEAD: City Votes To Go To Court, If Necessary, To Stop Medfly Spraying
DOC.TEXT: The City Council voted unanimously Tuesday to take all possible steps to stop aerial pesticide spraying against the Medfly, heating up the dispute between rural and urban areas over how to fight the crop-killing insect. Disagreeing with official assurances the spraying is safe, the council approved a motion to pursue lawsuits and administrative appeals to force the state to halt spraying and to study the potential risks of malathion. ``This is going to be a tough case. But it's a case we have to fight,'' said Councilman Joel Wachs. ``The public has a right and a demand to know if the goverment is leveling with them.'' The council also voted 15-0 to look into blocking the movement of all produce through Los Angeles airport and harbor facilities until farm officials agree to discuss with the city the use of malathion. Councilwoman Gloria Molina said state officials have failed to look seriously at the possible risks of spraying because of pressure from the powerful agricultural industry. The state is spraying 400 square miles of Los Angeles and Orange counties at night to wipe out the worst infestation of the crop-destroying bug since 1981-82. Helicopters drop a mixture of malathion and sticky corn syrup bait. Agriculture officials contend the spraying poses no health risks and is a necessary step to avert an estimated $200 million in crop losses a year if the Medfly becomes established in the state. The Mediterranean fruit fly lays its eggs in more than 250 varieties of fruits, vegetables and nuts grown in California. The crops are destroyed when the larvae hatch and eat their way out. Councilman Michael Woo called the spraying a ``blatant example of the urban population of this state being held hostage to the agricultural industry.'' California Farm Bureau spokesman Clark Biggs said farmers sympathize with Southern Californians for having to live with the spraying, but contended that wiping out the Medfly is in everyone's best interest. ``It's no fun to have helicopters flying over your house in the middle of the night. We understand i's a great discomfort and inconvenience for the urban residents,'' he said. ``We pray for them to stay with us until we can get this one under control.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush Tries a New Twist on Line-Item Veto Dispute
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is nibbling at the edges of a major constitutional confrontation with Congress, and so far Democratic leaders are not calling his hand on it. In a calculated act of civil disobedience, Bush has told Congress he won't carry out certain provisions of certain laws because he believes them to be an infringement on his constitutional powers. It's a new twist on the old argument over line-item veto powers _ long sought unsuccessfully by Republican presidents from Democratic Congresses. Bush's first act of defiance came, little noticed, last November on a bill providing money for two federal agencies. He did it again last Friday on a $9.8 billion State Department measure. So far, the president's actions have generated little heat in Congress _ largely because he asn't done much to publicize them and, consequently, members generally seem unaware of what he's been up to. ``We're going to put someone on this right away,'' said Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on civil and constitutional rights. Edwards, who usually keeps track of such things, said he had not been aware of Bush's assertions. ``It's totally unacceptable to have a president who doesn't comply with the law,'' he said. In November, Bush signed a bill providing funds for the Treasury Department and the Postal Service, but said he would refuse to obey one section. The section would have prevented him from requiring government employes to sign statements promising not to disclose classified information. Bush said the provision interfered with his ``constitutional duty to protect such information'' and that he wasn't going to obey it. On Friday, Bush signed a bill authorizing $9.8 billion for the State Department for the next two years, but said he would not go along with several key sections. Bush said he would refuse to obey a requirement that the administration report to Congress future sensitive diplomatic missions like national security adviser Brent Scowcroft's clandestine trip last June to Beijing. Furthermore, he said he would disobey requirements that he disclose any U.S. contacts with Palestine Liberation Organization members who might be terrorists; and that he include members of Congress in the U.S. delegation negotiating arms reductions in Europe. In each instance, Bush cited interference with what he asserted was his constitutional right to conduct foreign policy. Bush's initiatives were applauded by Mitch Daniels, who was White House political director for former President Reagan and who now is director of the Hudson Institute, a think tank in Indianapolis. ``I think it's an important step by Bush to reclaim the rightful presidential prerogative. This has really gotten to the ridiculous stage, where massive authorization bills not only attempt to hogtie the administration, but sometimes even with language that no one really voted for,'' Daniels said. ``I like the style, he's done it quietly,'' he said. Since the Supreme Court, and not the executive branch, has the final say on what's constitutional, Bush's strategy seems destined to end up in a court challenge. Still, Bush ``has long been concerned'' over what he views as the erosion of the executive's constitutional powers by Congress and ``he feels as president he has the constitutional duty'' to refuse to obey laws that he thinks jeopardize his constitutional powers, said deputy White House spokesman Alixe Glen. Bush's actions do not constitute a line-item veto as such, but have some of the same impact. A line-item veto is the ability to veto specific lines or sections of a spending bill while leaving the rest standing, a power enjoyed by 43 governors but not by the president. Most legal scholars _ although, significantly, not White House lawyers _ claim line-item veto powers require an amendment to the Constitution. Some conservatives, including White House counsel C. Boyden Gray, claim that the president may already have such powers. Congressional Democrats have said they'll sue the president if he attempts to exert them. Gray is searching for a test case on which to try to exercise line-item veto powers, aides said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Great Britain's Prince Charles is calling on business leaders for a ``new deal'' in which capitalism is more humane. ``The crucial factor is whether such an approach can be commercial. And yet, surely, it must be good business in the long run,'' the Prince of Wales told about 100 corporate executives gathered for an international business conference Tuesday. The two-day meeting of Business in the Community, a London-based group founded by the prince, brings corporate leaders together to discuss the roles and responsibilities of business. Charles said business leaders cannot leave problems of the environment and education only to the government. ``These are no longer frontier days when businesses can afford to make short-term decisions,'' he said. The prince will be in Charleston through today. Meanwhile, the prince's spokesman refuted reports that Charles' wife Diana, Princess of Wales, is expecting a third child. ``There is no truth to that,'' Philip Mackie said.

CBS Records honored singer Michael Jackson as the label's biggest money-maker of the 1980s, when fans bought more than 110 million of his records. ``I have to say now, no album sells itself,'' the 31-year-old singer said at a Tuesday news conference. ``It is up to the people to buy it.'' In a typically truncated speech, the gloved one thanked ``all the children of the world,'' several record industry executives and his parents. Jackson's output in the decade included the era's two largest-selling albums, ``Bad'' and ``Thriller.'' Tommy Mottolo, president of CBS Records, said, ``If I stood here 10 years ago and told you any artist would accomplish what Michael Jackson accomplished, you would probably have laughed me off the stage.'' ``Thriller'' was the first album to generate seven Top 10 singles, including the title cut and ``Beat It.'' There was some rain on Jackson's parade, though. Jackson was named in an amended class-action lawsuit filed Tuesday in Seattle that accuses him of using illness as an excuse to get out of three concerts in the Tacoma Dome. No dollar amount was set. Lee Solters, a Los Angeles spokesman for Jackson, said he had no comment.

Former talk show host Morton Downey Jr. is asking a federal bankruptcy court for protection from numerous creditors, including banks, businesses, restaurants and jewelers, according to court documents. Downey lists liabilities of nearly $2.4 million in a petition filed Friday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court seeking protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. Downey attorney Brian D. Spector would not comment on whether Downey's financial troubles were related to the demise of ``The Morton Downey Jr. Show,'' which featured the host ranting and taunting guests. The program was canceled after two years. Spector said his client, who lives in suburban Englewood, was out of town and that he would advise him not to comment. Downey's creditors include more than 75 banks, businesses and agencies _ including New York boutiques and restaurants _ a New Jersey limousine service and New York City's Parking Violations Bureau, court papers said. Listed among the 20 largest unsecured creditors are the New York jewelers Bulgari and Cartier, which he owes $24,000 and $9,000, respectively.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also moved on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Joe Montana broke tradition in failing to show up at the Maxwell Football Club as its choice for NFL Player of the Year, but the club was understanding. For the first time in the 30 years of the Bert Bell Award, the club's NFL pick wasn't on hand for the award Tuesday night. Francis ``Reds'' Bagnell, president of the club, called it a ``great disappointment'' that the San Francisco 49ers' star quarterback did not join Indiana running back Anthony Thompson, winner of the club's Maxwell Award as college player of the year. It didn't come as a surprise, however. ``There was every indication on an ongoing basis that he was reluctant about coming because of his other commitments _ if he did one, he'd have to do the others,'' Bagnell said. Bagnell said he believed Montana was on vacation in the Virgin Islands with his family. Thompson showed up in a tuxedo with his Indiana coach, Bill Mallory, to accept his award.

The star of ``Tonight Live Starring Freddie Roman'' at Trump Castle says his show's success has helped him in many ways. ``For the first time I feel like I have a job,'' Roman said this week. ``I've never gotten to stay in one place for more than six weeks since I started in show business.'' ``Tonight Live'' begins with Roman delivering his monologue before presenting the night's talent. He interviews each act, six days a week, and steps into the audience for a question-and-answer session that gives him a chance to do some improvisational comedy. ``Tonight Live'' has been doing so well that its original three-month stint has been extended, with the show now scheduled to run until Labor Day. The casino is in discussions with a cable television station to put together a ``best of'' show to air monthly, Roman said. Roman has been a frequent guest on television's ``The Merv Griffin Show,'' and ``Mike Douglas Show.'' His last film appearance was in 1987's ``Sweet Lorraine,'' starring Maureen Stapleton.

DOC.HEAD: `Daisy' Roars to First Place Box Office Finish
DOC.TEXT: ``Driving Miss Daisy'' drove hard at the box office, powered by its nine Oscar nominations, to collect $9.8 million for the holiday weekend. The story of a Southern widow (Jessica Tandy) and her black chauffeur (Morgan Freeman) was nominated for best picture last Wednesday, with its two stars and Dan Aykroyd in a supporting role receiving acting nominations. The film averaged $7,040 per screen over the holiday weekend, Exhibitor Relations Co. said in figures Tuesday. In second place was the Steven Seagal action movie ``Hard to Kill,'' which grossed $8.4 million and has made more than $20 million in just two weeks of release. It was followed in third by the new Kevin Costner film ``Revenge.'' The film, receiving mixed but mostly negative reviews, collected $6.1 million. ``Madhouse,'' a new film with John Larroquette and Kirstie Alley as a couple entertaining impossible house guests, had ticket sales of $5.2 million for fourth place. In fifth was director Oliver Stone's ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' which snared eight Oscar nominations last week. It collected $4.4 million. ``Nightbreed,'' a horror film from novelist Clive Barker, opened in sixth place with a take of $3.7 million and a lackluster per-screen average of $2,493. In seventh was Bette Midler's remake ``Stella,'' with receipts of $3 million. ``Glory,'' the melodramatic account of an all-black regiment fighting in the Civil War, finished in eighth on grosses of $2.7 million. The animated hit ``The Little Mermaid'' landed in ninth with a gate of $1.8 million. Rounding out the Top 10 was the ensemble drama ``Steel Magnolias'' on a take of $1.6 million. The illiteracy drama ``Stanley & Iris,'' with a weak $1.4 million for 11th, was spelling out as a flop after two weeks. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Warner Bros., $9.8 million, 1,397 screens, $7,040 per screen, $45.2 million, 10 weeks. 2. ``Hard to Kill,'' Warner Bros., $8.4 million, 1,452 screens, $5,799 per screen, $20.6 million, two weeks. 3. ``Revenge,'' Columbia, $6.1 million, 1,379 screens, $4,414 per screen, $6.1 million, one week. 4. ``Madhouse,'' Orion, $5.2 million, 1,552 screens, $3,377 per screen, $5.2 million, one week. 5. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Universal, $4.4 million, 1,363 screens, $3,233 per screen, $53.6 million, nine weeks. 6. ``Nightbreed,'' 20th Century Fox, $3.7 million, 1,488 screens, $2,493 per screen, $3.7 million, one week. 7. ``Stella,'' Disney, $3 million, 1,393 screens, $2,167 per screen, $13.2 million, three weeks. 8. ``Glory,'' Tri-Star, $2.7 million, 801 screens, $3,350 per screen, $16.3 million, 10 weeks. 9. ``The Little Mermaid,'' Disney, $1.8 million, 1,325 screens, $1,339 per screen, $74.3 million, 14 weeks. 10. ``Steel Magnolias,'' Tri-Star, $1.6 million, 1,216 screens, $1,275 per screen, $71.3 million, 14 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Finds Tax Deadbeats Among Fellow Agencies
DOC.TEXT: At least one federal agency is among the ranks of deadbeats who don't pay their taxes on time, adding as much as $250 million to the total of taxes owed but not turned over to the Internal Revenue Service. In fact, IRS officials hint that several federal agencies delayed handing over withheld taxes at one time or another, prompting Rep. Byron L. Dorgan, D-N.D., to complain such actions carry ``the definition of a tax deadbeat to a new low.'' ``If the IRS can't make a federal agency own up to its tax responsibility, who can they influence?'' Dorgan said Tuesday after a hearing by the House Ways and Means oversight subcommittee on taxes owed but not collected. The total of those 13 million accounts receivable is rising by $11 million a day, to as high as $87 billion. Dorgan said members of the subcommittee have information that one federal agency was late in turning over more than $250 million it had withheld from workers' paychecks. IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. acknowledged only that one agency _ which he would not identify because of privacy laws _ was once listed among taxpayers with a delinquency of $100 million or more. However, Senior Deputy Commissioner Michael J. Murphy said that when he served as director of the Philadelphia district office, ``we did have problems with some federal agencies.'' When Dorgan said there is evidence that two major federal agencies routinely delay making tax payments _ perhaps to avoid a temporary budget crunch _ Charly Brennan, deputy commissioner for operations, said, ``We will give you a report on it.'' Goldberg said that although the agency can impose stiff penalties on employers that are late in making tax payments, there is no authority to penalize government agencies for the same shortcoming. Goldberg and Jennie Stathis, a director of the General Accounting Office, agreed that as little as $30 billion of the gross $87 billion total of accounts receivable may be collectible. ``It is going to be tens of billions of dollars,'' Goldberg said. ``Whether it's $30 billion or $40 billion, it's a lot of money.'' He said the IRS has to abandon efforts to collect up to $3 billion each year, because of a six-year statute of limitations. Goldberg acknowledged the IRS has no way of knowing how much can be collected or even why the delinquency figure continues to grow. He said the IRS will be able to cut into accounts receivable if Congress approves the $50 million that President Bush asked to add 1,000 personnel to the agency's 20,000-employee collection division next year. He noted the IRS has under way a long-term plan to modernize its computer systems. Goldberg and Robert M. Tobias, president of the National Treasury Employees Union, which represents most IRS employees, criticized the up-one-year, down-the-next spending for IRS workers. Goldberg said about $25 billion of the $87 billion accounts receivable is considered currently not collectible and unlikely to be collected in the future. An account is given this label when, for example, a corporation goes out of business or the IRS determines an individual is unable to pay. The remaining $62 billion involves about 13 million accounts receivable, including 3,300 that total more than $14 billion. Goldberg said 17 accounts totaling $5.4 billion involve at least $100 million each. Much of the total is not collectible because it is bloated by duplications and by errors by the IRS and taxpayers. Goldberg defended the IRS's record. ``Between 1984 and 1989 we collected over $5 trillion in revenue,'' he noted. ``Our current (accounts receivable) inventory is less than 2 percent of that amount. And we will ultimately collect most of what is due.''

DOC.HEAD: 32nd Annual Awards Offers Chance for Beatles Reunion _ Sort Of
DOC.TEXT: The 32nd annual Grammy Awards offered a chance for a reunion of sorts for the three surviving Beatles at the Shrine Auditorium. Two former members of the Fab Four, George Harrison and Ringo Starr, were in contention for Grammys tonight and the third surviving member, Paul McCartney, was chosen in advance to receive an honor for his lifetime achievements. Former Beatle John Lennon was killed in a December 1980, attack by a deranged fan. Harrison, as part of the all-star Traveling Wilburys, was up for album of the year and best vocal rock group performance for the LP ``Traveling Wilburys Volume One.'' Starr's teaming with Buck Owens on the single ``Act Naturally'' earned a bid for best country vocal collaboration. McCartney and jazz artist Miles Davis were chosen to receive Lifetime Achievement Awards from the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences. The Academy said McCartney would be honored on stage, receiving the award from actress Meryl Streep. It was unknown whether Harrison and Starr would be on hand. A three-hour CBS-TV broadcast of top pop, rock, country and rap awards, as well as the coveted song-, album- and record-of-the-year awards was scheduled to be broadcast to the East at 8 p.m. EST and by tape-delay to the West. The bulk of about six dozen winners out of nearly 400 nominees were to be announced in a fast-paced, non-televised ceremony before the broadcast. Top nominees for the best music recordings of 1989 included Don Henley with four nominations on the strength of his ``The End of the Innocence'' album and rock star Prince, who had four bids based on his work for the ``Batman'' movie soundtrack. Bette Midler, Bonnie Raitt, Tom Petty, Billy Joel, Linda Ronstadt, the Rolling Stones, the late Roy Orbison, Neil Young, Lou Reed and Joe Cocker were among familiar names up for awards. Fine Young Cannibals, U-2, Janet Jackson, Bobby Brown, Anita Baker, k.d. lang, Randy Travis, Lyle Lovett and Rodney Crowell were also among nominees. Neneh Cherry, Indigo Girls, Milli Vanilli, Soul II Soul and Tone Loc were best new artist nominees.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands in Romania Line Up For Book of Dissident Cartoonist
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people crowded the sidewalk of Bucharest's main street, waiting in line not for some rarely seen delicacy but for copies of a previously banned book full of drawings. The coveted book is the work of Romanian cartoonist Mihai Stanescu, whose acid cartoons had belittled the ``Golden Epoch'' of ousted and executed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The dictator banned Stanescu's books. The police and army were called to keep order as the lines snaked toward the Dalles Gallery, where Stanescu was signing copies of the book, ``Now Is Not the Moment,'' and a poster showing how Romania had rejoined Europe after the December revolution which toppled the Ceausescus. Most buyers who lined up last week knew about Stanescu's cartoons bacause a photocopy of the volume had been smuggled into the country bere the revolution and circulated all over Bucharest. Costel Despa, a 28-year-old mechanic, said waiting four hours in line was worth it. ``This book is very good for all ages and can be understood by everyone,'' he said. ``Mihai Stanescu is the only one who told the truth, and he was not afraid,'' said another man, speaking on condition of anonymity. In an interview later, Stanescu _ still nursing a sore hand from signing his name about 5,000 times _ said his popularity helped keep him from arrest under Ceausescu. He said that with his favorite targets gone, he now was eying Romania's interim government and more than 40 political parties.
