But so far, he hasn't found much humor in them. ``Before, when the regime was evil, my work was motivated by hate,'' he said. ``Today I must base myself solely on humor _ it can be more difficult.'' While sipping passion fruit tea from an ``I Love London'' mug in his studio, he said he was ``very optimistic'' about Romania's return to democracy. ``I say this despite the fact that the Romanian people are not politically mature,'' he said. ``I think the front is sincere and we are on our way to pluralistic democracy,'' he added, referring to the National Salvation Front. The front ruled Romania for six weeks after the revolution, and now shares power with 37 other parties in the Provisional Council of National Unity. ``Now Is Not The Moment'' was published in paperback in France by Bernard Barrault several years ago. A hardback edition in color will be published this spring. The preface was signed by Minister of Culture Andrei Plesu and Octavian Paler, editor of Romania Libera, Romania's most widely read newspaper, and a member of the Group for Social Dialogue, comprised of the country's intellectual elite. Stanescu said 100,000 copies had been brought to Romania and a few were still on sale. The book includes his cartoon of the Berlin Wall, with thousands of people pressing against it and one man peering through a tiny exit overlooking a cliff. It won first prize in the Third Yomiuri International Cartoon Contest in Tokyo in 1982. Stanescu's studio is filled with cartoons, books and T-shirts on subjects from New York City to glasnost. Foreign diplomats smuggled his cartoons out of the country during Ceausescu's dictatorship.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Commissioner of Education Dies at Age 73
DOC.TEXT: Francis Keppel, a Harvard University lecturer who was U.S. commissioner of education under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, died at the university at age 73. Keppel, who died Monday at Harvard's Stillman Infirmary, was considered a leader in education. He was commissioner of education from 1962 to 1966 and was dean of the Ivy League school's Graduate School of Education from 1948 to 1962. Since 1974, Keppel had been director of the educational policy program of the Aspen Institute and was an adviser to libraries, art centers and the World Bank. Keppel led the drive for passage of the Elementary Secondary Education Act of 1965, which focused resources on classroom assistance for poor children. He was also closely involved in enforcing the Civil Rights Act of 1964 as it applied to equal access to education, and created was the National Assessment of Education Progress. ``Harvard and the nation lose one of their great public servants with the death of Frank Keppel,'' Harvard president Derek Bok said in a statement. ``He was a modest, ethical man; few can equal his lifelong dedication to improving education.'' Keppel received his A.B. degree from Harvard in 1938, and studied sculpture for a year at the American Academy in Rome. He resumed academic studies while serving as an assistant dean at Harvard College from 1939 to 1941. During World War II, he was secretary of the Joint Army and Navy Committee on Welfare and Recreation, then joined the Army, rising from private to lieutenant. He left the Army in 1946. Two years later, Keppel became dean of the Graduate School of Education. He promoted a master of arts in teaching program and other innovations in teaching. Keppel is survived by his wife, Edith Sawin Keppel of Cambridge, two daughters, a brother and four grandchildren. A mermorial service was to be held Friday at the Memorial Church in Harvard Yard.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Leaders Weigh New Income Tax Credit
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley says an income tax credit could be good way to help workers offset some of their Social Security payroll taxes. Foley told reporters Tuesday that the idea, one of several top Democrats are studying to deal with the giant Social Security trust fund surplus, is ``a very interesting proposal.'' ``It would I think tend to restore some progressivity to the tax system, and it has other features I think are worthy of very serious consideration,'' said Foley, D-Wash. Leading House and Senate Democrats are looking for ways to address questions that have been raised about the Social Security payroll tax and the surplus it has raised that some say is disguising the true size of the overall federal deficit. One option under study would let workers take a credit on their income tax return for a portion of the payroll tax they pay. Led by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., critics have said the Social Security levy discriminates against low- and middle-income people. Moynihan has proposed legislation slashing the payroll tax rate. Workers pay a 7.65 percent Social Security payroll tax, an amount that is in addition to their income tax. Employers must also pay the government an equal amount on behalf of each employee. The tax is levied only on the first $51,300 of annual earnings. People pay no payroll tax on their wages above that amount and pay no payroll tax on income from interest, dividends, rents and other non-wage earnings. As a result, wealthier people pay proportionately smaller payroll taxes than lower-income people. Sources, speaking on condition they not be identified, said Democratic aides have not decided how large the income-tax credit would be, who would be eligible or when it would begin. By letting workers recover some of their payroll tax payments by claiming income tax credits, the plan could blunt Bush administration charges that Democrats want to make changes in the Social Security system. ``Its one great source of appeal obviously is you don't have to do anything about the Social Security trust fund,'' said one source. Moynihan's plan would cut the government's payroll tax collections by $62 billion over the next two years, a sizeable addition to what is already an expected $138 billion budget deficit for this year. It has been criticized by Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas; House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill.; the American Association of Retired Persons and the National Association of Manufacturers. But the plan is believed to have the support of many members of Congress because it would cut taxes. Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said Tuesday there is ``a large, fluid body'' of senators undecided about Moynihan's bill. He predicted there ``could be a stampede in favor of the Moynihan proposal'' should there be a vote on it. The group studying the Social Security question hopes to make a recommendation as early as this week. It consists of Bentsen, Rostenkowski, Sasser, Senate Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. This year, the Social Security trust fund is expected to have a $66 billion surplus.

DOC.HEAD: Union Calls on President to Salute the Flag With Holiday
DOC.TEXT: The National Federation of Federal Employees says President Bush should ``stand behind his words and embrace the flag'' by making Flag Day a federal holiday. In a statement Tuesday, the union said it has written the president, who has often expressed his devotion to the American flag, urging him to give government employees the day off. Flag Day is June 14. Although it is printed in the calendar, ``it comes and goes every year with little or no recognition,'' said James M. Peirce, president of the union. Bush used the flag heavily in his presidential campaign and wound up his acceptance speech at the 1988 Republican National Convention by leading delegates in the Pledge of Allegiance. He later criticized his Democratic opponent, Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, for vetoing a bill that would have penalized schoolteachers who failed to lead their students in the pledge. He has also advocated a constitutional amendment to bar desecration of the flag in response to a Supreme Court ruling that burning a flag was a protected form of free speech under the First Amendment. ``NFFE strongly agrees with the president that Americans should salute the flag, rather than desecrate it,'' the employees' union said. ``Now it is time for President Bush to stand behind his words and embrace the flag by giving federal workers a day to honor and celebrate this great American institution.'' There was no immediate comment from the White House, where press officers were in a meeting. Jane Polanksy, spokesperson for the federation, said the union made no endorsement in the presidential campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Suit: Janitor Jabbed With AIDS-Contaminated Needle
DOC.TEXT: A janitor infected with the AIDS virus filed a lawsuit against a hospital, saying he has been going through ``a living death'' since a contaminated needle in trash he was ordered to remove punctured his leg. The 22-year-old Guatemalan immigrant filed suit against Cedars Medical Center Tuesday in Dade Circuit Court after negotiations with the hospital's insurance carriers failed to reach an acceptable settlement, his lawyer said. ``Cedars' negligence has effectively condemned the plaintiff to a living and premature death,'' said Miami attorney Ellis Rubin in the suit filed on behalf of the young man identified only as ``Jose Doe.'' The suit does not name a monetary figure, but Rubin said he will seek several million dollars. ``Money can never give me back the rest of my life that has been taken away from me,'' Doe said Tuesday in a statement. ``I can never have children and I am going through a living death.'' The suit claims the worker was ordered on Jan. 13, 1989, to remove garbage and medical waste from a vacant room most recently occupied by a patient being treated for human immunodeficency virus, which causes AIDS. The worker, hired to clean floors and empty trash from storerooms and snack rooms, was not told about the condition of the patient and was never trained in the proper disposal of contaminated medical waste, the suit said. The worker removed the medical waste in a red plastic bag and was bumped by someone getting onto an elevator. A contaminated needle inside the bag jabbed the worker's left calf, the suit alleged. ``The live virus was pumped directly into the plaintiff's bloodstream,'' the suit said. The worker was immediately given a blood test, which found no trace of the AIDS virus. But the suit said a follow-up test on March 7, 1989, found he had the AIDS antibodies. The suit said the worker had not had sex since late 1987, and is not an intravenous drug user or transfusion recipient. Rubin said his client has experienced nightmares and severe anxiety attacks since learning he has contracted AIDS. The suit claims Cedars was negligent for allowing an untrained janitor to remove HIV-contaminated waste and carry it by elevator to the incinerator, which violates rules on transportation of medical waste. Miles McGrane, an attorney for the hospital, was in St. Louis on Tuesday and unavailable for comment, his secretary said. Doe is still working at the hospital for Servicemaster Co., which contracts janitorial services. He is the sole financial support for his mother, two sisters and three brothers, Rubin said. ``This is the most tragic case I've ever had,'' said Rubin. ``Fate, God, or whatever you want to call it touched Jose Doe on Friday the 13th.'' Since the early 1980s, 19 health-care workers in the United States have been infected with the HIV virus from job-related activities, including 12 from needle jabs, said Charles Fallis, a spokesman with the national Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. In New York City last month, trial began in a $175 million lawsuit filed by an AIDS-infected doctor who claims she was stuck with a contaminated needle when she reached into a pile of gauze and bed linens in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: DOT Sees Greater Risk of Cancer in Airliners
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Transportation says the risk of cancer among airline crew members from cosmic radiation is nearly 17 times greater than it reported last week. The DOT on Tuesday acknowledged an error in a major study assessing airliner cabin environment. Officials said the error occurred when a researcher copied figures from the wrong table. The report originally estimated that cosmic radiation could cause from 5 to 61 additional deaths from cancer per 100,000 crew members flying for 20 years. The revised figures put this at up to 1,000 additional deaths per 100,000 for crew members who fly long routes about twice a week and about 500 deaths per 100,000 among passengers who fly long routes once a week. These deaths would be in addition to the expectation that 22,000 out of 100,000 _ about one out of five _ people will die of cancer from all causes. Officials cautioned, however, that the risk data is not based on any study of actual cancer cases but on mathematical models projecting the effects of low-level cosmic radiation based on what is known about higher radiation doses. Bob Marx, DOT spokesman, said officials are concerned about the radiation risk to airliner crews and the Federal Aviation Administration plans to issue a warning document.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers' Money for Guns Turned Over to Butter
DOC.TEXT: The House Agriculture Committee is questioning the Bush administration's tight-money budget policy toward agriculture while the White House calls for increases in controversial weapons systems. During a hearing Tuesday on the 1990 farm bill, Rep. Jim Jontz, D-Ind., asked Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter how much he recommended that the Office of Management and Budget allow for commodity programs in fiscal 1991. Jontz said that in light of increases in spending requested by the administration for the B-2 stealth bomber, Strategic Defense Initiative and foreign aid, ``we ought to do better.'' Yeutter did not say how much he recommended, saying only he'd asked for more than the $11.8 billion OMB projected for commodity program outlays. ``We got all we could reasonably expect,'' said Yeutter. Before Yeutter testified, the Agriculture Committee approved a letter to the House Budget Committee saying it ``must take exception with the budget proposals submitted by President Bush.'' ``The unspecified reduction of $1.5 billion in 1991 commodity spending, increasing to over $19 billion through 1995, is an unreasonably high 13 percent of commodity program outlays,'' said the letter from committee Chairman Kika de la Garza and ranking Republican Rep. Edward Madigan, R-Ill. ``Not only is this disproportionate when compared with other major programs, it threatens disruption of a delicate recovery of agricultural financial institutions,'' the letter said. De la Garza told Yeutter he thought it was wrong that agriculture, although only 1 percent of the total federal budget, was being asked to come up with 18 percent of the cuts needed to reduce the deficit in fiscal 1991. The committee chairman said he was tired of the ``obsession with bashing the farmer'' over the federal government's program for guaranteeing farmers a certain price for particular commodities. ``It there is any subsidy, it's the American consumer being subsidized on the backs of the American farmer,'' de la Garza said. Defenders of the farm subsidy programs often point out U.S. consumers spend a smaller proportion of their disposable income on food than consumers in other countries. The debate over commodity support in the 1990 farm bill, which sets policy for five years, is expected to be heated. But Congress is still in the developmental stage on the legislation. Another heavily debated issue is crop insurance, which Yeutter wants eliminated in favor of permanent disaster aid legislation. Nearly every member at the hearing showed support for improving crop insurance rather than eliminating it. ``Crop insurance as we now have it will not continue,'' said de la Garza. But he said the House will propose an ``actuarily sound'' system of insurance rather than permanent disaster aid. Congress established the federally subsidized crop insurance program in 1980 to insure 50 crops that are vulnerable to drought or other natural disaster, but farmer participation has been largely voluntary. During the 1988 and 1989 droughts, Congress provided additional money to cover crop losses that were not insured. Yeutter said he didn't have confidence the insurance program could be made actuarily sound because participation is so low. In other areas covered by the farm bill, Yeutter said: _the American Soybean Association's graduated equity loan program proposal is ``an expensive proposition'' which the administration does not think the country can afford. _he is not recommending any changes in the sugar program because sugar ``is a multilateral issue. We ought to deal with it in the Uruguay Round,'' the international trade talks scheduled to be completed by the end of the year. _the Farmers Home Administration needs tightening because ``it has tilted over the last decade or so into a grant agency. ... The whole program has gone off on a tangent'' which is costing the taxpayers too much money.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Barry to Move to New Treatment Clinic, Sources Say
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, who was indicted last week on cocaine possession and perjury charges, will continue his substance abuse treatment at a South Carolina hospital, top city officials say. The mayor, who has been receiving treatment for what an aide described as an alcohol problem, planned to enter the Fenwick Hall Hospital near Charleston, S.C., as soon as today, sources said. Barry decided to enter the new program at the urging of his wife Effi, one city official said Tuesday. That official and the other sources commented only on condition they not be named. Meanwhile, Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, was granted a one-week postponement of the mayor's federal arraignment on three felony perjury and five misdemeanor cocaine possession charges. In his motion, Mundy said the mayor's treatment would be interrupted if he had to return to the nation's capital for a court appearance. Judy Smith, a spokeswoman for U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens, said Barry's appearance will be required at the arraignment, now scheduled for Feb. 28. Mundy has said the mayor will enter innocent pleas to all charges. In a political development Tuesday, Democratic mayoral hopeful Sharon Pratt Dixon called on Barry to resign. Dixon said both Barry and the city need time to heal. The mayor has resisted calls for resignation. Barry enrolled at the Hanley-Hazelden Clinic in West Palm Beach, Fla., four days after his Jan. 18 arrest on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge. He had considered extending his treatment there past the 28-day original program, sources said, but top city officials told him that doing so would make it appear that the treatment had failed. ``We convinced him that what he needs now is after-care, convalescence,'' said one city official familiar with Barry's planning. City Administrator Carol B. Thompson and Barry's chief of staff, Maudine Cooper, met with the mayor in Florida over the weekend to discuss new treatment options, the officials said. One source said both city officials and Mrs. Barry wanted the mayor away from reporters. Barry issued a statement Monday asking the news media to respect his privacy and that of other patients at the Florida treatment center. Fenwick Hall is on John's Island outside Charleston.

DOC.HEAD: Pittston, UMW Prepare for Return to Work
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: The nearly 1,700 Appalachian miners who ratified a contract with Pittston Coal Group after a 10{-month strike prepared to go back to their jobs this week, but not everyone is happy about it. In the eastern Kentucky coal town of McAndrews, any plans to celebrate were tempered by the uncertain fate of 13 miners facing suspension during the bitter labor dispute. Pittston President Michael Odom, who announced the return to work, says most of the United Mine Workers in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky will be back on their jobs by Monday. The first shifts begin Thursday night. ``We're going to go about the business now of mining coal,'' UMW Vice President Cecil Roberts said Tuesday during a news conference to announce that the contract, replacing an agreement that expired in February 1988, was ratified by 63-37 percent. The miners got the job security and health and retirement provisions they sought, and Pittston won the right to operate round-the-clock, with voluntary labor Sunday morning and afternoon. Now the UMW leadership must turn its attention to Circuit Judge Donald McGlothlin, who rejected a request by union and company attorneys to drop $64 million in fines against the UMW but gave them until Thursday to try to change his mind. Still on the minds of many was the fate of 13 miners the union expects Pittston to suspend for alleged misconduct during the strike. Members of Local 5737 at McAndrews campaigned to defeat the contract because it failed to guarantee the miners' jobs. Many miners had expected the local to handily defeat the contract as a statement of union solidarity for the 13. Afterward, some spoke bitterly about the local's rejection of the agreement in a 96-93 vote. ``To me, it's the end of the union,'' said Ann Osborne, wife of a striking miner. ``I still say a man who voted yes on that contract is no better than a scab ... .'' Jack Clevenger Jr., a retired miner, said those who voted for the contract ``were independent people voting for themselves.'' The contract's approval probably will cause tension in the local, and he expected ``it's going to take time to heal it.'' The specific allegations against the 13 miners would be detailed after contract ratification, said Glenn Stanley, the local's president. The cases then would be turned over to an arbitrator for settlement. The Pittston dispute was marred by sporadic violence, but Roberts said: ``We all learned some lessons from this strike; it's better to talk than to fight.'' Roberts and Odom agreed it will take some time for the harsh feelings between the union and company to heal, but both predicted the animosity will be short-lived. ``A lot of times two tough kids on the block have a fight and become the best of friends afterward,'' Odom said. Odom declined to predict how long it would take to get back to full production, but he noted the union employees were enthusiastic as strikers and will be enthusiastic as workers. ``Everyone seems really happy to go back to work,'' said Roger Caldwell, a field representative for the UMW in Logan, W.Va. ``Overall it's a contract they can live with.'' In eastern Kentucky, residents and business owners in Pike County were happy the strike was ending. ``Everybody's just tickled that it's over,'' said Eva Ryan, who operates a motel in Toler near the Kentucky-West Virginia border. ``Everybody's for the miners. We want them to get what they want.'' Logan County in West Virginia has been the focus of most strike-related violence since about 300 miners walked off the job at Pittston there. ``When the mining industry gets sick, Logan County gets pneumonia,'' said Mark Spurlock, a Logan County commissioner. ``We're overjoyed that it's been settled, apparently with a contract that's well thought of by the miners.''

DOC.HEAD: Families Don't Always Win Battle Against Hunger, Congress Told
DOC.TEXT: Hunger is not just an abstract political debate _ it can be a daily battle for poor families, a pair of mothers on welfare told members of Congress. And it's a battle the families don't always win, they said. ``My children are always asking for food,'' said Peggy Adams, a mother of nine from Montgomery County, Md. ``You may think that's fairly typical for children, and maybe it is, but half of the time I don't have enough food to feed them whenever they are hungry,'' she said. Mary Tamper, a Prince George's County, Md., mother of two, told a similar story Tuesday to members of the Senate Budget Committee. ``There were times when my son would say, `Mom, I know you just fed me, but I'm still hungry,''' she said. ``This hurt me more than any knife, especially when there was no food in the cupboard.'' Both testified in the Senate committee's hearings on hunger and the Bush administration's proposals for food and nutritional funding. Sen. Jim Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Budget Committee, said the Bush administration's budget proposal for fiscal 1991 cuts $462 million from the child nutrition budget and freezes the food stamp program. ``It is a budget that goes in the wrong direction as far as hungry Americans are concerned,'' Sasser said. He said he believed Congress will support higher spending for nutrition programs for families with children. Dr. Victor W. Sidel, a social medicine professor at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, N.Y., cited estimates that 2 million to 5 million low-income children in the United States are hungry _ and that the figure could go as high as 9 million. He said hungry children suffer twice as many illnesses as other children, and he charged the nation's record on child and prenatal nutrition was ``obscene.'' ``A nation that permits its children to go hungry cannot claim moral leadership,'' Sidel said. Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., ranking Republican on the panel, defended the Bush administration's budget proposal, saying some cuts in eligibility for school lunch assistance may be warranted and that food stamp assistance levels were adequate in some cases. Both Mrs. Tamper and Mrs. Adams said the federal Women, Infants and Children program _ providing food assistance for pregnant mothers and their children up to age 5 _ filled the gaps after they found themselves thrust into poverty. ``All I can say is, thank God for WIC,'' said Mrs. Tamper. Although the assistance is provided for the youngest children and their mothers, both mothers said they used the WIC food to feed the whole family. Both described a sudden descent from middle class to welfare and poverty after losing their husbands' income. Mrs. Tamper's husband died after being diagnosed with leukemia. She said she was forced to give up her job as a teacher's aide for a time, and that they moved in with her mother while relying on Social Security Survivor Benefits, rent subsidies and other assistance. Mrs. Adams said her family lost its $55,000 annual income when she and her husband were separated and he was sentenced to prison. She said her family has benefited from food stamps, public assistance and WIC. Despite the aid, she said, her 9-year-old son's weight has dropped from 65 pounds to 60 pounds, and her 5-year-old son has dropped a size in clothing. Her 8-year-old twins haven't outgrown their clothes in two years. ``I have seen my children's bodies stop growing like they should, and I pray it's not their brains as well,'' Mrs. Adams said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 35,734.33, down 1,161.19 points, or 3.15 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Hands of Clock May Move Away From Nuclear Midnight
DOC.TEXT: Keepers of the Doomsday Clock say the world is moving drastically away from the threat of nuclear war. For years the Doomsday Clock on the cover of The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists has been ticking back and forth toward midnight, an indication of the state of superpower relations. After standing at six minutes before midnight _ or the threat of nuclear war _ for two years, the Bulletin's April edition may turn the clock back, reflecting recent reforms in the Soviet Union and its Eastern European allies. Editor Len Ackland said Tuesday that a decision hasn't been made on where the clock's hands will be in April. But Nobel laureate Leon M. Lederman, director emeritus of the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory outside Chicago and one of the scientists whose opinions influence the clock's movement, said, ``I wanted the hands to move back the most. The danger of military confrontation between the superpowers and the credibility of that threat is lessening every hour.'' The clock first appeared on the June 1947 Bulletin to evoke the image of the apocalypse _ universal conflagration bursting forth at the darkest hour _ and of military attack, with the countdown to zero hour, Ackland said. The clock was closest to midnight _ two minutes away _ in 1953, after the United States successfully tested the hydrogen bomb. It was farthest from midnight _ 12 minutes _ in 1963, after the signing of the Partial Test Ban Treaty, and again in 1972, when the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty was signed. It last moved in 1988, shifting back from three minutes before midnight to six minutes away, due in large part to the U.S.-Soviet treaty eliminating intermediate-range nuclear missiles, Ackland said. The Bulletin was founded in 1945 by scientists who worked at the University of Chicago on the Manhattan Project _ the successful U.S. effort to build an atomic bomb during World War II. Among its founders were J. Robert Oppenheimer, sometimes called the father of the atomic bomb, and Albert Einstein. The magazine, published by the Educational Foundation for Nuclear Science, has 17,000 subscribers in 70 countries. The magazine's worldwide Board of Scientific Sponsors debates the international climate through letters and over the telephone to determine whether the hands of the clock should move. The sponsors make their recommendations to the Bulletin's board of directors and editors, who have the final say. Lederman, a member of both boards, said he believes that since World War II, the world has never been further from nuclear war than it is now, though he added it will be hard for bureaucrats to stop asking for huge military expenditures. But despite the general view among Bulletin sponsors that the threat of nuclear war is diminishing, some note changes that could pose a threat to peace. ``They are concerned by the growth of nationalism, strident nationalism in Eastern Europe and other places,'' said Lederman, who won the 1988 Nobel Prize in physics.

DOC.HEAD: Students See People Living Longer in 2100, Shopping From Home
DOC.TEXT: People in the 22nd century will no longer have to go the store to shop but the kids will still go to school to learn, say junior and senior high school students who responded to a national survey. Results of the survey of 12,300 youngsters were announced by the National Society of Professional Engineers Tuesday. The survey was conducted in December by the society's National Engineers Week committee and Science World, a scholastic magazine distributed in classrooms. Seventeen percent of the students said all shopping would eventually be done from home. The remaining 83 percent said most of it would be. Asked whether people would still go to schools to learn things, 68 percent said yes. Eighty percent of the students predicted Americans would be working in space in the year 2100. Sixty-three percent said they would also be living in space. Only 24 percent believed people would learn to control the weather. More than one in every 10 students, or 11 percent, said the average life span would be more than 125 years. Thirty-three percent said it would be 100 years and 18 percent said it would be 80. Fifty-one percent of the students said people will be able to buy artificial body parts, such as knees, ``off the shelf.'' A slight majority, 51 percent, believed Earthlings will be communicating with extraterrestrial beings in the 22nd century. The students also were asked how tall the tallest buildings would be. Twenty-four percent said 300 stories, 28 percent 500 stories, 17 percent 1,000 stories and 32 percent even higher. Most of the students, 55 percent, said the average work week will be shorter, but 17 percent said it will be longer. Twenty-nine percent thought it would be the same. Just half of those responding predicted that solar energy will be the main energy source in the century after the next. Sixteen percent chose nuclear power.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Child Comes First in Some Suspected Abuse Cases
DOC.TEXT: The rights of endangered children sometimes outweigh an adult's right against self-incrimination, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in the case of a mother jailed for refusing to disclose her son's whereabouts. The court ruled 7-2 Tuesday that Jacqueline Bouknight of Baltimore may continue to be jailed indefinitely for refusing to tell authorities where her 3-year-old son, Maurice, can be found. Social service workers fear the boy is dead. ``The bottom line is the court is following an equation that says if we think it's important enough, individual rights have to give way. Here we think the rights of children, the concern for children, is important enough,'' said Mary Cheh, professor of constitutional law at George Washington University in Washington, D.C. But a defense attorney said the punishment has not worked, and announced plans to file a motion in Circuit Court in Baltimore seeking the immediate release of Bouknight, who has been held in a city jail since April 1988. ``Twenty-two months of incarceration has had no effect on Ms. Bouknight's position. It is against the law to keep her there. There is no reason for the court to reasonably believe that continued incarceration would do anything else,'' defense lawyer M. Cristina Gutierrez said. Maurice has been missing since September 1987, when he was 11 months old. When he was 3 months old, Maurice was admitted to a Baltimore hospital for treatment of a broken leg and other injuries. He was held temporarily in protective care. He was returned to his mother after she agreed to undergo training in parenting skills and said she would not physically punish him. Maurice's father was shot to death two years ago and his mother had a history of drug use, according to testimony in juvenile court. Nine months later, social workers said Bouknight was not cooperating with them. She was held in contempt by a judge after she refused to disclose Maurice's whereabouts. The Maryland Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled Dec. 19 that jailing Bouknight for refusing to disclose the information violated her constitutional protection against self-incrimination. That ruling was overturned Tuesday. Society's interest in protecting the boy from harm prevails over the mother's claim that her right against self-incrimination will be violated if she is forced to reveal the child's whereabouts, the Supreme Court said. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote for the court that Ms. Bouknight's claim that her constitutional rights are being violated is particularly weak because of her agreement with welfare officials. ``Concern for the child's safety,'' O'Connor said, ``underlay the efforts to gain access to and then compel production of'' Bouknight's son. But Justice Thurgood Marshall, in a dissenting opinion, accused the court of ``riding roughshod'' over individual rights. Public defender George Burns Jr., who represented Bouknight, said the ruling indicated that if she were forced to disclose information on the whereabouts of the boy, the information might not be able to be used against her in a criminal proceeding. ``There is at least the suggestion that if the state forced her to talk or produce something, that they may not let the state use that in a criminal proceeding _ a kind of limited immunity statute,'' Burns said. Some observers said the ruling could provide a new weapon for officials seeking to protect children from parental abuse. Ernie Allen, president of the Center for Missing and Exploited Children, in Arlington, Va., said the court recognized that the privilege against self-incrimination is limited. ``In a case like this, there is a legitimate, valid public purpose for the state to act and intervene to do what it can to protect the safety of a child,'' Allen said. Mitchell Merviss, the attorney representing Maurice, said parents have to be accountable to society for the care they give their children. ``Our hope is the mother will cooperate now. That's her choice,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 6:30 a.m. EST; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: A pharmaceutical company said today it will make up to $10 million worth of an antibiotic available to homeless families. The antibiotic, Suprax, will be distributed through vouchers issued by community health centers, according to a statement from Lederle Laboratories, the company making the grant. The vouchers will be issued through 600 community-based health centers affiliated with the National Association of Community Health Centers. Lederle, based in Wayne, N.J., also is giving $1 million to the Children's Health Fund to help bring health care to homeless families and children. The group, co-founded by Dr. Irwin Redlener of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, pioneered programs to reach the homeless, including the first mobile health units for the homeless in New York City. Lederle said the recently developed antibiotic is especially suited for homeless families because it requires no refrigeration and only one dose per day is necessary to treat both middle ear infections and bronchitis. Middle ear infection is one of the most common childhood diseases and bronchitis is a common ailment among homeless adults. The $10 million will cover the cost of treating 330,000 patients, according to Lederle. A course of treatment consists of 1 dose per day for 10 straight days. The grant was being formally announced today in Washington at a news conference with Sens. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., and Christopher Dodd, D-Conn. Dodd is chairman of the Labor and Human Resources subcommittee on children, family, drugs and alcoholism, which has been holding hearings on the problems of homeless children.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Who Took Over Armory Prepares To Wait Out Legal Challenge
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff who took over a National Guard armory as a remedy to jail overcrowding promised not to back down as state lawyers worked to oust him. ``Right from the beginning, I planned on digging in,'' Michael Ashe said. ``That's where I'm at. I want to indicate that I'm not above the law. I don't feel I violated any law.'' At a hearing in Hampden Superior Court Tuesday, Judge George Keady granted state officials 48 hours to come up with arguments why Ashe should stop using the armory. Attorneys representing the county had asked that the situation be made permanent. State officials say Ashe has no business using the armory as temporary quarters for overflow prisoners. But Ashe said the alternative was putting the prisoners on the street. The sheriff said he is backed up by a 17th-century statute commanding him to keep the peace. ``I can understand the National Guard feeling put upon, being thrust into a situation ... all I can say is this was not done irrationally,'' Ashe said. The sheriff fended off eviction Monday when a judge granted a temporary restraining order ruling that the prisoners could stay put. Life at the temporary jail became a little more comfortable when the judge ordered the National Guard to turn over keys to the showers and kitchen. Tuesday, a lone patrol car sat in the armory's parking lot. Unauthorized visitors were shooed away by deputies keeping close guard on the door. The 15 prisoners quartered in bunk beds on the armory's drill floor were busy at their daytime jobs, said Richard McCarthy, Ashe's spokesman. The Hampden County jail, built to hold 279 inmates and under federal orders to house no more than 500, is a four-tier, red-brick building featuring 6-foot by 8-foot cells and narrow hallways with antique fixtures. With its narrow peep holes built into brick walls and a small, dusty yard, it resembles lockups of 1940s gangster movies. A new jail is scheduled to be built in nearby Ludlow, but that is at least two years away. Meanwhile, the 5-year-old, two-story armory seemed like a solution, said Ashe, who has let 1,200 inmates go on early-release programs since the federal cap took effect in the fall of 1988. The idea first came up last week when a Westfield district judge detained two of Ashe's deputies, angry that they wouldn't take a prisoner to the already full jail. The judge said Ashe had responsibility for housing prisoners and should take whatever steps necessary. Ashe, citing a 1648 law that he said gave him authority to take necessary steps to preserve public safety, marched into the armory on Friday and informed the National Guard he was taking over. He later installed 15 prisoners and guards were posted. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said Tuesday the armory takeover is not a solution to the problem. ``The answer to this problem is (prison) expansion at Ludlow and New Braintree,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers See Free Speech Limited by Court Ruling on Biography
DOC.TEXT: Publishers, scholars and free-speech advocates are bemoaning the Supreme Court's refusal to overturn a ruling that drastically limits the right of authors to quote unpublished material such as diaries and letters. The justices, without comment, refused Tuesday to hear an appeal by a company that published a biography attacking the late L. Ron Hubbard, founder of the Church of Scientology. That left intact a ruling last April by the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that imposed strict limits on the use of quotations from unpublished material. E. Gabriel Perle, a lawyer who represents the Association of American Publishers, said the appeals court ruling could put a permanent chill on the use of important source material by biographers and historians. ``The 2nd Circuit decision is an inexplicable inhibition on scholarly writing and publishing. It is a clearly a misapplication of the law,'' Perle said. ``It makes it impossible for scholars to use quotations without fear'' their works will be banned. But Michael Lee Hertzberg, a lawyer for the Scientologists, minimized the importance of the appeals court ruling. ``There is, in effect, an important right in the creator of a work to control the first dissemination of that work. The only thing protected here is creative expression,'' he said. In a busy return from a four-week winter recess, the Supreme Court also: _Ruled, 7-2, that parents suspected of child abuse sometimes may be jailed indefinitely for refusing to disclose the whereabouts of their children. The court permitted the indefinite jailing of a Maryland woman for refusing to tell authorities the location of her young son, who is feared dead. _Made it easier for disabled children to win some federal welfare benefits. The 7-2 decision in a Pennsylvania case could force the government to re-evaluate benefits for some 250,000 children. _Agreed to use an Ohio case to decide whether prosecutors who exclude blacks as jurors because of their race violate the rights of white defendants. _Left intact Baltimore, Md., ordinances requiring the city's employee pension plans to divest themselves of all investments in companies doing business with South Africa. In the Scientologists case, the 2nd Circuit court said federal copyright law generally bars use of unpublished material without permission. The appeals court rejected arguments that the ban violates constitutionally protected free expression. The ruling relied, in part, on an earlier 2nd Circuit court decision barring Random House from publishing a biography of author J.D. Salinger unless quotations from, and paraphrases of, Salinger's letters were deleted. Because of a technicality, the appeals court refused to block further publication of the Hubbard biography, entitled ``Bare-Faced Messiah.'' The appeals court said the copyright owners, who are affiliated with the Scientologists, waited too long to seek a court order blocking publication. Ironically, that made Henry Holt and Co., publisher of the biography, the technical winner before the appeals court. It also may have contributed to the Supreme Court's refusal to review the 2nd Circuit court ruling. In its appeal, Holt said the 2nd Circuit court ruling is a grave threat to the publishing industry because the appeals court is based in New York City, home to most of the nation's major book publishers. Lawyers for Holt said the ruling means the copyright law that was ``intended to promote the progress of the useful arts is now repeatedly being used to muzzle responsible biographers and historians.'' Among the groups supporting the Holt appeal were the American Historical Association and the Authors Guild. ``Bare-Faced Messiah,'' written by Russell Miller, accuses Hubbard of fakery and deception. Holt said quoting from Hubbard's unpublished letters and diaries was intended to expose the church founder's lies.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Looks at Slashing More Weapons Programs
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, prompted by the lessening Soviet threat to the West, is adding at least five major weapons systems to its list of programs being studied for possible cuts. Pressed by members of a Senate panel about scaling back programs, Deputy Defense Secretary Donald J. Atwood said Tuesday that the administration likely would review the two land-based nuclear missiles and the SSN-21 Seawolf attack submarine. The Pentagon already is studying possible scaling back of plans for the B-2 stealth bomber, the Advanced Tactical Fighter, the Advanced Tactical Aircraft and the C-17 transport. Atwood told the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on defense the review should be completed before midyear when the panel begins crafting a defense spending bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Atwood said among the additional candidates for review are the already-deployed multiple-warhead MX missile, which the Pentagon wants to base on rail cars, the planned single-warhead Midgetman missile based on special trucks and the attack submarine. ``We do have these studies ongoing. They are looking at the best assessments of the requirements based on our visualization of what the defense needs will be and do they need them,'' Atwood said. Asked whether the SSN-21 submarine was under review, Atwood said: ``We are considering ... picking up another five to seven major programs, major issues, and this may well be one of them.'' He did not list all the programs he had in mind. Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, chairman of the panel, predicted Congress will likely choose either the MX or Midgetman missiles this fiscal year, instead of providing funds for both as it did in past years. Inouye also warned that the administration's attempt to delay $2.2 billion in Pentagon expenditures this year could prove costly for the fiscal 1991 defense budget. Administrations routinely ask Congress to delay billions in planned spending each year. By law, these requests _ called deferrals _ are permissible because of unexpected contingencies or a chance to save money through better management. The deferrals can be blocked by a majority vote of either house of Congress. Policy considerations are not considered reasons for such delays to be requested. Yet according to the documents Bush sent lawmakers dated Feb. 6, the administration justifies many of the deferrals with the statement, ``this proposal reflects changes in requirements in view of promising developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.'' Inouye questioned Atwood on where the administration ``found this authority to make such deferrals.'' The deputy defense secretary said the deferrals ``all came about as change in requirements.'' But the committee chairman said he ``found the logic of changes in requirements in view of the changes in the Soviet Union to be a rather dangerous one that we also could use to do away with these other programs _ SDI, B-2 and such. ``And I'm certain that many members of the Congress are looking at this logic.''

DOC.HEAD: Navy: Espionage Not Found in Trident Navy Base Shootings
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has found no evidence of espionage as a factor in the fatal shootings of two sailors at a top-secret base, the slaying of a pawnshop clerk and the apparent suicide of a third sailor. But a lawyer for the third sailor's family, who raised the possibility of spy involvement, said Tuesday that Naval Investigative Service agents ``apparently are just not talking to the right people.'' The lawyer, Larry Scruggs Jr. of Milwaukee, also said in a telephone interview he believed his safety and that of the sailor's survivors had been jeopardized since he raised the espionage issue. He refused to identify his sources on that question or disclose the reasons for his safety concerns. Lt. Cmdr. Keith Arterburn at the Trident nuclear submarine base at Bangor, about 20 miles west of Seattle, said Scruggs refused to give Navy investigators his sources and never previously mentioned any fears for his personal security. ``I've been, in my opinion, very cooperative with the Naval Investigative Services investigators,'' Scruggs said. ``There are some things I cannot disclose at this time because of concern for my sources and my clients.'' Relatives of 23-year-old Shyam David Drizpaul, whose body was found Jan. 17 in a motel near Vancouver, Wash., said they hired Scruggs because they did not believe the police and Navy accounts. Authorities believe that Drizpaul, a Guyana native who lived in Milwaukee, killed David Allen Parker, 21, of San Diego, and Scott Anthony Seely, 18, of North Ridgeville, Ohio, at the base on Jan. 16, and a few hours later fatally shot Julie Lynn Tuscher, 24, at the Charleston Pawnshop in Bremerton. The clerk's brother, 28-year-old Allan Michaels, who was critically wounded in the pawnshop shooting, identified Drizpaul as the attacker and said he took a gun from the store that was found with the body at the motel. The Navy believes Drizpaul committed suicide. Scruggs believes Drizpaul was killed. A Navy statement said 35 investigators had conducted more than 500 interviews, talking to some people more than once, and had only a few people still to contact in the case. ``The investigation has not disclosed any indication of espionage or espionage-related activity,'' the Navy statement said Tuesday. ``That's pretty much settled,'' Arterburn said. Scruggs said Drizpaul apparently had a girlfriend identified to the lawyer only as Cindy, who worked evenings, attended school by day and may have obtained sensitive information on the Trident, a key component of the nation's nuclear deterrent. Scruggs said the woman was mentioned by sources in Milwaukee and the West Coast, including some ``who actually saw a photograph of this individual.'' Navy investigators have been unable to find anyone who said Drizpaul had a girlfriend, nor has the name Cindy been mentioned in interviews in connection with him, Seely or Parker, Arterburn said. He added that he had never heard before of any picture. A motel housekeeper, Marcy Plonski, initially told a reporter she saw a woman's long evening jacket in the room where Drizpaul's body was found, but Navy investigators found no sign of any outerwear except ``a man's tan trenchcoat,'' the Navy statement said. She also told a reporter she had seen a box of what appeared to be business papers in the car Drizpaul drove to the motel. But investigators said she told them she never saw such a box, the Navy statement said.

DOC.HEAD: New Study Finds Walls Of Jericho Did Tumble Down
DOC.TEXT: The walls of Jericho did come tumbling down as recounted in the Bible, according to an archaeological study. ``When we compare the archaeological evidence at Jericho with the biblical narrative describing the Israelite destruction of Jericho, we find remarkable agreement,'' said archaeologist Byrant G. Wood of the University of Toronto. After studying data from recently published excavation reports of British archaeologist Kathleen Kenyon, Wood wrote in the March-April issue of the scholarly journal, Biblical Archaeology Review: ``Here is impressive evidence that the walls of Jericho did indeed topple as the Bible records.'' Ms. Kenyon had concluded after her excavations in the 1950s that the fortified city was destroyed about 1550 B.C., and was no longer there at the time of the Israelite invasion dated after 1400 B.C. As a result, for about 30 years, ``scholars by and large have written off the biblical record as so much folklore and religious rhetoric,'' Wood said. However, he said extensive ceramic remnants and a carbon-14 sample contradict Ms. Kenyon's dating of the city's fall, and other evidence converged to support the biblical account. ``The correlation between the archaeological evidence and the biblical narrative is substantial,'' he said. As described in Joshua 6, Joshua's army marched around the city for a week, blowing rams' horns, and on the seventh day, combined shouting with the piercing horns, ``and the wall fell down flat.'' Wood noted that collapsed mud bricks were found outside a thick lower revetment wall where they had fallen, and apparently served as a ramp for the Israelites, described as going ``up'' into the city. Also, the Bible relates the event occurred after spring harvest, and that the Israelites burned the city _ both factors confirmed by the archeological remains, Wood said. He said the siege of the city obviously was short as indicated by the large amounts of scorched grain found. ``The presence of these grain stores in the destroyed city is entirely consistent with the biblical account,'' Wood wrote. ``The city did not fall as a result of a starvation siege, as was so common in ancient times. ``Instead, the Bible tells us Jericho was destroyed after but seven days.'' Wood noted that Jericho is situated in the Rift Valley, an unstable region where earthquakes are frequent, and he suggested a quake could have caused both the tumbling wall and also temporary blocking of the Jordan river. That is described in Joshua 3:16, allowing the Israelites to cross on land. ``Historians and Bible scholars have focused on the `miraculous' nature of the event, with little regard for the seismology of the southern Jordan valley.'' He said that mudslides caused by quakes have blocked the Jordan ``a number of times in recent recorded history. ... So the stoppage of the Jordan's flow as described in the Bible is not so far-fetched as it might at first seem.''

DOC.HEAD: Longtime Head Of Princeton Seminary Dies
DOC.TEXT: PRINCETON, N.J. (AP) The Rev. James I. McCord, an internationally known Presbyterian leader in the ecumenical movement and longtime president of Princeton Theological Seminary, has died at the age of 70. The cause of death was not immediately available. He died Sunday. He was president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches from 1977 to l982. His diplomatic intiatives contributed to unions of Reformed and Congregational churches in many countries. A native Texan, McCord was president and professor of theology at Princeton Theological Seminary from 1959 until his retirement in 1983. That year he became chancellor of Princeton's Center for Theological Inquiry, which he had founded. He retired from that post last year. A graduate of the University of Texas, McCord got his divinity degree from Austin Presbyterian Theological Seminary and served churches in Austin, Texas, and Manchester, N.H., before becoming dean of the Austin seminary in 1952. He later became head of the Princeton seminary, one of the oldest and most prestigious theological training institutions in the country.

DOC.HEAD: Man Shot to Death by Bullet that Came Through Ceiling
DOC.TEXT: A man sitting in his living room was shot and killed by a bullet that was fired through the floor of the apartment above his, police said. Vernon Russell, 76, of Greece, a Rochester suburb, was shot Tuesday, said police Commander Michael Murray. Clifton Jackson, 52, who lives in the apartment above Russell's, was charged with second-degree manslaughter, police said. Jackson pleaded innocent before Gates Town Justice John Pisaturo. He was sent to the Monroe County Jail in lieu of $5,000 cash or $10,000 bond. There was no dispute between the neighbors, and Jackson did not intend to shoot Russell, Murray said. He declined to say why the firearm was pointed at the floor.

DOC.HEAD: No Coca-Eating Caterpillars Without Invitation From Host Country
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration insists that ``neither troops nor caterpillars'' will be dispatched to fight the cocaine wars in South America without an invitation from the host country. The pledge came in reference to an Agriculture Department program that is researching development of voracious caterpillars to kill off coca plants. The department, in a research program that President Bush proposes to increase by $5 million to $6.5 million in fiscal 1991, is looking at a white moth that, when in its caterpillar stage, eats coca plant leaves. ``We are not undertaking any biological war,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``Neither troops nor caterpillars will go in without prior request and consultation.'' On a related topic, he said U.S. officials had known there was a possibility that drug terrorists had surface-to-air missiles when Bush flew to Colombia for last week's four-nation drug summit, but that the reports were never confirmed. Ten such weapons were seized by Colombian police on Monday. ``There was intelligence before we left of various kinds about missiles and rockets and other kinds of equipment, about people with various plans,'' Fitzwater said. The summit was attended by the presidents of Peru, Colombia and Bolivia, the three leading cocaine-producing countries. The unleashing of a defoliation caterpillar in those countries would open a new era in coca eradication efforts. But Fitzwater and Don Hamilton, a spokesman for national drug control policy director William Bennett, emphasized that the insect research program is in the experimental stage. Hamilton said the proposal is to look ``at all drug plants to try and learn as much as we can about them, including herbicides and natural enemies of the plants. This isn't something that is an option yet. It's a prospect of an option.'' A Peruvian embassy spokesman said that after The Washington Post ran a story on the caterpillar program Tuesday, U.S. officials assured the ambassador that no such program would be initiated in Peru without Lima's approval. A Bolivian official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said his country's environmental concerns have prompted it to reject the use of chemical agents against coca crops, and likely would also reject biological agents. Some environmental activists also were wary about the idea. Coca growing and processing already are ``extremely destructive'' to the environment because of the insecticides and the harsh chemicals employed, said Sandra Marquardt, pesticide information coordinator for Greenpeace U.S.A. But instead of the caterpillars producing ``a nice biological control, you'll have growers adding ever more insecticides to an already destructive production program,'' she said. Eric Christensen, a Natural Resources Defense Council attorney, said he is ``extremely dubious that such a program could be launched without producing potentially major environmental consequences, either from spreading an exotic pest that could have far-reaching consequences, or from producing a major increase in pesticide usage.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge, Dollar Gains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with major drop on stock market, closing figures
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged amid fears of rising interest rates Wednesday, with the main market index dropping more than 3 percent in the third largest single-day dive in history. The U.S. dollar, meanwhile, firmed against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, the most widely-followed index, lost 1,161.19 points, or 3.15 percent, to close at 35,734.33. On Tuesday it shed 327.08 points. It was the third largest single-day decline for the Nikkei index and its sharpest since Oct. 23, 1987, when the benchmark index lost 1,203.23 points in the aftermath of the around-the-world stock market crash known as Black Monday. Analysts attributed the plunge to a combination of negative factors, particularly fears of rising interest rates, which also depressed bond prices, and the poor showing of New York and London markets overnight. Despite the sharp decline, some analysts and dealers said investors remained calm, coolly watching the falling share prices from the sidelines. ``There have been hardly any buying incentives in the stock market since the beginning of the year,'' said Keiichi Nishida, a dealer with the Kidder Peabody Securities. ``The 3-percent decline today may look a lot, but at least I can say it was not the result of investor's panic-selling.'' In the currency market, the dollar closed at 145.15 yen, up 0.57 yen from Tuesday's close of 144.58 yen. After opening at 145.55 yen, the currency moved in a range of 145.10-145.60 yen. Currency dealers attributed the dollar's strength to expectations that U.S. interest rates won't decline soon. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve Board, said in a U.S. congressional hearing Tuesday that economic growth was likely to pick up, indicating the Fed will not relax monetary policy any time soon. ``The speculation that Japan's central bank might raise its discount rate has been making market players nervous,'' said a dealer at Daiichi Kangyo Bank, who asked that his name be withheld. The discount rate, which Japan's central bank charges on its loans to commercial banks, currently stands at 4.25 percent. Many market participants have speculated that the Bank of Japan might raise the country's key interest rate now that the parliamentary elections are over.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Sees Little Impact From Canada Trade Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The year-old Free Trade Agreement between the United States and Canada is having little national impact on farmers, according to an Agriculture Department report. One reason is that the U.S.-Canada agreement was negotiated at the same time agriculture had the international spotlight in the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, said Alan Webb of the department's Economic Research Service. The U.S.-Canada pact went into effect Jan. 1, 1989 and was designed to remove all tariff and some non-tariff barriers to agricultural trade between the two countries within 10 years. ``The GATT talks probably caused both countries to restrain the scope of their bilateral agricultural negotiations,'' Webb said in the February issue of Farmline magazine. ``Neither side wanted to make major concessions that would have reduced their bargaining chips in the larger multilateral GATT talks.'' But the looming presence of GATT did help spur some progress on agriculture in the U.S-Canada agreement, largely because it would have appeared as bad form not to have some favorable results. ``For two relatively friendly, open countries to admit defeat on negotiating something on agriculture would have sent a bad signal to the international community, particularly since both countries maintain that the real culprits in international agricultural trade are the European Community and Japan,'' Webb said. Canada and the United States have similarities in agricultural production and trade, meaning there are few reasons to negotiate changes or opportunities for tradeoffs. Also, he said, agricultural trade with the United States _ and the free-trade agreement _ are far more important to Canada than the other way around. Webb said the U.S. view was that the small size of the Canadian market did not justify large concessions. ``The United States would not make major changes in its domestic agricultural policies, particularly those which would affect head-to-head competition with Canada in other export markets, on the basis of Canadian concessions on agriculture,'' he said. But Webb said that in the larger, multilateral talks of the Uruguay Round, significant changes in domestic policies are more likely.

An Agriculture Department report shows 1990 farm income estimates are holding as predicted, although there is some slippage from the record level of two years ago. Net cash income may be in the range of $52 billion to $57 billion, compared with an estimated $53 billion in 1989 and the record of $57.2 billion in 1988, the report said Tuesday. That is the money left over after deducting cash expenses from gross cash income during a calendar year. It can include proceeds from sales of inventory commodities produced in previous years. Net farm income, another method of bookkeeping, may be in the range of $44 billion to $49 billion this year, compared with $48 billion in 1989 and $42.7 billion in 1988. This method measures income from farming during a specific year, including changes in the value of inventories, allowances for family dwellings, depreciation and other factors. Figures for both accounting methods were unchanged from projections made by the department's Economic Research Service the last two months. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter noted in testimony before the House Agriculture Committee earlier Tuesday, ``virtually all indicators of farm sector well-being have improved'' the last few years. ``Farm income is up, farm failures are down, farmland values are recovering and debt-to-asset ratios have improved,'' Yeutter said. ``Commodity surpluses have all but disappeared, some idle land has returned to production, and farm program spending is down.'' The agency report said farmland values have been revised, based on the 1987 census of agriculture. The average U.S. price of farmland as of February 1989, for example, was revised upward to $667 per acre from the earlier estimate of $597. No state figures were included.

J. Patrick Boyle, a former administrator of the Agriculture Department's Agricultural Marketing Service, has been named as head of the American Meat Institute, a national trade association. Boyle will take over April 1 from Manly Molpus, who leaves March 1 to become president and chief executive officer of the Grocery Manufacturers of America. Molpus has headed AMI since 1979. Boyle, a Washington attorney, headed the Agriculture Department agency from 1986 to 1989, overseeing such programs as federal meat grading and marketing programs.

DOC.HEAD: Top Candidate For School's Presidency Bows Out Of The Running
DOC.TEXT: The top candidate for the presidency of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology pulled out of consideration, saying he'd rather continue his teaching and scientific research. ``I know that the presidency of MIT is an office of extraordinary importance, challenge and opportunity _ but in the end, I discovered that it is not me,'' said professor Phillip A. Sharp in a statement released Tuesday. ``As I anticipated dissolving my research program and teaching duties, I came reluctantly to the realization that I could not fill that void in my life with anything else,'' said Sharp, the John D. MacArthur professor of biology, who directs the MIT Center for Cancer Research. An MIT executive committee nominated Sharp last week after more than 200 candidates were considered for the position, a spokesman said. ``The committee has accepted this decision with great regret,'' said Paul E. Gray, the current president. Gray was scheduled to leave July 1 to become chairman of the MIT Corporation, but may stay longer, said school spokesman Kenneth D. Campbell. Sharp had undergone several interviews during the committee's search to replace Gray, who is leaving after 10 years at the university's helm. ``I apologize for my indecisiveness and for not more fully understanding this personal need,'' he said. Sharp declined to answer any questions about his decision. The MIT Corporation was due to vote on Sharp's nomination at its March 2 meeting. Following his withdrawal, however, the corporation would not consider any nominations at that meeting, Campbell said.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Won't Save Earthquake Donations
DOC.TEXT: The Red Cross' decision against spending most of the $52.5 million in earthquake relief donations on other disasters won praise from community leaders as necessary to prevent a breach of faith with the public. ``When people indicate they want their money spent in a certain way, I think their desires should be acknowledged,'' Oakland Mayor Lionel Wilson said. In a reversal, the Red Cross promised Tuesday to spend the entire $52.5 million for earthquake relief in Northern California. The move followed criticism from San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos and others over its plans to put at least $30.4 million of the money in an account administered by its Washington, D.C., office for other disasters. ``We needed to take some action to re-establish good faith with our donors, to keep the trust and confidence with them,'' said Barbara Lohman, a spokesman for the American Red Cross regional office in Burlingame. The 109-year-old, nonprofit international relief organization has spent $12.1 million on emergency relief for the 100-mile stretch of Northern California devastated by the 7.1-magnitude quake on Oct. 17. The agency had promised to spend only another $10 million on long-term rebuilding programs, contending there had not been a demonstrated need for using the rest of the money here. Oakland and Alameda County officials are seeking $18.7 million from the agency for housing and other assistance programs for earthquake victims. Agnos had sought at least $10 million from the Red Cross, much of it to meet the needs of homeless people. Agnos had chided the Red Cross for considering taking that money out of Northern California, which sustained $7 billion to $10 billion in damage from the largest quake here since the 1906 Great Earthquake. ``There's a lot of unmet needs here,'' he said. The $12 million already spent by the Red Cross has supplied food, clothing, emergency rents and medical aid, Lohman said. Several million dollars worth of other supplies also have been provided by the Red Cross and will have to be paid for from the relief fund, Lohman said. Following the quake, the Red Cross set up 45 shelters, helping more than 14,000 families and providing 500,000 meals. The Red Cross still operates two shelters, one each in Oakland and San Francisco that serve a total of about 400 people. The decision not to transfer earthquake funds out of the region was made over the weekend after discussions between George F. Moody, national chairman of the Red Cross, and the agency's executive committee of its Board of Governors, a volunteer group that oversees Red Cross operations. Lohman said the Red Cross does not have a policy requiring it to use all donations designated for a specific disaster in those programs. The extra $30 million will be used to fund proposals already submitted by officials of the quake-stricken areas, including the cities of San Francisco, Santa Cruz, Watsonville and Oakland. The allocations will be announced in mid-March.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The search for fake grill marks on hot dogs has spawned a promising by-product that advertisers may relish: frank ads. A peek between the buns could reveal ``Hebrew National,'' ``Go Dodgers'' or some other promotional message tattooed on the frankfurter, if Viskase Corp.'s idea takes hold. Viskase, one of the world's biggest producers of hot dog holders, has developed the E-Z Mark Nojax cellulose casing. The company says it allows a hot dog maker to transfer a message printed in a ``USDA-approved food-grade ingredient'' from the casing to the meat. Viskase spokesman Doug Morris says the company steamed up the idea of making the hot dog an edible billboard while trying to figure out how to put fake grill marks on franks to make them look barbecued. Morris predicted that the printed dogs could begin turning up at special events and promotions within two months. But John Trosper of ARA Leisure Services Inc., concessions manager at Anaheim Stadium, said he's not sure the idea would work at the ballpark's high-volume refreshment stands. ``Our hot dogs are already cooked and in a bun and wrapped when they're sold,'' he said. ``You wouldn't see (the message). And by the time you unwrap it, where is it? It could be face down.''

The unofficial mascot of Phillips University _ P.U. for short _ wandered through an open door and caused quite a stink. A wayward skunk sprayed the floors of Marshall Hall on Tuesday as animal control workers hustled it outside. ``You try to keep them as calm as possible,'' said David Handley, manager of the Enid animal shelter. ``If you get them by the tail, they won't spray. This one we got around the mid-section and he let go. I kept him pointed at the floor.'' The skunk, whose fragrance sometimes arouses a response similar to the university's initials, was adopted by students more than 40 years ago as the school symbol.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't to Sell Public Telephone Company To Raise Money For Education
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon says the U.S. commonwealth's public telephone company will be sold to private investors and the proceeds used to improve education and public services. ``This means there won't be one school in Puerto Rico that is not painted, repaired,'' the governor said in his ``State of the Commonwealth'' address Tuesday. ``That no school lacks desks, blackboards, chalk. That no child lacks books or the necessary supplies for an education.'' Colon said the Puerto Rico Telephone Co. ``is the only company which has enough value'' to generate the money needed to revamp Puerto Rico's school system and the Caribbean island's infrastructure. He said he would sell it for ``no less than $2 billion.'' It was not immediately known if there is a buyer for the telephone company. Hernandez Colon was in New York City in January and met with the billonaire financier Donald Trump. The governor refused to provide details but said then they discussed ways to invest in education reform plans. At the time, Hernandez Colon said Trump ``was interested.'' The governor said without elaboration that Telefonica Espanola, the Spanish telephone company, ``is one of the enterprises that could be interested'' in the long-distance service. Hernandez Colon said he wanted to create two ``perpetual funds'' from the telephone company sale: a $1 billion fund for education and a $1 billion fund to modernize the island's highways, public housing, airports, waste dumps and energy operations. The government would use interest from those funds for the improvements, the governor said. Hernandez Colon said the government bought the telephone company during his 1974 administration for $165 million when it ``was in total abandonment'' and had only 300,000 telephone lines. He said the company, which made $70 million in net income last year, now accounts for 1 million telephones in the Spanish-speaking U.S. commonwealth of 3.3 million people. Hernandez Colon said that in private hands, the telephone company can make at least $170 million a year. ``Technologically, Puerto Rico Telephone is among the most advanced in the world,'' he said. The company's Puerto Rico Long Distance subsidiary has an estimated $200 million long-distance market. Hernandez Colon said he will introduce legislation stipulating none of the telephone company's nearly 8,000 jobs would be affected by the sale and that there be no rate increases for three years after it is bought. The governor has long said educational reform _ revamping schools, classrooms and textbooks and providing salary increases for teachers _ was a priority of his administration. He repeated his pledge when he was re-elected in November 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Say Bush Giving Away U.S. Store to Unified Europe
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's free trade approach to Western Europe's drive towards a one-market economy by 1992 is drawing fresh criticism in Congress as American companies relocate plants and jobs across the Atlantic to avoid being frozen out. Officials in the State and Commerce Departments and the U.S. Trade Representative's Office were barraged Tuesday with harsh attacks by both Democrats and members of the president's own party. ``Let's be honest, our trade policy is to have no policy,'' said conservative Rep. Toby Roth, R-Wis., who complained Bush ``is still living in the 1950s and '60s'' with his free-trade beliefs. ``We're in a real economic battle ... and you say `free trade' and nothing happens,'' Roth said during a hearing before the House Foreign Affairs trade subcommittee. ``That's the problem.'' The officials acknowledged they were unsuccessful in stopping the 12-member European Community from adopting restrictions on broadcasting last October that would allow member countries to keep U.S. television shows and movies off their airwaves. ``But we have not left the playing field on that one, let me assure you,'' said Peter Allgeier, the assistant U.S. trade representative for Europe. Subcommittee Chairman Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn., complained the administration hasn't even put a full team on the field yet, citing unfilled posts that Congress created last year to monitor the EC '92 negotiations taking place in Brussels. ``Our single biggest trading partner is changing all the rules of the game,'' he said, while the administration is treating the issue as ``something we can get around to in the lazy, hazy days of summer. It just boggles the mind.'' Gejdenson cited recent decisions by General Electric Co. and United Technologies Corp. to move some of their jet engine facilities from the United States to Europe. He said several semiconductor manufacturers have reversed their initial plans to build new plants here and instead are going to put them in Europe in order to assure access to the market there after 1992. ``This isn't a simply a debate between liberalization and protectionism,'' Gejdenson asserted. ``Companies in this country have decided that you're not going to get the job done, so they're moving their investments to Europe.'' Administration officials acknowledged their prediction a year ago that the EC '92 process would move slowly has been overtaken by the overthrow of communist governments in Eastern Europe and the crumbling of the Berlin Wall. Assistant Secretary of State Eugene McAllister said moves this month to reunify East and West Germany ``could very well help speed up'' the adoption of a single-market economy for all of Western Europe. ``Many of the EC nations are intent upon keeping Germany western oriented and they see EC '92 as a very important contributing factor to that,'' he said. ``(French) President (Francois) Mitterrand has stated that in very blunt terms.'' Gejdenson complained Bush continues to shun threats of retaliation while EC members draft protectionist directives against imports of U.S. agriculture and big-ticket items such as telecommunications and electrical equipment. He cited memorandums of understanding assuring Italy and the Netherlands continued wide access to Pentagon procurement contracts regardless of the trade talks. ``The one thing we have in our cards is access to American defense procurement,'' he said. ``Did any of you guys ever play poker? You have to have chips, you need cards in your hand. What are you threatening the Europeans with? That you'll go home empty?'' Allgeier called defense procurement a ``very sensitive issue'' within the administration but pledged, ``We will use whatever leverage we can.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration, Labor Leaders Clash Over Eastern Strike
DOC.TEXT: Union leaders accused the Bush administration of favoring Eastern Airlines in its bitter 11-month dispute with machinists, but administration officials said the president has remained neutral.
