AFL-CIO leaders, gathered at their annual winter meeting, charged Tuesday that the federal government has a $120 million contract with Eastern. Lane Kirkland, head of the 14.1-million member federation, suggested that President Bush had been influenced by lobbyists for Texas Air Corp., Eastern's parent. ``They're not collecting fees for nothing,'' he said. In a letter sent to Bush Tuesday, George Kourpias, president of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, said the contract ``is not the impartial act of an even-handed federal executive. It is the biased antagonism of an underhanded administration.'' But U.S. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole told reporters there was no favoritism toward Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo. She said Lorenzo's labor practices ``leave a lot to be desired,'' and promised to look into the alleged contract for federal travel services. At the White House after labor leaders met with Mrs. Dole in Florida, deputy press secretary Stephen Hart said, ``the Labor Department assures us that there is no such contract.'' An administration official speaking on the condition of anonymity said the issue involves General Services Administration guidelines on preferred city-to-city airline rates for couriers. The machinists' union calculated what the maximum benefit in income to Eastern might be from these guidelines, and came up with the $120 million figure, the official said. Eastern filed for bankruptcy reorganization law five days after the machinists union walked out in March 1989, and the carrier has hired replacement workers as it attempts to reduce its size. Eastern faced a midnight Tuesday deadline for submitting a reorganization plan to a federal bankruptcy judge.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Debates `Armenian Genocide' Resolution
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain; debate resumes midday
DOC.TEXT: The Senate is embroiled in debate over the ``Armenian genocide'' that is pitting GOP members against the Bush administration and threatening to poison relations with Turkey. Led by Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole, R-Kan., supporters of the controversial resolution say the measure is an effort to remember the 1.5 million Armenians who were killed in 1915-1923 during the Ottoman Empire because of their ethnic background. The Ottoman Empire is now Turkey. Opponents of the measure said it could sour U.S. relations with Turkey, a NATO ally, and threaten the future of military bases in the Moslem country. The Senate was expected to continue debate today, with a cloture vote scheduled on Thursday to cut off debate. Sixty senators must approve that motion before a vote on the measure can be taken. ``It is time for the Senate, the Congress, the United States government _ it is time, finally, for all of us to do what is right,'' said Dole. ``It's time for the United States, officially, to commemorate the Armenian genocide.'' Dole sponsored the resolution to make April 24 a national day of remembrance of the anniversary of the ``Armenian genocide, 1915-1923.'' Turkey is fiercely opposed to the measure and has objected to the term ``genocide.'' Prime Minister Turgut Ozal has said the measure has united all Turks. ``I am deeply concerned that if the Senate passes the resolution, it will unwittingly slap the face of a very important NATO ally,'' said Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., an opponent. Byrd was the only senator to speak against the measure Tuesday. Others supporting it included Sens. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Pete Wilson, R-Calif., a gubernatorial candidate in a state with a large Armenian-American population. Much of the debate centered Tuesday over the term ``genocide,'' which Byrd said may not apply to the massacre of Armenians under the strict definition of the Geneva Convention. Although the Bush administration opposes the resolution, the measure is a potential source of embarrassment for President Bush, who said during the 1988 campaign that he would be inclined to support it. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., quoted Bush as saying during 1988 that the United States ``must acknowledge the attempted genocide'' of the Armenians. ``I would join Congress in commemorating the victims of that period,'' Simon quoted Bush as saying. ``Clearly a different signal is coming from the White House today,'' he said. Dole's spokesman, Walt Riker, said the senator and White House officials had tried unsuccessfully to arrive at compromise language on the resolution. Dole has rejected any effort to water down the language, but said he might offer amendments that contain ``less offensive'' words when the measure reaches the Senate floor. Dole complained about the ``massive lobbying effort'' to block the measure, which was passed last year by the Senate Judiciary Committee. He said the resolution had 61 co-sponsors last year, but today has only 46 co-sponsors. ``What has changed is the launching of a massive lobbying effort against the resolution _ by the administration, by the government of Turkey, by American businesses who operate in Turkey and _ regrettably _ by some private organizations and individuals who ought to be supportive of the resolution,'' he said. Last year, Dole wrote to the Israeli ambassador asking if Israel had asked some Jewish groups to work against the measure, according to Riker. Turkey is a Moslem country that has relations with Israel. Meantime, Turkey has already taken steps to show its displeasure at the resolution. The country has banned ports of call by U.S. nuclear-powered warships and barred flights by training missions into a gunnery range, according to Mike McNamara, who represents Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter's Notebook: Washington Toasts Czechoslovak Delegation
With PM-US-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The maiden voyage of Czechoslovakia's new reformist government to the United States was a symbolic full-circle return to values long cherished by Czechs and Slovaks, but also an exciting personal experience for members of the delegation. When President Vaclav Havel shook President Bush's hand inside the White House, it was a beginning of a new era, a strong reminder of 1918 when Woodrow Wilson played a key role in establishing free Czechoslovakia, and an overwhelming victory for Havel, a former dissident playwright. Havel, the first president in Czechoslovak history to visit Washington with full honors of a head of state, still remembers the first time 22 years ago when he visited the United States as a promising writer and human rights activist. ``The difference is not that I am the president now, but rather that we did not have freedom and now we do,'' Havel said on NBC-TV's ``Today'' show on Tuesday. His countrymen have always looked up to American ideals of democratic freedom and private enterprise, but often history took them in a different direction. The Munich Pact stripped Czechoslovakia of meaningful defense against Hitler in 1938, communists took over with Soviet support 10 years later, and Warsaw Pact tanks crushed Alexander Dubcek's ``Prague Spring'' in 1968. But in the tradition of his absurdist plays, it took Havel no more than 41 days to lead his country from the spiritual depression caused by four decades of communist rule to national euphoria during his inauguration on Dec. 29. ``For some time I knew things had to change, but nobody was more surprised when they did,'' Havel told about 500 students at the Gaston Hall of Georgetown University on Tuesday. The presidential Ilyushin plane also carried a 7O-member delegation of government officials, Havel's former comrades-in-arms, fellow artists and friends. Many had never before visited the United States, while others had to wait many years to return. Jiri Dienstbier once was sentenced by communists to four years in jail and a menial job of a furnace stoker, only to come back as Czechoslovak foreign minister to Washington where he worked as Prague Radio correspondent in 1968. He still loves New York as the second best town in the world _ next to Prague _ and clearly enjoys the frantic schedule of a highly popular foreign minister who visited more than 10 countries in January alone. ``In two months more has happened in Czechoslovak diplomatic life than in the last 10 years before that,'' Rozarka Hunatova, Dienstbier's adviser, said at a party given Tuesday night by the Czechoslovak embassy in Havel's honor. ``We have not seen anything like this as far as I can remember,'' said Karel Huska, a senior Czechoslovak diplomat serving his third year in Washington. More than 800 people thronged the once-placid embassy, where an adjacent tent was built to accommodate the guests. ``How do you like America?'' a reporter asked Olga Havlova, the president's wife, who shook hands with teary-eyed countrymen who came to see their hero. ``It's okay,'' she replied, while the president joined in the chorus of the Czech version of ``On Top of Old Smokey,'' rendered by Waldemar Matuska, an exiled Czech singer now living in Florida. Vaclav Klaus, the multilingual finance minister who spent 20 years in the obscurity of a bank clerk, asked a reporter, ``The Village Voice? You mean the Village still exists? I remember it 20 years ago.'' The mood was relaxed, in spite of another 16-hour working day for the Czechoslovak delegation, frequent flights, countless meetings and ceremonial receptions. ``We started out with having to sit through one of his (Havel's) plays in a Reykjavik theatre for over two hours and listening to the whole thing in Icelandic, but from then on it was just great,'' a delegation member quipped. During six hectic days of his tour, Havel visited Iceland and Canada, met with Bush on Tuesday, addresses a joint meeting of Congress today and attends a star-studded concert in his honor in New York on Thursday. ``The trip will undoubtedly produce a better understanding of economic and political relations between the two countries,'' Vice Premier Vladimir Dlouhy said. ``What I like best are the motorcades,'' added his assistant. ``But somebody should find our luggage which got lost on its way to the Blair House.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Predict Upset Chamorro Victory in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Three House members just back from Nicaragua are predicting a stunning upset victory for opposition candidate Violeta Chamorro over leftist President Daniel Ortega in Sunday's national elections. ``If I were a betting man, I'd go with the longshot. I think she's going to upset him,'' said Rep. Gary Ackerman, D-N.Y., who made the trip with Reps. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., and Doug Bosco, D-Calif. ``I think she's got the votes,'' Ackerman said, basing his prediction on the responses of crowds at UNO rallies last week in the area around the capital of Managua and on conversations with citizens who appear confident of the election's integrity. Ackerman said he went to Nicaragua sharing the widely held view that Mrs. Chamorro's campaign has been so weak and that Ortega's ruling leftist Sandinista party holds such a grip on the country that the election was no contest. ``I came away with a different perspective,'' he said in an interview. An ABC-Washington Post poll released Tuesday indicated that Ortega held a 16 percentage point lead over Mrs. Chamorro, 48 percent to 32 percent. The ABC-Washington Post poll was based on interviews with 925 likely Nicaraguan voters on Feb. 11-15. The margin of error was plus or minus 3.5 percentage points. Polls have generally put the Sandinistas ahead. However, experts caution that polling in less developed countries such as Nicaragua is, at best, a tricky business. Ackerman said the group was impressed by the vigorous campaign being waged by both the Sandinistas and the 14-party opposition coalition known as UNO. ``There's a real, genuine, knockdown, drag-out, hometown campaign going on,'' he said. The Sandinistas have erected billboards showing Ortega holding a child and promising a better future for the country. Ackerman also said the Sandinistas are using telemarketing to make calls that feature a recorded message from ``your president.'' ``One lady said she was called four times,'' Ackerman said. While Mrs. Chamorro's side has few of those political trappings, she draws large, enthusiastic crowds at rallies, he said. The head of the country's Roman Catholic Church, Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, has done everything but make an outright endorsement of UNO, Ackerman said. But most telling, he said, was that voters questioned by the congressmen consistently told them, ``My vote is secret,'' an indication of faith in the voting process that bodes ill for Ortega. ``People remember they were hungry yesterday, and that their kids couldn't go to school. ... They really have little hope except in overturning things,'' Ackerman said. With the country's economy in a shambles after a decade of civil war, ``you don't want to validate the past, you want a change,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fresh MiGs Sent To Cuba; US Concerned
DOC.TEXT: The State Department says it is not threatening Cuba when it says it ``simply cannot tolerate'' such developments as Cuba's receipt of a new shipment of high-performance Soviet fighter planes. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler confirmed Tuesday that Cuba has received a delivery of new MiG-29 jet fighters. Although Ms. Tutwiler gave no figure, The Washington Times reported in Tuesday's editions that six were received. Ms. Tutwiler quoted Baker as saying, ``Cuba is actively supporting the insurgency in El Salvador and it is these kind of activities close to the shores of the United States that we simply cannot tolerate.'' However, she said the statement intended no threat to Cuba. Ms. Tutwiler referred reporters to Secretary of State James A. Baker III's recent testimony before a Soviet legislative committee in which he said Cuba posed no threat to the United States. The report said the combined total of MiGs in Cuba's arsenal has risen to more than 300, most of them older models. Ms. Tutwiler noted Baker had told the Soviet legislators during a visit to Moscow earlier this month that the United States has difficulty understanding why the Kremlin continues to send MiG-29s to Cuba, particularly at a time when Cuba has been so critical of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform policies.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Cites Faster Lifting of U.S.-Canada Tariffs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has notified Congress that the governments of the United States and Canada have reached agreement on the quick lifting of tariffs on some 400 products worth $6 billion in trade. For the products covered, the agreement announced Tuesday speeds up the timetable for lifting duties under the landmark U.S.-Canada free-trade agreement that took effect Jan. 1, 1989. That pact calls for phasing out all tariffs by 1999. U.S. products on which duties will be eliminated at once under the speeded-up agreement include chemicals, pharmaceutical products, photographic film, telecommunications equipment, electric motors and generators, hydraulic pumps, printed circuits and scientific instruments. Canadian products that will benefit include diesel engines, chemical plastics, machinery, textiles and certain food products. Two-way trade in goods and services between the United States and Canada is roughly $200 billion. About 70 percent is currently duty free. However, many products _ notably Canadian steel, lumber, paper and other forest products _ remain under tariffs that are being phased out under terms of the original free-trade agreement and were not affected by Tuesday's action.
DOC.HEAD: Fifteen Held, None Yet Charged in Killings of Americans in Panama
DOC.TEXT: Former members of the Panamanian Defense Forces are among 15 people in custody in Panama in connection with the murders of an American citizen and a U.S. Embassy employee, the FBI says. Those in custody include both potential witnesses and ``possible participants'' in the killings of Raymond Dragseth, an American living in Panama City and Fernando E. Brathwaite, a U.S. Embassy employee, FBI officials said Tuesday. Panamanian authorities are expected to bring formal charges in the near future, according to the FBI. The bodies of both men were found Dec. 21, the day after U.S. troops invaded Panama. The FBI said its investigation determined that members of the PDF abducted Dragseth from his house at gunpoint on Dec. 20. Brathwaite was abducted later in the day. Both men were taken outside the city and shot to death, the FBI said. The former PDF members in custody were members of a special anti-terrorism unit of the Panamanian military under the government of deposed leader Manuel Antonio Noriega, said a law enforcement source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The investigation was conducted by the FBI along with the Panamanian Technical Judicial Police and the U.S. Embassy.

DOC.HEAD: Critics See Flaws in Social Security Toll-Free Phone Network
DOC.TEXT: Social Security's toll-free telephone network is coming under fire from members of Congress who say the new national phone system has depersonalized service and too often offers busy signals and wrong answers to frustrated callers. ``When our nation's government starts throwing machines where experienced people belong, service becomes disservice,'' Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., said in testimony prepared for a hearing today of the House Ways and Means subcommittee on Social Security. Pryor, who chairs the Special Senate Committee on Aging, complained of ``excessive busy signals and wrong or incomplete answers'' when people call the Social Security phone network. The senator said he would introduce legislation today requiring Social Security to offer direct telephone access to its field offices and to make use of the 800-line service optional. ``There can be little doubt that the 800 line has seriously eroded the quality of the agency's service to the public,'' he said. The telephone network _ reached by dialing 1-800-2345-SSA _ is staffed from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. across the country, and allows callers to take care of many matters without going into a Social Security office. In many cities, the toll-free number is the only Social Security number listed in the phone book. But congressional critics complain people often are unable to get through on the toll-free lines and that many don't get full and accurate information when they do get through. Congressional caseworkers report people are frustrated when they get connected to someone at a distant location who doesn't understand local problems, and because they usually can't talk to the same person if they call back. On Tuesday, Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King defended the telephone network as a ``success story'' but acknowledged that callers too often get busy signals. The telephone network, which went nationwide last October, was expected to handle about 250,000 calls a day, but more than 1.5 million people try to get through on peak days, and many of them call between 10 a.m. and 2 p.m., she said. ``The 800-number is the biggest success story we've had,'' Mrs. King said at a press briefing. ``We just have too a big a success on our hands. ... the trick is how to manage it so that it works better.'' Mrs. King said the agency is preparing television and newspaper public service announcements that encourage people to ``have breakfast with Social Security'' by calling between 7 a.m. and 9 a.m. when the phone lines are less busy. Mrs. King said a new study by the Inspector General's Office of the Department of Health and Human Services found that 67 percent of those who used the toll-free line said they would use the telephone again to do business with Social Security, up from 53 percent in 1984. Eighty-two percent of those who used the 800 number reported the service was good or very good, she said. ``What we are finding is that when people do get through, they find the service is courteous, they're very happy with the information they received,'' she said. In January, traditionally a busy month for the agency, an estimated 52 percent of calls to Social Security's 800 number were met with busy signals, compared with 14 percent in December, 51 percent in November and 30 percent in October, Mrs. King said. Her goal is to reduce the busy rate on peak days to 35 percent by the end of the year. ``The busy rates are a lot higher than we or anyone would like to have them on those peak days,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Asbestos Risk Still a Concern
DOC.TEXT: Recent articles in science journals that claim asbestos is not as dangerous as once believed should be met with skepticism by the public, a group of scientists said. Articles in the past year in such publications as The New England Journal of Medicine and Science magazine and a Harvard University symposium played down the risks associated with asbestos, panelists at the National Asbestos Conference said Tuesday. Warren Friedman, who coordinates the asbestos program at the U.S. General Services Administration, said there is ample evidence from recent studies that indicate asbestos exposure does pose health risks, particularly long-term exposure. More studies are needed, he said. ``You increase the duration of exposure, you're going to increase the risk,'' he said. Asbestos was used for years in buildings as a fire retardant and an insulator. But research in the 1960s found that inhaling asbestos fibers increases the risk of developing lung cancer. The fallout from that research helped create a $51 billion ``asbestos abatement'' industry to remove asbestos from schools and other buildings, and to monitor its presence elsewhere. ``At the very least, it's not yet time to say all is well,'' said Dale Keyes, a physicist with Environmental Sciences of Phoenix. Richard Kronenberg, a researcher with the University of Texas Health Science Center at Tyler, noted that the asbestos articles published the past year in scientific magazines were written by reputable researchers, but he said any conclusions are still ``uncertain.'' Current federal regulations do not require asbestos removal and most contractors do not routinely expose workers or the public to health hazards, Kronenberg said. ``By and large it's a very tightly regulated, excellent industry,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Announce Offensive Against U.S. Interests
DOC.TEXT: A pro-Cuban guerrilla group holding two Americans captive says it will attack U.S. interests in Colombia and if the United States intervenes, ``there will be an uprising like in Vietnam and El Salvador.'' The National Liberation Army declared ``Death to gringos.'' President Virgilio Barco called an urgent meeting of the National Security Council. Earlier Tuesday, at Barco's urging, a federal court pardoned 35 members of another guerrilla group _ the April 19 Movement _ who were accused of taking part in the 1985 takeover of the Palace of Justice that claimed the lives of 95 people, including 11 Supreme Court justices. The National Liberation Army is one of six guerrilla groups in Colombia and is under the command of Manuel Perez, a former Roman Catholic priest. It sent a letter to the families of two Americans kidnapped last week by its guerrillas in the northwestern city of Medellin, according to Colombian news reports. The Medellin daily El Colombiano published the letter Tuesday. The letter was directed to the families of James Donnelly, a 65-year-old mechanical engineer from Detroit, and David Kent, a 40-year-old schoolteacher from Indianapolis. The guerrilla group said it abducted the two men Feb. 13 to protest President Bush's visit to the port city of Cartagena Thursday to attend an anti-drug summit. ``We are inclined to give a lesson in respect to the government of the United States, and if it intervenes in Colombia there will be an uprising like in Vietnam and El Salvador,'' the letter said. ``Our position will change only when North America suspends its ways of intervening and of military aggression in Latin America.'' News accounts read on the radio identified some of the U.S. targets cited as Occidental Petroleum, Texaco and other U.S. oil companies and enterprises. The Defense Ministry estimates the group has about 2,000 of the 10,000 guerrillas figured to be operating in Colombia. The National Liberation Army blew up an electrical tower shortly before midnight Monday and blacked out most of Cartagena, the city of 530,000 where Bush met with Presidents Barco, Alan Garcia of Peru and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia. Insurgents then attacked a police station and five neighborhood police command posts, wounding five policemen, a national police communique said. Also Monday, the guerrilla group set fire to equipment at a government oil drilling camp and fought two battles with police. One police officer and two guerrillas were killed and one policeman wounded. A police communique also said Fabio Gomez, mayor of Almaguer in southwest Cauca state, and Colombian anthropologist Jesus Bolivar were kidnapped Saturday in Almaguer. In the last 18 months the National Liberation Army has kidnapped 16 mayors. The guerrillas have been releasing the mayors after warning them to spend more money on projects for poor people. The guerrilla group late Monday freed an American priest, Francis Amico Ferrari, 43, of Rochester, N.Y., who was kidnapped Thurday from his parish in the slums of the western city of Cali. The pardons given to guerrillas on Tuesday are part of an attempt by the Barco government to end three decades of rebel violence in which more than 75,000 people have been killed. In all, five guerrilla groups have told the Barco government they are interested in peace talks. In another development, Gen. Miguel Maza, chief of Colombia's secret police, said 10 shoulder-fired, surface-to-air missiles seized Monday from drug traffickers were to have been used to attack the Bogota international airport and other major government installations. A major drug cartel is based in Medellin. It has waged war against the government the last six months because of the Barco administration's anti-drug crackdown, which includes extraditing suspected drug traffickers to face charges in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Allows 92-year-old to Keep her Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `In opening ...' to restore first reference to Harlow; picks up 12th graf, ``Mr. Vance ...'.
DOC.TEXT: The walls of 92-year-old Luella Wilson's home are covered with the treasures of a lifetime. Trophies from the hunting expeditions of her younger years _ moose and coyotes _ hang on the walls, and her rooms are cluttered with sentimental bric-a-brac. Now, for the first time in three years, Wilson is safe in the knowledge that her home and 80-acre property will be hers for the rest of her life. She agreed to a court settlement that lets her keep both. Seated at the kitchen table Tuesday afternoon, surrounded by family and friends and sipping a celebratory shot of whiskey, Wilson looked markedly healthier and happier than she had just hours earlier seated in a wheelchair at the start of the liability trial. The settlement, reached during the noon hour on the first day of the trial, in effect overturns a jury verdict in 1987 that Wilson had to give up her home and life savings, valued at $950,000. ``Certainly I am (relieved),'' said Wilson. ``I don't feel so damn good. I can't walk. But I did win.'' The 1987 jury had found her liable for severe injuries suffered by Mark Vince, who had been riding in a car driven by Wilson's great nephew in a 1984 accident. Wilson had loaned her great nephew, Willard Stuart, the money to buy the car and jurors felt she should have known Stuart lacked a driver's license. Wilson learned of the settlement at home in a telephone call from her lawyer. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. Wilson said she thought her insurance company, Vermont Mutual, was picking up her share of the settlement tab. But an attorney for Vermont Mutual, Richard Bowen, denied that scenario. Bowen, who attended the Tuesday trial, said the company and Wilson had settled a separate suit, but he would not disclose the terms of that settlement. In opening arguments Tuesday morning, Wilson's attorney Frederick Harlow told jurors Vince, not Wilson, must bear the blame for the fact he is mostly paralyzed and has lost a leg. ``Mr. Vince knew the designated driver was drinking beers, having some marijuana. Mr. Vince knew that,'' Harlow told jurors. On Monday Wilson rejected settlement offers that she leave her home and assets to Vince upon her death. ``My husband Harry would roll over in his grave if I ever did that,'' she said. She said Tuesday that she would not have to leave the farm to Vince after her death under the approved settlement. Rolf Sternberg, one of Vince's lawyers, had argued that Wilson, the car dealership and the car salesman were negligent in loaning Stuart money and selling him a car knowing he did not have a license and was not competent to drive. ``Mrs. Wilson had no reason to consider her nephew an unsafe driver, someone she should not lend money to,'' Harlow countered. Stuart said he had lived with Wilson for a short time and had served as her driver during that time, even though he didn't have a license. Shortly after he bought the car in 1984, Stuart drove it off a bridge after drinking beer and Black Velvet whiskey and smoking marijuana, with a group of young men, including Vince, according to court records. Vince, a back-seat passenger, was partially paralyzed as a result of the accident, according to records. He later had one leg amputated.

DOC.HEAD: Riots in Venezuela Over Bus Fares
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to restore time element.
DOC.TEXT: Mobs angered by a public transportation strike looted a dozen grocery stores and burned a truck, a TV news program reported. Rock-throwing students battled police in Caracas. At least 50 people were reported arrested. The disturbances Tuesday in seven cities were among the worst since February 1989, when 300 people were killed and more than 1,000 injured in widespread rioting over an increase in bus fares. In the cities of Barcelona and Puerto La Cruz, both about 120 miles east of Caracas, at least 12 grocery stores where sacked before police fired tear gas to disperse the mobs, Radio Caracas Television said. No casualties were reported during the violence but at least 30 people were arrested in both cities, the TV reported. At least 20 students were arrested after a two-hour battle with police in a square outside Venezuelan Central University in Caracas, witnesses said. The students threw rocks and set a truck on fire, students said. Minor disturbances broke out in Merida, Cumana, San Cristobal, Barquisimeto and Maracaibo, police sources said. Many of the protesters were students angered by the strike and by the refusal of some bus lines whose to grant student discounts. The strike left most cities with only partial public transportation. The strike was called by unions protesting delays by the government in paying subsidies that allow discounts of up to 50 percent over regular rates for students. Increases of 30 percent to 50 percent in public transport tariffs and price gouging by bus drivers set off the rioting in February 1989 _ the worst violence in Venezuela in 31 years. The nation of 18 million had been regarded as an island of tranquility in a region of increasing violence and political and economic instability. The price increases were part of a government austerity program intended to halt the downward economic spiral that has gripped Venezuela since the collapse of oil prices in the early 1980s. The Caracas-based Latin American Institute for Social research surveyed 2.3 million families in 1981 and classified 22.5 percent of them as poor. In 1987, it surveyed 3.1 million families and categorized 54 percent of them as poor.

DOC.HEAD: Kevin Costner Receives Hasty Pudding's Man Of The Year Award
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Actor Kevin Costner says the Man of the Year honor from Harvard University's Hasty Pudding Theatricals is one of his first awards, and he treats it ``with more reverence that you might think.'' Costner, who has starred in such films as ``Bull Durham,'' ``No Way Out,'' ``The Untouchables,'' and ``Field of Dreams,'' received the traditional Hasty Pudding pot from the undergraduate theatrical group Tuesday, then fell right in with the college hi-jinks. ``My father was terribly concerned that this kind of thing would happen as a result of acting,'' Costner quipped after donning a red-sequinned bra with a baseball motif over his tuxedo. He accepted kisses from men in drag before a whooping crowd of 300. The theatrical group said some of Costner's lesser known roles caught its attention. ``What first attracted our eye was the soul-searching in such films as ``Night Shift'' and ``Sizzle Beach U.S.A.,'' joked Sharon Owyang, a junior and one of the show's producers. Costner, who lives with his wife and three children in La Canada, Calif., is the 24th recipient of the annual Hasty Pudding pot, joining the ranks of such alumni as Paul Newman, Johnny Carson, Robert Redford and Bill Cosby. Actress Glenn Close was named the club's Woman of the Year last week, an honor that Kathleen Turner received in 1989. Costner, 34, began his career as a janitor, sweeping stages until he gradually began working with film crews and taking acting lessons at night. He got a big break when his wrists and hair appeared in the early 1980s hit movie ``The Big Chill,'' in which he played a dead man whose suicide brings together a group of old college friends. Most of that appearance ended up on the cutting room floor, but the film's director cast him in another role and his star has been rising ever since.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We are not undertaking any biological war. Neither troops nor caterpillars will go in without prior request and consultation.'' _ Marlin Fitzwater, White House press secretary, on an Agriculture Department program that is researching development of voracious caterpillars to kill off drug-producing coca plants in South American jungles.

``It's kind of like poker _ you can't win if you don't play. We had no choice but to play the game.'' _ Alan Purcell, 27, stepfather of 12-year-old Stormie Jones, on the girl's second liver transplant. Stormie received the nation's first heart-liver transplant in 1984.

``I wanted the hands to move back the most. The danger of military confrontation between the superpowers and the credibility of that threat is lessening every hour.'' _ Leon M. Lederman, Nobel laureate, on the status of the Doomsday Clock. The clock, which appears yearly on the cover of The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, has been near midnight since its debut in 1947, indicating high superpower tensions.

DOC.HEAD: Main Stock Exchange Takes Biggest Single-Day Dive Since '87 Crash
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index fell more than 3 percent today in its third biggest single-day dive ever and worst since the worldwide stock market crash in October 1987. Traders blamed heavy computer-guided selling by foreign brokerage firms for the decline and said there was no panic-selling. Amid concerns about possible interest rate increases, the index already had fallen a total of nearly 565 points on the previous two trading days. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, the most widely followed index on the exchange, fell 1,161.19 points, or 3.15 percent, closing at 35,734.33. It was the index's sharpest decline since a plunge of 1,203.23 on Oct. 23, 1987, following a round-the-world stock market crash. The largest single-day plunge in Tokyo was 3,836.48 points on Oct. 20, 1987. The dollar meanwhile rose moderately against the yen. Analysts and dealers said today's abrupt drop was largely due to waves of computer-guided selling by foreign brokerages in the last half-hour of trading. The computers figure out when to buy or to sell to profit from price differences between shares changing hands immediately and those promised for delivery in the future. With most investors on the sidelines, the analysts said, a lack of buy orders allowed the index to fall sharply. They said market sentiment was not necessarily as pessimistic as the plunge indicated. ``The market has been very quiet since the beginning of the year, and it was even quieter today,'' said Keiichi Nishida of Kidder Peabody Securities. ``Then came a large volume of index-linked program selling by foreign brokerage houses. It is no wonder the index droped so sharply. At least, I can say today's sharp decline was not a result of panic-selling.'' Volume traded on the first section of the exchange, where most major shares are listed, was estimated at 430 million shares, up slightly from Tuesday's 335 million shares. Analysts also attributed the market's weakness to widening speculation that the Bank of Japan would raise its official discount rate, the interest it charges for loans to commercial banks. Higher interest rates tend to dampen stock investment. ``There is general agreement in the market that the official discount rate is going to be raised, but because of upcoming overseas travels by Bank of Japan Gov. (Yasushi) Mieno, the timing of the increase is unclear,'' said Michio Katsumata of Nomura Securities Co. ``So participants are worrying about when it will be raised and by how much.'' Robert Alan Feldman of Salomon Brothers added: ``It appears the institutions have finally woken up to the fact that interest rates are up and will continue to be up.'' A Bank of Japan spokesman said there is no change in the central bank's stance that it will continue to study the impact of spiraling long- and short-term interest rates that have resulted from the December base rate increase. The discount rate now stands at 4.25 percent after three increases last year. Many market participants had speculated the Bank of Japan might raise it after Sunday's parliamentary election. In the currency market, the dollar closed at 145.15 yen, up 0.57 yen from Tuesday's close of 144.58 yen. After opening at 145.55 yen, it ranged between 145.10 yen and 145.60 yen. Currency dealers attributed the dollar's strength to prevailing expectations in the market that U.S. interest rates would remain at their current high level. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve Board, said in a U.S. congressional hearing Tuesday that the Fed would not relax monetary policy any time soon. A dealer at the Bank of Tokyo, speaking on condition of anonymity, added that Japan's weak bond market also contributed to weakening the yen.

DOC.HEAD: PT-109 Survivor Saved in War by JFK Dead At 84
DOC.TEXT: Patrick Henry McMahon, the wounded sailor whom John F. Kennedy towed to safety after a Japanese warship crushed their PT boat during World War II, has died of natural causes. He was 84. McMahon died Sunday at an Encinitas convalescent home in northern San Diego County, where he lived for the last 15 years. ``He thought the world of President Kennedy _ he called him skipper,'' said McMahon's stepson, William H. Kelly of Pascagoula, Miss. ``The president saved his life, and any time somebody does that for you, you're going to feel strongly about it.'' Nicknamed ``Pappy,'' he was the oldest member of the PT-109 crew because he enlisted in the Navy at age 37. Though exempt because of his age, McMahon was determined to serve when his stepson, then 19, enlisted in the Navy one day after the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor. ``He felt, `If my son is in there, I couldn't face him after the war if I was sitting around the house having a beer,'' said Kelly, 68, a submariner aboard the USS Greenling during World War II. The Wyanet, Ill., native was assigned to PT-109 as a Machinist's Mate 1st Class. He served under Kennedy, then a 26-year-old lieutenant junior grade and skipper of the patrol-torpedo craft. Over the years, McMahon often told the story of the night of Aug. 2, 1943, when the crew was patrolling Blackett Strait in the Solomon Islands. A Japanese destroyer burst out of the darkness and smashed through their boat, slicing it in two and instantly killing two of the 13 crewmen. McMahon suffered burns on his face, chest, arms and legs and couldn't swim because of the pain, Kelly said, so Kennedy put him across his back and kept him there by clenching McMahon's life-jacket strap in his teeth. Other crew members clung to a plank from the sunken boat until the exhausted survivors reached Plum Pudding Island four hours later. ``Dad was burnt so bad,'' Kelly said. ``He thought he was holding (Kennedy) up so he asked the president, `Just leave me. I'll be all right by myself.' But of course, he would not think of it.'' Finding little food and no drinking water on the island, the group left four days later for Olasana Island, requiring another swim of several hours. Kennedy again towed McMahon. A few days later, with the help of island natives, American forces rescued the PT-109 survivors. McMahon recovered from his burns and was discharged from the Navy in November 1945. After the war, McMahon went to work for the U.S. Post Office. He started as as a letter carrier, and eventually became postmaster in Cathedral City near Palm Springs. McMahon moved to Encinitas after his 1975 retirement. He and Kennedy stayed in touch after the war and through Kennedy's presidency, Kelly said. ``I remember a couple of times when he was president and came out to Palm Springs, the Secret Service would call dad, and they would sit in the limo and talk for a few minutes,'' he said. ``The president would always ask him if there was anything he could do for him and my dad always said, `Mr. President, you've done enough for me. You saved my life.''' McMahon also is survived by his wife of 62 years, Rose; a daughter-in-law, Merlene Kelly, and four grandsons.

DOC.HEAD: Britain, Defying Europe, Cracks South African Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with ANC denouncing British move. Picks up 3rd pvs, `Irish Foreign...'
DOC.TEXT: In the first major dent in international sanctions against South Africa, Britain has defied the rest of the European Community and will unilaterally lift a ban on new investment. Britain's move Tuesday, following its failure to persuade other members of the 12-nation community to follow suit, underlined its reputation as a reluctant member of the European Community. The African National Congress today accused Britain of breaking its word on economic sanctions and said the action was part of a pattern by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of favoring South Africa's white minority government. ``She has been quite prepared to be out of step with the rest of the world in her anxiety to accommodate the Pretoria regime,'' Pallo Jordan, the ANC's information chief, said at the guerrilla group's headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia. Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins accused Britain of setting a ``dangerous precedent'' and added: ``I would appeal to everyone here not to embark on such a course.'' In contrast to the fallout over South Africa, the community's foreign ministers displayed marked unanimity over the upheavals in Eastern Europe, declaring that the Western trade bloc sees itself as a ``mooring for a future European equilibrium.'' They urged that the officials of 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe begin meeting by no later than July to set up an East-West summit later this year. Assurances by Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany that a united Germany would not seek to dominate Europe and would respect existing frontiers appeared to soothe even the most wary, including Britain. ``It was the most open discussion we have had among the twelve on German unification,'' said British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. Genscher, however, left open the question of Polish demands for a treaty to enshrine Polish territory, one-third of which was part of Germany before World War II. He said the issue could be considered in six-power talks among the two Germanies and the World War II allied powers, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France, and in the Conference on Security and Cooperation. On South Africa, only Portugal supported Britain's in arguing that an easing of sanctions was warranted by the lifting of some restrictions by South African President F.W. de Klerk this month and the Feb. 11 release of black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela. ``It is not enough to sit back and say, `that's encouraging, let's see what you do next','' said Hurd. Collins said the community view was that the reforms ``while welcome ... do not yet go far enough ... Perhaps there is agreement that we could look at our policy again when the state of emergency is lifted and all political prisoners are released.'' The community agreed to send a fact-finding mission to South Africa comprised of representatives from France, Ireland and Italy. Hurd said the move would be interpreted as a ``signal of the Twelve delaying rather than encouraging.'' The new investment ban was one of a series of non-binding measures the community agreed to in 1986. Britain has long opposed sanctions and now argues that its policy of seeking to encourage South Africa's white-led government to move way from apartheid has helped push de Klerk into reform. Most other countries say he has moved because of the pressure of sanctions and resistance by the black majority, which is denied a vote in national affairs by apatheid. Mrs. Thatcher is already under attack for what critics say is compromising British influence internationally by being out of step on South Africa and being hesitant about German unification. Hurd indicated Tuesday that President Bush supports the British view that de Klerk deserves a response from the international community. Hurd said Bush wrote to Mrs. Thatcher on Tuesday and said he is prevented by Congress from lifting U.S. sanctions. ``He went on to say the steps we are taking are positive and added that he feels very strongly that when someone does what you are asking you should recognize that fact,'' said Hurd. Britain is the largest single foreign investor in South Africa, although several major British corporations and the London-based Barclays Bank pulled out because of pressure from anti-apartheid groups. South Africa's biggest foreign trading partners are four European Community nations _ Britian, West Germany, Italy and France _ and the United States and Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Pass the Angst, Dear
DOC.TEXT: Men worry less than women about what they eat and how it affects their physiques, a national poll suggests. Fewer than three in 10 men responding to a Gallup survey said they feel guilty about eating foods they like; more than four in 10 women reported such feelings. The poll, released Tuesday, also found men were less worried about chowing down and less conscious of dietary concerns. Fifty-seven percent of men said they were eating more fiber; among women, that rose to 70 percent. Fewer than four in 10 men sought more calcium; six in ten women did. Overall, 52 percent of the respondents said they were eating more oat bran, which has been touted recently as an aid in lowering blood cholesterol. Again, considerably fewer men than women said they had made the change. The survey found fats and oils scarcer at everybody's table: Nearly three-quarters said they were trimming fat from their diets and roughly two-thirds reported cutting out saturated fats, cholesterol and fried foods. But in spite of all this action against fat, only 56 percent of respondents admitted worrying about it. More than nine in 10 people of both sexes said they enjoy food, and nearly six in 10 said they enjoy it a lot. The Gallup Organization conducted the telephone survey of 772 American adults Dec. 11-28 for the American Dietetic Association, a dieticians' group, and the food industry-funded International Food Information Council. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Reassures Business Community, Opposition Urges Faster Progress
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela has attempted to calm fears among business leaders with an assurance the African National Congress would not impose drastic economic changes if it takes control, a newspaper said today. Mandela was quoted as saying the ANC would consult business before making any major changes in the economy. Business leaders have been frightened by recent Mandela statements backing the ANC's plan to nationalize the economy. ``This is an extremely important matter, and in any democratic situation a free expression of opinion is absolutely vital. I also expect compromise from both sides,'' Mandela was quoted as saying by Business Day. A lawmaker of the liberal Democratic Party said today that the ANC and the governing National Party were moving too slowly and must accelerate efforts to bring about black-white dialogue on ending apartheid. Tony Leon of the white opposition party said the ANC's decision not to hold a congress on formulating policy until December was a mistake. He told a meeting in Durban that the ANC and the government had to move more quickly. ``Whether or not the ANC or the government anticipates events achieving their own head of steam is almost irrelevant to the fact that the country, and its people, are hardly likely to stand still while the various parties get their act together,'' he said. President F.W. de Klerk released Mandela on Feb. 11 after legalizing the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups. De Klerk says he wants negotiations on ending white-minority rule and extending political power to blacks. The ANC's exiled leadership in Zambia responded Friday to de Klerk's initiative by announcing it would send delegates to meet with the president to try and clear the way for constitutional negotiations. The ANC wants release of all political prisoners and an end to the state of emergency before taking part in formal talks. De Klerk has said that political prisoners convicted of violent crimes cannot be released. On Tuesday, Britain defied the rest of the European Community and said it will unilaterally lift a ban on new investment to South Africa in recognition of de Klerk's latest moves. Mandela, in the Business Day interview, said the ANC did not want to take any major action on the economy without consulting business leaders. ``We are very keen not to do anything without proper discusssion with those interested and involved,'' he said. Mandela had expressed support for ANC plans for nationalization of mines and other key sectors of the economy. The statements, made after his release following 27 years in prison for taking up arms to fight white-minority rule, caused widespread fear in the white-dominated economy. Mandela, 71, also said other nations must continue sanctions against South Africa to force the end of apartheid. ``What we set out to achieve, we are far from achieving and there is nothing that has happened that has required us to review this decision.''

DOC.HEAD: New Bishop Says Cuomo Has `Problem' on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: The new bishop of the nation's fifth largest diocese said he would bar Gov. Mario Cuomo from speaking in parishes because of the governor's support for legalized abortion. Bishop Thomas V. Daily, who will be installed April 18 as the spiritual leader of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, said Tuesday that he rejects Cuomo's argument that a Catholic elected official can personally be opposed to abortion, but support laws or policies such as Medicaid funding of abortions for poor women. ``If anyone supports, either directly or indirectly, the practice of killing babies in the womb, that is terrible,'' Daily said. ``As a Catholic, he's got a problem,'' Daily said of the governor, a New York City resident who has been a member of the Brooklyn diocese all his life. A spokesman for the governor, Gary Fryer, said Cuomo would not respond directly to Daily's comments until meeting him, but he offered his congratulations. Daily, 62, who spent the last 5{ years as the head of the Diocese of Palm Beach, Fla., succeeds Francis J. Mugavero, who has reached the church's mandatory retirement age of 75. There are more than 1.5 million Catholics in the Brooklyn diocese, fifth largest of 185 Catholic dioceses and archdioceses in the United States. Pope Paul VI named Mugavero to head the diocese in 1968. Daily also said there was ``no way'' he would allow Dignity, a group of dissident Catholic homosexuals, to use diocesan churches, as they had for a time under Bishop Mugavero. The bishop said he supports Courage, a group of Catholic homosexuals who advocate chastity. ``Chaste,'' the new bishop said. ``That's a word we've got to bring back into the vocabulary.''

DOC.HEAD: Milder in Midwest, Northeast; More Rain in Southeast
DOC.TEXT: More rain fell in the soggy Southeast while clear, milder weather in the Midwest and Northeast today preceded weekend predictions of arctic chill. A cold front today brought flurries to the Northern Plains. Snow continued in southern Colorado and northern Arizona. The Cascade Mountains looked for accumulations of up to 10 inches by today. High winds lingered in the Front Range of the Rockies and in Montana's upper Yellowstone Valley. Winds gusted to near 65 mph at Cut Bank on Tuesday. The storm system that dumped snow in the West moved eastward today, changing from mostly snow to rain along a warm front from central Texas to southern Arkansas to Florida's Atlantic coast. In the Northeast and Midwest this weekend, an arctic wind is expected to whip through both regions. Rain in the Tennessee and lower Mississippi valleys so far this month is two to three times above normal _ and more precipitation was forecast by tonight. The National Weather Service office in Mobile, Ala., predicted 5 to 8 inches of rainfall by Thursday. Meteorologist Jim Hyder said the Tombigbee, Alabama and Mobile rivers are due for crests well above flood stage this week and next. Snowfall diminished across western Kansas, although driving conditions remained hazardous today. Tuesday's snowfall included 11 inches at Liberal, 10 at Tribune and in Lamar County; and 9 at Elkhart and Garden City. By late Tuesday, a foot of snow blanketed Guymon, Okla.; Boise City, Okla.; and Clayton, N.M. Ten inches fell on Las Vegas, N.M., and Spearman, Texas. International Falls, Minn., warmed to 48 degrees on Tuesday, breaking the previous high by 5 degrees. Four Florida communities tied Tuesday for hottest spot in the nation with readings of 86 degrees: Fort Myers, Lakeland, North Dade County and West Palm Beach. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th pvs, `1.6595 French...' to CORRECT figures for francs; picks up 11th pvs, `1.8783 Dutch...'
DOC.TEXT: Foreign currency dealers today said they were surprised when the dollar fell in early European trading, after Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's suggestion that the Fed won't lower interest rates further. Gold prices rose. The West German mark strengthened against the dollar and the yen after weak stock markets in New York and Tokyo undermined confidence in those currencies, dealers said. ``It is mostly a technical movement. Fundamentally there is no special reason to be short on dollars at the moment,'' said Jens-Uwe Fischer, senior trader at Manufacturers Hanover Trust in Frankfurt. Paul Brewer, a senior dealer at Salomon Brothers International in London, said: ``The trend still seems to be one of weakness despite Greenspan's comments, which should have lent some support to the dollar.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.57 yen to a closing 145.15 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 145.25 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6653 West German marks, down from 1.6748 _1.4744 Swiss francs, down from 1.4865 _5.6595 French francs, down from 5.6875 _1.8783 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8845 _1,235.50 Italian lire, down from 1,243 _1.1995 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2014 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.7143, compared with $1.7040 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $421.40 a troy ounce, up from $419.75 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $420.60. In Zurich, the bid price was $421, up from $419.75 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.18 to close at a bid $419.68. Silver was unchanged in London at a bid price of $5.35 an ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Dies of Leukemia Despite Nationwide Search for Bone Marrow
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Removes Post attribution in 1st and 3rd grafs; inserts 1 graf after 2nd; picks up 3rd graf pvs, Ms. Johnson's.
DOC.TEXT: A suburban Maryland teen-ager who was the object of a nationwide search for a bone marrow donor has died of leukemia. JoAnne Johnson, 19, died Monday evening at her home in Silver Spring, he family announced Tuesday. She had been undergoing treatment at Georgetown University Hospital, but doctors had told the family they had done all they could. Ms. Johnson was visited by the Rev. Jesse Jackson and singer Dionne Warwick during her hospitalization. Ms. Johnson's parents, Howard and Sylvia Johnson, said they made the decision last Friday to bring her home to die. The young woman's only chance for survival lay in a bone marrow transplant, and no donor could be found in her immediate family. Her parents over the last six weeks had organized a grassroots campaign in an effort to find a matching bone marrow for their daughter. They knew finding a donor of Ms. Johnson's ethnic background was their best hope, but black Americans made up only a small fraction of people listed in national bone marrow registries. The Johnsons set up mass screening drives with the help of dozens of volunteers who worked out of their kitchen, and were able to triple the number of blacks registered. A near-perfect match was found for Ms. Johnson last week, but by then she was too weak to endure the procedure, said her aunt, Henrice Taylor.

DOC.HEAD: Beaches Reopened After Fouling by Crude Oil, Sewage and Filthy City Runoff
DOC.TEXT: Miles of scenic Southern California beaches fouled by 400,000 gallons of crude oil, 7.6 million gallons of sewage and untold amounts of filthy urban street runoff have been reopened. A new stretch of Orange County shoreline tarred by an oil slick was reopened to public use Tuesday, as were most of 18 miles of beach fronting Santa Monica Bay closed after the storm-related sewage spill. ``If I was a fish, I'd swim south for the rest of this winter,'' said Tim Little of Heal the Bay, an environmental group. A team of government surveyors, meanwhile, charted the mooring area about 2 miles off Huntington Beach where the tanker American Trader tanker spilled 400,000 gallons of oil Feb. 7. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the federal agency that draws underwater maps, was using sonar to examine the approach to the area and the submerged pipeline that had been near the ship. A 1{-mile stretch of oiled beach were reopened Tuesday. It was part of more than a dozen miles of golden sand closed by the spill. On Monday, 2 miles of affected beach were reopened. Off Santa Monica Bay to the north, nearly all of the 18 miles of beaches closed by a 7.6-million gallon spill of partially treated sewage over the weekend were reopened after tests found bacteria levels within acceptable levels. The treated sewage was released from the Hyperion plant into Ballona Creek because heavy rains could have caused backups and sent sewage flowing onto city streets. The creek empties into Santa Monica Bay. The weekend storm, which dumped 2.51 inches of rain on the Los Angeles Civic Center, also washed pollutants from streets, driveways and sidewalks into the ocean.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard: Four Die In Escape
DOC.TEXT: Four Cubans seeking to escape their homeland on rafts died in attempted crossings, while five other refugees survived the dangerous trip across the Florida Straits, the Coast Guard said. Two men died at sea and their bodies were thrown overboard by their companions, a third disappeared overnight and the fourth was dead by the time he reached a Florida Keys hospital. The Cubans, the latest of dozens this year who have tried the journey of more than 100 miles, were in two groups sighted on rafts Tuesday, officials said. The survivors brought to 66 the number of Cubans who have successfully made the voyage since Jan. 1. The deaths were the first known fatalities this year. Last year, 391 Cubans made it safely across the Florida Straits. ``It's a hazardous trip, very dangerous,'' Coast Guard spokesman Luis Diaz said. ``At this time of year, the waters are much colder, and exposure has to be a factor.'' In the homemade rafts usually used, the journey can take several days. Two Cubans were taken off a 6-foot-by-3-foot raft, made of styrofoam pitched with tar, about 11 miles east of this Florida Key, Diaz said. One, a teen-age boy, was dead on arrival at Mariners Hospital while the other man was in serious condition, Diaz said. He reported that a third passenger was lost at sea overnight. A second group of four Cubans was picked up 28 miles east of here, hanging onto an inner tube, Diaz said. They told the Coast Guard that two companions died on the voyage and their bodies were thrown overboard. Newly arriving Cubans say the island's economy and repression are worsening and that many more Cubans would leave if they could do so safely. Some 125,000 Cubans came to the United States in 1980 when the Cuban government temporarily opened the Port of Mariel to boats coming from Florida. On Monday, the motor vessel Pacific Prosperity rescued seven Cuban men from a sinking innertube raft 25 miles south of Key West, the Coast Guard said. Those Cubans, who ranged in age from 18 years to 27, all arrived in good health, the Coast Guard said.

DOC.HEAD: Steep Fall in Tokyo Putting Pressure on London Market
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with later market trading
DOC.TEXT: London shares fell sharply in nervous but light trading today, pressured by a sharp fall earlier in Tokyo. The already faltering London market couldn't buck the Tokyo decline, which came on fears of a rise in interest rates, and worries about the bond markets, market watchers said. Volume was ``pretty feeble,'' said Jeffrey Thompson, chief equity strategist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. ``We just haven't got the volume to resist'' nervous selling on the back of Tokyo's losses, said Chris Stallard, a director of Panmure Gordon Ltd. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was 16.1 points, or 0.7 percent, lower at 2,260.9 at 10 a.m. It opened 25.2 points lower an hour earlier. The Nikkei index tumbled 1,161.19 to 35,734.33 in Tokyo earlier today. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 38.74 points to 2,596.84 on Tuesday. ``The equities are following the bond markets downward,'' Thompson said. He cited worries about inflation, uncertainty about German unification, and concerns about corporate profitability. As bond prices fall, their yields, or their rates of interest, rise. In addition, with Sunday's Japanese general election now out of the way, many analysts are convinced it is only a matter of time before the country's central bank raises its discount rate. Recent rises in West Germany's money market rates also have increased investors' fears that West Germany's central bank might raise its key interest rates soon. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony before Congress on Tuesday also suggested that the Fed wasn't likely to lower interest rates. London's 100-share index will continue downward, through a key 2,250 support level, analysts predicted. ``My judgment would be that it (2,250) is not going to be strong enough this time,'' said Randall Goldsmith, an equities analyst with James Capel and Co. Goldsmith said he expected the Financial Times index to eventually find support somewhere above 2,200. The early trend followed sharp losses in New York on Tuesday, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 38.74 to 2,596.84, and even steeper losses in Tokyo overnight, where the Nikkei index tumbled 1,161.19 _ or 3.5 percent _ to 35,734.33.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Accuses Vietnam of Human Rights Violations
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said today that Communist Vietnam is still convicting people in unfair trials, cutting food rations for some prisoners and putting some in solitary confinement or shackles. The London-based human rights group said Vietnam has undertaken major human rights reforms since pragmatists took over the Communist Party leadership in December 1986 but many of the measures have not yet been implemented. New legislation provides for development of an independent judiciary and contains such principles as the presumption of innocence, the right not to be detained without a court order, the right to legal defense and to choose an independent lawyer, said the report, released today. ``However, many of the reforms intended to protect specific human rights have not been implemented and human rights violations continue,'' it said. Many Western governments and human rights groups have accused Hanoi of widespread human rights violations since North Vietnamese forces defeated the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government in April 1975. The government told an Amnesty delegation that visited Vietnam last May that it was committed to ``renovation'' in all fields and stressed the importance of the rule of law, the report said. A copy of the report, ``Vietnam: Renovation (Doi Moi), the Law and Human Rights in the 1980s,'' was received in Bangkok. Doi Moi is the Vietnamese term for renovation. The 66-page study said reports of abuses of detainees ``suggest that these practices are still common and that measures to combat them are not yet adequate.'' ``Abusive treatment in re-education camps includes the use of solitary confinment in combination with beatings, the use of shackles or leg irons and the reduction of food rations,'' it said. The report welcomed the release of thousands of people under government amnesties in 1987 and 1988, including more than 1,500 political prisoners detained without charge or trial in ``re-education'' camps since the end of the war. It said Hanoi has told Amnesty it soon will free the remaining 130 former South Vietnam government and military personnel arrested just after the war. But it added that Hanoi has not said anything about the many political prisoners detained more recently who had no connection with the former government. ``Among prisoners of conscience convicted in unfair trials have been Buddhist monks, Jesuit priests, Protestant pastors, writers and others believed to have been convicted solely because they were critical of government policies,'' it said. The report said the 1989 Criminal Code Procedure contains no provision for detention without trial and appears to make such detention for re-education illegal. But the norms of the procedure have not been comprehensively implemented, it said. Amnesty also expressed concern over the broad definition of ``crimes against national security'' in the code, and said this has been used to convict prisoners of conscience in unfair trials. The report said prisoners of conscience include poet and writer Nguyen Chi Thien, who has spent more than half his life in detention. He is believed still under detention since he was arrested for the third time in 1979, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi Says East Germany Wants Jewish Investment To Slow Unity
DOC.TEXT: An ultra-Orthodox Jewish rabbi says East German Communist officials have appealed for Jewish investment in their crippled economy to help slow unification with financially powerful West Germany. The Communist leaders also expressed disappointment that Israel has not taken a strong stand against the prospect of German unity, said Rabbi Zvi Weinman, who visited East Berlin this month to find out how the state's 5,000 Jews are faring. During the private trip, Weinman met with several officials, including Gregor Gysi, chairman of the former Communist Party, now called the Party of Democratic Socialism, and Deputy Premier Lothar de Maiziere. Israel and East Germany do not have diplomatic ties. Weinman on Tuesday quoted Gysi as saying only massive foreign investment could slow down German reunification. ``Gysi appealed to Jews around the world to invest in East Germany. He said he would give investors good conditions,'' Weinman said in a telephone interview from his Jerusalem home. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government has rejected East Germany's request for immediate aid of $9 billion, saying aid would only be forthcoming when a new East German government takes over after March 18 elections. During his Feb. 8 meeting with Weinman, Gysi also said ``he was disappointed that Israel has not come out against unification,'' according to the rabbi. Since the Gysi-Weinman meeting, Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens has cautiously embraced unification, saying there was no reason for Jews to be concerned if a united Germany was democratic and recognized its historic obligations to the Jews. Arens' statement caused a furor in Israel, with some government ministers demanding that he be rebuked. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has expressed concern about unification privately, but has not taken a public stand opposing it. Israel's leaders cannot afford to disrupt flourishing ties with West Germany but don't want to alienate the many Israelis whose relatives were among the 6 million Jews killed in the Holocaust. Weinman also quoted Gysi as saying East Germany would form a special police unit to monitor the activities of emerging neo-Nazi and fascist groups. Until the ouster of hard-liner Communist leader Erich Honecker last year, East Germany's secret police, known as the Stasi, had monitored right-wing groups. But the hated Stasi was dissolved after the old government was toppled.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodia Gov't Attack Reported As Peace Talks Start
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf, `In Bangkok ...' to UPDATE with joint communique; Picks up 12th graf, `The Thai-sponsored ...'
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of warring Cambodian factions began peace talks today and guerrilla radio said government forces launched a fierce counteroffensive against guerrillas in northwestern Cambodia. There was no immediate confirmation of the reported attack by Cambodian officials in Phnom Penh or in Bangkok. Government forces attacked this morning to try to retake a base in the strategic northwestern district of Sisophon from the guerrillas of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, the guerrilla radio said. ``Fierce fighting is going on'' for control of the base at Kakaoh village, it said. Government forces captured another Liberation Front base in the region Tuesday morning but the guerrillas retook it in the afternoon, the broadcast said. Resistance officials and Thai military officers reported that government forces also had struck Monday night near Svay Chek, a gateway to Sisophon. The Liberation Front guerrillas seized the town in Battambang province Dec. 5 as part of the stepped up guerrilla offensive. About 250 government soldiers backed by four T-54 tanks attacked positions about six miles from Svay Chek for five hours, said Ok Serei Sopheak, a senior official of the Liberation Front. He said the guerrillas lost no ground. Eleven government soldiers were killed and 24 captured while only six guerrillas were wounded, he claimed. A Thai military officer said the fighting could be termed the start of a small counteroffensive. In Bangkok, Hun Sen, the premier of Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government, held talks over a lunch with guerrilla leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk. They then went into a second round at a Thai government building. A joint communique reaffirmed their agreement that a United Nations presence ``at appropriate levels in Cambodia is essential and should be encouraged.'' It also said they wanted a ``supreme national body'' that would symbolize national unity, but they gave no details. The communique said the two leaders thoroughly discussed issues blocking a settlement, and ``felt there is now a better understanding of the issues involved that may lead in the not-too-distant future to a convergence of views on how to settle the Cambodian problem.'' The Thai-sponsored talks pave the way for wider negotiations next week in Jakarta, Indonesia, said Suvit Yodmani, a Thai government spokesman. The Cambodians have been quarreling over the composition of an interim government that will manage the country before a proposed general election. The Thai newspaper The Nation today quoted Cambodian Defense Minister Gen. Tea Banh as saying the guerrillas have been receiving more and increasingly sophisticated military aid since Vietnam purportedly withdrew all its troops in September, ending more than a decade of occupation. These arms, he said, were coming from China and the United States and transported into the country by the Thai military. Hun Sen was to travel later to Indonesia for talks starting Monday with guerrilla leaders and also involving Vietnam, France, Indonesia and other nations. Son Sann, who heads guerrillas of the Liberation Front, said Tuesday he would try to revive at Jakarta a guerrilla peace plan Hun Sen already has rejected. That plan calls for a transitional government comprising the Phnom Penh authorities, the Liberation Front, Sihanouk's group and the third guerrilla force, the Khmer Rouge. Hun Sen will not have anything to do with the Khmer Rouge, which killed hundreds of thousands of people during its 1975-1978 rule. The Jakarta talks are expected to focus on an Australian proposal for setting up a U.N. interim administration before an election. Sihanouk will not attend the Jakarta talks and instead plans to go northwestern Cambodia Friday to end a decade of lavish living in exile and reside in a bamboo hut in ``liberated'' areas of his homeland, his spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter, Reagan Seek to Delay Release of Videotaped Testimony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS word to ``asking'' sted ``asked'' in 4th graf, But Reagan's
DOC.TEXT: John Poindexter says former President Reagan's testimony is favorable to his case, but the former national security adviser wants to delay its release until after a jury is sworn in for his Iran-Contra trial. Twelve news organizations on Tuesday suggested in a court filing that the videotape and transcripts of Reagan's testimony Friday and Saturday in Los Angeles be made available as soon as possible. Iran-Contra prosecutors told U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene, who is presiding in the case involving Poindexter, that they have ``no objections'' to releasing the videotapes and transcripts of Reagan's deposition now. But Reagan's lawyers filed court papers asking that the tapes be withheld until the end of the trial. Poindexter's lawyers maintained in court papers that Reagan's testimony ``is favorable to the defense.'' But the former president did not support Poindexter in connection with key portions of allegedly false letters which Poindexter sent to Congress in 1986, according to sources familiar with Reagan's testimony who spoke on condition of anonymity. Poindexter's letters embraced the White House's denials the previous year that National Security Council aide Oliver North was raising money or providing military advice to the Contras. In his initial answers about the letters, Reagan focused on portions which stated the NSC staff was complying with the spirit and the letter of the Boland Amendment barring U.S. intelligence agencies from providing military aid to the Contras. Reagan, in his deposition in Los Angeles, supported those sections of the letters. The ex-president has said publicly he did not regard the NSC as being subject to the restrictions of the Boland Amendment. However, under cross-examination by Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb, Reagan's attention was drawn to other statements in Poindexter's letters referring to the earlier information provided to Congress. That information included the denials that North was fundraising or supplying military advice. Reagan agreed with Webb he didn't recall seeing those earlier responses at the time Poindexter's letters were sent to Congress, according to the sources. The earlier responses led to a guilty plea by ex-national security adviser Robert McFarlane to misdemeanor charges of withholding information from Congress. Poindexter's lawyers maintained in court papers that publicizing Reagan's testimony now would have an ``incalculable impact'' on prospective jurors. Disclosing Reagan's testimony prior to the March 5 trial date could result in Iran-Contra prosecutors rejecting prospective jurors who otherwise would be favorable to the defense, lawyers for Reagan's former national security adviser said. They also said the testimony should be made public only ``after the jury in this case has been sworn and instructed regarding trial publicity.'' Alternatively, Poindexter asked that the media before the trial be provided only with a transcript of Reagan's testimony and that access to the videotape be deferred until the jury is sworn in. In their own filing, Reagan's lawyers asked that copies of the tape not be disseminated until the end of the trial, and that public access to Reagan's testimony ``be limited to reviewing the videotape at a location under control of the court.'' Any earlier distribution of copies of the tape ``goes far beyond the requirements of the First Amendment and may damage irreparably the rights of the defendant and the former president,'' the former president's lawyers argued. The news organizations told Greene that Cable News Network Inc. would act as pool representative for distribution of copies of the videotape to the news media. In addition, the news organizations suggested, transcripts should be released at the same time as the videotape through a commercial copying center selected by the news media.

DOC.HEAD: Minister: Shamir's Peace Obstacles Lead to Anti-Israeli Terror
DOC.TEXT: An Egyptian Cabinet minister said in an interview published today that Israel's prime minister is blocking Middle East peace efforts and creating a climate that leads to terror attacks. Butros Ghali, state minister for foreign affairs, charged that Yitzhak Shamir of Israel is the sole impediment to current efforts to organize a peace dialogue in Cairo between Israelis and Palestinians. Egypt initially proposed the dialogue last summer to discuss a plan Shamir introduced in May for elections among Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Secretary of State James A. Baker III became the prime sponsor of the dialogue concept by making it the centerpiece of a five-point proposal presented in October. No talks have taken place. ``The only obstacle so far has been Israel's reluctance to keep up with the peace tide and the insistence of the Israeli prime minister to plant obstacles after obstacles to prevent the start of real movement toward peace,'' Ghali said in an interview with the state-owned weekly Al-Mussawar. ``Israel's persistent refusal to talk with the PLO despite the fact that it is the principal party qualified for the dialogue under a full mandate from the Palestinian people ... shows a position that is not serious about peace,'' he said. Israel considers the PLO a terrorist group, and Shamir has sought assurances from Washington that it will be excluded from all peace moves.
