Ghali blamed the absence of peace for terrorist acts such as a Feb. 4 attack on an Egyptian tour bus in which nine Israelis died. He said the ambush was ``as much an aggression against Egypt as an aggression against foreign nationals on our soil. ``But if we look for the roots of such incidents, be they in Egypt or Israel itself or London or Paris, we undoubtedly will find that the absence of peace remains a condition that spawns such incidents.'' The bus attack on a desert road between Cairo and the Suez Canal was ``the product of anxiety, tension, lack of confidence and despair that affect many parties because of continuing obstacles on the road to peace and continuing intransigence,'' he said. Egyptian investigators say Palestinian gunmen carried out the raid, during which Egyptians were ordered off the bus before two masked men opened fire with automatic weapons and tossed grenades. Ghali also criticized the United States for tightened U.S. immigration rules that he said are resulting in thousands of Soviet Jews going to Israel. Arabs fear that many of the immigrants will settle in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, although Israeli government officials deny there is a policy of settling them in the occupied lands. About 12,000 Soviet Jews went to Israel in 1989, but under liberalized Soviet emigration policies, 80,000 to 100,000 are expected this year. More than 8,000 already have arrived. Ghali said Egypt ``cannot possibly interfere'' with the Soviet Union's liberalization of travel for its citizens. ``All that interests us is that they not be settled in the occupied Palestinian lands,'' he said. ``The United States bears a fundamental responsibility, because its decision to limit the immigration of Soviet Jews opens the way for pressure on Moscow to route emigration in Israel's direction,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Valdez Skipper Says Captains Were Advised To Stay on Bridge
DOC.TEXT: The skipper who commanded the Exxon Valdez before Joseph Hazelwood testified that Exxon advised its captains to remain on the bridges of their ships during any hazardous passage. Michael Stalzer, who sailed the Exxon Valdez in 1987, read Tuesday to jurors from a company manual that offered advice to captains on the officer configurations necessary for operating the high-tech tanker. ``What are the tanker captain's general responsiblities?'' asked Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole. ``He's responsible for the safety of the ship, the crew and the cargo,'' said Stalzer. He then read the section dealing with hazards including weather or a voyage past rocks and shoals. ``Could ice be a hazard that presents a threat to a tanker the size of the Exxon Valdez?'' Cole asked. ``If it's sufficient in quantity, yes,'' Stalzer said. Hazelwood has come under attack by the prosecution for leaving the bridge of his ship in control of the third mate 10 minutes before it grounded, spilling 10.92 million gallons of oil into Prince William Sound. The March 24 disaster killed countless birds, fish and wildlife and blackened hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline. The 43-year-old former skipper is charged with second-degree criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanors, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, his maximum penalties could be 7\ years in prison plus $61,000 in fines. The ship's third mate, Gregory Cousins, has blamed the ship's helmsman for failing to follow steering commands that would have kept the ship off jagged Bligh Reef. But Stalzer's testimony suggested that Hazelwood should have been present on the bridge to direct the ship around chunks of ice in the shipping lanes outside the Valdez Narrows. Cole has said he probably will rest the prosecution case against Hazelwood by week's end. Another Exxon employee, William Deppe, at first appeared to support Hazelwood's decision to let the third mate navigate through the sound. ``One of the responsibilties a master has is to delegate a lot of responsibility to other people,'' he said, adding, he would entrust the command to another ``if I had an officer I had confidence in to carry out commands.'' But Deppe later said, ``I probably would have been on the bridge and not left it to the third mate.'' Deppe, who holds a captain's license and is assigned to a shore job with Exxon, took over the Valdez after Hazelwood left the ship to talk with investigators. In other testimony Tuesday, two marine engineers said three backup systems built into the high-tech tanker to prevent accidents were functioning perfectly when the tanker ran aground. One of the engineers, Stanley Andresen of Sperry Marine Inc., said the system, which includes an optional autopilot, is designed to be as simple as possible for helmsmen to operate. Jurors also were shown a videotape of the crippled Exxon Valdez stranded on Bligh Reef. Dan Lawn, who shot the footage, explained the scene and pointed out the thick coating of black oil bubbling up around the ship.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer Suspected in Bomb Killing of Undercover Detective
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to tighten lead and clarify time sequences. Pickup 4th graf, `Wustenhoff was...' SUBS penultimate graf, `Horan's name...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with suspect having received explosives training, house searched, other detail.
DOC.TEXT: The bomb slaying of an undercover narcotics detective may be the result of a love triangle, not a revenge bombing by drug dealers as was first suspected, according to a police source. A Nassau police spokesman confirmed today that Nassau County Police Officer Robert Horan is a suspect, although no arrest has been made in the slaying. A second source, also involved in the investigation and who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday that the victim, Suffolk County Police Officer Dennis Wustenhoff, 41, allegedly was involved with Horan's wife, a federal Drug Enforcement Administration employee. Wustenhoff was killed Thursday when a bomb exploded seconds after he got into an undercover police car parked in front of his home in Patchogue on New York's Long Island. Police at first thought drug dealers may have planted the bomb to frustrate a current investigation or avenge one of Wustenhoff's previous cases. The disclosure of the possible love triangle motive surfaced Tuesday, a day after Wustenhoff was given a hero's farewell in a funeral attended by more than 5,000 officers from 50 police departments across the nation. Spokesmen for the Suffolk County police and Suffolk County District Attorney James Catterson refused to comment. ``We are not going to give a progress report at this time,'' said William McKean, a Suffolk County police spokesman. Horan's name was confirmed by Nassau police spokesman William Bendel. Horan, a 20-year veteran, was assigned to Emergency Services Bureau for Nassau County, where officers receive bomb detonation and explosives training. Police interviewed Horan on Tuesday in Cooperstown, N.Y., where the officer recently bought a vacation home, the police source said. Suffolk police obtained a search warrant and used two bomb-sniffing dogs to search Horan's Long Island home Tuesday, said Kevin Cronin, a homicide detective who supervised the search. Wustenhoff's wife, a 14-year-old son and 10- and 12-year-old daughters have been in hiding since the bombing because of speculation it had been revenge.

DOC.HEAD: City to Cite Low-Flying Choppers to Curtail Medfly Spraying
DOC.TEXT: Helicopters spraying a controversial Medfly pesticide face prosecution under a new city ordinance banning low flying helicopter formations at night. ``Realistically speaking, we can't stop them,'' said Lt. Terry Blumenthal, who oversees city police helicopter operations. ``We can only cite them afterward. ``It's going to be a tough situation at best.'' If convicted, pilots could face a $1,000 fine and a year in jail, he said. The state is spraying 400 square miles of Los Angeles and Orange counties with the pesticide malathion to wipe out the worst infestation of Mediterranean fruit flies since 1981-82. Agriculture officials maintain the spraying is a safe and necessary step to prevent the Medfly from harming the state's multibillion-dollar farm economy. Pasadena's governing board early today approved the citywide ban on nighttime helicopters formations below 700 feet. Emergency helicopters will not be affected. Rick Cole, a member of the city's Board of Directors, said the law was necessary to get the attention of agriculture officials who have scheduled spraying tonight over a 53-square-mile area despite objections from some of the municipalities encompassed. ``We need to do what we can to flex our muscle,'' Cole said. Earlier Tuesday, the Los Angeles City Council agreed to pursue lawsuits and administrative appeals aimed at halting spraying and to study malathion's potential health risks. ``This is going to be a tough case. But it's a case we have to fight,'' said Los Angeles Councilman Joel Wachs. ``The public has a right and a demand to know if the government is leveling with them.'' The city of Burbank adopted a similar measure Tuesday. Los Angeles Councilman Michael Woo called the spraying a ``blatant example of the urban population of this state being held hostage to the agricultural industry.'' Clark Biggs, spokesman for the California Farm Bureau, said farmers sympathize with Southern Californians for having to live with the spraying, but contended that wiping out the Medfly is in everyone's best interest. The Mediterranean fruit fly lays its eggs in more than 250 varieties of fruits, vegetables and nuts grown in California. The crops are destroyed when the larvae hatch and growing maggots eat their way out.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Visits High-Tech Navy Ship in Japanese Port
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 7th graf, Another Aegis, with Vincennes incident
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was treated to a demonstration of some of the U.S. Navy's most sophisticated weaponry today as he witnessed a simulated sea and air battle aboard an Aegis cruiser based in this port city. Cheney, in Japan on the last stop of his two-week tour of Asian nations hosting U.S. forces, watched four huge blue computerized screens aboard the USS Bunker Hill simulate an attack on the American aircraft carrier Midway in the Sea of Japan. ``Got a mad, mad, mad at zero-15 miles,'' yelled one sailor as Cheney observed the crew in the ship's Combat Information Center fend off a series of submarine and air missile attacks. Cheney watched the pretend battle in the darkened command center as the screens in front of him danced with spots and lines reflecting the positions of various Soviet attack bombers and submarines, as well as the U.S. ships. Capt. Rodney Rempt told Cheney the ship was designed to simultaneously track a number of enemy ships, planes and incoming missiles within a 280-mile radius with its state-of-the-art computerized radar and weapons systems. ``We fire long before seeing the whites of their eyes,'' asserted the ship's motto, inscribed on one of the computer screens. Another Aegis cruiser, the USS Vincennes, shot down an Iran Air jumbo jet over the Persian Gulf in July 1988, with the loss of 290 lives, after the ship's crew mistook the airliner for an F-14 fighter plane. ``We are capable of providing defense in all sorts of different realms for the Midway battle group,'' the captain told Cheney. The sophisticated cruiser is one of 10 ships home-ported in Yokosuka, where some 7,500 military personnel are based fulltime about 35 miles south of Tokyo. The port is the home of the Navy's 7th Fleet, which cruises the waters from Hawaii to the Indian Ocean. The secretary also was escorted by the commander of the 7th Fleet, Admiral Henry H. Mauze. Cheney left the command center to chat with the 350 sailors and officers aboard the cruiser, some of whom asked him about congressional moves to slash the defense budget and expressed concern over possible pay cuts and promotion difficulties. ``If the Cold War is over and they cut ships and carriers, won't our deployments be extended?'' asked one of the sailors. Cheney responded that his primary priority was to preserve pay and quality of life for the armed forces even if defense budgets are reduced. ``We'd rather shrink the size of the force to preserve the quality than get in the business of cutting pay and benefits,'' Cheney said. ``We want to manage it so we don't do violence to the all-volunteer force that we have today.'' Cheney dines tonight with Japanese Defense Minister Juro Matsumoto. He meets Thursday with high-ranking Japanese officials, when he is expected to discuss Pentagon proposals for a 10 percent to 12 percent cutback in U.S. troop strength in the Pacific Rim. Cheney is also seeking a sizable increase in Japan's $2.4 billion annual contribution to the $7 billion cost of basing America's 50,000 soldiers, sailors and marines in Japan and Okinawa.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: United Germany Must Respect European Borders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to recast lead, UPDATE with Kohl's promise, corrects spelling of Philippines, restores first reference to Kohl; Picks up 12th graf, `In Paris ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said the Soviet Union ``has an inalienable right'' to guard against political or economic damage from a reunified Germany and said Europe's postwar borders must be guaranteed. In an interview published today in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda, Gorbachev said he believes it is up to the Germans to decide the nature and timing of unification. But he said a united Germany must respect Europe's current borders and that only the four victorious Allies of World War II can determine Germany's final status. Emergence of a reunited Germany as a powerful economic and military force in central Europe has aroused concern, particularly among the Russians and Poles, who lost millions of people to Nazi aggression and acquired territory after World War II that had belonged to Germany. Kremlin spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said today that the Soviet Union supports Poland's desire to join talks with the Allies and the two Germanys on unification. ``We must discuss this with other participants, but we understand that Poland has the right because Poland suffered most during the war,'' he told a news conference in the Philippines. Progress toward reunification has accelerated in recent weeks. Premier Hans Modrow of East Germany, plagued by mass emigration and a crumbling economy, asked on Tuesday for immediate reunification talks under the formula worked out with the Allies last week in Ottawa. But Gorbachev cautioned: ``No one has a right to ignore the negative potential formed in Germany's past, especially as it is impossible to fail to consider people's memory of war, of its horrors and losses. Therefore, it is very important that Germans, deciding the question of unification, should be aware of their responsibility. ``This applies particularly to our country, to the Soviet people. It has an inalienable right to expect, and the possibility to exert efforts to ensure, that our country should not sustain either moral or political or economic damage from German unification.'' Gorbachev said Germans should decide the form and schedule of unification, but emphasized that Germany unity also concerns others and ``any encroachment upon the borders of other states must be ruled out.'' Gorbachev specifically mentioned Poland's western border. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's failure to make a public pledge to respect that border prompted Poland to request the role in talks on unification between the two Germanys and the Allies. Kohl, speaking Tuesday in East Germany, promised that ``peace will emanate'' from a reunified Germany. In Paris, Adam Michnik, editor of Poland's most influential newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza, said Tuesday that Kohl must ``openly declare'' that he recognizes the existing border if he wants ``credibility with his neighbors.'' Bronislaw Geremek, leader of the Solidarity bloc in Poland's parliament, said: ``The only way to change the border is war.'' The two were attending a conference on the future of Eastern Europe. Both Germanys are bound by treaties to respect the frontier, but a united country would not be, and some conservatives in West Germany have suggested reunification be sought within the 1937 borders. In 1937, one-third of what is now Poland was German territory. Gorbachev spoke in the interview of the rights of nations to protect their interests, and said: ``I refer primarily to Poland. The inviolability of its postwar borders, like the borders of other states, must be guaranteed. Only an international legal act can provide such a guarantee.'' Speaking about a united Germany's relationship with NATO and the Warsaw Pact, he said the alliances will have a role as a new European security system evolves, and any disruption of the military-strategic balance is unacceptable. East Germany is Moscow's most important military ally and about two-thirds of the 575,000 Soviet troops in Eastern Europe are stationed there. However, Moscow has agreed to a proposal set forth by President Bush to cut its troops in Eastern Europe to 195,000 and there is considerable disagreement among NATO and Warsaw Pact members over whether a united Germany will be neutral, belong to the NATO alliance or be split into two security zones.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Say Con Artist Painted Himself Into a Corner
DOC.TEXT: It was a con worthy of Tom Sawyer _ persuading 30 people to pay up to $500 each for an unauthorized job painting stripes on elevated-train pillars. But it was no fresh-faced boy who allegedly pulled this con, said police, who arrested 63-year-old Vincent Pannone of Brooklyn on fraud and larceny charges Tuesday. He was later released. Pannone took $250 to $500 from at least 30 job seekers, telling them it was a refundable fee for health insurance, said Edward Barbini, a spokesman for state Attorney General Robert Abrams. The painters never saw their money again and got little or no pay for painting hundreds of pillars with black and white stripes, Barbini said. Some worked as long as four months before giving up. Someone, presumably a disgruntled worker, firebombed Pannone's Cadillac on Jan. 24, Barbini said. Barbini said Pannone placed newspaper advertisements claiming his Show N Tell Contracting Co. had a painting contract with the Transit Authority and promising painters $92.50 a day. Unlike the Mark Twain novel in which Tom Sawyer persuaded other youngsters to pay for the privilege of whitewashing his aunt's fence, the pillar painting was not authorized, officials said. The painting, in a section of Brooklyn where the city subway runs on elevated platforms, did not meet Transit Authority specifications, which require zebra stripes only at intersections, said spokeswoman Caren Gardner. Also, the paint covered only the lower sections of the pillars. ``We do not paint just pillars. When we paint, we paint an entire structure,'' Gardner said. Authorities said Pannone has an arrest record dating back to 1957, when as a 30-year-old clerk earning $62 a week, he was convicted of pilfering $174,000 from his employer, the American Express Co. If convicted of the fraud and larceny charges, Pannone could face a maximum penalty of four years in prison and $5,000 in fines.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Girl Has Second Liver Transplant; Returns to Surgery Today
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with Stormie returning to surgery, delete outdated material; picks up 14th graf pvs, `The girl's....'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PG2
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old girl who was the first heart-liver transplant recipient returned to the operating room today because doctors feared she was bleeding internally a day after a second liver transplant. Stormie Jones' new liver was functioning, but a drop in blood pressure Tuesday night prompted doctors to reopen the incisions this morning, said Children's Hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon. ``They really are not considering this any type of setback,'' she said. ``Stormie is doing very well. She is incredibly strong.'' Doctors estimated it would take several hours to determine if she was bleeding and to locate the source, Ms. McMahon said. Stormie had asked her doctors for a new liver in November, after she began to have symptoms of liver inflamation, her mother, Lois ``Suzie'' Purcell, 33, said at a news conference. Stormie became especially ill two weeks ago, suffering from weakness, jaundice and itchiness. Doctors decided Feb. 13 that Stormie's liver should be replaced because of damage from hepatitis caused by an unknown virus in early January, when she was hospitalized for treatment of an infection. Her family was notified Monday that a suitable donor organ was available. The hospital declined to release information about the donor. The 10-hour transplant operation began about 3:15 a.m. Tuesday, nine hours after Stormie and her mother arrived from their home in the Fort Worth, Texas, suburb of White Settlement. Stormie had no qualms about undergoing another major operation, her parents said. ``It's kind of like poker _ you can't win if you don't play,'' said Stormie's stepfather, Alan Purcell. ``We had no choice but to play the game.'' Monday night, the girl spent her time asking why doctors and nurses seemed to be delaying preparations for surgery. ``She was asking, `When are they going to get here?' `When are they going to show up?' and `I want my liver,''' Mrs. Purcell said. Dr. Andreas Tzakis, who led a seven-member team of surgeons, said the new liver ``seemed to start functioning right away.'' He said Tuesday that doctors expected no complications during Stormie's recovery because of her relatively good health. The girl's heart was not affected by the disease, Tzakis said. ``Her heart responded perfectly during the transplant,'' he said. Stormie received a new heart and liver on Feb. 14, 1984, to control levels of cholesterol 10 times higher than normal. Her cholesterol level has since decreased to nearly normal, Tzakis said. Starzl replaced the girl's heart and liver with those of a 4-year-old girl who had died in a New York car accident. The success rate of a second liver transplant is estimated at 65 percent to 70 percent, hospital officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Robber's Force of Habit Proves His Undoing
DOC.TEXT: Police stalking a bank robber who preferred certain bank branches correctly predicted where the thief would strike next and nabbed a suspect emerging from a bank after a holdup. Allen Lorenzo Mills, 34, of Capitol Heights, was charged with armed robbery and assault with intent to rob after he tried to leave a Sovran bank branch Tuesday. Police said a man who had become known as the ``bearded bank robber'' seemed to prefer Sovran Bank branches, striking three times at one branch and once previously at the Bladensburg branch that was held up Tuesday. Police guessed the robber might return to the Bladensburg branch because his robbery there had been among the most lucrative, and set up a stakeout. Shortly after noon, a man who resembled photographs obtained during other bank robberies entered the bank, police said. Within seconds, a special alarm in the bank alerted authorities that a robbery was in progress. Undercover officers met the man as he walked out the door and arrested him without incident, police said. ``We've had several banks under surveillance over the last two weeks, but today, this was the only bank we were watching,'' said Maj. Tony Leo, commander of the Special Operations Division. ``The officers figured he would come back to this branch sooner or later and he did.'' Police are investigating whether Mills is connected to at least six other robberies committed in the past two months, including another Tuesday in District Heights.

DOC.HEAD: Hollywood Character Actor, Comic Foil Dies at 77
DOC.TEXT: Henry Brandon, a Hollywood character actor who ranged from Indian chieftains to the comic foil for Laurel and Hardy has died of an apparent heart attack. He was 77. Brandon was working up to the time of his death Feb. 15, primarily doing voice-overs for commercials, and was again cast as an Indian in a television movie, said his agent, Gary Butcher. He was the animators' model for Captain Hook in Walt Disney's ``Peter Pan,'' Butcher said. Born in Berlin, Brandon came to Hollywood with his family as a baby. He caught the attention of Hal Roach, the producer of the Laurel and Hardy comedies, and was cast under his real name, Henry Kleinbach. He played Old Barnaby in the 1934 classic ``Babes in Toyland.'' His other film credits include ``Beau Geste,'' ``Nurse Edith Cavell,'' ``Underground,'' ``Joan of Arc,'' ``Pony Express,'' ``The War of the Worlds,'' and ``Auntie Mame.'' He played Indian chiefs 26 times, including parts in director John Ford's ``The Searchers'' and ``Two Rode Together.'' His film work extended to the mid-1970s. Survivors include a brother and sister.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Peacekeepers Wounded in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Shiite Moslem militiamen opened fire at a group of U.N. peacekeepers in south Lebanon today and wounded three Irish soldiers, one of them critically, U.N. spokesman Timur Goksel said. Goksel said the soldiers were attacked by gunmen from the Amal militia in the village of Haddatha, just north of Israel's self-proclaimed ``security zone.'' The three soldiers were flown to the field hospital of the U.N. Interim Force in Lebanon in the southern border town of Naqoura, Goksel said. Their names were not immediately available. Amal leaders were investigating the incident. The militia is known to have good relations with the 5,800-strong U.N. peacekeeping force, which has been stationed in south Lebanon since March 1978. A spokesman for Amal in Beirut, who refused to be named, said the firefight could have developed due to ``personal reasons.'' He did not elaborate ``The investigation is currently under way. Of course, we regret the clash and stress that it was not politically motivated. Our militiamen are under strict orders to respect UNIFIL,'' the spokesman added. UNIFIL, drawn from nine nations, mans a narrow buffer of south Lebanon separating Israel's security zone from predominantly Shiite villages hostile to Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Evangelist Guilty of Murder in Child's Death
DOC.TEXT: An evangelist has been convicted of first-degree murder in the starvation death of a 4-year-old girl she was allegedly trying to exorcise of evil spirits. Mary Nicholson, 40, of Pace, showed no emotion when the verdict was read Tuesday and refused to comment afterward. Darlene Jackson, the mother of Kimberly McZinc, had pleaded guilty last March to third-degree murder and child abuse in her daughter's beating and starvation death on Feb. 8, 1988. Ms. Jackson, 33, who is serving a seven-year prison sentence, told jurors last week that Ms. Nicholson convinced her that Kimberly was possessed by demonic spirits that could be exorcised only through strict diet and discipline. She was the state's key witness in Ms. Nicholson's seven-day trial. Ms. Nicholson was also found guilty of aggravated child abuse. Santa Rosa Circuit Judge George Lowrey ordered a pre-sentence investigation into the evangelist and said sentencing would be scheduled when it is completed. Assistant State Attorney Kim Skievaski said earlier he would not seek the death penalty. The only other penalty for a first-degree murder conviction is life in prison with no chance of parole for 25 years. The aggravated child abuse conviction is punishable by up to life in prison. ``I am glad to see someone's paying for my daughter's death,'' said Kimberly's father, Kenneth McZinc. Earlier Tuesday, Skievaski told the jurors in his closing arguments that Ms. Jackson ``was led like a cow with a ring through her nose to believe her child was possessed by evil spirits.'' But defense attorney R. Glenn Arnold argued that Ms. Jackson, a former schoolteacher, was having religious visions long before she met Ms. Nicholson and that her testimony about his client's participation in Kimberly's death was just another dream or hallucination. Witnesses testified that Kimberly weighed 28{ pounds when she died. A child her age and height should have weighed about 45 pounds.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Of Sandinistas Gather For Ortega's Final Rally
With PM-Nicaragua-Opposition, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Sandinista supporters on foot or in cars, trucks, buses and wheelchairs began gathering today for President Daniel Ortega's final campaign rally. Bands of youths stayed up all night raising black-and-red banners across two parade routes, and crowded vehicles began arriving from out of town before dawn for this evening's rally alongside Lake Managua. ``We're here to flatten Violeta,'' said Jorge Luis Garcia Castana, a Sandinista army veteran who was almost totally blinded by mortar fragments in Nicaragua's civil war. He and other disabled veterans said they thought a vote for Violeta Barrios de Chamorro was a vote for the U.S.-supported Contra rebels who left them crippled for life. They were part of a group of about 250 disabled veterans, 23 in wheelchairs, who made a 17-day, 160-mile trek from the Honduran border under their own power. Meanwhile, the secretary-general of the Organization of American States, Joao Baena Soares, arrived to head a contingent of more than 400 OAS election observers. ``We are convinced that on election day there will be tranquillity that will allow Nicaraguans the free exercise of their right to vote,'' said Baena Soares in an airport arrival statement. Election observers said the biggest danger of violence might come in small towns and rural areas where politics become part of local feuds or ``Hatfield-McCoy situations,'' as one put it. The observers are important to both sides; Mrs. Chamorro's United National Opposition hopes they will enforce a fair vote, while the Sandinistas want to legitimize their government. On Tuesday, Mrs. Chamorro said she was certain of victory but could accept defeat and called on the ruling Sandinistas to make the same guarantee. ``We don't know if they have accepted the rules of the election game,'' Mrs. Chamorro told about 400 of her UNO coalition workers. Sandinista campaign manager Bayardo Arce told reporters that Ortega was willing to turn over the government in the ``hypothetical'' event of a loss. Three U.S. officials just back from Nicaragua predicted an upset victory for Mrs. Chamorro. ``If I were a betting man, I'd go with the longshot. I think she's going to upset him,'' said Rep. Gary Ackerman, D-N.Y., who made the trip with Reps. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., and Doug Bosco, D-Calif. The election is being held as part of a Central American accord also designed to disband the U.S.-supported Contra rebels who have been trying to topple the Sandinistas since 1981. The voting pits the Sandinistas against Mrs. Chamorro's UNO, a 14-party coalition, and eight other opponents. A president, vice-president, 90-member assembly and local officials will take office April 25 for a six-year term. Arce said the Sandinistas were optimistic the United States would change its hostile policy toward Nicaragua if the Sandinistas won an election certified as fair by international observers. Alfredo Cesar, one of Mrs. Chamorro's top advisers, said Ortega would have a chance to become a historical figure by becoming the first head of a revolutionary government in the Americas to step down voluntarily. ``We have lots of guys in Latin America who refuse to hand over power,'' said Cesar in an interview with The Associated Press. ``If he didn't, he'd be just one more little dictator. But he has a chance to make history,'' Cesar said. The Sandinistas were generally seen as leading, but the outcome was considered uncertain because so many Nicaraguans were reluctant to tell strangers who they support. Managua was festooned with red-and-black Sandinista party banners and slogans, and a red-and-black hot air balloon floated over the city briefly. Youths toted Sandinista backpacks. Only a few blue and white UNO signs were visible. But an undercurrent could be felt even at a Sandinista reception for the international press. One reporter asked for a drink that was renamed the ``Nica libre'' after the Sandinistas took power in 1979 and was coldly told, ``It's called a rum-and-Coke.''

DOC.HEAD: Christian Militia Regroups Forces
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces today used a cease-fire to stockpile weapons and redeploy troops for their next battle, while civilians fled their ruined neighborhoods for refuge in safer Moslem areas. Samir Geagea, leader of the Lebanese Forces militia, refused to give any concessions to Gen. Michel Aoun and said his fighters were ready for war. A source close to Geagea's command said his militia had adopted a new military plan to block any attempt by Aoun to storm its strongholds if the current cease-fire collapses. ``If clashes break out anew, it will be a tough, crushing battle throughout the Christian enclave,'' the source said. Snipers killed one person and wounded five in various parts of the Christian enclave today, police said. By police count, the fight for the 310-square-mile enclave has killed at least 673 people and wounded 1,877, in addition to inflicting more than $750 million in damage. The dead include 97 soldiers killed since the confrontation broke out Jan. 30. The fighting began when Geagea refused Aoun's demand that he disband the Lebanese Forces, the largest Christian militia in Lebanon. Geagea's 6,000-strong militia has deployed about one-third of its fighters in east Beirut, the military source said. They are to defend its urban strongholds and deny Aoun access to the port through the streets of the Ashrafiyeh district. Aoun lost the port in the early days of the fighting. Military analysts believe Aoun must regain control of the port to ensure safe supply lines by sea before accepting any peace settlement. The Lebanese Forces moved new heavy fire power into place in the Kesrouan mountains to harass Aoun's back if he tries to move into the port area, the source said. The upgraded fire power includes about 120 truck-mounted multi-barreled rocket launchers brought out of weapons depots. The launchers, obtained from Iraq more than a year ago, can fire 40 122mm shells a minute. Geagea's men are outnumbered by Aoun's army at least 3-to-1 and hoped to counter his superiority with their upgraded weapons, the source said. Lebanese forces militiamen, with nearly 15 years' experience in street battles, ``are waiting for Aoun's army in the narrow alleys of Ashrafiyeh, which has become a huge garrison,'' the source said. The militia force defending the port, Ashrafiyeh and the military headquarters of Karantina have been beefed up from 1,200 to 2,000 men, the source said. The surrender of Aoun's troops Saturday at Adma, an isolated pocket in Kesrouan, freed the militiamen for the new deployment. The source said the bulk of the militia's fighting force, backed by tanks and armored personnel carriers, was deployed along the southern and eastern edges of Kesrouan province, separated from Aoun's troops by a no-man's-land of just a few hundred yards. A police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, confirmed that both factions were bolstering their forces. Aoun's army stockpiled ammunition, especially tank cannon and howitzer rounds, in depots in the Metin mountains northeast of the capital. Meanwhile, civilians continued to desert the Christian enclave, seeking refuge in the predominately Moslem areas outside the enclave. The Christian communities, dispersed throughout Lebanon before the civil war, have gradually consolidated in the enclave since 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Harsh Weather Stalls Antarctic Expedition
DOC.TEXT: Storms have forced International Trans-Antarctica Expedition members to remain in their tents for extended periods as they near the end of their 3,600-mile journey across the continent, a spokeswoman said. ``This is particularly frustrating as they get closer and closer to their goal, and their thoughts begin to turn toward home,'' spokeswoman Jennifer Gasperini said Tuesday in a statement from the expedition's St. Paul office. ``It is also worrisome for the team as they have only a two-day supply of dog food.'' However, rescuers with more supplies in a Soviet truck are stationed about 40 miles ahead of the six-member team and could turn back if necessary, Gasperini said. The team led by Minnesotan Will Steger and Jean-Louis Etienne of France has an estimated 221 miles to go in the seven-month ski and sled-dog journey. ``This expedition is crazy and we are crazy to have done it,'' Gasperini quoted team co-leader Jean-Louis Etienne of France as saying. Over six days ending Monday, the team was able to travel just 56 miles, Gasperini said. It stayed Friday and Saturday at the abandoned Soviet base of Pioneerskaya. The team traveled 26 miles Sunday in temperatures as low as 53 degrees below zero with winds of 33 mph and zero visibility, and it became tentbound Monday. Gasperini said that as the team descends toward Davis Sea and the end of its trek, the weather is expected to get worse. The team also is entering the worst area for crevasses, which are giant cracks and fissures.

DOC.HEAD: Court Sends Case of Retarded Texas Man Back to Appeals Court
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today told a federal appeals court to restudy the case of a retarded Texas man who killed a deputy sheriff in Houston 11 years ago. The justices unanimously sent John Henry Selvage's case back to the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals to determine whether the constitutional claim he raises can be handled by a Texas state court. When the nation's highest court agreed in October to hear Selvage's appeal, it was expected to use the case to clarify the scope and retroactive effects of a decision announced last July. In it, the court allowed states to execute mentally retarded killers only if jurors were allowed to take a defendant's mental condition into consideration. Selvage was convicted and sentenced to death for killing Albert Garza, a Harris County deputy sheriff, during a July 30, 1979, robbery of a Houston jewelry store. His lawyers argue that his death sentence is unconstitutional because jurors did not consider his retardation. The justices were to decide whether there was a legitimate cause for Selvage not raising that issue at some earlier stage. But in an unsigned opinion today, they said the 5th Circuit court should clarify whether Selvage's claim _ based on their July ruling _ could be made in the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals. Lawyers for Selvage and the state disagree over whether his constitutional argument is procedurally barred in that state court. ``The (5th Circuit court) is more familiar with Texas law than we are, and we therefore ... remand the case to it for determination of whether (Selvage's) claim is presently procedurally barred under Texas law,'' the court's brief opinion said. The case is Selvage vs. Collins, 87-6700.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Federal Regulations on Social Security Overpayments
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today upheld federal regulations aimed at saving the government time and money when it mistakenly overpays some Social Security recipients. The justices, voting 5-4 in a case from Colorado, said the rules are a reasonable interpretation of the Social Security Act. The court rejected arguments that needy recipients could suffer undue hardship. The regulations apply to two Social Security programs: old age, survivors and disability insurance benefits and supplemental security income. Adopted by the Department of Health and Human Services, the rules cover instances in which the government at different times overpays and underpays recipients. The rules allow officials to balance the overpayments against underpayments, arriving at a net amount that is owed either the government or the receipient. The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals based in Denver ruled in 1988 that the regulations illegally may deprive needy recipients of the chance to keep overpayments. The appeals court said federal law requires the government to abandon recovery of overpayments when a recipient is blameless or if returning the extra money would cause the recipient serious hardship. But the Bush administration said the appeals court misunderstood the way the rules work. Administration officials said the regulations would not deprive needy people of the opportunity eventually to keep the extra money. Government lawyers said the regulations would spare federal officials from paying out millions of extra dollars automatically and then going through an elaborate procedure to recover some of the money. From 1981 to 1986, about 4.7 million people a year received too much or too little due to errors in the retirement and survivor's insurance program alone, federal officials said. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the Supreme Court today, said the rules are reasonable. He was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun and Sandra Day O'Connor. Dissenting were Justices John Paul Stevens, William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and Anthony M. Kennedy. The case is Sullivan vs. Everhart, 88-1323.

DOC.HEAD: University President Criticizes Local School Official's Praise For Mandela
DOC.TEXT: Boston University's acting president has criticized Chelsea public schools' superintendent for holding up South African activist Nelson Mandela as a role model for students, according to a published report. ``Nelson Mandela is not someone who should be held up as an heroic example of patient commitment to a good cause,'' Jon Westling wrote in a Feb. 8 letter to Diana Lam, saying the African National Congress leader ``has thrown in his lot with killers.'' Lam became Chelsea superintendent last year after the university began managing the school system in an unprecedented educational reform effort. Westling was named Boston University acting president recently when John Silber took a leave of absence to run for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Lam received the letter after she cited Mandela's human rights crusade during a speech before a group of 8th-grade students in Chelsea, according to today's Boston Globe. The newspaper said it obtained a copy of the letter Tuesday. Mandela was freed Feb. 11 after serving 27 years in jail for his role in the anti-apartheid struggle waged by the ANC. He helped launch the ANC's guerrilla campaign in 1961 and has said he supports continued armed struggle against apartheid. ``Nelson Mandela could have sided with the advocates of freedom and democracy and of the non-violent abolition of apartheid. Instead, he has thrown in his lot with killers,'' Wrestling wrote. Lam told the Globe Tuesday that she ``was surprised at (Westling's) reaction and quite honestly ... very upset.'' ``Here was a timely `teachable moment' for young adolescents who rarely view themselves as active participants in experiencing, let along shaping, history,'' she wrote in a response to Westling's comments. ``... I stand by my words. I would be honored to have Mr. Mandela as a guest in Chelsea, or in my home.'' Telephone calls to Wrestling's office for comment went unanswered this morning. The university issued a statement Tuesday that said ``this kind of interchange of communication is what would be expected between academic professionals who have challenging points of view.''

DOC.HEAD: Restart of Key Weapons Plant Not Likely Before Summer, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Production of plutonium triggers for nuclear warheads at the Rocky Flats plant in Colorado may not resume completely before late summer, a senior Energy Department official said today. Production was suspended indefinitely late last year to allow EG&G Inc., which runs the plant under an Energy Department contract, to install new safety and management practices. The plant is the only source of plutonium triggers and is considered a vital link in the U.S. nuclear weapons production chain. Adm. J.M. Barr, a top adviser to Energy Secretary James D. Watkins on nuclear arms production, said no firm target date had been set for resuming production but that Rocky Flats was expected to be in full swing sometime between July and September. Watkins had said shortly after the shutdown that he hoped production could resume by February. Speaking to a reporter during a break in a meeting with a department advisory committee, Barr said Watkins now hoped to get the first plutonium processing facility, known as Building 771, back in operation by June at the latest. Five other buildings at the site, near Denver, also are involved in plutonium processing. Barr told the Advisory Committee on Nuclear Facility Safety, which is monitoring efforts to get Rocky Flats back in operation, that by early April he would offer a specific target date for full resumption of plutonium trigger production. ``We're afraid anything we would give you now would be wrong,'' he told the panel. Rocky Flats has been plagued by a variety of operating and waste handling problems in recent years. Last June, the FBI raided the facility in search of evidence of criminal violations of laws governing the handling of radioactive waste. Rockwell International Corp. quit as Rocky Flats operator last September. Barr told the advisory committee that the top objective of EG&G's overhaul of Rocky Flats operations is to improve the ``margin of safety.'' He stressed, however, that there was no imminent danger to the public from Rocky Flats operations last fall. Dave Van Leuven, EG&G's associate general manager for defense production at Rocky Flats, outlined for the committee the tasks to be completed before production resumes. He said, for example, that more than 1,000 engineering drawings of safety systems would be checked for accuracy. About 150 of the drawings have been checked already, he said, and it will take another eight weeks to do the rest. Van Leuven said the technical competence of about 1,500 plant operators would be verified before production is resumed. He did not say how many already have been tested, but he said the failure rate so far was about 30 percent. EG&G, a Massachusetts-based private technology company, runs several Energy Department nuclear facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Empty Exxon Ship Runs Aground Briefly
DOC.TEXT: An empty Exxon tanker awaited a marine safety inspection after it briefly ran aground in a narrow channel at the mouth of the Columbia River, a Coast Guard officer said. The Exxon Philadelphia was making a scheduled stop at Astoria for the inspection before heading to Valdez, Alaska, when it ran into trouble Tuesday in foul weather, said Coast Guard Lt. j.g. Ed Gibbons. An off-duty radioman notified the Guard that the tanker was aground and five tugs were working to free it, Gibbons said. ``By the time we got to talk to them, they were apparently under way.'' Gibbons said the tanker's master reported that the boat was empty and there was no hull damage and the ship docked at Astoria. He said gusts of more than 30 mph could have made it difficult for the ship to navigate the narrow channel.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Snow in Plains, Southwest; Floods Threaten in South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to update with more rain forecast. Picks up 2nd graf, `In east-central...'; SUBS grafs 8-9, `Nearly a foot,'' with 3 grafs to add snow amounts in Texas and Colo.
DOC.TEXT: A forecast of more heavy rain threatens more flooding in the South, where nine deaths are blamed on high water in the past week, and more than a foot of snow broke a dry spell in southern Colorado. A flash flood watch was posted for tonight over much of Mississippi, where up to 5 inches of rain was forecast. ``Our winds are picking up southernly, bringing in Gulf moisture,'' said Wayne Gasson, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Jackson, Miss. ``The surplus moisture will be in place before the storm gets here. That's one of the ingredients of why we think it's going to be a very good rain producer.'' In east-central Illinois, a federal disaster assessment team said a Valentine's Day storm caused $3.5 million dollars in property damage in Champaign County. Seven people in Urbana were overcome Tuesday by carbon monoxide from charcoal grills they were using to heat their home, one of thousands that has been without power since the Feb. 14 ice storm, authorities said. ``They were awfully, awfully lucky,'' said Urbana Assistant Fire Chief Richard Dunn. ``If the one hadn't woken up, they probably wouldn't have survived.'' In Georgia, Gov. Joe Frank Harris asked for $15.7 million in federal disaster assistance to help nine counties devastated by floods and tornadoes. Interstate 25 over Raton Pass in northern New Mexico was closed for a few hours because of poor visibility caused by blowing snow, but authorities reopened the highway late Tuesday morning. The snow in Colorado was welcomed by most. ``This is a very good deal for southern Colorado,'' said Joe Baskin, a weather service forecaster in Denver. ``They've been dry. They're well below their usual moisture levels across the southern part of the state.'' Trinidad, Colo., got 15 inches of snow and 8 to 10 inches fell at Walsenburg. Nearly a foot of snow fell in parts of southwestern Kansas, closing some schools. A woman died when the car she was riding in slid into another lane and was struck by a truck. The weather service posted winter storm warnings for the Texas Panhandle, where 7 to 10 inches of snow closed schools and sent trucks skidding. ``It's snowin' and blowin','' said Buddy Loften of the Texas Highway Department in Dalhart. ``We've got some (snow plows) out there, but you go up and you go back down there and you can't tell you were there before.'' The storm, which began dumping snow on the northern part of the Panhandle late Monday, forced officials to close a 200-mile section of Interstate 40 on Monday in Arizona, and New Mexico authorities on Tuesday closed two highways westward out of Clayton, N.M. Since late last week, floods have been blamed for three deaths each in Georgia and Alabama, two in Mississippi and one in North Carolina. The high water from heavy rain that drenched northern and central Alabama was flowing southward along rivers, inundating new low-lying areas and forcing the evacuation of more homes. The Alabama River was cresting 8 feet above flood stage at Montgomery and was expected to crest at about 6 feet above flood stage at Selma today. At Selma, Chief Deputy John Howell said the predicted crest would mean that about 70 families would be flooded out of their homes. The Sucarnoochie River in Sumter County destroyed seven mobile homes and two houses and damaged 47 other dwellings. The National Guard has moved families out of 19 homes in west-central Alabama's Greene County, where the Black Warrior and Tombigbee rivers converge. The weather service at Mobile predicted 5 to 8 inches of rainfall by Thursday, and meteorologist Jim Hyder said the Tombigbee, Alabama and Mobile rivers in Alabama can expect crests well above flood stage this week and next. A spokesman for the Red Cross said at least 2,281 families in more than 36 counties had been affected by recent flooding and a Feb. 10 storm, which spawned tornadoes and violent winds that wrecked homes and downed power lines, mostly in central Alabama.

DOC.HEAD: Legislature Receives Draft of Law on New Powerful Post of Presidency
DOC.TEXT: Legislators got their first look today at a draft of proposed constitutional changes that would strengthen the post of the presidency, now held by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Vladimir Tumanov, an official at the Institute of State and Law in Moscow who helped prepare the draft, said copies were distributed to members of the Supreme Soviet, the national legislature, which held closed committee meetings today. He said he had not seen the draft and could not give details. Gorbachev has appealed to the Supreme Soviet to approve his plan for a Western-style presidential system. The Washington Post reported today that copies of the proposed changes have circulated in the Kremlin. It said that the changes would, among other things, provide for the president to be elected to six-year terms and give him veto power. The New York Times today also carried a story on the proposed changes. It quoted legislators who have seen the draft as saying the plan would include creation of a strengthened presidency this spring and the immediate selection of the president by the national parliament. Sergei Stankevich, a progressive member of a parliamentary commission that considers draft laws submitted to the Supreme Soviet, said the changes would give the Soviet president most of the powers of his French and American counterparts without many of their constitutional limitations, the Post said. However, deputies from the northern Baltic states are alarmed over provisions that impose severe restrictions on the rights of republics to secede and permit authorities to crack down on ``nationalist'' organizations. ``I don't think this new legislation will be acceptable to anyone who believes in a constitutional system of checks and balances,'' Stankevich told the newspaper. Alexander Yakovlev, a key Gorbachev aide, said the presidential system was necessary to ensure the stable development of a democracy in the Soviet Union. Deputies who have read the proposed changes told the Post the draft includes the following points: _A six-year presidential term, with the first president elected by the 2,250-seat Congress of People's Deputies, the parent body of the Supreme Soviet. Subsequent presidents would be elected by universal suffrage. The Times said the president would be elected to five-year term. It said a nationwide, direct vote would not be held the first time because the feeling is that the country now cannot afford the time required to plan such a vote. _The president would have the right to veto legislation adopted by the Supreme Soviet. A presidential veto could be overridden by a majority in both houses of the Supreme Soviet. _The president could declare a state of emergency in any region without securing the consent of the relevant republic. _The president would have wide powers to rule by decree when the Supreme Soviet is not in session. _The president would have the right to cancel legislation adopted by the parliaments of constituent republics. The Times said the changes would give the parliament the right to conduct a vote of no-confidence in the president's government and that if the president lost he could disband parliament and call new elections. The Post said the draft could be submitted by the end of this month or the beginning of March to the 542-member Supreme Soviet. The Congress of People's Deputies, the supreme state body, would have to approve any constitutional changes.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. Feb. 16 Carlsbad (N.M.) Current-Argus on the drug summit: While some still claim the futility of fighting a drug war, contending we have already lost it, others forge ahead, however haltingly, refusing to lie down and die. The drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia, concluded with President Bush admitting to the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia that the United States must do something to curb the demand. Without demand, there would be no production and sales. We were encouraged by that conclusion, but we must see more tangible efforts made to convince the American public of the dead-end road exemplified by drug use. Too little is being done _ either in terms of funds for education or in direct communication _ to show all our citizenry how terminal their drug use activities are.

Feb. 17 The Kansas City (Mo.) Times on the drug summit: Although many Colombians found the additional security surrounding the four-nation anti-drug summit in Cartagena an annoyance, the Colombians did a good job in looking after the safety of their president and the presidents of the United States, Peru and Bolivia. ... The significance of this meeting was mostly symbolic, a courtship. It was the chance for the presidents ... to come together to respectfully discuss a common problem, if only from different perspectives. Put another way, it was a meeting of coca-supplying nations and the leader of the hemisphere's No. 1 consumer of cocaine. (President) Bush said that an anti-drug cartel was born. That cartel is only as good as the commitment to it and the understanding of situations unique to each nation.

Feb. 19 The Anniston (Ala.) Star on the drug summit: President Bush got out of Colombia intact, a symbolic drug treaty under his arm. We run our country with symbolism these days. But bullets and surface-to-air missiles are not symbolic. The risk to the president was real. The president felt he had to go to the Cartagena summit, however, because it was an event that most of all was symbolic.

Feb. 15 The Indianapolis Star on a reunified Germany: The reunification of Germany is only a matter of time. West Germany has the vigor to nurse the sick East back to economic health and put it on a sound course. The question of keeping Germany in NATO is a stumbling block. The Soviets are not keen about the prospect. But the stumbling block may not be insurmountable. ... Membership in NATO could widen a reunified Germany's ties with the Western community and deepen mutual trust between Germany and other members of the alliance. If the current era of good feeling between the USSR and the Western community continues and progresses into a phase of general demilitarization and disarmament, NATO could evolve eventually into a peace-keeping alliance in which even the Soviet Union and former Warsaw Pact members have votes.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Promises Peace, Pensions To Cheering East Germans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grfs to make clear that Kohl is West German chancellor and reason for campaigning in East Germany. Pickup 1th pvs, `He also...
DOC.TEXT: In his first campaign stop in East Germany, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl told cheering crowds that ``peace will emanate'' from a united nation and that his country's social security system will protect them. Kohl was kicking off a conservative alliance's campaign for East Germany's March 18 elections, the country's first free vote after 40 years of Communist rule. But West German politicians, who themselves face the voters in December, are increasingly using East Germany's election campaign to promote themselves and their causes. Meanwhile, East Germany's deputy defense minister and chief of staff said today the two countries' armed forces should merge and be deployed on the entire territory of a reunited Germany. ``Every sovereign state has the right to defend its sovereignty,'' Manfred Graetz told the East German newspaper Junge Welt. ``There are also neutral states that have armed forces. I believe that a future Germany must be allowed this right.'' Graetz also rejected extending NATO's territory over what is now East Germany, but said he did not believe it could become a ``no man's land.'' His remarks could further complicate discussions over the military role for a united Germany. East Germany and the Soviet Union have insisted that the future state be neutral. West Germany and its Western allies want the country to remain in NATO. The West German government has said no NATO or German troops should be stationed in what is now East Germany. On Tuesday, most of the 90,000 people who crowded in front of Erfurt's cathedral for Kohl's speech chanted ``Helmut! Helmut!'' and ``Our Chancellor!'' Many waved West German flags. ``There are fears in East and West of a Germany that would have 80 million inhabitants ... (and) be a tremendous economic force,'' Kohl said. He also observed that a reunited Germany ``will have to live with its past, with the horrors that were committed in the name of Germany this century'' and noted fears that it could again threaten its neighbors. ``I take these fears seriously. ... Peace will emanate from German soil,'' he said. Germans have been seeking to assure their European neighbors and the world that a unified Germany will not pose a military threat. In Moscow, Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed an international treaty on Germany reunification, saying his country ``has an inalienable right'' to ensure that it does not sustain moral, political or economic damage from a united Germany. In an interview published in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda today, Gorbachev said a united Germany must respect Europe's current borders and only the four victorious Allies of World War II can determine Germany's final status. Both Germanys are bound by treaties to respect their current frontiers, but a united country would not be, and some conservatives in West Germany have suggested reunification be sought within the 1937 borders. In 1937, one-third of what is now Poland was German territory. Kohl said he would seek massive investment by West German firms and extend Bonn's social security safety net to offset the economic chaos caused by what he called ``40 years of red dictatorship'' in East Germany. ``We have created in the Federal Republic (West Germany) a social security system that is exemplary in Europe,'' Kohl said. ``We want this system for people in East Germany as well.'' Specifically, he promised East Germans that they could draw the same unemployment benefits as West Germans after reunificiation and said East Germans would get adequate pensions. Retirees would also see the value of their savings protected. Kohl was campaigning for the Alliance of Germany, which includes the East German branch of Kohl's Christian Democrats as well as the Democratic Awakening and the German Social Union parties. The coalition, which polls show running behind the Social Democratic Party, is one of the most outspoken champions of German unification. Kohl was repeatedly jeered by about 100 hecklers waving East German flags, and several anti-Kohl posters, apparently printed by left-wing groups, were pasted up in the city. But cheering broke out for minutes after Kohl's hourlong speech, forcing him to appear several times at an open window overlooking Cathedral Square. ``Nothing better could have happened,'' retiree Hans Wagner said from the square.

DOC.HEAD: Sudanese Strongman: Israel, Cuba Giving Rebels Military Help
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's military ruler alleged today that Israel and Cuba are giving military aid to southern Sudanese rebels and that Israeli experts are helping train the rebels. Israeli and rebel spokesmen denied knowing anything about an Israeli presence among the rebels. Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, who leads the military junta ruling Sudan since a coup June 30, spoke at a news conference at the end of an official visit, his third as head of state. ``We have definite proof of the presence of Israeli experts at rebel centers for training and operational planning and of military support reaching the (rebel) movement from Israel,'' he said. He said his government has ``information that there have been human losses among Israelis in some battle areas.'' The Sudanese leader gave no details. But his main field commander in the south was quoted Tuesday as saying that three Israeli experts were reported wounded in fighting in the Equatoria region. Equatoria is one of three southern regions wracked by civil war since renegade army Col. John Garang's Sudan People's Liberation Army launched operations against the Moslem-dominated government in 1983. The rebellion was to press demands for autonomy and economic reforms in the south, inhabited mostly by Christians or animists of African descent. Maj. Gen. Nasr el-Din Suliman, the government's military commander in Equatoria, told the Sudanese newspaper Al-Inkaz Al-Watany that his command had received a report saying three Israeli experts were wounded in a mine explosion while inspecting a rebel camp in Equatoria. In Jerusalem, Israeli Defense Ministry spokesman Dan Weinreich said: ``I don't know about such an accident, and I don't know about Israelis in southern Sudan.'' In Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, a spokesman for the Sudan People's Liberation Army, Lam Akol, said: ``There has not been a single Israeli that has gone to the south or near the border'' between Ethiopia and Sudan. Akol said the rebel command has not ``contemplated or anticipated any form of assistance from Israel'' and charged that Sudanese government claims of involvement by the Jewish state were intended to ``isolate us from the Arab world.'' In his news conference, el-Bashir said the rebels sent ``very large numbers of young southerners'' to Cuba for ideological indoctrination and military training. ``They are there now, and our information is that there is a school in Cuba called the Sudan school,'' he added. Dominique Cassiano, a member of el-Bashir's junta, told the newspaper Al-Inkaz Al-Watani the rebels have 12,000 men in Cuba. El-Bashir told reporters that he and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt discussed how to end the southern Sudan rebellion peacefully. They dealt with a potential Egyptian role in peacemaking, he said. The rebels and the government held peace talks in Addis Ababa last August and in Nairobi, Kenya, in December. Both rounds were inconclusive. The Sudanese leader asked Mubarak after the December meeting to try to organize a third round of talks in Cairo. President Mobutu Sese Sekou of Zaire also has been mediating.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: have votes.
DOC.TEXT: Feb. 20 Los Angeles Daily News on the U.S. Postal Service: The U.S. Postal Service plans to slow its service as well as raise its rates. Currently 4 percent of letters scheduled for overnight delivery arrive late. The new plan will increase that figure to 7 percent. But Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank denied that this will amount to a ``degradation of service.'' He said in a recent interview that what Postal Service customers will lose in timeliness will be offset by more important improvements in consistency and reliability. That's another way of saying that if consumers lower their expectations far enough, it will be easy for the Postal Service to reach its own. The problem with the Postal Service's plan is that it assumes a great public willingness to reduce standards. That's a lot to assume along with a possible 20 percent rate increase next year.

Feb. 17 The Hartford (Conn.) Courant on military spending: In the wake of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's presentation of the military budget for (the) next fiscal year, the big word in Washington is strategy. Rep. Les Aspin and Sen. Sam Nunn, respective chairmen of the House and Senate armed services committees, are saying that the budget lacks an overall scheme. ... Nunn says that Congress would be inclined to support a defense secretary who could show that his numbers are part of a long-term plan to redesign America's military capacity relative to a reduced Soviet threat. ... Cheney admits he has no such plan. No one in Washington does. The reason no one has a grand strategy is that no one saw the changes coming in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. ... Grand strategy emerges from bold choices. So far there has been no perestroika in Washington.

Feb. 17 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on nuclear arms control: Has anybody noticed that public concern about nuclear arms control has practically evaporated? ... When President Bush announced that plans to reduce nuclear, chemical and conventional forces were going smoothly, White House correspondents were curious only about troop levels in Europe. This subject has taken center stage in a way that once would have been inconceivable, overshadowing the news of progress toward the START treaty. ... The public has tuned the topic out: The Soviets (don't) seem very dangerous anymore, and most of Eastern Europe has skipped out of the Soviet orbit, practically without a shot being fired. That must mean something. Well, let us hope it means that the West has actually ``won'' the Cold War. But if so, the war had more than one loser. Organizations that called for nuclear disarmament are suffering the mortification of contradiction by the Kremlin itself, and now are finding it difficult to keep members and friends. ... Their counterparts at the other end of the ideological spectrum aren't doing so well, either, but at least they have some pleasure of vindication.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: of vindication.
DOC.TEXT: Feb. 20 The Philadelphia Inquirer on cigarette marketing: The last time poor R.J. Reynolds lobbed an easy pitch over the plate, Louis W. Sullivan, the secretary of health and human services, knocked it outta here. The secretary has been benched for some contests the White House does not want any part of, for instance, family planning. But he has been a tiger on tobacco: Within 24 hours of blasting Reynolds for planning to test-market a cigarette called Uptown in Philadelphia, the company dumped the test. It does tend to mess up a test-marketing effort if the secretary of health and human services says your product is fostering a ``culture of cancer'' among the target group _ young blacks, in this particular case. ... Sullivan knew it and Reynolds knew it, so that was that. That brings us to the next inning in this business. The fellas at Reynolds are planning yet another limited rollout of a new product. This time the test market is Houston, where the target is women aged 18 to 20, one of the few segments of the U.S. market where smoking is still on the upswing. Well, we could have told Reynolds what would happen. ... We suppose it's silly to expect a company that's burying folks as often as Reynolds is to fully appreciate the term ``decent interval.'' ... But give the White House points for unleashing the secretary. Having hit a home run with his efforts to protect young blacks, he is apt to rip the cover off given the chance to defend motherhood. You'd have thought the geniuses in the Reynolds promotion department would have considered that.

Feb. 19 The Milwaukee Journal on baseball arbitration: Baseball owners have done to spring training what Buster Douglas did to Mike Tyson. But, while Douglas' boxing victory was not immediately recognized, there is no doubt that spring training _ and the spirit of winter-weary baseball fans _ has taken it on the chin. Eventually, Tyson got up off the floor. Maybe there's a way to revive spring training, too. The owners and players are sparring over _ what else? _ money. The main issue is the complex process by which disputes over player salaries are resolved. Because they couldn't reach an agreement with the players, the owners have refused to allow spring training camps to open. As a result, February is even more bleak than usual. Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent is trying to mediate this dispute, but his efforts seem as futile as they are well-intended. This disagreement seems too tough to yield to ordinary negotiation. The financial stakes are too large _ it is not unheard of for journeyman ballplayers to be paid $1 million a year _ and the differences are too wide. It is time to submit this dispute to binding arbitration. Not only are the two sides deadlocked; time is short. Unless this dispute ends by mid-March, the regular major league baseball season, set to begin in early April, may have to be delayed. That would cost real money and deprive baseball-hungry fans of games they have waited a long winter to see. Because of the nature of this dispute, the arbitrator would have to be a person of unquestioned ability. Such a person will not be found easily or quickly. That's another reason that the search ought to start now.

Feb. 22. Charleston (W. Va.) Daily Mail on coal strike settlement: The means of reaching the agreement were ugly, but everyone in Appalachia must be happy with the new contract between the United Mine Workers and the Pittston Co. The contract seems to ba a model of negotiation. The union got what it wanted most and company managers got what they wanted most. For union members, this means fully funded medical and pension benefits, improved safety requirements, single-employer status and wage increases that over a three-year period will be 15 cents an hour higher than the industry average. For company managers, this means flexibility in work schedules and a reduction in the amount of money it contributes to the 1950 pension fund. As for the general public, this contract agreement means an end to the violence and the reopening of all public highways. That's not much, but that's about as well as innocent bystanders usually fare in these deals. Was it worth it? Pittston's profits fell $63 million last year to less than $4 million. The 1,700 strikers went without paychecks for 10 months _ losses they will never recoup. West Virginia lost whatever claim it had to being a safe place to do business. The public footed the bill of sending troopers and U.S. marshals to the coalfields. But perhaps everyone has learned something, and the hope is that future negotiations will be less violent _ and less costly both to the participants and the spectators.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Officials To Review 1982 Coors Groundwater Contamination
DOC.TEXT: Eight years after Adolph Coors Co. discovered waste solvents in two springs beneath its brewery, public disclosure of the problem has led to a state and federal review. ``We have no evidence to indicate there is a public health problem,'' Dr. Tom Vernon, executive director of the state health department, said Tuesday. But officials said state and federal agencies would investigate how Coors dealt with the problem and whether environmental laws were being met. ``I'm confident that there were no levels of these chemicals in the beer,'' Coors Brewing Co. president Peter Coors said. The brewery, which markets its beer as being made of pure Rocky Mountain spring water, said it discovered in 1982 that the waste solvents had leaked from a corroded sewer pipe into the ground and reached two of Coors' 40 springs. Coors said the company immediately began pumping water from the springs to reduce the contamination level, and removed the affected springs from its water collection system. Coors also rebuilt sewer lines and hired contractors to remove solvent traces from the soil. An anonymous tipster told the state health department about the problem in June 1988, but it was not disclosed publicly until a recent report by KMGH-TV. Theodore Halaby, a Denver lawyer hired by Coors to conduct an independent investigation after the television report, said the chemicals found in the groundwater, including cancer-causing tetrachloroethylene, never exceeded limits suggested by the National Academy of Sciences. There were no applicable federal or state standards for the substances at the time, he said. Halaby said Coors should have notified the health department when it learned of the problems. Vernon said the health department has asked Coors to supply documentation of its efforts to correct the solvent leak. He said the U.S. Food and Drug Administration would be consulted about Coors' claim that no beer was made with the contaminated water. ``We commend Coors for taking the initiative in beginning this investigation,'' said Vernon.

DOC.HEAD: 40-Year-Old Bomb Discovered Under Hotel
DOC.TEXT: An army unit has safely recovered a live bomb that had been buried under a hotel in the coastal city of Ningbo since 1949, a Shanghai newspaper said. The Shanghai Daily said in its Tuesday edition that an army demolition crew found the 330-pound, 3-foot-long bomb under the Jiangbei Dongya Hotel. It was thought the bomb was dropped in an air raid by Nationalist forces in July or August 1949, shortly before the Communists triumphed in the civil war and the Nationalists fled to Taiwan. People who remembered the raid said the bomb entered through a second floor window, crashed through the floor and lodged itself under the hotel without going off. Several hundred thousand people have slept above the bomb since then. However, when the hotel was razed recently for rebuilding, older staff members remembered the bomb and warned that construction pile drivers might set it off. A construction worker discovered the bomb Feb. 6 and the army engineers safely removed and detonated it.

DOC.HEAD: Charges Filed Against Russian Nationalist Group
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors have launched criminal proceedings against Pamyat, a Russian nationalist group that has been accused of anti-Semitic actions, a newspaper reported Wednesday. Jewish groups have been demanding for years that Pamyat, a loosely knit organization with affiliates nationwide, be prosecuted for provocations against Jews. Literaturnaya Gazeta, a literary weekly, said Moscow prosecutors are pursuing charges against Pamyat of ``inciting national and racial hatred and strife.'' According to the newspaper, Pamyat was charged because of a statement published in another newspaper calling for a campaign to ``de-Zionize'' the country. According to the report, the Pamyat statement said, ``Jews and their relatives must not be allowed to defend dissertations, to acquire knowledge and get academic titles, to join the Soviet Communist Party ... to be elected to local governing councils, must not be appointed to leading party, government and other posts.'' The report called Pamyat a chauvanistic group and praised the prosecutor's office because it ``realized the danger and unlawfulness of such extremist actions.'' Many of the thousands of Soviet Jews emigrating to the West say they are doing so in part because of a reported rise in anti-Semitism. The Soviet press has responded to the reports recently by carrying statements from government agencies condemning people who fan inter-ethnic strife and promising to investigate.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Forces Exchange Sniper Fire in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Rival forces exchanged sniper fire in the embattled Christian enclave Wednesday and stockpiled weapons and ammunition in case their latest cease-fire collapses. Despite the occasional crackle of snipers' bullets, scores of people abandoned their homes and sought refuge in safer, Moslem areas. Police said one person was killed and five people, including a 6-year-old boy, were wounded by sniper fire between Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia and Gen. Michel Aoun's troops in east Beirut and the northern suburbs. A police spokesman said the intermittent exchanges continued all day despite the cease-fire, which went into effect Saturday in an effort to halt the intra-Christian power struggle for control of the 310-square-mile enclave. It was the 12th cease-fire since fighting broke out Jan. 30. Geagea has refused Aoun's demand that he disband the Lebanese Forces, the largest Christian militia in Lebanon. By police count, at least 673 people have been killed and 1,877 wounded in the worst intra-Christian fight in Lebanon's nearly 15-year-old civil war. Aoun's command said at least 97 soldiers have been killed. A military source close to Geagea's command said the Christian militia has a new plan to thwart expected efforts by Aoun to storm through its isolated pockets of resistance in east Beirut. The plan aims at defending the militia's main stronghold and powerbase in the Christian hinterland of Kesrouan, north of Beirut, said the source, who refused to be further identified.
