It also outlines a major tank-led attack by Geagea's men against the rear of Aoun's troops if the general tries to penetrate the militia's stronghold in east Beirut and retake Beirut's port to secure maritime supply lines. Aoun lost the port in the early days of the fighting. ``If clashes break out anew, it will be a tough, crushing battle throughout the Christian enclave,'' the source said. About one-third of Geagea's 6,000 militiamen were deployed in east Beirut defending the city's harbor, the adjoining hilltop district of Ashrafiyeh and their war council headquarters at Karantina, the source said. About 300 other militiamen have been deployed in the Lebanese Forces' other Beirut pocket of Nabaa north of Ashrafiyeh. Lebanese Forces fighters, with nearly 15 years' experience in street battles, ``are waiting for Aoun's army in the narrow alleys of Ashrafiyeh, which has become a huge garrison,'' the source said. The major part of Geagea's militia, according to the source, was entrenched along the eastern and southern flanks of the Kesrouan province, separated from Aoun's lines by a no-man's land of just a few hundred yards. The militia force in Kesrouan is backed by Soviet-designed T-54 and T-55 tanks, a variety of armored personnel carriers and a dozen U.S.-made M-48 tanks gained from Aoun's 19,000 troops in previous battles, the source said. He said Geagea also has upgraded his firepower in Kesrouan by 120 truck-mounted multibarreled rocket launchers brought out of weapons depots. The Soviet-designed launchers, capable of firing 40 projectiles a minute, were obtained by the militia from Iraq more than a year ago. The Christian militia also called up some of its 20,000 reservists and assigned them to non-combat duties, the source added. The police spokesman also confirmed that both sides have been ``heavily rearming and reorganizing their forces. They are preparing for war.'' He said Aoun's command was reorganizing its lines in east Beirut and the Metin mountains northeast of the capital, which overlook the Kesrouan province. The army also stockpiled ammunition, especially tank cannon and howitzer rounds in mountain depots in the Metn region, the police spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Refinery Workers Die in Blaze at Petroleum Gas Loading Station
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CORRECT spelling of liquefied and UPDATE with Amoco response. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `She said...'
DOC.TEXT: A fire inspector said Amoco Oil Co. officials failed to keep authorities informed about a refinery fire that killed two workers at a liquefied petroleum gas loading station. Amoco fire brigades controlled Tuesday's fire effectively, preventing the blaze from spreading to 500,000 gallon petroleum storage tanks, said Hammond chief fire inspector James Walsko. But Amoco failed to keep Hammond and Whiting officials informed, establishing emergency headquarters separate from posts set up by the cities' officials, Walsko said. The firefighters' decision to evacuate about 100 residents and plan for a greater emergency was made largely in an information blackout, he said. The city fire department learned of the blaze only when a firefighter saw smoke in the sky and an Amoco official called the city environmental protection office, Walsko said. Amoco spokeswoman Lisa Houghton said the company called local authorities in Whiting, Hammond and East Chicago, the communities adjacent to the refinery, within minutes of learning about the fire. Amoco is willing to talk with police and fire officials about improving coordination, she said. ``We will seriously consider all of their suggestions,'' she said. She said Tuesday that the fire broke out during the morning in a loading area about a mile from the main refinery building and a half-mile from the storage area. The state fire marshal's office, city investigators and Amoco are investigating its cause. Killed in the fire were Delphin Flores, 40, of East Chicago, and Rich Misiolek, 40, of Crown Point, said Lake County coroner Dr. Daniel Thomas. Three tanker truck drivers remained hospitalized in fair condition today. The massive refinery stretches across sections of Whiting and Hammond in a heavily industrialized and populated corridor of northwest Indiana. The accident was the worst at the refinery since an October 1988 explosion at an asphalt plant that killed three workers and seriously injured a fourth.

DOC.HEAD: Military Ruler Takes King's Powers
DOC.TEXT: The military ruler of this southern African country stripped King Moshoeshoe II of his powers Wednesday and said the military council would rule without him for the time being. Since taking power in a January 1986 coup, Maj. Gen. Justin Lekhanya and his military council have said they were governing the country in consultation with the king, while outlawing all political activity. On Monday, Lekhanya ordered the army to detain three members of the military council who were regarded as allies of the king. Two of them were royal cousins. After the king refused on Wednesday to officiate at a palace swearing-in ceremony for replacement council members, Lekhanya said he understood the king's feelings of family ties, but the military council was not a family matter. ``His majesty's powers, for the time being, will be vested in me ... with the assistance of the military council,'' Lekhanya said. He said the king would remain head of state. The army, which had been deployed around the palace and the military headquarters on Monday, remained in barracks Wednesday. But witnesses said they saw members of the Royal Lesotho Defense Force taking other soldiers out of their homes to detention. Witnesses said some soldiers were taking others out of cars and leading them away. Lekhanya did not refer to any new detentions, but he said in his statement that the army belonged to the state, not to the king. Lesotho, a country of 1.6 million people, is completely surrounded by South Africa. There have been reports of turmoil within the government since revelations that Lekhanya fatally shot a college student in December 1988. At an inquest seven months later, Lekhanya said he shot the student, George Ramone, after the man tried to rape a woman and fled. The inquest ruled the shooting was justifiable homicide.

DOC.HEAD: Hun Sen, Sihanouk Meet; Guerrillas Report Government Offensive
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's premier and its former ruler, who now leads resistance forces, conferred Wednesday and the guerrilla radio reported government attacks in newly captured territory. The radio said government forces attacked Wednesday, trying to recapture a base in the strategic Sisophon district of northwestern Cambodia, where the guerrillas have advanced in recent weeks. Premier Hun Sen and Prince Norodom Sihanouk met over lunch in Bangkok and for several hours. Sihanouk leads an alliance of two non-Communist groups and the Khmer Rouge, strongest guerrilla faction. Hun Sen and Sihanouk issued a vaguely worded statement saying a U.N. role ``at appropriate levels in Cambodia is essential and should be encouraged,'' but did not specify how completely they accepted a proposal for the United Nations to administer the country pending elections. It said they wanted a ``supreme national body'' that would symbolize unity, but gave no details. The statement said they discussed issues impeding a settlement and felt ``there is now a better understanding of the issues involved that may lead'' to a settlemnt. International pressure has grown for a U.N. role in Cambodia to avoid a return to power by the Khmer Rouge, whose brutal rule in the 1970s cost more than 1 million lives through execution, starvation or death from disease. Vietnam invaded in December 1978, ousting the Khmer Rouge. Hun Sen and Sihanouk, who agreed to meet again later, expressed hope that a meeting of all parties next week in Jakarta, Indonesia, will open the way for resuming the Paris conference on Cambodia. The conference broke up in August after little progress. Guerrilla radio said the attack in the Sisophon district was on a base of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front led by Sonn Sann. ``Fierce fighting is going on'' for Kakaoh village, it said. Soldiers captured another Sonn Sann base Tuesday in the same district, but the guerrillas regained it later, the radio reported. Resistance officials and Thai military officers said government forces also attacked near Svay Chek, a gateway to Sisophon, on Monday and Tuesday. The guerrillas seized Svay Chek on Dec. 5. About 1,300 soldiers attacked guerrilla defense lines 6 to 12 miles from Svay Chek, said a statement from Ok Serei Sopheak, a spokesman for the Sonn Sann high command said. He said they were supported ``far more than ever before'' by rocket launchers, heavy artillery and at least six Soviet-made T-54 tanks. The high command claimed 49 soldiers were killed and 20 wounded, and the guerrillas lost only one killed and eight wounded. It said the guerrillas held Svay Chek. A Thai newspaper, The Nation, quoted Gen. Tea Banh, the Cambodian defense minister, as saying the guerrillas had received greater supplies of more sophisticated weapons since Vietnames troops withdrew at the end of September 1979. Tea Banh said they were being supplied by China and the United States via the Thai military, the paper reported. He said the guerrillas had advanced less than 40 miles from the Thai burder, and ``we left several towns to the resistance forces because we believed they were not worth defending.'' Hun Sen, whose government was installed by Vietnam, is to meet in Jakarta next week with guerrilla leaders and representatives of France, Vietnam, Indonesia and other Southeast Asian nations. The talks are expected to focus on Australia's proposal for an interim U.N. interim administration in Cambodia. Sihanouk will not attend the Jakarta talks. His spokesman in Bangkok said the prince would go to northwestern Cambodia on Friday and live in ``liberated'' areas until his entire country was free.

DOC.HEAD: Cholera Death Toll At 80
DOC.TEXT: Cholera has killed at least 80 people out of 906 reported cases in the Zambian capital and surrounding areas, it was reported Wednesday. The epidemic broke out in Lusaka this month, health ministry officials said. A World Health Organization spokesman, Dr. Eric van Praag, said the disease was being contained. ``There are cases still coming in from rural villages but the disease has definitely declined,'' he said. ``The situation is being contained and a smaller number of cases are appearing every day.'' The government, he said, was spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on controlling cholera and was improving Lusaka's inadequate sanitation system. Only a third of the capital's homes have sewage systems, while others have open-air pit latrines. Bad sanitation, heavy seasonal rains, erratic garbage collection services and overcrowding of slums all contributed to the cholera outbreak, officials said. Health Minister Mavis Muyundu has ordered restrictions on public gatherings, including funerals, weddings and sports events to halt the spread of cholera from the western suburbs and central areas of the city. Street vendors were ordered not to sell foodtuffs, and city dwellers were advised to boil drinking water. Cholera is an intestinal disease spread mainly by poor hygiene and and sanitation. City authorities have said Lusaka has less than six garbage trucks on the road out of fleet of about 60 vehicles several years ago and admitted they did not have the facilities to clear open garbage dumps that proliferated in residential areas.

DOC.HEAD: Volcano Spouts Off After Oil Terminal Shut Down
DOC.TEXT: Redoubt Volcano erupted with a plume of gritty volcanic ash again early today, just hours after the Coast Guard ordered the shutdown of an oil terminal along the Drift River because of volcanic hazards. Just after midnight, the 10,197-foot peak spewed a cloud of abrasive ash that headed eastward toward the Kenai Peninsula. Moderate ashfall was reported in Nikiski and North Kenai. Redoubt Volcano last erupted Feb. 15, sending a jet of ash and steam nearly seven miles high and scattering grit that led authorities to cancel classes for 2,000 students. The mountain was quiet for 25 years until a series of eruptions began in mid-December, disrupting air travel in and out of Anchorage during the holidays. Ash clogged all four engines of a KLM Boeing 747 on Dec. 15, and the aircraft fell more than two miles before the engines could be restarted. The Coast Guard order cited the threat to oil storage tanks posed by flooding after recent eruptions of the volcano, said Bill Lamoreaux, regional supervisor of the state Department of Environmental Conservation. Volcanic activity can melt snow and ice on Redoubt, leading to flooding downstream on Drift River. Previous eruptions have flooded the river, sending water coursing through the terminal and creating the potential for an oil leak in Cook Inlet. Last weeks' eruption partially flooded the containment area of one empty tank at the terminal and forced the evacuation of workers.

DOC.HEAD: Firm Paid Out Millions in Bonuses Weeks Before Bankruptcy Filing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Drexel confirming bonuses, DELETES newspaper attribution. No pickup. A version also moving on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. paid bonuses of between $300 million and $350 million in the weeks before its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection, officials confirmed today. A Drexel spokesman said the payments were determined in December and were not made with any knowledge that the firm would go out of business. Drexel's parent company filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors last week. ``We did what we believed we had to do competitively, and it was within both the norms of what the longstanding practice had been at the firm and within the norms of the industry,'' spokesman Steven Anreder said. Several published reports today said some individual bonuses at Drexel exceeded $10 million. Year-end bonuses are standard practice on Wall Street, although Drexel has been known for paying huge bonuses. Anreder said the size of most of the bonuses was determined in December, while others were committed to early in 1989. Some bonuses were paid in late December and some in early January, he said. ``If you're not going to pay a competitive level you're not going to have your people,'' Anreder said. ``There was no sense of foreboding here at all,'' he said. ``It was only in the last week and a half that things were difficult, but even then no one thought'' the firm would go under. Drexel's parent, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., sought bankruptcy court protection after defaulting on $100 million in short-term debt. Representatives of Drexel's creditors said they would examine the bonus payments to determine if they could be recovered as part of the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. Creditors may face a hurdle in trying to recover any bonuses because Drexel's securities subsidiary, which paid the bonuses, wasn't covered by the parent company's bankruptcy filing.

DOC.HEAD: `Chorus Line' Closing, Longest-Running Broadway Show
DOC.TEXT: ``A Chorus Line,'' the longest-running show in Broadway history, will close March 31 because of dwindling ticket sales, producer Joseph Papp said today. The show will have been performed 6,104 times when it closes. Papp said weekly operating costs at the Shubert Theater are $160,000 and the show's average weekly income this year has been $122,825. ``A Chorus Line'' tells the stories of a group of dancers competing for jobs. The Michael Bennett musical won a Pulitzer Prize in 1976 and its profits helped fund Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival. Papp said the show might be extended about two weeks if the closing announcment generates ticket sales.

DOC.HEAD: Students Boycott Classes, Opposition Leaders Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf with students dispersing.
DOC.TEXT: The government has arrested seven political opponents, an opposition party said Wednesday, as protesting university students boycotted classes and armed soldiers patrolled the campus. The clandestine Ivorian People's Front said seven of its members were arrested between Friday and Monday, apparently in connection with the distribution of leaflets urging the ouster of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny. Students also have demanded the downfall of the conservative leader, but it was not clear whether the demonstrations were linked to the arrests. In the past, the government has accused the Ivorian Popular Front and its leader, Laurent Gbagbo, of inciting student unrest. In a statement Wednesday, Gbagbo asked the people ``to mobilize for the conquest, to win a multiparty state, justice and dignity.'' He challenged Houphouet-Boigny's Democratic Party, the only legal political group in this West African nation, to ``the only debate that matters today: peaceful transition to democracy.'' Students interviewed Wednesday said they were angered by continuing police harassment of opposition politicians. ``But this is just one sign of the lack of freedom and lack of democracy that we are protesting,'' said Gregoire Tape, a law student and member of the year-old National Ivorian Commission for the Defense of Human Rights. Soldiers with rifles roamed the campus in the luxury suburb of Cocody and police watched a university residence in the poor suburb of Yopougon, three miles away. Between 200 and 300 students gathered on the main campus and soldiers did not interfere during a rowdy meeting to discuss strategy. But in Yopougon, police ordered students to stop forming groups. Students said police blocked them from going to the main campus Wednesday, but there was no violence. On Monday night, police and soldiers beat up students and stormed their dormitories after they set two cars ablaze. On Tuesday, they fired tear gas to force demonstrators to disperse. They also charged students at the main campus after the protesters stormed two buses and smashed their windows. There has been no comment from the government about the demonstrations or the arrests, although Houphouet-Boigny was said to be chairing a weekly Cabinet meeting Wednesday where the events may be discussed. Students say they are protesting the opulent lifestyles of government leaders while the country struggles through a recession that has brought salary cuts, unemployment and declining living standards. The students dispersed peacefully later Wednesday after presenting demands to Toure Bakary, the university rector. They requested a meeting with Houphouet-Boigny, an end to police and troop harassment, and the dissolution of a student body that effectively is a youth league of the ruling party.

DOC.HEAD: France to Sell Pakistan a Nuclear Power Plant
DOC.TEXT: France on Wednesday ended a 14-year ban on sales of nuclear energy to Pakistan, announcing a commercial venture that would set up a nuclear power plant in the country. ``France pledges to authorize French industrial enterprises ... to make rapidly a technical and commercial offer for the sale of a nuclear power plant to Pakistan,'' President Francois Mitterrand told a news conference during a four-day visit. Mitterrand did not say how big the plant would be. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said a French-supplied plant would be ``open to all international safeguards and monitoring teams.'' Pakistan, however, is not a signatory to the international nuclear non-proliferation treaty and refuses to sign it unless India does. Pakistan must convince Washington each year that it does not have a nuclear weapon before Washington frees millions of dollars in loans. Ms. Bhutto has often said Pakistan does not have a nuclear weapon nor does it want to produce one. ``Pakistan is not trying to enter into a nuclear arms race,'' she said again today, adding that Islamabad has pressed India to sign a regional nuclear weapons test ban. India has refused. Mitterrand's announcement only vaguely referred to a 14-year-old dispute between Pakistan and France over a promised sale of a nuclear reprocessing plant. France reneged on the deal because of U.S. pressure to drop the sale unless Pakistan agreed to sign international nuclear treaties and open its nuclear facilities to international monitoring teams. Pakistan lodged a variety of complaints until a French arbitration board ruled in its favor and ordered Paris to pay a fine. No figure was ever mentioned, but Pakistani media have cited figures ranging from $250 million to $400 million.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Charged in Toddler's Cake Choking Death
DOC.TEXT: A man and woman have been charged with murder for allegedly force-feeding chocolate cake to her 3-year-old daughter until she suffocated. Marjorie Griffin, 24, and Frank Johnson Jr., 46, were indicted Tuesday in the Dec. 21 death of Myra Griffin. Her stomach and throat were stuffed with cake, which blocked her windpipe and nose, Deputy Coroner Chuck Smith said. Police said the mother became angry when the child did not finish her cake and forced the girl to eat it. Johnson was charged because he did nothing to stop it, police said. Griffin and Johnson face life in prison if convicted. They were held without bail Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President's Speech Stirs Ex-Countrymen, Congressmen
With AM-US-Czechoslovakia Bjt
DOC.TEXT: George Volak had to dodge communist bullets when he escaped from Czechoslovakia to Austria. More than two decades later, he drove all night to witness a moment he'd thought could never happen: Vaclav Havel's speech Wednesday to Congress. ``I think he's a great man. I hope he runs for re-election,'' said Volak, of Murfreesboro, Tenn. He and his wife spent 11 hours on the road without even knowing if they would be able to see Havel once they got to Washington. Their risk paid off when Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn, was able to get them tickets. Havel, the shy playwright who moved from prison to Czechoslovakia's presidential castle in a matter of months, demonstrated to the Volaks and hundreds of others in the packed House chamber why he has become his country's beacon of democracy and hope. In a speech unusual for its modesty, metaphors and metaphysics, Havel noted that he had barely two months' experience as president and felt more comfortable in the realm of philosophy. But he went on to advise America's highest office-holders how to do their jobs. ``We still don't know how to put morality ahead of politics, science and economics,'' Havel told his audience of senators, representatives, Cabinet members and diplomats. He urged them to follow their consciences rather than act on behalf of ``my family, my country, my firm, my success.'' Havel, a small blond man dressed in a dark suit and blue-striped tie, read his speech in Czech from a written text, eschewing the TelePrompTers that American politicians favor for the best television appearance. He flashed the victory sign during a long, vociferous welcome and was interrupted two dozen times for cheers and ovations, most often during his calls for peace, morality and a return to the ideals of Lincoln and Jefferson. Some House traditions were broken for the occasion. Czechoslovak officials accompanying Havel brandished cameras and tape recorders, usually forbidden on the House floor. Czech-born film director Milos Forman, now a U.S. citizen, sat with them wearing a red turtleneck instead of the customary dress shirt and tie under his sport jacket. Seated in the last row of the gallery was tennis star Martina Navratilova, now a U.S. citizen. As soon as Havel spoke her native language, she began wiping her eyes and nose with a handkerchief. ``I started crying right away,'' she said later. ``I wish I could make speeches that good.'' Havel, author of numerous plays and books, punctuated his address with poetic images and metaphors. His country, he said, had been ``pinned under a boulder'' by communism. He said Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary were Europe's ``wayward children.'' He called the world's governing systems ``anonymous megamachinery.'' And democracy, he said, is like the horizon _ ``one may approach it ... but it can never be fully attained.'' Volak, 44, was among those who took to the streets during the ``Prague Spring'' of 1968 to protest the Soviet presence in his country. He escaped to Austria soon after, moving to Canada and then the United States. ``When I was crossing the border, they were shooting at me,'' he recalled while waiting for Havel's speech to begin. Volak worked as a construction architect and now owns a campground. He said he and his wife visited Czechoslovakia in December, shortly after the ``velvet revolution'' that ended communist rule. ``I couldn't believe it, especially because it was so peaceful,'' Volak said. ``I met President Havel at that time, except at that time he was not president. He didn't even want to be president.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Brothers Raid Store, One Shot Dead
DOC.TEXT: A storekeeper foiled a holdup by four brothers by shooting to death the driver of the getaway car, and police later charged two of the alleged raiders, one aged 11, with the murder of their brother. The fourth brother, identified as Ed Sid Scott, was still at large and may have been wounded, police spokesman Sgt. Steve Weintraub said Wednesday. Police arrested two suspects, Robert Scott, 23, and the 11-year-old whose name was withheld, and charged them with armed robbery and the felony murder of their 18-year-old brother, Timothy. In Florida, if a participant is killed during the commission of a crime, others involved in the crime can be charged with murder. The cashier at Little Annie's Food Store, Claudette Jones, told police that a young man came into the store at about noon Tuesday, looked around for a while and then left. She said she told her sister-in-law, store owner Betty Jones, that the youth was acting suspiciously, Weintraub said. A few minutes later, the youth and three others returned. One pulled out a sawed-off shotgun, took the money out of the cash register and the four fled, Weintraub said. Betty Jones grabbed a .45-caliber pistol and ran outside after them. As they sped away in a car, she fired several shots, one of which hit Timothy Scott, who was driving, Weintraub said. The car ran off the road and crashed into a house about a half block from the store. Scott died en route to a hospital. Robert Scott and the 11-year-old were arrested about 30 minutes later.

DOC.HEAD: Critics Lambast Social Security's Toll-Free Phone System
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee heard a chorus of complaints Wednesday about Social Security's new toll-free telephone network from critics who said it can take days to get through to operators who sometimes give bad information. Members of Congress and congressional caseworkers told the House Ways and Means subcommittee on Social Security that frustrated constituents report they cannot get through on the toll-free 800-number and no longer can call their local Social Security offices directly. ``It's time now for Social Security to say `We goofed up,''' Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., told the subcommittee. ``This system is nuts.'' The telephone network _ reached by dialing 1-800-2345-SSA _ is staffed from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. across the country, and allows callers to take care of many matters without going into a Social Security office. In most cities, the toll-free number is the only Social Security number listed in the phone book. In January, traditionally a busy month, an estimated 52 percent of calls to Social Security's 800 number were met with busy signals, compared with 14 percent in December, 51 percent in November and 30 percent in October, agency figures show. The telephone network went nationwide last October. ``I applaud efforts by the Social Security Administration to improve productivity, but these efforts must not come at the expense of service to the public,'' said Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich. ``The data and anecdotal evidence ... indicate that the 800 number was not a step forward.'' Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., released a letter to Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King in which he said the problems go deeper than busy signals in that they reflect ``a distressing shift toward a technological form of service delivery, to the detriment of personal contact in the local community.'' Geneva Leasner of Baltimore testified that her Supplemental Security Income benefits were incorrectly cut off for three months after a Social Security operator failed to properly advise her on how to file a timely appeal. ``I had to borrow money from friends just to keep my house,'' she said. A college professor from Connecticut assigned her entire class to call the toll-free number for two days straight and no one got through, said Gerald Martin, a caseworker for Rep. Barbara Kennelly, D-Conn. Several people in western North Dakota who could not get through by phone became so frustrated that they drove more than 100 miles to the nearest Social Security office to get answers, said Gregory Rohde, an aide to Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D. ``Constituents complain about numerous transfers, busy signals and having to listen ad nauseam to a recording that a representative will be available soon,'' Rohde testified. Mrs. King admitted that the system is ``a lot less than perfect,'' but said the program is being improved. She maintainted that, overall, it enhances Social Security's ability to serve the public. ``With teleservice representatives answering incoming calls, our field employees are able to devote greater, uninterrupted time and attention to those who come through their office doors seeking personal assistance,'' she said. The phone network was expected to handle about 250,000 calls a day, but more than 1.5 million people try to get through on peak days. She said operators now are instructed to provide the telephone number for local field offices to people who ask for it. ``I am committed to an 800-number system that delivers high-quality, courteous, person-to-person service as an option and enhancement to the face-to-face service local offices have provided for so many years,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sets GOP Swing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Annenberg in grafs 4-5 pvs, On March
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will travel to New York and California next week for a series of Republican political events, the White House announced Wednesday. Bush will leave Feb. 28 for a Staten Island fund-raising dinner to benefit the congressional campaign of Republican Susan Molinari. He then will fly that evening to San Francisco to stump for Sen. Pete Wilson, who is running for governor of California. He will spend the night in Los Angeles, where the following day he will address a fund-raising event for the Republican Governors' Association and a centennial gala for the California Chamber of Commerce, said White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater. On March 2, Bush travels to Palm Springs where he will spend the weekend as a guest at the lavish estate of former publisher Walter Annenberg. Bush has stayed previously with Annenberg, who is a close friend of former President Reagan and hosts Reagan every New Year's Eve. Fitzwater said there are no plans for Reagan, who now lives in Los Angeles, to join Bush during the Palm Springs weekend.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Weather, Commander's Illness Delays Space Shuttle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with launch delayed by weather condition, astronaut's illness, edits to conform. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: NASA today delayed the launch of the space shuttle Atlantis' secret military mission for at least 24 hours because of the commander's health and weather conditions. A brief statement said the commander, Navy Capt. John O. Creighton, had ``developed an upper respiratory tract infection. In addition, the launch weather is not predicted to be favorable.'' NASA said it would decide Thursday whether to try the launch at the Kennedy Space Center on Friday. The space agency said a cold front was expected to move through the area tonight, bringing with it clouds, rain and high winds at the expected early Thursday launch time. The weather forecast had improved during the day, with the odds for launch increasing from 30 to 50 percent. But that was not acceptable, and shuttle managers decided to call off the flight in early afternoon before technicians began pumping half a million gallons of propellant into Atlantis' fuel tank. Officials had been anxious to launch Atlantis on Thursday because long-range forecasts call for even worse conditions Friday and Saturday. Early today, a service structure which provides workers access to the space shuttle as it sits on the launch pad was rotated away from Atlantis and parked to one side. ``They wouldn't do that if they had a problem,'' said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. Atlantis astronauts took advantage of a slight break in the weather today to fly practice landings in the space shuttle training craft. They spent the rest of he morning in briefings and went to bed at noon. The early bedtime for the five-member shuttle crew is designed to shift their sleep cycle to the rest schedule they'll follow in orbit. In addition to Creighton, Atlantis' crew includes the pilot, Air Force Col. John H. Casper and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Lt. Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. Because of Atlantis' classified military cargo, NASA officials did not announce the precise launch time, saying only that it would come between midnight and 4 a.m. Thursday. The mission is the sixth of 34 shuttle flights to be dedicated to a classified, military cargo. Once Atlantis is in orbit, communications to the space shuttle will be blacked out to the public until just an hour before the craft returns to Earth. The flight is expected to last four days. According to sources, Atlantis' payload is a 37,300-pound, $500 million spy satellite known by the code name AFP-731. The device is said to be able to take high-resolution reconnaissance photos and to listen in on military and diplomatic communications around the world. Placed into a high inclination orbit, the spy satellite will pass over most of the Soviet Union, including northern areas not previously probed by shuttle-launched satellites. This orbit may be important in verifying Soviet compliance with disarmament agreements now being negotiated between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. The Soviets have spy satellites of their own to assure U.S. compliance.

DOC.HEAD: Foundation Gives $27 Million to 15 Cities
DOC.TEXT: The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation on Wednesday announced grants to 15 cities in a $27 million program designed to fight demand for illegal drugs and alcohol. The foundation, based in Princeton, N.J., said the program is the largest private effort ever to help local communities fight drug and alcohol abuse. The communities selected will receive one- or two-year planning grants of $100,000 per year, and eight of them will be selected for five-year, $3 million grants to carry out their strategies, the foundation said. The 15 cities are Charlotte, N.C.; Columbia, S.C.; Gallup, N.M.; Kansas City, Mo.; Little Rock, Ark.; Milwaukee; Newark, N.J.; New Haven, Conn.; Oakland, Calif.; San Antonio; San Jose, Calif.; Santa Barbara, Calif.; Vallejo, Calif.; Washington and Worcester, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Cavazos Sticks With Troubled Loan Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Cavazos thruout
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos said Wednesday he would continue supporting federally guaranteed loans for students in private vocational and technical schools despite their default rate of 37 percent. ``I want to make it clear that in no way does the Secretary of Education advocate stepping away from support of guaranteed student loan programs for proprietary schools,'' Cavazos told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee. Cavazos added, however, that the administration was determined to crack down on institutions with high rates of default. Proprietary schools are privately owned institutions which teach trades such as electronics or auto repair. Overall, counting loans for regular college attendance, there were 1.9 million defaults in the guaranteed student loan program overall in 1989, and the projected number this year is 2 million. Cavazos affirmed that ``I am a very strong advocate of vocational and technical education.'' He said ``we have excellent, first-rate'' associate degree programs in junior colleges, and ``there are also some very fine proprietary schools.'' Cavazos was testifying on President Bush's eductional budget request of $25 billion, up more than $500 million from the 1990 budget. He noted the federal contribution is about 6 percent of the nation's total expenditure of $353 billion for the current school year. He stressed state and local responsibilities for funding education, saying the federal role has evolved into one of guidance and evaluation. ``We have successfully changed the focus of the national debate on education from inputs to outputs, from resources to results,'' he said. Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, said the federal financial share just a decade ago was 9 percent, and complained that ``The administration's rhetoric ignores the fact that the federal government is the major player in many critical areas of education.'' Harkin, chairman of the education subcommittee, said ``Seventy-five percent of all the student aid available to college students in this country is derived from the federal government, and in the area of rehabilitation services, it closely approaches 100 percent.'' Harkin and others criticized the budget proposal as well for relying on unrealistically low projected interest costs for the guaranteed loan program. ``Unfortunately, almost all of the new initiatives are paid for by a dramatic reduction in guaranteed student loan costs, which result from the administration's rosy interest projections,'' Harkin said. Cavazos said the lower interest rates, combined with reductions in lower priority programs, will provide $1.8 billion for programs.

DOC.HEAD: C-17: Long on Cost, Short on Range
DOC.TEXT: The military's transportation chief acknowledged Wednesday that the Douglas C-17 transport plane has soared $4 billion over budget while coming up 90 miles short of its specified range of 2,400 miles. Gen. Hansford T. Johnson also told the Senate Armed Services Committee that production of the 210 Air Force planes, now estimated to cost $41 billion, is six months behind schedule, with the first model now expected in June of next year. The Pentagon currently is reviewing whether to proceed with full production in light of the lessening Soviet threat overseas and budget constraints at home. The Bush administration, in its $292 billion defense budget for fiscal 1991, is asking for six C-17 transport aircraft. Requests in later years include 12 planes in fiscal 1992 and 25 the following year. Members of the Senate panel, including its chairman, Sam Nunn, D-Ga., and conservative Republican Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming, expressed concerns about the plane's mounting cost and its range limitations. ``I would like to see ... what can be done with the purchase of off-the-shelf programs versus the amount of money that we might be able to spend on other military programs,'' Wallop told Johnson. The commander said the military uses commercial airplanes for carrying passengers and transporting cargo, but those planes and the aging fleet of C-141s cannot do the job of the C-17. ``I understand that, but I'm saying that these airplanes ... are already in production and they're not $37 billion away,'' Wallop said. Johnson said the $4 billion increase was triggered by modifications the Congress and Pentagon demanded in fiscal 1990, stretchouts in the program, and inflation. The commander argued that the military is using ``all the commercial (transport) we believe we can.'' ``We need the C-17 for three reasons at least,'' Johnson said. ``One, is the overall capacity. Two, ... we need a vehicle to deliver forward from the battle area. Third, ... the C-141 is becoming a very tired aircraft.'' The current fleet includes 234 C-141 aircraft, which are about 25 years old, or three times as old as most commercial jets, Johnson said. That comment prompted Nunn to note that life of a plane is determined by its flying hours, not its age. On the range issue, Nunn noted that Pentagon specifications call for the C-17 to carry 167,000 pounds a distance of 2,400 nautical miles, but the Air Force and the contractor, Douglas Co., agree that the plane cannot fly from Dover Air Force Base in Delaware to the Azores, a major refueling base in the mid-Atlantic, a flight which is exactly that distance. ``It seems to me that's a serious problem,'' the senator said. Johnson conceded that the Pentagon added new, heavier equipment on the aircraft and if the Air Force used a typical type of fuel, the plane would come up 78 nautical miles short, or 90 statute miles. But the commander said if a new, higher-energy fuel is used, the Air Force would go back to its original specifications. ``You're saying you had unrealistic specifications then,'' Nunn said. ``No sir,'' Johnson answered. ``What's the purpose of the specifications if you don't intend to meet the specifications?'' Nunn interrupted. ``You're basically saying the specifications weren't needed, you overspecified.'' Johnson said the specifications were part of the contract between the Douglas Co., which is assembling the plane in Long Beach, Calif., and the government, and if the contractor fails to meet the arrangement, it will cost them financially. The commander also argued that the problems exist only on paper since the first plane won't be ready until June 1991, six months after the target date. ``We're confident that we can manage that weight to give us the specifications, to meet the specifications, but right now, you're correct, they're 78 (nautical) miles short,'' Johnson said.

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian-Americans to Monitor Election
DOC.TEXT: A team of three Ukrainian-Americans plans to monitor the fairness of the March 4 election in the Ukraine on behalf a politically conservative U.S. foundation, it was announced Wednesday. ``Our aim is to determine whether you could call this a free and fair election,'' said Askold Lozynsky, a New York attorney, who will be accompanied by his wife, Ronya, and Borys Potapenko of the Ukrainian Cultural Center in Detroit. Lozynsky said the group will form a moniotoring network, mostly in the cities of Kiev and Ldiv, and will distribute a survey to some 40 opposition candidates, political organizers and voters to form at least a limited basis for evaluating the election process. The group's efforts are sponsored by the Free Congress Foundation whose president, Paul Weyrich, has been involved in offering campaign training to Soviet political opposition leaders. Lozynsky said his monitoring team proceeds with an admitted bias. ``We are not pro-Soviet,'' he said. ``We are anti-Soviet and anti-communist. We support democracy.'' Other international observers are attempting to monitor elections in the Ukraine and throughout the Soviet Union, but Weyrich said some are experiencing difficulty in obtaining visas.

DOC.HEAD: US Says Sandinista Intimidation of Opposition Continues
With AM-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Wednesday that Nicaraguan authorities have been routinely threatening opposition party activists as part of a campaign to influence national elections set for this Sunday. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that UNO sympathizers have told the U.S. Embassy in Managua that security agents of the leftist government have threatened them with ``loss of job or land, bodily harm or even death.'' The embassy has been told that supporters of opposition candidate Violeta Chamorro who are members of the armed forces have had their voter registration cards confiscated. According to one deserter, 100 soldiers in his unit were ordered to turn in their cards because of questions about their political reliability, Ms. Tutwiler said. Ms. Tutwiler said opposition poll watchers in the Boaco area and in other regions ``have been threatened not to show up on election day. As the international observers have emphasized, poll watcher presence is a critical aspect of a free and fair election,'' she said. Ms. Chamorro, who is receiving financial backing from the U.S. government, is challenging President Daniel Ortega in Sunday's election.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Man Claims He Had to Break Law
DOC.TEXT: A homeless man who said he broke into an abandoned apartment house to escape bitter cold pleaded innocent to trespassing Wednesday on grounds that he was justified in breaking the law. The defendant, who gave his name as Benjamin Franklin Pierce, 44, was arrested in 7-degree weather Dec. 27. The justification defense maintains that a person may break the law to prevent worse consequences. Pierce could get up to 90 days in jail if convicted. City Judge Roy Tepper said he will hear pre-trial motions March 22. ``It's the first time we know of that a homeless person claims he was legally justified to break the law in order to seek shelter in a life-threatening situation,'' said Douglas Colbert, a Hofstra University law professor helping in Pierce's defense. Pierce broke into a building that had been vacant for two years to save himself from freezing, Colbert said. ``Any reasonably educated person would have done the same thing,'' he said. Colbert said Long Beach provides neither shelter nor transportation to shelter for its homeless. Pierce, a Vietnam veteran, has worked mainly as a painter and has been homeless for a couple of years since losing his apartment to gentrification, Colbert said.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Offers Defense Against U.S. Criticism of Rights Record
With AM-Rights Report, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials said Wednesday that a U.S. report alleging human rights violations in the occupied lands was unfair because it did not take into account the violence authorities face from Palestinians. Col. Renaan Gissin, the army's deputy spokesman, said any human rights abuses were in response to violent incidents related to the 26-month-old Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``I agree that in the process of this excruciating struggle, there may be violations of human rights. I disagree that there is an intentional policy of violating human rights in the territories or elsewhere,'' Gissin said. Moshe Raviv, the Foreign Ministry's deputy director general for information, said, ``I believe Israel is receiving criticism without people understanding that our policy is a reactive policy, reactive to violence.'' ``The criticism in the report emanated from the necessary steps that the Israeli Defense Forces must undertake in order to react to terror and violence'' he told a briefing on the annual U.S. State Department report on human rights. The report, released Wednesday in Washington, expressed ``deep concern'' about the human rights situation in the occupied territories. It said Israeli soldiers often did not follow rules intended to protect lives and that many unjust killings by soldiers went unpunished. The report noted that new rules allow soldiers to shoot directly at fleeing masked men, even if they are unarmed, after a warning shot has been fired in the air. Earlier, soldiers could fire only if their lives were in danger or at a felony suspect. Raviv said Israel ``has no problem in principle ... with the reliability of the report,'' but at another point he said ``the report has been inundated by false claims, false reports that sometimes cannot be verified.'' Gissin said the Israeli army itself has trouble verifying facts on the weekly average of 250 violent incidents in the occupied territories. He denied the report's allegations that 10 Palestinians died of beatings in custody or while soldiers searched their homes. Gissin said the figure was four, including two who died in custody. According to an Associated Press count, Israeli soldiers or civilians have killed 658 Palestinians since the uprising began in December 1987. The reference to the beating deaths was in a section of the U.S. report quoting allegations of torture. Gissin said in response: ``There is no policy of torture.'' The State Department repeated past U.S. criticisms on the demolition and sealing of homes of Palestinians suspected of being active in the uprising. Soldiers have destroyed 268 Palestinian homes and sealed 147 others during the uprising, according to the army. Two more homes were sealed Wednesday, the army announced. Both were in the West Bank city of Nablus, and the residents were jailed on suspicion of distributing uprising leaflets and taking part in violent attacks on alleged collaborators, the army said. Arab reporters said a total of 13 people lived in the two homes.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Writes Thatcher but Doesn't Mention Lifting of British Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material thruout
DOC.TEXT: President Bush wrote British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher a ``positive'' letter discussing negotiations between the South African government and the nation's black majority, but did not discuss her decision to lift sanctions against South Africa, the White House said Wednesday. Britain has announced it will lift its ban on British investment in South Africa and end its attempts to discourage Britons from traveling there. Bush, while indicating he is willing to review the U.S. sanctions in light of positive moves by the white minority government of South African President F.W. de Klerk, has proposed no change in the sanctions. On Capitol Hill, meanwhile, House Democrats indicated they would press ahead with move to tighten the sanctions. Bush's letter last week to Thatcher spoke approvingly of de Klerk's leadership and said the South African government was serious about negotiations with blacks, White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater told reporters. Bush wrote of steps he has taken in hopes of ending racial violence in South Africa, such as telephoning de Klerk and recently released political prisoner Nelson Mandela, leader of the African National Congress. ``At the same time, the president took the opportunity to state that the actions of the South African government do not yet fulfill the conditions required by U.S. law to remove sanctions,'' Fitzwater said. Under the sanctions imposed by Congress in 1986, South Africa would have to fulfill several conditions before the United States would lift the sanctions. Among the conditions are the freeing of all political prisoners and the beginning of good-faith negotiations between the government and blacks. ``The president reiterated that once the criteria set by U.S. law has been met, he will consult with the Congress,'' on whether to remove the sanctions, Fitzwater said. Asked whether Bush had encouraged the Thatcher government's decision to end British sanctions, Fitzwater said of Bush's letter: ``The president's response was positive in the sense of encouraging a move toward negotiations in South Africa and taking those general steps that could be helpful. He did not comment on any individual actions in that process.'' Asked specifically if Bush in his letter approved of Britain's lifting of the ban on new investments, Fitzwater replied that Bush ``was positive on the overall encouragement of progress in South Africa.'' Britain has been criticized by its European Community allies for its unilateral decision to ease sanctions against the Pretoria government. The EC contends that de Klerk's freeing of Mandela and lifting of a ban on political opposition groups do not go far enough to warrant lifting sanctions. On Capitol Hill, Walter Fauntroy, the non-voting Democratic delegate from the District of Columbia, said there is no guarantee that de Klerk will ``bite the bullet'' and make fundamental changes ``unless pressure is maintained and intensified.'' Fauntroy, chairman of a House Banking subcommittee, is pushing for the adoption of a measure to prevent banks from rescheduling $8 billion in debt held by American banks. Anti-apartheid activists in Congress are upset that banks have allowed South Africa to stretch out some of its debt repayment until 1993. The repayment is on loans made before 1985. Rodney Wagner of Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. in New York told a joint hearing of the Banking subcommittee and a Foreign Affairs subcommittee that banks oppose apartheid. But he said the proposed legislation is economically unfeasible because South Africa doesn't have the money to repay 20 percent of its principle each year.

DOC.HEAD: Rescuers Resume Search for Bodies in Convict Lake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with search resuming, camera locating two bodies. Picks up 7th graf, `The recovery...'. SUBS 13th graf, `The still-missing...', to UPDATE with victim's ID.
DOC.TEXT: A team of divers with an underwater video camera slipped into icy Convict Lake today to retrieve the bodies of six of seven people who died in the frigid waters. The camera immediately located two bodies on the lake bottom at a depth of 117 feet, said Mono County sheriff's Lt. Terry Padilla. Divers were preparing to bring them to the surface. The body of U.S. Forest Service ranger Clayton Cutter, 31, was recovered on Tuesday. But the bodies of three teens from a nearby camp for young offenders who fell through the ice and three of the adults who tried to rescue them were still missing in the lake, authorities said. The six-member Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department deep-sea diving team joined other divers today, said sheriff's spokeswoman Gail Merritt. ``We've got state-of-the-art stuff up here now. We're sure we will find them all now,'' she said. It was sunny, but 20 degrees when the search resumed. The Los Angeles dive team, wearing iron helmets and outfitted with surface air equipment that allows them to go deeper and stay down for up to 30 minutes, was also equipped with a camera to search the lake bottom. Cutter fell into the water as he tried to aid the victims, who were bobbing and thrashing in holes broken in the ice. ``Just watching those heads bobbing up and down was too much,'' said Chris Baitx, 31, chief of the Long Valley volunteer fire department. ``We figured we should have waited for the rescue team. But when people are bobbing up and down, you know what's next.'' The recovery could be hampered because the extreme cold may force the bodies to the bottom of the lake, which is 140 feet deep at its deepest point, said Mono County Sheriff-Coroner M.A. Strelneck Jr. Twelve teen-agers and two adults from Camp O'Neal, a residential facility for troubled youths, had been on a holiday outing Monday when four youths fell through the ice. Four adults _ including two camp counselors _ perished as they attempted to rescue the others. For those watching from the shore, horror turned to hysteria as the tragedy was compounded again and again. ``It was a bad scene and it just kept getting worse,'' Baitx said. Baitx also slipped beneath the splintering sheets of ice while attempting to rescue the victims, but he was pulled to safety. He was hospitalized overnight. ``I had to beat the ice out with my hands,'' Baitx said. ``I was sure I was gone. I was thinking of my wife and kids and are they going to be OK, because I'm history.'' The still-missing adults included the two camp counselors, Dave Meyers, 53, and Randy Porter, age unknown, and Vidar Anderson, 58, a volunteer firefighter. David Christopher Sellers and Shawn Rayne Diaz, both 15, and Ryan Charles McCandless, 13, were among the missing. Two other youths fell into the water, but survived: a 15-year-old boy who was treated for hypothermia at Centinela Mammoth Hospital and released and a teen-ager who clambered out of the water on his own and didn't require treatment. A paramedic plunged through the ice when he tried to reach the teen-agers and went down three times before a diver pulled him out. He was hospitalized overnight. The eastern Sierra Nevada ski resort community of 5,000 residents, about 250 miles north of Los Angeles, was stunned by the tragedy. ``We are a close-knit community and this accident touched everyone. ... Any kind of tragedy like this has a tremendous effect on our town,'' said Town Manager Paul Marangella. The privately operated probation camp is for young people convicted of relatively minor offenses. Convict Lake, just south of the Mammoth ski resort, got its name from a shootout between a posse and convicts in the late 1800s.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Nuclear Arms Plant to Remain Idle Until Summer
DOC.TEXT: The idled Rocky Flats weapons plant in Colorado, the sole supplier of plutonium triggers for U.S. nuclear warheads, is unlikely to resume full production until at least July, a senior Energy Department official said Wednesday. The plant, situated about 16 miles northwest of Denver, was closed indefinitely late last year for safety and management improvements. Production of plutonium triggers is vital to maintaining the nuclear weapons stockpile. Neither the Energy Department nor the Pentagon has said how long Rocky Flats could remain out of service before the arms stockpile would be jeopardized. The plant was closed for a few months in 1988 after a worker was contaminated by radioactivity. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins had said shortly after the latest shutdown that he hoped Rocky Flats would resume production by February, but the contractor that runs the facility says it needs more time to install new safety procedures and retrain workers. Adm. J.M. Barr, the deputy assistant energy secretary for military application, said Wednesday that one of the key plutonium processing facilities, known as Building 771, could be ready to resume operation by the end of June. Barr, speaking to a reporter during a break in a meeting with an Energy Department advisory committee, said current plans called for the full resumption of Rocky Flats production sometime between July and September. He stressed that this was a preliminary target that was subject to revision. Barr told the Advisory Committee on Nuclear Facility Safety, which is monitoring progress toward resuming operations, that he would have a more specific target date ``very early in April.'' ``We're afraid anything we would give you now would be wrong,'' he said. Barr stressed that the final decision to resume production rested with Watkins, who in recent weeks has pledged to subject the plant overhaul to a full review by independent observers. Rocky Flats has been plagued by a variety of operating and waste-handling problems in recent years. Last June the FBI raided the facility in search of evidence of criminal violations of laws governing the handling of radioactive wastes. Rockwell International Corp. quit as Rocky Flats' operator last September in a dispute with Watkins over legal liability for environmental violations. EG&G, a longtime weapons industry contractor based in Wellesley, Mass., officially took over Rocky Flats on Jan. 1, but has been working there since September. Barr told the advisory committee that the top objective of EG&G's overhaul of operations is to improve the ``margin of safety.'' He stressed, however, there was no imminent danger to the public from Rocky Flats operations last fall. Dave Van Leuven, EG&G's associate general manager for defense production at the facility, outlined for the committee the tasks to be completed before production resumes. He said, for example, that more than 1,000 engineering drawings of safety systems would be checked for accuracy. About 150 of the drawings have been checked so far, he said, and 14 were found to contain significant errors. He said it would take another eight weeks to check the rest. Van Leuven said the technical competence of about 1,500 plant operators would be verified before production is resumed. He did not say how many already have been tested but the failure rate so far was about 30 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Jaguar Recalls Thousands of Cars for Brake, Cruise-Control Defects
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Jaguar said ...'. to CORRECT to XJ-S sted XJ-2. A version also moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Jaguar Cars Inc. is recalling more than 70,000 cars for braking and cruise-control system defects. The automaker said Tuesday it was recalling 38,315 1988 and 1989 Jaguar sedans, including the XJ6, Vanden Plas and Majestic, because of a brake-system defect. Jaguar said high pressure hoses that supply fluid to the power assist system could rupture, causing a loss of fluid. The escaped fluid could lead to engine fire, smoke under the hood or loss of braking power. The company also said hydraulic fluid may leak from the brake system, which could damage electrical wiring or cause the power assist system in the brakes to fail to recharge. If both mishaps occurred, the driver could lose the car's power braking feature but still could stop the car without the power system, Jaguar said. Jaguar said it also is recalling 31,835 1979-model XJ12 sedans and 1982 to 1990 model Jaguar XJ-S vehicles because of improper functioning of the cruise-control system. The cruise control could fail to disengage normally, Jaguar said. These owners are being advised to avoid using the cruise-control system until their cars are fixed. Jaguar owners affected by the recalls are being alerted by mail to make appointments with their dealers to have the repairs done for free.

DOC.HEAD: GM Teamwork Course Has Employees Quacking, Jumping Off Wall
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp., which some analysts say has a stodgy, unbending personality, is offering some employees the chance to quack like a duck and jump from a pole to ring a little bell. The voluntary training program, designed to encourage teamwork among employees, is running this week and next for workers in the company's international export sales unit. It isn't sitting too well with some. ``When adults are working and trying to earn a living, they belong in an office,'' said a 53-year-old employee who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``They shouldn't be in some survival course yelling, `Quack, quack.''' A second group of employees was proceeding through the 2{-day course Wednesday. The first group began Sunday, and the final group will run through the program next week, GM spokesman Mark Rollinson said. He said about 175 people are eligible to participate, and groups range from 25 to 40 workers. The program is operated by Pecos River Learning Centers Inc. of Santa Fe, N.M. ``The point is to get you out of your comfort zone,'' said Danlee Winegar, the company's director of marketing communication. At the beginning of the teamwork-building training, participants are asked to quack and ride stick horses around a room. ``These fun types of things loosen people up.'' Winegar said. ``It can break down barriers to be goofy, to feel OK about doing stupid things in front of the others.'' The whole thing can be stupid, not to mention dangerous, said William Dwyer, a 49-year-old GM employee. ``A lot of people, including myself, think they could get hurt in the process,'' he said. ``Personally, I don't think I'm in shape to do it.'' Among the tasks participants perform are jumping off an 8-foot wall to be caught by co-workers and climbing a ladder beside a pole, standing on a wobbly disc and jumping off to ring a small bell. ``We do run into the fear factor, but it's all in your head,'' Winegar said. ``On the pole, you're held up by a harness that keeps you from falling more than a few inches.'' GM spokeswoman Patricia Molloy and Dale Hermiller, a manager of the export sales unit, stressed that all parts of the program are voluntary. Detroit lawyer V. Paul Donnelly said about a dozen workers have told him they were worried about the training. ``I can't advise them whether to attend or not,'' he said, ``but they may be at risk if they go without legal representation.''

DOC.HEAD: New Mineral Water Recall; Tap Water Cut to 160,000 People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-6 with four grafs to CORRECT spelling to alkane, sted alcane, and provide some background.
DOC.TEXT: Worries over chemical contamination forced a recall of up to 2 million bottles of mineral water Wednesday, while authorities warned 160,000 people in central and eastern France not to consume polluted tap water. The moves came as a dispute began between environment and agriculture officials over widespread pollution of drinking water due to drought, heavy use of nitrate-based fertilizers and recent floods. The Societe Generale des Eaux Minerales de Vittel announced it would withdraw from sale an estimated 1 million to 2 million bottles of Hepar mineral water to allay consumer worries some might be contaminated with traces of hydrocarbons of the alkane type. The underground springwater is distributed and consumed almost exclusively in France, Director Alain Dorfner told The Associated Press. The company also produces the popular Vittel water for domestic and foreign consumption. Supplies of Hepar were contaminated Jan. 10-11 when water sitting in a tank awaiting bottling came into contact with a filter exposed to air polluted with alkane, Dorfner said. Alkanes are a class of hydocarbon compounds, including methane or ethane. They occur naturally in some types of petroleum. The water was bottled and shipped to points in France in January, Dorfner said, and later quietly withdrawn from sale after the company discovered the contamination. But the global recall of Perrier water after a U.S. laboratory found traces of benzene in some samples put the spotlight on Hepar, casting doubts on the water's purity. ``The water now on the shelves is pure, but we want to avoid confusion in people's minds,'' Dorfner said. ``New bottles will be on the shelves in 15 days.'' Dorfner said he could not estimate the cost of the operation. Hepar represents $21 million of Vittel's annual profits of $316 million, Dorfner said. In the eastern city of Belfort, meanwhile, health authorities warned citizens to either drink bottled water or to add chlorine to their drinking water after bacteria was found in taps Wednesday. About 100,000 residents cleared shop shelves of chlorine and bottled water to last for a week _ the amount of time authorities estimate it will take to clean the city's water system. Tests are still being run on the bacteria, which entered the region's wells and reservoirs during last week's flooding in parts of France, authorities said. The bacteria causes stomach problems but is not life-endangering. A similar infestation struck over the weekend at Chateauroux and Delos in central France, where 60,000 people remained on bottled water Wednesday as health officials ran tests on the bacteria. Concern over France's water supply entered the political arena Tuesday when Secretary of the State for the Environment Brice Lalonde criticized farmers for dumping nitrate-based fertilizers onto the soil that eventually wash into water systems. Lalonde estimated 800,000 people regularly drink water above safe nitrate levels and called agriculture ``a black point'' in environmental protection. High levels of nitrates are particularly bad in Britanny, parts of northern France and Alsace, the daily newspaper Liberation reported. Serious drought last summer compounded the problem, Liberation said, as farmers dug irrigation ditches and diverted streams to water their fields, disrupting the environment. Agricultural representatives said Lalonde's remarks were off-base but admitted the drought prevented fertilizer from being absorbed properly by the soil. The agriculture and environment ministries promised Wednesday to work together with the 12-nation European Community to solve the problem of nitrate pollution. Elsewhere, the president of the private water company Lyonnaise des Eaux, Jerome Monod, estimated that only 40 percent of the pollutants in urban tap water are cleared out by filtration plants. In an interview with the newspaper France-Soire, Monod said the price of tap water could double in the next 10 years if French consumers decide to make the investment to clean up their water. ``This price will still be minimal if we compare it to mineral water, which today costs 500 times as much as tap water,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Trip A Snooze
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's two-week tour of the Pacific Rim was barely a day old when Philippine President Corazon Aquino declared she wouldn't receive him during his visit to Manila. The snub was striking in light of the crucial air cover the U.S. Air Force had provided in December to help her survive a coup attempt. But Cheney reacted with characteristic equanimity: he fell asleep. On the balmy Sunday the spat became front-page headline news in Honolulu, the defense secretary declined to talk with reporters about Mrs. Aquino. Instead, he sought some peace and quiet at a friend's home, and promptly dozed off while lounging on the lawn, associates said. He woke up when a light rain started to fall, so he went inside _ and fell asleep again. Cheney's wife Lynne woke him up hours later when it was time to go back to the hotel for dinner _ and when he got there, he fell asleep again. In an appearance before a military support group later in his visit, Cheney joked about the slight, telling his audience his lengthy introduction lacked one title _ being Corazon Aquino's ``favorite defense secretary.''

Cheney's visit to the hills above Honolulu brought to mind Shakespeare's Macbeth: ``Macbeth shall never vanquished be ``Until Great Birnam wood to high Dunsinane Hill shall come against him.'' Such tactics ultimately fooled Macbeth, and the defense secretary learned first-hand they've become part of the Army's 25th Infantry Division's commando training in Hawaii. As Cheney was escorted into the lush forests to meet the young soldier-trainees, there was no one to greet him. That is, until the shrubbery started to shake and crawl his way. Up from the ground arose about two dozen camouflaged soldiers with twigs, leaves, ferns and assorted lush greenery tied to their shoulders and backpacks, their faces covered in green, black and brown makeup. Cheney clearly was taken by the scene, and eager to speak with the young warriors. That is, until a two-star general sat down next to him on a tree stump to explain their training _ supplemented by an over-eager officer with a plastic coated flip-chart. Cheney finally did get a chance to talk with the greenery-attired young men who'd waited patiently for their general to finish his lecture. The picture of the scene was later dubbed, ``Cheney Talks to the Trees.''

Cheney's arrival at the airport in Seoul got a fair amount of attention from the South Korean press corps, given that the issues he wanted to discuss _ U.S. troop cuts and increased Korean contributions to their support _ are hot topics. As Cheney took the microphone to offer his thanks for being received in Seoul, a South Korean anchorman stood nearby and began to boom out a report on camera, drowning out the secretary's remarks. Cheney plodded on, and so did the television reporter. Eyebrows were raised. The official South Korean delegation stared blankly forward, acting as if nothing were happening. Both men continued, their Korean and English commentary tangled in a jumbled mess. Finally, the wife of an American diplomat in the greeting party elbowed a Korean aide, who in turn waited politely for the anchorman to draw a breath before he tugged at his arm and silenced the journalist.

DOC.HEAD: UMW Gets Extension on $64 Million in Coal Strike Fines
DOC.TEXT: A judge Wednesday gave the United Mine Workers 10 more days to find a way to persuade him to drop or reduce $64 million in fines against the union for its tactics during the Pittston Coal Group strike. Circuit Judge Donald McGlothlin had set a Thursday deadline for the UMW and Pittston to return to court after he rejected their joint request Feb. 12 to drop the fines. McGlothlin last week called the union's offer of 10,000 hours of community service ``an affront to this court'' because it would amount to about five hours of work for each striker. Union officials said they needed time to develop a new proposal because they were tied up arranging for about 2,000 Pittston employees and laid-off workers in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky to vote on a contract they ratified Monday. The ratification ended the nearly 11-month strike. ``The whole ratification process created a big burden of work, and we had to deal with that,'' UMW spokesman Gene Carroll said. UMW Vice President Cecil Roberts said he hoped the judge would soften his position now that the miners have agreed to go back to work. But he said he did not know what union attorney swould propose to get the fines waived or reduced. The union originally planned to hold up a vote on the contract until the legal action was disposed of. But during the hearing before McGlothlin last week, he lectured the union on trying to use judges as ``bargaining chips.'' ``It was clear the judge was not going to be pressured,'' Roberts said. The fines were imposed for violations of judges' orders limiting picket line activity and prohibiting the disruption of Pittston's operations. About half of the fines were for violence aimed at company personnel and property. McGlothlin also fined the union $5 million for taking over Pittston's main coal processing plant in September for four days and several million dollars for using sit-down demonstrations and big bumper-to-bumper convoys of cars and trucks to block coal truck traffic.

DOC.HEAD: Himalayan Shangri-La Seeks Political Change
DOC.TEXT: A movement to restore political pluralism has gripped this Himalayan kingdom, pitting its Harvard-educated monarch against two banned political parties inspired by the changes sweeping Eastern Europe. Clashes between police and demonstrators who demand an end to a 29-year-old ban on political parties have killed at least 11 people this week in usually tranquil Nepal, where crime is rare and murders make front-page news. Activists claim the government has arrested more than 1,000 people in its crackdown on the movement for restoration of multiparty democracy. The government says 175 people have been arrested since the campaign was launched Sunday _ for the third time in 11 years. ``I think this time the government is shaken,'' said a Western diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``They have realized that bullets and tough talk won't make the problem disappear.'' Leading the agitation are the banned coalition of left-wing parties and the Nepali Congress Party, which governed Nepal during its only two years in history as a Western-style democracy. ``For the last 29 years we have faced atrocities,'' said Hari Bol Bhattarai, a senior member of the Congress Party who has evaded arrest. ``It's time to get rid of the system, bring in a fresh system.'' Bhattarai, who spoke in a telephone interview from an undisclosed location, said the movement would continue until the government gave in. ``We have waited enough. Now we won't give up until our demands are fulfilled.'' Nepal has witnessed startling political events since the Shah dynasty began its rule in the mid-18th century. After almost a century on the throne, the Shahs were reduced to titular heads by the Ranas, who established a parallel line of hereditary prime ministers. In 1951, King Tribhuvan of the Shah dynasty and the Nepali Congress Party overthrew the Rana prime minister and established a democratic constitution under which the monarch and an elected government were to share power. The country's first general elections were not held until eight years later, as Tribhuvan and later his son, King Mahendra, appeared loath to accept the role of a semi-titular head of state. The Congress Party was voted to power in 1959, but Mahendra dismissed its government two years later and banned all political parties, accusing them of corruption and misleading the nation. That ban still stands, despite agitations and violence in 1979 and 1985. The 1979 movement led to a historic national referendum the next year, in which the people narrowly voted to retain Nepal's non-partisan Rashtriya Panchayat, or national assembly. Analysts say one reason the people voted for a partyless democracy was the assurance by King Birendra, Mahendra's son, of greater political freedom and genuine representation in the assembly. ``We thought we would have it good either way,'' said Debendra Raj Panday, a political commentator. ``But we remained where we were. The palace still runs everything in this country. ``The legislators are voted with the government's support. In effect, the prime minister is chosen by the king,'' he said. The government says the 1980 referendum remains valid and the will of the people will not be changed. ``Nepal follows the middle path,'' chief government spokesman Radhey Shyam Bista said. ``We rejected the one-party system of our northern neighbor, China, and the multiparty system of our southern neighbor, India.'' ``For us the monarchy is the only institution. Democracy can only grow with the cooperation of the monarch,'' he said. He credited 44-year-old Birendra, a graduate in political science from Harvard University, with ushering in ``remarkable progress'' in Nepal, a mountainous kingdom of 18 million people and one of the poorest countries in the world. According to government figures, life expectancy has risen from 38 years in 1960 to 47 at present. About 70,000 Nepalese receive a university education. Still, half the population lives in poverty, with a per capita annual income of $150, and more than 70 percent of the population has no safe drinking water. ``I trace all economic problems to the political process,'' Panday said. ``It's a feudal economy and there are little fiefdoms everywhere with no regard to the people's needs.'' Economic problems apart, the demonstrators' tone appears to be getting more strident, and they have increasingly aimed criticism at the king, which is a punishable offense. ``Our king is trying to kill democracy,'' said Rishikesh Shaha, a former foreign minister, who fell out with the palace and left for India on Feb. 7, saying he feared he would be arrested. ``He is trying to put the clock back ... at a time when around the world the voice of freedom, the voice of democracy is getting stronger and stronger,'' Shaha said in an interview in the Indian capital, New Delhi. ``You just can't talk about him. You are required to worship him. But the pro-democracy movement has gone very deep down into the hearts of the people,'' Shaha said. ``There is no question of turning back.''

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rain Produces Soggy Prelude to Mardi Gras
DOC.TEXT: It's raining on this city's parade, with up to 5 inches forecast for Wednesday and Thursday, enough to turn the glossy papier mache floats of Carnival season into heaps of soggy newspaper. Since Sunday, at least of the six parades leading up to Mardi Gras next Tuesday have been canceled or postponed because of rain. ``It's a horror story, and it's cost me a fortune so far,'' said float builder Blaine Kern. ``When it rains real hard, the figures are made of papier mache and they sort of start reverting back to their original shape _ which is nothing.'' But good news in the offing. On Friday, forecasters say, skies should clear for two of the largest, most lavish parades on the weekend before Mardi Gras, or Fat Tuesday, which ends the feast of Carnival and begins the fast of Lent.
