DOC.HEAD: Soviet Scientists Invite Swedes to Study Chernobyl Damage
DOC.TEXT: Sweden will send radiation experts to a badly contaminated area in the Soviet Union to study the effects of the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear power plant accident, Soviet scientists said Wednesday. The agreement was announced at the end of three days of talks by Soviet, Finnish, Swedish and Norwegian officials on international cooperation in the event of nuclear accidents. Pavel Ramzaev of the Institute of Radiation Hygiene in Leningrad said the Soviets hoped to gain a broader view of contamination problems. ``Our vast material and data from the affected areas is only a first step toward knowledge about the effects of the accident,'' Ramzaev said, adding that the Soviets were seeking ``new ways of thinking.'' A Swedish team will go this summer to an area in the Russian republic several hundred miles northeast of Chernobyl, where radiation levels were far higher than expected. ``We have a lot to learn about the medical effects on human life, and how to measure and decontaminate agriculture land and the environment in general,'' said Jan Olof Snihs, of Sweden's National Institute of Radiation Protection. The Soviets said a conference in Vienna starting Friday will discuss the organization of an international research institute to be established at Chernobyl. The April 26, 1986, explosion at the No. 4 reactor of the four-unit nuclear power plant in the Soviet Ukraine was the world's worst atomic accident. The accident sent a cloud of radiation over large parts of northern and central Europe, leading to bans on foodstuffs from several countries. The plant is 80 miles north of the Ukraine capital of Kiev. Two workers died immediately of burns they suffered in the explosion, 28 died shortly after the accident from radiation exposure, and one died of a heart attack while fighting the fire. By 1989, officials said more than 250 people who had worked at the polant or who were involved in the post-accident cleanup had died of various causes, not all of them necessarily traceable to radiation exposure.

DOC.HEAD: Report Former East German Spy Chief Fled to Soviet Union
With AM-Germany Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Markus Wolf, the retired chief spy of East Germany, has taken refuge in the Soviet Union to avoid possible arrest at home in an arms export scandal, a West German newspaper reported Wednesday. He lived in the Soviet Union for many years and once called it his ``second homeland.'' Wolf is believed to have had close ties to the KGB secret police. The Sueddeutsche Zeitung said East German prosecutors believe Wolf was involved in the illegal arms operation and may even have directed it. East German authorities have said the the exports were handled by Alexander Schalck-Golodkowski, chief foreign trader for the ousted Communist government. He fled to West Berlin when the operation was discovered in December and spent several days in jail, but a judge said there were no grounds in West Germany for holding Schalck-Golodkowski and released him in January. Wolf retired in February 1987 from the State Security Ministry, where he was in charge of the espionage section and directed such agents as Guenter Guillaume, whose unmasking led to the resignation of Willy Brandt as West German chancellor. Guillaume had been one of Brandt's closest aides. The Sueddeutsche Zeitung said Wolf was living with his half-sister in a villa near Moscow and writing a book on East Germany politics of recent years. In its report, made available to other news media before publication Thursday, the paper said he had offers for the book from two West German publishers. East German TV carried the Sueddeutsche Zeitung report without comment. The former spy turned to writing after retirement. In the turmoil that brought down old guard Communist Party chief Erich Honecker in October, he supported the type of political and economic reforms championed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet president. Wolf's father, Friedrich, was a prominent author and physician with Communist convictions. He fled when the Nazis came to power in 1933 and took his family to Moscow, where his son attended Communist Party schools. When the younger Wolf arrived in the Soviet sector of occupied Germany in 1945, he worked as a radio journalist. Later, Wolf returned to Moscow as an East German diplomat. He described the family's life in Moscow during Stalin's rule in a book published after his retirement. Wolf joined the State Security Ministry in 1951, became espionage chief in 1957 and retired with the rank of general. His career was said to have inspired spy novelist John Le Carre's character Karla, a fictional Soviet spymaster who finally is forced to defect to the West by an elaborate plot devised by British agent George Smiley. After decades of virtual invisibility, Wolf spoke at rallies in the early days of East Germany's revolution and appeared in several discussions on East and West German TV. There is an arrest warrant out for him in West Germany because of his espionage activities.

DOC.HEAD: There's Hope Yet for Scum
DOC.TEXT: Genetic experiments with ordinary pond scum show it may be an automatic dispenser of fertilizer in rice fields, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. But the department's Agricultural Research Service said it may be another 15 years before rice growers are able to use the pond scum, or blue-green algae, as a fertilizer source. If the procedure can be developed, the natural fertilizer dispensed by the special algae could have a significant effect on rice production around the world, including many Third World countries that rely on the crop as a food staple. Stephen Albrecht, a plant physiologist at the agency's laboratory in Gainesville, Fla., said greenhouse tests with the altered algae boosted rice production eight-fold. However, he said it didn't do well in the field, probably because the algae had not been adapted to field conditions. Normally, pond algae produces just enough nutrient-rich ammonia from nitrogen in the atmosphere to take care of its own needs. The genetically engineered strains keeps producing as long as nearby plants need it. When rice plants stop taking in ammonia, the algae stops production before excess amounts spill over into the environment. Albrecht said the on-and-off fertilizing system could mean less groundwater contamination. Tests showed that while rice with algae at its roots had some ammonia, there was none in the environment. If the algae can be adapted to rice fields, Albrecht said growers could grow algae alongside rice fields and flood it into the rice areas at irrigation time. He said it would be cheaper and require less work than with commercial fertilizers.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Denied Permission to Observe Lithuania Elections
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has denied permission to four U.S. congressmen who want to travel to Lithuania for this weekend's elections in the Soviet Baltic republic, the legislators said Wednesday. The group, led by Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., was selected by Congress to observe the local elections Saturday after an invitation was received from the Lithuanian national movement Sajudis. Other members of the party include Reps. Christopher Cox, R-Calif., and John Miller, R-Wash., and Texas Democrat Bill Sarpalius, D-Texas. The group had hoped to pick up its visas at the Soviet consulate in East Berlin, Durbin said, then catch an Aeroflot flight to Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. ``To our surprise we were greeted with a cable from the Soviets, sent at 11 o'clock Washington time last night advising us that we would not be allowed towitness the Lithuanian elections,'' Durbin said. ``We thought that things were on track and that the visas would be issued.'' ``It's very frustrating. We're running into the limits of glasnost, apparently,'' Miller said. Asked if the Soviets had specified reasons for the denial, Durbin said they were told they hadn't gone through the appropriate procedures. ``But frankly that conflicts with the fact that other parliamentarians from Canada and Austria are presently in Lithuania. It appears that they have made some special ruling, as (the denial) relates only to members of Congress from the United States,'' he said. In Moscow, Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev said the congressmen had not been invited by any officially recognized groups and said their trip was not coordinated or discussed through diplomatic channels. ``Taking all these facts into account, the congressmen were informed that their trip to the U.S.S.R. at present would be incorrect,'' he said. ``This decision of course is in no connection with the personalities of the congressmen. They are welcome in the U.S.S.R. at any convenient date which could be mutually agreed upon.'' Durbin said the delegation would continue to press for permission to go to Lithuania and would contact Washington ``to rally some support'' to pressure the Soviets. ``We still have time to make it to Lithuania before the election and we all consider that to be of the utmost importance,'' Durbin said. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were independent states between World War I and 1940, when they were annexed by the Soviet Union. The Baltic republics are seeking to obtain a measure of independence from Moscow, and the elections Saturday will test the strength of the nationalist movement in Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Urges Steps to Prevent Miscommunication
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to raise reference to fuel problem
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety officials investigating the crash of an Avianca jetliner in New York issued emergency recommendations today aimed at clarifying how pilots should declare fuel emergencies. Seventy-three people died when the fuel-starved airliner crashed in Long Island while on approach to Kennedy International Airport in New York. The National Transportation Safety Board urged the Federal Aviation Administration to alert all air carriers with flights in the United States that their crews must be ``thoroughly knowledgeable'' about FAA rules, including specific phrases to be used when a plane is running out of fuel. The board, with three of its four members concurring, also called on the FAA to issue a general notice to air traffic controllers on the circumstances of the Jan. 25 crash of the Colombian airliner and to emphasize the need for controllers to request clarification of ``unclear or ambiguous transmissions'' from airliners that may convey an emergency. Pilots of the flight from Bogota and Medellin, Colombia, told controllers several times they were running out of fuel. However, they never declared a formal ``minimum fuel'' status or ``emergency fuel condition,'' which would have alerted controllers to clear them for landing as quickly as possible, NTSB members said. The board said it was continuing investigation into the cause of the crash and ``has not concluded that any specific communication or coordination problems were causal to the accident.'' The FAA is not required to adopt recommendations by the NTSB, an independent agency. Eighty-six people survived the crash of the Avianca Boeing 707 in Cove Neck, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Vermont Couples' Challenge of `Rails to Trails' Law
DOC.TEXT: A federal law aimed at creating new hiking and biking trails along unused rail lines was upheld Wednesday by the Supreme Court. The justices unanimously rejected an appeal by a Vermont couple who said their property rights were being trampled to satisfy the nation's back-to-nature and physical-fitness boom. The court upheld a 1983 law, known as the ``rails-to-trails'' act, that permits unused rail lines to be converted into nature trails. In other decisions, the court: _Voted, 7-2, to limit the authority of the White House Office of Management and Budget to revise federal job-safety rules to reduce paperwork for private businesses. _Upheld, by a 5-4 vote in a Colorado case, federal regulations aimed at saving the government time and money when it mistakenly overpays some Social Security recipients. _Reinstated, by a 5-4 vote, a $6.1 million award against the Arthur Young & Co. accounting firm won by investors in the Farmer's Cooperative of Arkansas and Oklahoma. In the abandoned rail line case, the court said J. Paul Preseault and his wife, Patricia, of Burlington, Vt., have not shown their rights were violated by a 7.2-mile bicycle path that passes through their lakefront property. The bike trail replaced a Vermont Railway line after train service ended in 1975 and the tracks were torn up. The Interstate Commerce Commission approved the conversion under the 1983 federal law. Justice William J. Brennan, writing for the court, said the Preseaults still can file a claim for compensation against the federal government under a separate law. The Preseaults said they may continue their fight. ``I guess at this point I'm stunned,'' J. Paul Preseault said. ``I didn't do this, go all the way to the Supreme Court, to have them tell me to file my case in another court. I wasn't looking for money. I wanted my property rights honored.'' The Preseaults said the 1983 law violates the Constitution's Fifth Amendment, which bars the taking of private property without just compensation, and also said it interferes unlawfully with interstate commerce. Brennan said the rails-to-trails law is a legitimate exercise of congressional power aimed at ``encouraging the development of additional recreational trails.'' The ruling could affect a large number of property owners. The nation's railway system, at its peak in 1920 with 272,000 miles of track, is now down to 141,000 miles and 3,000 more miles are abandoned each year. Ownership of the land claimed by the Preseaults is in dispute. Vermont officials say the property belongs to the state. But if the Preseaults own the property, they say they have a right under Vermont law to use the land once the rail line is abandoned. But the 1983 federal law _ an amended version of the earlier National Trails System Act _ allows for railroad rights-of-way to be maintained for possible future railroad use while the land is converted at least temporarily to nature trails. This practice, known as rail banking, is at the heart of Wednesday's ruling. Vermont entered into a lease with the city of Burlington that allows the city to maintain the right-of-way as a trail while preserving it for possible rail use. Citing the state-city agreement, the Interstate Commerce Commission rejected the Preseaults' bid to have the rail line declared officially abandoned. The Preseaults said the rail-banking provisions are a sham to conceal the true purpose of the federal law _ preventing railroad rights-of-way from being returned to their rightful owners after abandonment. The couple said the rail-banking procedure disguises the fact that the rail lines have been abandoned. Brennan rejected that argument. The law is not invalid ``merely because more Draconian measures _ such as a program of mandatory conversions or a prohibition of all abandonments _ might advance more completely the rail-banking purpose,'' he said. ``The history of congressional attempts to address the problem of rail abandonments provides sufficient reason to defer'' to Congress, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Impose Curfew in Kosovo
DOC.TEXT: The government imposed a nighttime curfew Wednesday in Kosovo province, where more than two dozen people have died this year in ethnic clashes. The official Tanjug news agency said Soviet-built T-55 tanks and armored personnel carriers patrolled the streets of most Kosovo towns to enforce the 9 p.m. to 4 a.m. curfew. Tanjug said Yugoslav authorities decided Tuesday that the curfew was needed ``to defend the constitutional order and prevent violence.'' MiG-21 fighters streaked at low altitude over several towns, and small groups of heavily armed soldiers patrolled villages, sources in the region said. Thousands of Serbs had rallied for three days in Kosovo Polje, a suburb of the provincial capital of Pristina, demanding a curfew and protesting what they claimed were threats by ethnic Albanian ``separatists and terroritsts.'' Ethnic Albanians comprise 90 percent of the population in Kosovo, a province of the Serbian republic. They oppose moves by Serbian leaders to more tightly control the province. One person died Tuesday and dozens were injured in clashes between security forces and tens of thousands of ethnic Albanian demonstrators demanding free elections, an end to a year-old state of emergency and the release of political prisoners. Since January, 28 ethnic Albanians have been killed in ethnic unrest, according to official figures. The same number were killed in all of last year. During the curfew, ``movements and gatherings of people for the purpose of demonstrating'' were strictly forbidden, said Belgrade radio. Some small protests were reported during the day, mainly involving ethnic Albanian schoolchildren and youths who taunted riot police in several towns. A journalist who spoke by telephone from the region said nearly all ethnic Albanian students boycotted classes and at least 30,000 workers continued a 2-week-old strike to protest what they described as ``police repression.'' Serbian students at Pristina university demanded that authorities ``guarantee their safety'' from ethnic Albanians, Tanjug said. The students also demanded that all university officials who supported past demonstrations by Albanian students be fired and threatened to ``continue their education outside the province'' if the demands were not met, Tanjug said. The students also want authorities to jail the leaders of seven new opposition movements. The Serbs accused the students of inciting demonstrations and strikes by ethnic Albanians last month. The independent groups on Wednesday appealed to Kosovo residents not to demonstrate. ``The authorities are trying to provoke an intercommunal conflict in Kosovo,'' said the appeal. Tanjug said several bus companies from outside Kosovo have discontinued service to the province because they fear attacks. Last month, at least five buses were badly damaged by stone-throwing demonstrators, Tanjug said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: To Zeke the Sheik, the giant heap of manure in his back yard is a monument to worldwide salvation. Local authorities see it as a big pile of something else. Timothy Dundon, whose sartorial preference for turbans and caftan robes has won him the nickname ``Zeke the Sheik,'' says he started constructing the 30-foot-high pile of cattle and horse droppings 17 years ago. He had a vision and a mission _ to create a ``living monument'' that would save everyone in the world from a coming firestorm of destruction. The compost pile _ with onions and cactus growing out of it _ has taken on all sorts of symbolic significance, Dundon says. ``This is alive,'' he says. Horsefeathers, say Los Angeles County fire and health officials, who see it as a giant, smelly health hazard that could catch fire and set the neighborhood ablaze. Dundon, 57, is well known in this city 12 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles _ he likes to talk in rhyme and hum the theme to ``Dragnet,'' and the manure mountain marks only his most recent brush with notoriety. ``It's awful,'' said neighbor Elisha Harrison. ``Especially in the summer. There's flies, flies, flies.'' ``We've never had any problems with it,'' said another neighbor, Greg Jones. ``He's a cool dude.''

A historic gingko tree, believed planted 136 years ago by the founder of this village, attracts admirers from all over. Phooey, says its owner, it's a nuisance and should be chopped down. ``The tree is smelly, messy and very brittle, making it a hazard to the children who are continually climbing it,'' said Patrick Gillespie. ``Besides, I am the one responsible for maintaining it, and it is quite a job.'' Mayor Scott Newberg said a national society of gingko tree admirers frequently has its annual meeting in here because of the 100-foot tree. Gillespie is aware of the tree's historic value and says he's wrestled with his conscience for years before deciding the ``rational thing to do'' is cut it down. In addition to raking up its leaves in the fall, Gillespie says he must have the tree sprayed to prevent the growth of its nuts, which form inside plum-like fleshy fruits that stink like rancid butter. ``Everyone else has the idea that I am calloused,'' he said. ``I appreciate their point of view, but they are not looking at mine. I'm the one who has to live with it in my backyard.''

DOC.HEAD: Illness of Commander Forces Space Shuttle Launch Delay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `Herring said ...' and 7th graf, `Herring said ...' to CORRECT spelling of Creighton.
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis' commander got a sore throat Wednesday, forcing NASA to postpone for at least 24 hours the launch of the shuttle on a secret, all-military mission to put a spy satellite in orbit. A space agency statement said a bad weather forecast also was a factor in the postponement, but officials said that if not for the illness they would have continued the countdown, hoping for clear skies by launch time early Thursday. Navy Capt. John O. Creighton has ``basically a sore throat with a little head congestion,'' said agency spokesman Kyle Herring. ``He does not have a fever. It could be an indication of a cold coming on.'' Herring said Creighton would not be replaced on the flight because his illness is not serious. NASA said Creighton's health and the weather will be evaluated Thursday in deciding whether to attempt a launch Friday morning. ``We've never had a postponement due to the illness of an astronaut; this is the first time in the space program,'' Herring said. In 1970, astronaut Thomas K. Mattingly was taken off the Apollo 13 crew a few days before the flight was to lift off for the moon. But backuop astronaut Jack Swigert replaced him without delaying the flight. Herring said Creighton and the other four Atlantis crew members were healthy when they took a physical exam on Tuesday and that Creighton had approached the flight surgeon Wednesday with his problem. All have been in semi-isolation the last week, their contact limited to immediate family members and essential launch official to reduce the possibility of exposure to illness. The afternoon announcement came shortly before technicians were to begin pumping more than half a million gallons of propellant into Atlantis' fuel tank for the four-day mission, which was to end at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. A bleak forecast early Wednesday had gradually improved throughout the day to a 50-50 chance for a fiery night launch on Thursday. But the outlook for Friday and Saturday was even worse, with one cold front moving out and another moving in. Because the Pentagon mission is classified, the space agency would not provide the exact launch time, saying only that it would occur between midnight and 4 a.m. Thursday. However, sources said that Atlantis was to lift off at 1 a.m. Atlantis' orbit reportedly will cover a greater area of the globe than any previous shuttle so that the satellite, once released by the five-member crew, can gather intelligence over northern areas of the Soviet Union where there are numerous military bases and missile sites. To reach the high latitude, the shuttle is expected to fly into orbit on a course skirting the East Coast, flying within a few hundred miles of shore. Thus, if weather conditions are right, residents along the Eastern Seaboard as far north as New Jersey might see Atlantis' fiery tail. This is the sixth secret military mission and fourth after-dark launch in 34 shuttle flights. The launch time is dictated by the destination of the cargo. Creighton's crew is Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Lt. Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, reported the astronauts were to deploy a 37,300-pound, $500 million spy satellite capable of taking super-sharp reconnaissance photos and listening in on military and diplomatic communications around the world. Placed into a high inclination orbit, the spy satellite will pass over most of the Soviet Union, including northern areas not previously probed by shuttle-launched satellites. This orbit may be important in verifying Soviet compliance with arms agreements now being negotiated between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. The Soviets have their own satellites to monitor compliance. Military officials said the secrecy surrounding Defense Department shuttle flights is necessary to make it more difficult for Soviet reconnaissance satellites and spy ship off Cape Canaveral to track the spacecraft. But critics argue that Soviet intelligence agents undoubtedly already know a great deal about Atlantis' mission and once the shuttle is in orbit, they will be able to track it precisely and know what it is doing.

DOC.HEAD: Leahy Says Foreign Trade Policy Could Help Farmers
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee on Wednesday called for a more coordinated foreign trade policy in the 1990 farm bill as a way to bolster agricultural income. ``I would love to come here and promise American farmers that the federal government will have more money to help them compete internationally,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. ``But the realities of our budget deficit make this unlikely.'' He said more needs to be done with the funds available. ``We should target the most promising markets (and) adopt a long-term market development strategy for those markets,'' said Leahy, suggesting that the developing world holds the brightest future for U.S. exports. Leahy directed his comments to Richard Crowder, undersecretary for international affairs and commodity programs at the Agriculture Department, during the last hearing the Senate Agriculture Committee has scheduled on trade issues in preparation for the farm bill. The senator said several studies have criticized federal export promotion programs. He said that one bank participating in one of those programs is being investigated on fraud charges. The bank _ a branch of the national bank of Italy in Atlanta, Ga. _ has extended millions of dollars in loans guaranteed by the Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corp. to Iraq. Leahy questioned whether the country was a good credit risk. He said there had been rumors that Iraq was diverting the commodities for purposes other than feeding its citizens. Crowder said Iraq's repayment record had been ``excellent.'' ``We have audited some of the exporter's records and found nothing to conclude there had been diversions,'' said Crowder. He said the criminal investigation of the bank was being handled by banking authorities, not the USDA, and as long as the loans were being repaid, the USDA was satisfied. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., asked Crowder the department's philosophy on using the Export Enhancement Program, a bonus program for exporters that makes U.S. commodities less expensive for foreign buyers. Crowder said the main criteria was whether the European Community sells to a certain country and if the United States could displace European sales. ``As long as the European Community is selling, we will provide export bonuses,'' said Crowder. The Bush and Reagan administrations both have characterized the subsidies the EC puts on agricultural products it exports as trade unfair. U.S. negotiators engaged in the ongoing Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talk are trying to get the Europeans to soften their subsidy system, but administration officials, including Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, have said U.S. subsidies will not be dropped until there is a multilateral agreement. The talks, usually referred to as GATT, are expected to be complete at the end of this year. Their outcome could lead to revisions in U.S. farm policy. Among the administration's proposals for the farm bill is a lifting of the ceiling Congress put on the amount that can be traded under the Export Enhancement Program.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Party Alleges Two Members Murdered by Political Rivals
DOC.TEXT: Two opposition party activists were beaten to death and the tongue of one victim was cut out by party opponents, the traditionally anti-Communist National Peasants Party alleged Wednesday. Peasants Party spokesman Valentin Gabrielescu declined to make specific accusations about who was behind the reported killings, but suggested they were politically motivated. Three suspects have been arrested in the Feb. 11 death and mutilation of Vasile Velescu, Gabrielescu said, refusing to identify them or their possible motives. He said only that Velescu, 60, ``was killed because he was the chief of our organization'' in Bacau, 180 miles northeast of Bucharest. Another party activist, from Calarasi County in southern Romania, also was murdered, Gabrielescu said. He refused to name the victim or give further details, saying he was following the wishes of the victim's family. There was no independent confirmation of the alleged murders, which would be the first ones with apparent political motives since the end of the revolution that overthrew and executed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in December. Gabrielescu warned of the possibility of further violence against the Peasants Party, the strongest rival of the National Salvation Front in Romania's elections in May. The front governed alone for six weeks after the revolution before being pressured to share power with 37 other parties in a provisional Council of National Unity. Peasants Party members were ``afraid to go ... to investigate exactly what happened,'' Gabrielescu said. Meanwhile, Romania's newly appointed minister of defense said that the Securitate, Ceausescu's infamous secret police, had been completely dissolved. The Securitate battled the army and civilians in the December revolution. But Col. Gen. Victor Stanculescu said a new security force would be formed to protect the state's interests. His comments were an apparent attempt to quell persistent concern that Securitate forces continued to operate. A new security apparatus ``composed of army officers who have proved their loyalty to the state'' would be created ``to protect it from those who would destablize society,'' he told the independent Romania Libera. In Bucharest and elsewhere, 3,294 Securitate members were put on reserve army status, including 611 officers of the former counter-espionage unit, he said. ``The majority ... who gave illegal orders or contributed to the repression of the revolution are under investigation, under arrest ... and will be tried,'' he said. Supervisory groups from the Ministry of Defense have been posted in all the surveillance and bugging centers run by the Securitate, and the listening equipment is being destroyed, Stanculescu said. Deputy Prime Minister Gelu Voican said 15,000 full time employees _ each with an undetermined number of civilian informers _ had worked for the Securitate.

DOC.HEAD: A Billion More People Will Be Born in 1990s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `In 1990...' to DELETE erroneous reference to ``will be born.'' Picks up 4th graf, `By and...'
DOC.TEXT: Earth's population of 5.2 billion people will increase this decade by nearly 1 billion, the fastest population growth in history, a United Nations official said Wednesday. The population is increasing by three people every second, or about a quarter of a million every day, said Nafis Sadik, executive director of the United Nations Population Fund. In 1990 alone, 90 million to 100 million people, or about the combined population of the Philippines and South Korea, will be added in the world, she said. ``By and large, the biggest increases will happen in the poorest countries, those by definition least equipped to meet the needs of the new arrivals and invest in their future,'' Mrs. Sadik said in a speech at the weeklong One Asia Assembly. In 1984 population growth was slowing everywhere except in Africa and parts of South Asia, but the decline was not enough, she said. ``Today, the situation looks less promising. Progress in reducing birth rates has been slower than expected.'' Unless the trend is reversed soon, she said, the world's population by the end of the next century probably would reach 14 billion rather than the 10 billion to 11 billion now projected. She said many Asian governments have declared a determined effort to reduce population growth, but many countries continue to grow at an average of 2 percent to 2.5 percent annually. In Southeast Asia, she added, rapid population growth is damaging the economic gains many countries have achieved. ``One consequence of rapid population growth is to hold back or cripple altogether the prospects of balanced development,'' she said. ``In rural areas, landholdings are already small, generation by generation they are growing smaller, and their owners poorer. ... (Population growth) has swallowed up most of the benefit from investment and services.'' Population growth also threatens food supplies and the environment, she added. Nations should not wait to become industrialized before launching population control programs, she said. Indonesia, South Korea and Thailand made great economic strides while at the same time controlling population growth. ``My vision of the future, despite the gloomy statistics I quoted earlier, is quite optimistic,'' she said. ``Asian countries have shown that population programs can be successful. This is the first step toward a sustainable development.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Subpoenas Three Former New Jersey Housing Officials
DOC.NOTE: EDs: To UPDATE with comment from attorney Nagel, who says he represents Marguglios but not Pieri, SUBS grafs 10-11 with 4 new grafs, bgng, Bruce Nagel ...; picks up 12th graf, The Passaic ...
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators issued subpoenas Wednesday for three former officials of a New Jersey public housing authority accused of receiving improper salaries, including one who was paid for four jobs at the same time. The House subcommittee that has been investigating scandals at the Department of Housing and Urban Development voted to subpoena Paul A. Marguglio, who was suspended from his job as executive director of the Passaic, N.J., Public Housing Authority following a HUD audit. Also subpoenaed was his wife, Louise Marguglio, and the Passaic authority's suspended deputy executive director, Donald V. Pieri. Both were accused by auditors of receiving excessive pay. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., chairman of the Government Operations subcommittee on employment and housing, said none of the three had responded to requests to appear before the panel voluntarily. ``We have received no cooperation,'' Lantos said. ``Therefore, the subcommittee has no option but to issue a subpoena for these individuals.'' The subpoena for each was approved on 7-0 votes, with Republicans joining Democrats in voting to compel their appearance. They were ordered to appear March 2, or at another date set by Lantos. According to an audit by the HUD inspector general and testimony before the Lantos panel, Paul Marguglio received more than $245,000 in salaries during 1988 for holding two full-time and two part-time job titles with the Passaic Public Housing Authority. Louise Marguglio, according to the subcommittee, was paid more than $95,000 as the authority's director of administration between January 1986 and her retirement in April 1988 _ but worked only one day. Auditors concluded she received at least $50,000 in improper compensation. Pieri, according to auditors, also held more than one job and received more than $106,000 in salary. His job as deputy executive director was budgeted to receive $57,970 in annual salary. Bruce Nagel, a New Jersey attorney for the Marguglios, declined to comment on the subpoenas or on the allegations against his clients. Congressional staff investigators said in a memo prepared for members of the panel that neither Nagel nor the three former officials had replied to letters and phone calls from the panel's staff. Nagel denied that he had failed to respond to the committee. ``That's absolutely not true,'' he said. ``I've responded repeatedly. Every time I call, their subcommittee people are not available.'' Nagel said he did not represent Pieri. Efforts to reach Pieri were unsuccessful. His telephone number was unpublished. The Passaic audit prompted HUD to begin a national investigation to look for similar activities. HUD General Counsel Frank Keating told Congress earlier this month, however, that the department believed salary abuses uncovered at Passaic were ``a unique situation.'' Public housing authorities such as the one in Passaic are local agencies that operate primarily with federal HUD money. Paul Adams, the HUD inspector general, said the federal government was likely defrauded when the Passaic authority's commissioners approved more than $245,000 in 1988 pay to Paul Marguglio. He said his office is investigating further.

DOC.HEAD: Quadriplegic Pleads for Change in State Laws on Disabled Care
DOC.TEXT: A quadriplegic who won court permission to shut off his life-sustaining ventilator told lawmakers Wednesday that the state's way of caring for the severely disabled was a big reason behind his wish to die. Larry McAfee, 34, appeared before the Georgia Senate to plead for changes in Georgia's system of care for the disabled, which he called obsolete and cruel. Although he has changed his mind and decided to live, McAfee said the quality of his life since he was paralyzed in 1985 has been poor, primarily because he has been in institutions. ``When you look at me, try to remember that, but for the grace of God, you could be like I am,'' he said, speaking slowly and sometimes gasping for breath. ``Imagine being 34 years old and being forced to live in a nursing home, far from your family and friends.'' McAfee asked a Superior Court judge in Atlanta last year to grant him permission to unplug the ventilator that has helped him breathe since he was paralyzed from the chin down in a 1985 motorcycle accident. The court agreed and the ruling was upheld by the state Supreme Court, but the case raised questions about the quality of life states provide for the disabled. Advocates for the disabled later persuaded McAfee to change his mind about dying and promised to help him find employment. McAfee, a mechanical engineer and outdoorsman before his accident, is dependent on Medicaid and Medicare to pay for the care he receives in an Alabaster, Ala., nursing home equipped to care for patients on ventilators. He has said that depression over becoming an indigent ward of the state contributed to his wish to die. He described life with paralysis as ``existence without choice'' and said the disabled are ``prisoners of bureaucracy that doesn't address the quality of our shattered lives.'' ``I will never, never get used to being totally paralyzed and helpless,'' McAfee said. ``But I have accepted it as my fate.'' McAfee said the state should adopt programs of independent living for the disabled and should not send them to out-of-state nursing homes. ``Unless I and others like me have your help, we have no hope for the future,'' he said. ``If only some of you would have the courage to push for change.'' Sen. Hildred Shumake, who invited McAfee to speak, said he will work to change the system that forces disabled people to remain in institutions. ``He went to school in my district and he's my age,'' Shumake said. ``I felt that something should be done for him.''

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Signing First Loans For Polish Economic Reform
DOC.TEXT: World Bank President Barber Conable will sign two loans totaling $360 million Thursday, the first to Poland since it rejoined the development agency. ``The loans that we will sign are the opening part of an extended program that can last as long as the courageous course continues,'' Conable said at a news conference Wednesday. Poland, which rejoined the World Bank in 1986, stands to receive half of the $5 billion the 152-country agency plans to make available to Eastern Europe in the next three years to fuel economic reform. Future lending being negotiated with the World Bank includes environmental projects, energy development, telecommunications and a structural adjustment loan to support Poland's balance of payments and other potential casualities of the dramatic economic restructuring under way. Conable said he envisions a ``strong pipeline of diverse loans addressed to repair and improvement of the infrastructure.'' He said the first loans ``signal the strength of support for the Polish economic program.'' ``We are not here to provide short-term relief but to contribute to the long-term growth,'' he said. But Conable stressed that future borrowing depends on Poland's resolve to stick to the harsh reform measures adopted Jan. 1 to cap inflation, close the budget deficit and reshape the nation's centrally controlled socialist economy as a market-driven system. ``It is an extremely difficult, complex and heroic program,'' Conable said. He said that after two days of meetings with government and financial leaders, he finds the public mood ``strongly supportive at this point'' and is ``encouraged by the courage the Polish people are showing.'' The economic reform plan has sent prices soaring as government subsidies to state-run industries are cut _ inflation was put at nearly 79 percent in January _ and substantial unemployment is anticipated as unprofitable enterprises close. The World Bank loans follow International Monetary Fund approval of economic reform plan drafted by Poland's new non-Communist government. A $260 million loan will support industrial export, while the second $100 million loan will finance agricultural development. Both are intended to ``break bottlenecks'' such as poor packaging and lack of machine parts that stymie production in Poland's outmoded industries and under-mechanized farming, said Janel Loos, the World Bank's expert on Poland. The 17-year loans will be made available to Poland's national bank, which will extend credit to commercial banks for lending to industries that meet the World Bank's criteria for viability and repayment potential. Conable said Poland must seek further agreements with the Paris Club, the informal group of 17 countries that holds $27 billion of the $40 billion foreign debt. The Paris Club agreed Friday to reschedule nearly $10 billion in Polish debts, suspending all payments until March 1991 and spreading out the rest over 14 years. Poland is seeking reduction of the debt. Also on Wednesday, a European Community spokesman said Polish and Hungarian farmers should lose fewer crops this year to disease because of agricultural chemicals the trading bloc will supply in the next two months. The $61 million in insecticides and herbicides will come from the EC's $366 million aid package for Poland and Hungary. Nico Wegter, EC spokesman for foreign affairs, said the products had to be supplied urgently so that they could be used before spring sowing begins.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Addresses Business Council
DOC.TEXT: President Bush was to press his appeal for more volunteerism in a speech to the nation's most powerful business leaders, his spokesman said Wednesday. Bush was to address the Business Council, composed of chief executive officiers of the 100 largest U.S. corporations, later in the day at a dinner at the Library of Congress. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush would ask their support for ``the administration's legislative agenda.'' The business community generally supports most of Bush's proposals, including his advocacy of a lower capital gains tax _ a subject he mentions whenever he addresses business groups. In his speech to the corporate executives, Fitzwater said, Bush also wanted ``to discuss their involvement as voluntary leaders in their communities.'' As with most Business Council sessions with government officials, the session was to be closed to the press. Fitzwater said that ran against White House wishes, but that the president would respect the organization's request for privacy. ``We always want these things open. The president makes the same remarks whether it's open or closed,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin Rejects Visa Requests from Congressmen
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has turned down visa requests from four members of Congress who had planned to go to Lithuania for legislative and local elections this weekend, the State Department said Wednesday. Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler expressed regret over the decision and said U.S. Ambassador John Matlock was raising the issue with Soviet authorities. Soviet officials said the visas for the lawmakers were not approved because the four had not been invited by the appropriate authorities in Moscow, the spokeswoman said. An invitation had been extended instead by an independent movement in Lithuania, where a pro-secessionist movement has been gaining strength. The congressmen are Richard Durbin, D-Ill.; Bill Sarpulias, D-Texas; Christopher Cox, R-Calif., and John Miller, R-Wash. They departed on their trip Tuesday and were in West Berlin on Wednesday, hoping the Soviets would reverse their decision. ``The Soviet refusal to issue visas is inconsistent with a pattern of broad contacts between legislators in both countries,'' Ms. Tutwiler said, adding that the United States recently hosted a visit by Soviet legislators.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Accuses Ex-minister of ``Egotism''
DOC.TEXT: A special prosecutor Wednesday accused a former justice minister of being stubborn and egotistical, and he urged the supreme court to convict her of leaking official secrets to her husband. Joseph-Daniel Piller, the state prosecutor in the nation's first criminal trial of a former Cabinet member, also asked the court to fine former Justice Minister Elisabeth Kopp $5,400. Mrs. Kopp, the only woman in Swiss history to sit in the Cabinet, went on trial Monday and pleaded innocent. A verdict by the five-man supreme court, the Federal Tribunal, is expected Friday. At Wednesday's session, Piller accused Mrs. Kopp of ``egoism'' for trying to pin her one-time personal assistant with the blame for the telephone call to her husband that is at the center of the case. In a final statement to the court Wednesday, Mrs. Kopp rejected Piller's portrayal and pleaded for acquittal. She cited her 20-year record of public service. Her attorney, Peter Hafter, charged that Swiss news media prejudiced the trial with their reporting on the scandal. In his summary, Piller also attacked Mrs. Kopp for what he called showing ``stubbornness and untruthfulness'' in her halting public disclosures during the affair, which forced her resignation in January 1989. He also demanded convictions and lesser fines for Mrs. Kopp's assistant, Katharina Schoop, and another former Justice Ministry aide, Renate Schwob. All are charged with violating official secrets laws, an offense that carries a maximum three-year prison term and fines of up to $27,000. Mrs. Kopp, 53, admitted in court that she called her husband, lawyer- businessman Hans W. Kopp, from her office on Oct. 27, 1988, and urged him to break ties with a firm under scrutiny in Switzerland's biggest inquiry into the laundering of drug money. Kopp resigned as vice president at Lebanese-controlled Shakarchi Trading A.G. the same day. No charges have been filed against Shakarchi, and the company has denied involvement. Ms. Schoop testified that Schwob showed her department documents containing the Shakarchi suspicions. Ms. Schoop said that when she rushed to tell Mrs. Kopp, the information's source was never mentioned. However, she said she believed Mrs. Kopp must have realized it came from inside the ministry. Mrs. Kopp denied that version, saying she tipped her husband believing the suspicions came from ``banking circles.'' However, Mrs. Kopp acknowledged she told her husband to phone Ms. Schoop for details.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Won't Have to Cut 400 Agents, Justice Department Says
DOC.TEXT: The FBI won't have to cut 400 agents from its payroll next year because it has found new ways to save money under President Bush's proposed 1991 fiscal-year budget, the Justice Department said Wednesday. The cost-cutting measures were worked out in the last few weeks since Bush's budget proposal was sent to Congress, said Justice Department spokesman David Runkel. Under the proposed budget, the FBI would have been forced to cut more than 400 agents from its payroll, probably through attrition, in order to finance an estimated $42 million in additional overtime expenses. A new law passed by Congress last year increases the overtime pay for federal law enforcement officers, including FBI agents. After the budget was unveiled, FBI officials said the bureau would be forced to cut more than 400 agents from its workforce of more tan 10,000. But under the new plan to pay for the overtime costs, the FBI will stagger the hiring of 338 new agents provided in the 1991 budget to investigate organized crime, drugs and white-collar fraud, said an FBI official. The hiring of these additional agents will be spread out over the 1991 fiscal year to save money, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The FBI will also save money by postponing purchase of some new equipment, said the official.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Went Berserk, Bit Passers-By, Had AIDS, Police Say
DOC.TEXT: A man who went berserk on a city street and bit at least eight people before he collapsed and died was suffering from AIDS, police said Wednesday, and they encouraged his victims to call health authorities. Experts say there are no known instances of AIDS being transmitted by biting, but police said they were issuing the appeal as a precaution. The incident occurred Feb. 7 when Jean Marc Rosius, 28, who gave his address as a homeless shelter, began accosting passersby, said police spokesman Ray Lang. At least four people were bitten seriously enough to be hospitalized, including some who had flaps of skin hanging off arms and faces. The arresting officer, Orestes Guas, was also bitten and treated, Lang said. ``After Mr. Rosius was subdued, he had breathing difficulties, and was transported to Jackson Memorial Hospital, where he died,'' said Lang. An autopsy found that Rosius, who had a history of mental problems, had used cocaine and had AIDS. ``At this point, what we're doing is recommending that anyone who had any contact with Mr. Rosius _ if they were bitten or scratched or had any relationship at all,'' contact their local AIDS hotline, he said. In addition to the four people hospitalized, three others initially reported that they had been bitten. Authorities think they may be illegal aliens who are reluctant to come forward. One of those bitten and hospitalized was Guillermo Herrada, 54. ``This is the worst news I've ever had in my life,'' Herrada said Tuesday. ``I don't know what I'm going to do.'' ``There aren't documented instances of HIV (the AIDS virus) transmitted by a human bite, but in health care settings, there have been instances of HIV transmitted by blood through a needle stick,'' said Constance Wofsy, professor of clinical medicine at the University of California at San Francisco. ``There's a theoretic possibility that falls between no reported cases and the hypothetical risk of blood being exchanged through a deep bite,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Flooded Areas Brace for More Rain
DOC.TEXT: A new storm system raised the threat of more flooding Wednesday in the saturated South, where heavy rains last week were blamed for nine deaths. ``There are places that have no room to put more rain _ I'm talking about completely saturated,'' Dusty Perkins of the Mississippi Emergency Management Agency said Wednesday. ``If heavy rain falls in areas that are already inundated, we are going to certainly have an aggravated situation in terms of more evacuations and additional damage.'' The rain was associated with a strong low pressure system and cold front moving eastward from the Texas Gulf Coast. By midday, showers and thunderstorms already extended from the eastern half of Texas across Louisiana, southern Alabama, southwestern Arkansas and southern through western Oklahoma, the National Weather Service said. During the six hours up to noon, 2.66 inches fell at Palacios, Texas and 1.25 inches at Victoria, Texas. Flood watches were posted to the east as far as northwestern Florida. Since late last week, floods have been blamed for three deaths each in Georgia and Alabama, two in Mississippi and one in North Carolina. In southern Mississippi, residents along the Pascagoula River system were told to prepare for what could be the worst flooding in years. The Pascagoula at Merrill was up to 24.7 feet and still rising Wednesday, heading toward a predicted 27-foot crest Friday. Flood stage is 22 feet. ``The question now is how much more rain are we going to get,'' said Hank Turk, Jackson County public safety director. Rivers were receding over much of Alabama, but the ground was saturated and the weather service predicted 2 to 4 inches of rain, meaning some streams would likely jump their banks again. The additional rain comes while damage estimates for the floods that began last week are still far from complete. ``Our damage figures continue to increase as flood waters recede and we are able to get into areas that were under water,'' said Rudy Duncan, who is directing the Red Cross operation in Alabama. Georgia Gov. Joe Frank Harris has asked for $15.7 million in federal disaster aid for nine counties because of floods and tornadoes. Up to 5 inches of rain was forecast from the new round of storms in Mississippi, but the weather might be less severe in Georgia, producing up to 2 inches instead of the 10 that hit parts of Georgia last weekend. ``It will be cooler than last week, so that will limit the rain a little bit,'' said weather service hydrologist Russell Post in Atlanta. ``But there's still a potential for several inches of rain.''

DOC.HEAD: More Rain Heads in South, Snow in Northwest
DOC.TEXT: A new round of storms moved into the flood-weary South on Wednesday, and the Northwest received up to a foot of snow. By Midday, showers and thunderstorms extended from the eastern half of Texas across Louisiana, Alabama, Arkansas and Oklahoma. Flood watches were issued for southeastern Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and northwestern Florida. Morning thunderstorms generated wind gusting to 60 mph at Alice, Texas. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to noon included 2.66 inches at Palacios, Texas, and 1.25 inches at Victoria, Texas. As much as 12 inches of snow fell overnight across the northern Cascades and northeastern mountains of Oregon, with lighter snowfall over the southern Cascades. Rain was scattered over the northern Pacific Coast. Farther north, Kodiak, Alaska, got 6 additional inches of snow Wednesday morning for a total February snowfall of 21 inches and 102 inches for the season to date. The record is 159 inches, over 13 feet, in the winter of 1970-1971. Elsewhere, snow was scattered over northern Maine and south-central Kansas. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 11 degrees at Limestone, Maine, to 86 at both Fort Myers and Naples, Fla. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 15 below zero at Caribou, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Terrorist Abandons Appeal
DOC.TEXT: A convicted Palestinian terrorist has dropped his appeal in a bombing case after a co-defendant confessed to involvement, news reports said Wednesday. A district court in December sentenced Abu Talb and Marten Imandi to life in prison for three bombings in Denmark and the Netherlands in 1985 and 1986. Both pleaded innocent and later appealed their convictions. However, Imandi confessed earlier this month to having carried the trunks containing the bombs. One person was killed and several injured in the explosions outside American and Israeli targets in Copenhagen and Amsterdam. ``Since the confession of Marten Imandi has rendered a trial of the case in the Appellate Court pointless, I hereby recall my notice of appeal,'' the national news agency TT quoted Abu Talb as saying in a letter to the court. Abu Talb has been named as a possible suspect in the explosion of Pan Am's Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988. A total of 270 people died in the bombing, which was linked to Abu Talb through clothes found in the suitcase containing the bomb. Abu Talb's lawyer, Sven-Erik Sjogren, told TT the decision to drop the appeal ``has no connection with the Lockerbie case.'' Despite his confession, Imandi is still appealing to challenge his life sentence. The appeals trial opens in Stockholm on Wednesday for him and a third defendant, Moustafa Mougrabi. He was sentenced to one year in prison. His brother, Mahmoud Mougrabi, also confessed to taking part in the bombings and did not appeal his six-year sentence.

DOC.HEAD: It's Back to Winter for Winter Wheat Growers
DOC.TEXT: The nation's winter wheat region has returned to February reality after weeks of balmy temperatures, the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Wednesday. ``Winter returned to the northern and central plains as Arctic air plunged south and reversed the warm spell of the last two months,'' the facility said in its report for Feb. 11-17. ``Rain benefited winter wheat in portions of the central and southern Great Plains,'' the report said, although ``additional moisture was needed in Kansas.'' The facility is operated by the department's of Agriculture and Commerce. The weekly reports cover weather and crop conditions but do not include crop production forecasts. In a related report, the USDA said wheat inventories may drop to 443 million bushels by the beginning of the next marketing year on June 1, the lowest in 15 years and down from 702 million bushels a year ago. ``However, increases in planted area and a return to normal yields in 1990 will likely allow modest stock rebuilding if use is similar to the previous two years,'' the department's Economic Research Service said. The U.S. area planted to winter wheat last fall is up 3 percent, even though an additional 1.9 million acres of wheat base were enrolled in the Conservation Reserve Program during 1989. ``While the winter wheat crop in the southern plains was stressed by dryness in the fall and early winter, precipitation and relatively mild temperatures in January and February have raised crop prospects,'' the report said. ``Nonetheless, timely rains will be needed in coming months.''

DOC.HEAD: Havel Says Europe `Will Decide for Itself' on U.S., Soviet Troops
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 3-4, bgng, At Bush's ... to UPDATE with meeting at White House
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel told Congress Wednesday that his nation welcomes U.S. help after decades of Soviet domination but that eventually Europe must ``decide for itself'' how long American and Soviet troops should remain. His speech, to a joint meeting of the House and Senate, came a day after President Bush told the playwright-turned-president that NATO would ``continue to play a vital role in assuring stability and security in Europe'' and that the United States would maintain a ``strong military presence.'' At Bush's request, Havel returned to the White House after his speech to Congress. White House aides said the 45-minute return session was not designed to smooth over any differences on troop levels, but to complete talks on economic issues and trade. ``They didn't get to all (the items) yesterday,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. He said they talked at length Wednesday about the future of Europe and agreed to stay in close contact during this period of rapid change. Havel, the first of the new East European leaders to address Congress, said the United States could best help his country by pressing the Soviet Union to stay on its own road to democracy. He said he recognized a need for U.S. troops in Europe. But, he added, ``Sooner or later, Europe must recover and come into its own, and decide for itself how many of whose soldiers it needs.'' In a speech that was largely philosophical, Havel said Americans need to learn, along with his country, ``how to put morality ahead of politics, science and economics.'' Havel, who reluctantly accepted the popular mandate of his country to lead during its time of rapid transition, received a two-minute standing ovation in the crowded House chamber, and appeared somewhat stiff and surprised at the reception. As he began to speak, U.S. tennis star and former Czechoslovak citizen Martina Navratilova dabbed at her eyes with a handkerchief in the top row of the visitor's gallery. Speaking through a translator, Havel called Czechoslovakia one of Eastern Europe's ``wayward children'' and said it wants to coordinate its return to the economic and political mainstream with Hungary, Poland and other nations emerging from 40 years of Soviet domination. The United States can best aid that return, he said, by helping the Soviet Union ``on its irreversible, but immensely complicated road to democracy.'' ``The more quickly and the more peacefully the Soviet Union begins to move along the road towards genuine political pluralism'' and economic reform, ``the better it will be _ not just for Czechs and Slovaks, but for the whole world,'' he said. Addressing reporters later, Havel declined to elaborate on that call, saying it was not his place to suggest specific moves to the United States. The members of Congress came to their feet when Havel said his country's peaceful revolution was inspired by the U.S. Constitution, Bill of Rights and Declaration of Independence. ``They inspire us to be citizens,'' he said. After his White House meeting, Havel was leaving Washington for New York and meetings with business leaders _ and a rock concert in his honor. Havel, the first head of state from his country to visit Washington, said that Europe is leaving the ``antiquated straitjacket'' of a world dominated by two superpowers for one in which nations can stand more independently. Lawmakers applauded his conclusion that American troops will be able to return home ``because Europe will at last be able to stand guard over itself.'' In the meantime, he declared, ``Czechoslovakia is returning to Europe.'' Havel called for the removal of ``as many Soviet (military) units as possible'' from his country before national elections scheduled for June. He also called for moving up the Helsinki II international conference now planned for 1992 and turning it into a European peace conference ``that would finally put a formal end to the Second World War and all its unhappy consequences.'' At a brief news conference later, he suggested such a meeting might come in 1991. Turning philosophical, he said years of repression have given his countrymen time to ponder what is truly important, and said Americans can learn from that experience as well. ``The salvation of this human world lies nowhere else than in the human heart, in the human power to reflect, in human meekness and human responsibility,'' Havel told the lawmakers. ``We are still under the sway of the destructive and vain belief that man is the pinnacle of creation, and not just a part of it, and that therefore everything is permitted.'' His speech came a day after Havel got promises from Bush of freer trade between the two countries and incentives for new investment and economic development. The Bush administration and leading lawmakers also have proposed expanding an aid program begun last year for Poland and Hungary to include Czechoslovakia and other countries emerging from Soviet domination. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has proposed sweetening the program with an additional $511 million next year and including new countries that meet certain tests for economic and political reform. Havel did not directly address the question of aid, but at one point commented that greater stability in Europe would lead to reductions in U.S. military spending. ``The millions you give to the East today will soon return to you in the form of billions in savings,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Claims Responsibility for Explosion Near Army Van
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with police stoned while trying to arrest suspects in other incident, MINOR EDITING; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility Wednesday for a bombing near an army van in the center of Leicester that shook buildings, knocked down pedestrians and slightly injured three people. In a separate incident, a stone-throwing crowd forced police officers to release five people suspected of planning to attack an army helicopter, authorities said Wednesday. Three suspects were recaptured later, however. A forensic examination had established ``similarities'' between Tuesday's bomb in Leicester, 100 miles northwest of London, and a device found after an unsuccessful attempt to assassinate Lt. Gen. Sir David Ramsbotham in London's fashionable Kensington district on Nov. 14, said Assistant Chief Constable Tony Butler. Both were homemade devices containing 4 to 5 pounds of high-powered plastic explosive and mercury tilt switches and were attached to the bottom of the vehicles by magnets, he said. On both occasions, the magnets failed and the bombs fell onto the road, preventing death or serious injury. The IRA claimed responsibility for Tuesday's blast in a statement Wednesday night to Britain's domestic news agency, Press Association. The blast shook buildings within 200 yards and shattered more than two dozen windows at a nearby unused factory, sending shards of glass over a wide area. The van's driver, a Women's Royal Army Corps sergeant, and her passenger, a Coldstream Guards sergeant, escaped with only minor injuries, as did a passerby who was showered with glass. Home Secretary David Waddington on Wednesday described the blast as ``another diabolical enterprise by the IRA.'' The IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the province, where Protestants outnumber Catholics 3 to 2, with the Republic of Ireland, where 95 percent of the people are Catholic. In their report on the alleged plan to shoot down the helicopter, police said the crew of the aircraft spotted masked men preparing an ambush outside Cullyhanna village in South Armagh. The area is known as ``bandit country'' because of its links with the IRA and because it is close to the border with the Irish Republic. The crew radioed an alert to police, but the attack squad apparently heard it on their own radio and fled toward the border, authorities said. Police arriving at the scene reported finding three rifles and two heavy machine guns that can fire 800 armor-piercing bullets a minute. They have been used by the IRA in past attacks on helicopters. The police chased the group, which hijacked and abandoned eight cars in their escape attempt over narrow, twisting country roads. They were finally cornered in Silverbridge village. However, the police said they had to set their captives free when the officers were surrounded and stoned by a crowd of about 40 men in a housing project. The police managed to resume the chase and make three arrests, but at least two suspects escaped.

DOC.HEAD: Law to Create Powerful Presidency Goes to Legislature
DOC.TEXT: Soviet legislators were given copies Wednesday of proposed constitutional changes that would make the presidency, now held by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, much more powerful. Gorbachev has urged the Supreme Soviet to approve the plan for a Western-style presidential system of government. Vladimir Tumanov of the Institute of State and Law in Moscow, who helped draft the proposal, said copies were distributed Wednesday and the Supreme Soviet held closed committee meetings. Tumanov said he had not seen the final version and could not give details. News reports said the changes would provide for the president to be elected to terms of either five or six years and give him the power to veto legislation, which could be overriden. According to the published accounts: Sergei Stankevich, a member of a parliamentary commission that considers draft laws submitted to the Supreme Soviet, said the Soviet president would have most of the powers of his French and American counterparts with few of the constitutional limitations. Deputies from the Baltic states are alarmed about provisions that would impose severe restrictions on the rights of republics to secede and permit authorities to crack down on ``nationalist'' organizations. Stankevich said: ``I don't think this new legislation will be acceptable to anyone who believes in a constitutional system of checks and balances.'' Alexander Yakovlev, an aide to Gorbachev, said the presidential system was necessary to ensure stable development of democracy in the Soviet Union. The reports said the president would be empowered to declare an emergency without the relevant republic's consent, to rule by decree when the Supreme Soviet was not in session and to cancel legislation adopted by the legislatures of Soviet republics. They said the parliament could take votes of no-confidence, and if the president lost he could disband the parliament and call new elections.

DOC.HEAD: South African Minister's Visit to Angola Reportedly Postponed
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Ministry sources said a visit to Angola by South African Foreign Minister Pik Botha, expected Thursday, was postponed and would take place March 1. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Wednesday Angola was informed of the postponement by a telex from South Africa's Department of Foreign Affairs. Botha reportedly will have confer with Foreign Minister Pedro de Castro van Dunem, and possibly with President Jose Eduardo dos Santos, on deteriorating peace prospects here. Bitter fighting intensified Wednesday around Mavinga, 700 miles southeast in Cuanda Cubango province. An airstrip at Mavinga and a nearby rebel base block the government forces' way to rebel headquarters at Jamba, more than 120 miles farther south. A statement released in Lisbon, Portugal, and signed by UNITA chief Jonas Savimbi said soldiers retreated under rebel pressure. It gave no details of positions held in the town's seven-square-mile area. The statement claimed that government planes were dropping chemical bombs on civilian and military targets behind UNITA lines. It said rebels captured more than 15 pilots and tank engineers in the clashes and would turn them over to Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko, who was appointed mediator after a short-lived truce last June. UNITA _ the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ has been fighting to force the Marxist government in Luanda to share power since shortly after Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. The battle for Mavinga has raged since the government launched an offensive late December. ``We will resist to the last, and in this sense we have been able to count on the Americans, who have guaranteed us material and moral support,'' the UNITA statement said. UNITA receives a reported $50 million in U.S. aid yearly, including sophisticated Stinger ground-to-air missiles. Angolan troops use Soviet weapons. Botha and Van Dunem will try to set a possible date for a meeting here of Angolan, Cuban and South African officials, the sources said. Angola, Cuba and South Africa signed U.S.-brokered regional peace accords in December 1988 in New York that set terms for withdrawal of about 50,000 Cuban soldiers from Angola, a halt in South African aid to UNITA and independence for Namibia, formerly ruled by South Africa. A meeting of the three nations with U.S. and Soviet observers had been set for mid-February, but was postponed after Cuba suspended its troop withdrawal on Jan. 25 after four Cubans died in a UNITA raid in western Angola. Cuba and Angola said Tuesday in Luanda the pullout would resume Sunday, after Savimbi apologized to Cuban President Fidel Castro for the deaths. An Angolan-UNITA truce was agreed on last June, but it collapsed within weeks and peace talks broke down. Mobutu's efforts to get the two parties back to negotiations have failed, despite backing from the superpowers and African and European leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Police Mobilized as Gang Battle Spreads
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of police were mobilized Wednesday to protect a Tokyo suburb from a war between an affilitate of the Yamaguchi-gumi, Japan's largest underworld syndicate, and a smaller gang. The violence began last Thursday when two members of the Yamaguchi-gumi faction led by Masaru Takumi were beaten to death at an office of the Nibiki-kai gang in the suburb, Hachioji. In a show of strength Wednesday morning, dozens of police raided the Takumi group's headquarters and several other Yamaguchi-gumi buildings in Osaka, western Japan. Later Wednesday, a two-ton truck was rammed into the home of Kazuhiko Yanai, a Nibiki-kai leader in Yokohama, a city police official reported. He said several shots were fired, but no one was injured. After gang boss Yoshinori Watanabe, Takumi is the most powerful leader in the Yamaguchi-gumi, which police say has about 21,000 members. They declined to estimate the size of the much smaller Nibiki-kai. Nearly a dozen gang clashes have been reported since last Thursday, including the fatal shooting of a Nibiki-kai leader in Hokkaido, northern Japan. Thirteen Yamaguchi-gumi members and three from Nibiki-kai have been arrested. On Tuesday, a Yamaguchi-gumi member turned himself in to Hachioji police after mistakenly ramming a pickup truck into a building he thought belonged to the rival gang, officers said. No one was hurt. Because of that incident and nine shootings, police in Hachioji mobilized 300 to 400 officers Wednesdy to crack down on gang activity, a police official in the suburb said. Children have been told not to walk near the gang office, which is near an elementary school. The official, who would not let his name be used, said Hachioji police were joined by investigators from Tokyo's Metropolitan Police Department, but he would not say how many. An official at Tokyo headquarters, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the department held a strategy meeting Wednesday morning. He would not comment further, to avoid ``giving away our battle plan.'' Handguns are illegal in Japan and violent crimes are relatively rare, but police say a three-year war between the Yamaguchi-gumi and the Ichiwa-kai that cost more than 25 lives led many gangs to obtain more weapons. Police also say the Yamaguchi-gumi's lack of a decisive victory in the war, which ended last year with the rival leader's retirement, encouraged other gangs to challenge its turf. They estimate the total number of gangsters in Japan at 90,000 and say nearly half are associated with the three largest gangs _ the Yamaguchi-gumi, Inagawa-kai and Sumiyoshi Rengo. Total underworld income, derived mostly from drugs, extortion and gambling, is believed to exceed the equivalent of $9 billion a year.

DOC.HEAD: Some British A-Plant Workers May Be Warned: No Children
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with company comment. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Gardner met ...'
DOC.TEXT: Some workers at the Sellafield nuclear reprocessing plant may be counseled not to have children because higher-than-expected rates of leukemia have been found among workers' children, a company official said Wednesday. Dr. Roger Berry, health and safety director for British Nuclear Fuels Ltd., operator of the plant, said: ``Workers who want individual counseling can get it and if they are so worried the advice could be: `Don't have children.' It is not something, however, that I hope would be widespread advice.'' British Nuclear Fuels later issued a statement saying advising workers not to have families ``is not company policy.'' A research team headed by Martin Gardner, professor of medical studies at the University of Southampton, reported in last week's British Medical Journal that children of men who worked at the plant had a higher-than-expected rate of leukemia. British Nuclear Fuels said the company had promised medical counseling for all employees to ensure they understood the report and the risks to them if its findings are confirmed. ``Ultimately, it is then for each individual worker to reach a decision, not for the company to advise on one course of action or another,'' it said. Gardner met with workers at the plant in northern England on Wednesday and later said he was urging British Nuclear Fuels to study whether it was possible to minimize radiation exposures of younger workers. ``These would be the sort of people who were still capable of having families and may prefer not working in higher radiation levels,'' said Gardner, adding he did not wish to overstate the risks involved. ``The risk of a child in this country getting leukemia is 1 in 2,000, while those whose fathers were exposed to the highest radiation levels is about 7 in 2,000, or 1 in 300. ``What I am saying to them is that 299 out of 300 children will not get leukemia even if their fathers have been subjected to the highest exposure levels.'' Gardner said he told workers his report did not prove a connection between childhood leukemia and radiation exposure to the fathers. ``It is something that I suggest could be associated and not necessarily showing cause and effect,'' he said. Alan Johnson, director of reprocessing at Sellafield, said he wanted to see more studies on possible links between leukemia and radiation. ``We have always reduced radiation levels over the past 20 years and will continue to reduce them,'' he said. Bernard Owen, a local official of the General and Municipal Boilermakers Union, said that ``as a matter of urgency we want to see a follow-up of his study and the collating of further studies into the problem before we can come to a firm conclusion.'' Martin Forwood, campaign secretary of CORE _ Cumbrians Opposed to a Radioactive Environment _ said he hoped Wednesday's meetings would calm workforce fears. ``Publicly, the workers may not state their worries because they are a very loyal and captive work force,'' Forwood said. ``However, I am sure that behind closed doors there must be a lot of doubt and concern among them, especially among those of the reproductive age.'' Gardner's study examined 52 victims of leukemia and lymphoma under 25 years old, born in the West Cumbria health district and diagnosed between 1950-85. They were compared with 1,001 control children. One researcher, radiotherapist Michael Snee, said the radiation probably caused a mutation in the fathers' sperm. In November, the Medical Research Council and the Imperial Research Fund reported that an increased risk of leukemia is not associated with exposure to radiation, with the possible exception of the Sellafield plant, which has been plagued by radiation leaks. Gardner said the main finding of his study was that the risk was highest for a father who received total exposure exceeding 100 millisieverts. One millisievert equals half a typical individual's annual dose from natural radiation, or 50 times the dose of a single chest X-ray.

DOC.HEAD: East Berlin Synagogue Reconstruction Cost To Exceed $16 Million
DOC.TEXT: Reconstruction of an East Berlin synagogue that was once one of the most important in Europe will cost at least $16.6 million, a Jewish community official said Wednesday.
