The Neue Berliner Synagogue, destroyed by air raids in World War II, is being rebuilt as a synagogue and a Jewish center. It is more commonly known as Oranienburger synagogue, after the street it is on. Reconstruction began on Nov. 9, 1988, the 50th anniversary of a pogrom in which Nazis beat and killed Jews and destroyed synagogues and Jewish businesses. The Neue Berliner Synagogue was set afire that night. Only about 400 practicing Jews remain in East Germany today, about half of them in East Berlin. According to Heinz Galinski, leader of the West Berlin Jewish community, there were 173,000 practicing Jews in Berlin before the Holocaust. Hermann Simon, director of the foundation overseeing reconstruction of the synagogue and deputy leader of East Berlin's Jewish community, said the project is relying mainly on donations. The official news agency ADN distributed his remarks. He also is counting on help from the present and future East German governments. The government under Erich Honecker, now ousted, had agreed to finance 35 percent of the project. Simon praised West Germany for its recent contribution of about $580,000. ``Every German government has to face this part of history, no matter what the common future may bring,'' Simon said. He said projects at the new center will include continuing education classes for teachers and art exhibitions about Jewish life.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Nominate Education Official to Postal Service Position
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he will nominate LeGree S. Daniels, an assistant secretary of education, to be a governor of the U.S. Postal Service. Mrs. Daniels, 69, would succeed John L. Ryan if confirmed by the Senate. Since 1987, Mrs. Daniels has been assistant secretary of civil rights in the Education Department.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-PLO Leader Says Jews Could Live in Future Palestine
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian who is considered a potential peace negotiator said Wednesday that Jewish settlers in the occupied lands could stay in a future Palestinian state if they integrated into Arab villages. ``People who want to live in mixed Jewish-Moslem-Christian villages, that's fine, but there will be no room for ghettos,'' pro-PLO activist Faisal Husseini said. He was speaking to about 200 Israeli activists of a newly formed peace movement of Sephardic Jews from slums and poor towns. Husseini, speaking in Hebrew, said more than 70,000 Israelis who live in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip would have to agree to live under Palestinian rule if they wished to remain. The Israelis live alongside 1.7 million Palestinians. The Sephardic group, called The Forum for Social Justice and Peace, claims a membership of 2,000 Jewish Israelis of Arab origin. Such people traditionally have been steadfast supporters of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc. However, the new group's leaders want the Israeli government to begin peace talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization. ``We have no choice but to talk to the Palestinians, even with (PLO chief) Yasser Arafat. Arafat is showing openness. Why shouldn't we be going for peace?'' said one organizer, Yehuda Elush, a former Likud supporter from the southern town of Beersheba. Husseini's 20-minute speech was one of a series he has given lately to Jewish groups as part of a new PLO-backed strategy to win more grass-roots sympathy among Israelis for the Palestinian cause. Husseini, a 49-year-old historian from Israeli-annexed East Jerusalem, has been named as a possible negotiator with Israel for proposed talks in Egypt on Israel's plan for elections in the occupied lands. He has also spent about 18 months in jail during the 26-month-old Palestinian uprising on allegations of inciting anti-Israeli unrest. In response to a question, Husseini told his audience that Palestinians could drop the stone-throwing and firebomb attacks if Israel ends its strong-arm tactics. ``If we are offered another path, one of compromise from the Israelis, and we are allowed to hold non-violent demonstrations without being attacked by the army, then we will take a different path. We won't need stones, firebombs or violence,'' Husseini said. More than 650 Arabs have been killed by Israelis in the unrest, and 187 others been slain by fellow Palestinians as alleged collaborators with Israel. Forty-three Israelis also have died.

DOC.HEAD: Mothers' Milk Contains Natural Tranquilizers, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Mothers' milk contains natural tranquilizers, Swedish researchers reported Wednesday. The results could help explain why babies become calm and fall asleep after breast feeding, said Professor Sven Dencker of Lillhagens Hospital in Goteborg on Sweden's west coast. ``We studied the breast milk of women who were known not to take benzodiazepine-substances (tranquilizers) and to our suprise we found that such substances existed anyway,'' he said in a radio interview. Dencker said the quantities were small but existed in all 10 women included in a control group for research on the effects of tranquilizers on women who breast feed. He said research results were being published in the next issue of the British medical journal Lancet. ``It is feasible that this calming effect ... played a greater role in early history, when a family would be surrounded by wild animals and it was necessary for survival that children kept quiet,'' Dencker said. The Svenska Dagbladet daily said discovery of natural tranquilizers in mothers' milk could explain why human cells have natural receptors for benzodiazepines. The function of the receptors has been a mystery, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Looting of Food Stores Follows Months of Recession, Inflation
DOC.TEXT: Slumdwellers reacting to months of rampant inflation looted food stores Wednesday despite the efforts of police and paramilitary border guards to keep order, news agencies reported. Looting began before dawn with attacks on several delivery trucks and small stores, the government news agency Telam said. Fifteen arrests were reported. Police patroled the streets of Rosario, 185 miles north of Buenos Aires, all day and the Interior Ministry described the city as calm and ``absolutely normal'' by late afternoon. The private news agency Diarios y Noticias said, however, that looters appeared at half a dozen stores just before dusk. It said, quoting police in Rosario, that some of the looters were women and children, who fled when officers approached. ``I felt sorry for them,'' the driver of a truck that was stopped and looted of tons of flour, sugar, noodles and other food said on television. ``They looked hungry. ... No one tried to hurt me. They told me to get out and run. I did.'' Similar looting in May 1989 grew to riots in which 16 people were killed, nearly 200 injured and more than 1,700 arrested. Those disturbances also were centered in Rosario, Argentina's second-largest city. The cost of living soared by 79 percent last month and is projected at about the same level this month. Wages have not kept pace and unemployment has grown to 10 percent, with another 10 percent of the 12.5 million workers underemployed. In Cordoba on Monday, several dozen women ran through a market grabbing fruits and vegetables. They were not caught.

DOC.HEAD: Assault on World's Tallest Peak Has New Aims
DOC.TEXT: The first American to scale Mount Everest is planning another assault 26 years later, this time with a trash bag on his back and Soviet and Chinese colleagues at his side. Jim Whittaker is leading the three-nation ``Peace Climb'' to celebrate world peace and mark the 20th anniversary of Earth Day. The 30-person expedition will clean decades of discarded oxygen bottles and other debris left by previous climbers, he said. If all goes as planned, one climber from the United States, China and the Soviet Union will set foot on the 29,028-foot peak on April 22. Gaining the participation of climbing teams from the Soviet Union and China, which only recently eased relations after decades of mutual hostility, took a little shuttle diplomacy, Whittaker said. When he approached the Chinese in 1987, they told him they were interested but would only invite the Soviets if they knew in advance the Soviets would say yes. ``They didn't want to lose face,'' Whittaker said. In Moscow, he said, the Soviets told him they would participate only if they knew for sure they were invited. ``They thought the Chinese may be trying to embarrass them,'' he said. So he returned to China, where he finally was told, ``Mr. Whittaker, you may bring your Soviet friends to our mountain.'' ``When you get enough people behind a movement _ the environment and peace _ leaders will get smart and get in front or be toppled,'' Whittaker said. Whittaker said the team members will plant their national flags and bounce signals off a U.S. space satellite to broadcast live television footage of the event. Each will speak to their nation's leader by telephone. The idea for the Peace Climb was hatched during a 1981 ascent of the 14,411-foot Mount Rainier during which Whittaker and two friends guided several disabled climbers to the summit. They wondered what else they could do to make the world a better place to live, to show that people from entirely different worlds can work together toward a common goal. On the day of the climb, children from several American schools will climb nearby hills and pick up garbage as they go, Whittaker said. On the Peace Climb, dozens of climbers hauling gear and food from lower camps to higher camps to support the summit assault will stop on their way down to fill empty duffels with trash left behind by climbers over the past seven decades. An estimated two tons of discarded tents, empty oxygen bottles, tin cans and other garbage littering the flanks of Everest will be buried in a landfill near the base camp at 17,100 feet, team members said. Whittaker, who scaled Everest in 1963 and led the first American ascent of K-2 in 1978, doesn't plan to try for the summit himself, preferring to leave that bid to younger and stronger climbers. ``An essential ingredient to this is that if one climber falters, climbers from all three countries will turn back,'' said Warren Thompson, the expedition's deputy leader. ``It's important that what we accomplish is accomplished together.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Cabinet Will Weight All U.S. Peace Ideas
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Party Wednesday won a pledge from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to allow the Cabinet to review U.S. peace proposals offered at meetings later this week, a Labor official said. Labor's leader, Finance Minister Shimon Peres, also said the party will quit the coalition government if it rejects a proposal for Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens is scheduled to stop in Washington for two days after a visit to Mexico. He will meet Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Friday for a discussion of the stalled Mideast peace process. Shamir, of the right-wing Likud bloc, ordered that no U.S. ideas be immediately rejected, a senior Labor official said. He said Shamir acted after his coalition partners in the left-of-center Labor Party expressed fears that Arens would reject Baker's proposals without consulting them, the Labor official said. The official said Peres and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, also of Labor, met with Shamir on Wednesday to tell the premier that Arens ``cannot respond in a negative way to Baker's proposals regarding issues on which there is no Cabinet decision.'' ``Shamir is to instruct Arens he should not reject Baker's proposals but pass them on to the Cabinet,'' the official said. He said Labor leaders were satisfied with the decision ``as this is exactly what they wanted.'' Shamir aide Avi Pazner would not confirm that any such specific instructions would be given to Arens. However, he said U.S. ideas would be passed on to the Cabinet. ``Arens is not going to conduct negotiations there,'' Pazner said. Baker has proposed a three-way meeting with foreign ministers of Israel and Egypt to discuss the peace process and resolve the differences over the makeup of a Palestinian delegation for proposed Israeli-Palestinian talks. The meeting would be aimed at reviving an Israeli proposal for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as a first step toward peace. Likud and Labor are deeply divided over the issue of Palestinian representation in peace talks. Labor is ready to give a role to Palestinian exiles and residents of Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem, but Likud fears that would provide a back-door entry for the Palestine Liberation Organization and put Jerusalem on the agenda. Official policy is to refuse to talk to the PLO, which Israel considers a terrorist group. Peres said Wednesday that Labor would leave Shamir's government and try to form a narrow coalition with religious and left-wing parties if the Cabinet rejects the efforts to begin Israeli-Palestinian talks. ``We have to make up our minds _ clear and now and decisively,'' he said. ``It is really a trying moment in the history of the state of Israel, and I believe the coming two or three weeks will be of crucial importance in deciding the destiny of our country.'' He made the comments in a speech to about 600 delegates to the Emergency World Jewish Peace Conference in Jerusalem.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Approves Joint Operating Agreement in York, Pa.
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh approved the partial merger of the two daily newspapers in York, Pa., Wednesday under the antitrust exemption of the Newspaper Preservation Act. Thornburgh, accepting the recommendation of the Justice Department's antitrust division, approved the plan to merge the production and commercial operations of the morning York Daily Record and the evening York Dispatch. Thornburgh found that the Record qualified for a limited antitrust exemption as a ``failing newspaper'' because it lagged the Dispatch in both circulation and advertising revenue. ``This record reveals no plausible method by which the Record could maintain its competitive position and its current revenues while continuing to defer ... long-delayed capital expenditures,'' Thornburgh said in his opinion. Thornburgh said there did not appear be any alternatives to a joint operating agreement ``that would allow the Record to remain financially as well as editorially independent of the Dispatch.'' The Record, owned by Buckner News Alliance, has a circulation of 40,408 weekdays and 38,328 on Sundays, according to 1988 figures. That year the Dispatch, owned by Garden State Newspapers Inc., had a weekday circulation of 48,310, and the company's Sunday News had a circulation of 42,482. Under the joint operating agreement, the newspapers will maintain separate reporting staffs and publish separate editions during the week. The Record will discontinue its Sunday edition but will produce its own comment section for insertion into the Sunday News. The Dispatch will discontinue its Saturday afternoon edition.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Adviser Says No One Can Prevent Baltic Secession
DOC.TEXT: Andrei Grachev, an aide to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said Wednesday that no one could prevent Lithuania from seceding from the Soviet Union if it wants to. Grachev, deputy chief of the Soviet Communist Party's international department, was in Paris this week for a series of conferences on Europe. He said the future of the three Baltic republics _ Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia _ ``is an open question'' and ``should be debated and resolved in the Soviet parliament.'' Local elections this weekend in Lithuania are expected to test the strength of the nationalist movement Sajudis. Free debate would convince the citizens of the Baltics that their future belongs in the federated Soviet Union with power passed on from Moscow to the separate republics, Grachev said. ``But if this discussion doesn't convince the Lithuanian people that their interest is to remain in a renewed federation, they make the decision and no one can prevent them from fulfilling it,'' Grachev said. Egor Yakovlev, editor in chief of the Moscow News, echoed Grachev's sentiments at their appearance in a debate held at the Ecole Centrale de Paris. ``An eventual separation of a Baltic republic from the Soviet Union will be less pain from the point of view of progress and perestroika than an attempt to keep it by force, by tanks,'' he said. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were independent states between World War I and 1940, when they were annexed by the Soviet Union. They now seek to obtain at least a measure of autonomy from Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Official: Hazelwood Said Accident Was `His Fault'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with afternoon testimony from company official saying Hazelwood said accident was his fault, further testimony from other skipper saying he went by book, acknowledging for first time Exxon's interest in case; further quotes; editing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An hour after the Exxon Valdez struck a reef causing the nation's worst oil spill, skipper Joseph Hazelwood said the accident was his fault, an Exxon official testified Wednesday. Paul Myers, now project manager for the 987-foot tanker's repair, said he telephoned the ship in the early morning hours of March 24 after being told it had run aground. He said he reached Hazelwood, who told him oil was in the water and that the ship was safe. ``What did he tell you had happened?'' asked Assistant District Attrorney Brent Cole. ``He indicated the third mate zigged for ice and it went aground,'' said Myers. ``He said he wasn't on the bridge.'' ``What else did Captain Hazelwood say?'' asked the prosecutor. ``He indicated ... it was his fault. He was to blame,'' Myers replied. ``He had just gone down to do some paperwork when this happened and he should have been on the bridge.'' The witness, who said he was testifying under a grant of immunity from prosecution, said he thought Hazelwood felt responsible as the ship's captain. But he was prohibited from answering a question from the defense on whether Hazelwood was accepting criminal responsibility. The 43-year-old former skipper is charged with second-degree criminal mischief, a felony; and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, his maximum penalties could be 7\ years in prison plus $61,000 in fines. Earlier Wednesday, another Exxon Valdez skipper testified that Hazelwood violated a company operating manual in commanding the tanker, but acknowledged that broke no laws. Michael Stalzer, who preceded Hazelwood in commanding the ship and since has succeeded him as captain, told jurors how Hazelwood acted against the rules set down in Exxon's bridge manual. But during cross-examination by Hazelwood lawyer Dick Madson, Stalzer conceded the manual was merely a guideline, a statement of Exxon policies on how to run a tanker. During his cross-examination, Stalzer also told jurors for the first time that Exxon is concerned about the outcome of Hazelwood's trial. He said the company, which has employed him since 1973, is paying for his lawyer as well as for attorneys representing other crewmembers who have testified. ``I believe Exxon does have an interest in the outcome of this case,'' he said in response to a question from Madson. During questioning by Assistant District Attorney Cole, Stalzer said he felt the company was interested because Hazelwood was its employee at the time of the March 24 grounding. ``I believe that perhaps the outcome of this case will have an effect on some of the other pending litigation,'' he added. Stalzer, who said he personally followed the Exxon bridge manual to the letter, described the Exxon Valdez as the newest and probably most technically advanced of all the tankers in Exxon's approximately 30-ship fleet. He also indicated he would have chosen different staffing than Hazelwood did for a hazardous passage into Prince William Sound. Hazelwood left the ship in control of the third mate 10 minutes before it grounded, spilling almost 11 million gallons of oil into the clear waters of Prince William Sound. The disaster killed countless birds, fish and wildlife and blackened hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline. Stalzer said he would have followed a section of the manual suggesting that the captain, an officer and a seaman be on the bridge if hazards existed. He cited ice in the shipping lanes as a hazard, but acknowledged that captains have the option to interpret the manual as they see fit.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Hails `Peaceful Revolution' in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Wednesday hailed the mostly peaceful revolution of Eastern Europe and recalled the leading role played by the Solidarity Labor movement in his native Poland. The pope's remarks were among reflections dedicated to Jasna Gora, Roman Catholic Poland's holiest shrine, as part of preparations for his fourth pilgrimage to his homeland next year. Democratic reforms have improved the status of the church in Eastern Europe, and the Vatican also has announced papal trips to Czechoslovakia in April and Hungary next year. Speaking to about 250 Polish pilgrims at his general audience, the pope said Wednesday that most of the changes ``happened in a bloodless fashion with only one painful exception,'' a reference to Romania. The pope recalled the lack of violence in the Solidarity movement in 1980-81, when the first independent labor movement in the Soviet bloc was born. He also applauded the peaceful change last year, when a Solidarity-led government took over from the Communist Party.

DOC.HEAD: Bartlett, Gentile Win Committee Approval
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Energy Committee on Wednesday approved President Bush's nomination of a former Battelle Laboratories nuclear waste expert to supervise the government's attempt to dispose of radioactive waste from nuclear power plants. John W. Bartlett, a chemical and nuclear engineer, won the committee's unanimous support to be director of the Energy Department's Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management. Sens. Richard H. Bryan and Harry Reid, both D-Nev., had objected to Bartlett because of a technical paper he presented last year asserting that scientific evidence cannot assure with 100 percent that any repository site for nculear waste will safely contain the wastes for 10,000 years. Reid interpreted the paper as evidence that Bartlett endorsed Congress' choice of Yucca Mountain in Nevada three years ago for the site ``regardless of the scientific consequences.'' Bryan said it showed Bartlett was ``blatantly biased against Nevada.'' However, a committee source said Wednesday that veiled threats by Bryan and Reid to attempt to block Bartlett's nomination on the Senate floor appear to have dissipated. The waste in question is currently stored at power plants. Nevada is objecting to the federal government's plan to bury it in Yucca Mountain, if the geology proves acceptable, where it is supposed to decay undisturbed for thousands of years. Also approved unanimously by the committee was Bush's nomination of former Ohio coal operator Robert H. Gentile to be an assistant secretary in charge of the Energy Department's fossil fuels program.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Backs Giving Soviet Union Most Favored Nation Status
DOC.TEXT: The AFL-CIO on Wednesday urged the Bush administration to give the Soviet Union most favored nation status, which would allow it to benefit from lower trade tariffs. The Executive Council of the 14.1 million-member federation, which traditionally has taken a hardline stance toward the Soviet Union, said the Soviets should receive the best trade treatment possible from the United States for a one-year trial period. The 33-member board said the status should be subject to congressional review and ``conditioned on Soviet respect for basic worker and human rights.'' The status should be granted separately to the Soviet republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, where there are strong pro-independence movements, the AFL-CIO said. The United States has never recognized the incorporation of those three republics into the Soviet Union. ``The AFL-CIO is convinced that reform in the U.S.S.R. is driven primarily by the crisis afflicting the Soviet economy,'' the labor leaders said. But they said the Soviet eagerness to participate in the world economy could be used ``as a constructive lever to propel the process of democratization'' in the Soviet Union. Congress prohibited the Soviet Union from receiving the most favored nation trade status in 1974 with the Jackson-Vanik amendment, a retaliation for the prohibition of immigration of Soviet Jews and other dissidents. Because of that amendment, U.S. tariffs on Soviet goods can be 10 times as high as products from other countries. Soviet immigration policies have eased over the last year, and President Bush has said he would consider granting the improved trade status to the Soviet Union if it liberalizes its immigration policies. At December's Malta summit, Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said they would try to have a new trade treaty ready by their scheduled June meeting in Washington. Trade talks between both sides began last week. Also Wednesday, as labor leaders spent much of their closed-door session debating international affairs, they offered their harshest criticism so far of Bush's policy on China following that government's bloody crackdown in Tiananmen Square last summer. AFL-CIO leaders said Bush _ by vetoing legislation to protect Chinese students in the United States and sending high-level emissaries to Beijing _ had undermined ``America's leading position in the world as a defender of human rights.'' The China statement came as the federation's board awarded Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi the federation's George Meany Human Rights Award. AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland distributed a letter that Lizhi, who has been in refuge at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing since July, sent after learning he would receive the award. ``Today is a very cold day in Beijing. The heartening news sent from you is like a burning coal to warm both my body and spirit,'' Lizhi wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Hails Rostropovich After Soviet Tour
DOC.TEXT: President Bush hailed exiled Soviet conductor Mstislav Rostropovich as ``a national treasure'' on Wednesday as he welcomed the National Symphony home from its tour of the Soviet Union. ``Your orchestra's long-awaited trip to the Soviet Union reflects the drama of our changing world,'' Bush told Rostropovich at a White House reception. The president noted that Rostropovich had received ``ovation after ovation'' on his just-completed tour of the homeland he had been forced to leave in disgrace in 1974. Bush said the conductor and cello virtuoso had returned ``to a place he never really left'' in the Soviet tour. Rostropovich was stripped of his Soviet citizenship in 1978. He got in trouble with the communist authorities at the time for his vigorous defense of out-of-favor author Alexander Solzhenitsyn. His Soviet citizenship was restored last month and he was given an official apology under political reforms undertaken by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Bush said the conductor of the Washington-based National Symphony was ``inded a national treasure and America is very proud of you.'' Before an audience that included members of the orchestra, Soviet Ambassador Yuri V. Dubinin and industrialist Armand Hammer, Bush said: ``Maestro, you are a true virtuoso, not only of music but of the heart and mind as well.'' Rostropovich then led a string section of 12 cellos in a performance of a work named ``Dodecacelli'' by American composer David Ott.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Announced to Stop Snuff, Chewing Tobacco Use Among Young People
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, bgng: The American, to show campaign begins Sunday
DOC.TEXT: Medical experts announced plans Wednesday for a week-long, nationwide educational campaign aimed at stopping the use of snuff and chewing tobacco among young people. The American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery Inc. said the ``Through with Chew Week'' campaign, which begins Sunday, is designed to educate teen-agers about the health risks of smokeless tobacco _ including life-threatening cancers of the mouth and throat. ``Our goal is to alert the public to the senseless risks of smokeless tobacco,'' Dr. Jerome Goldstein, the academy's executive vice president, told a news conference. The academy represents physicians who specialize in the medical and surgical treatment of health problems of the ear, nose, threat, head and neck. Goldstein estimated that 12 million people _ including 3 million under the age of 21 _ use snuff and chewing tobacco. Most users are male, he said. Among males ages 17-19, snuff use increased 15-fold and chewing tobacco use grew more than four-fold from 1970 to 1986, according to the 1989 surgeon general's report on smoking. The British government has decided to ban oral snuff, which is powdered tobacco held in one place in the mouth for an extended period, because of the growing weight of medical and scientific evidence that it causes oral cancer and other diseases. The ban is intended ``to nip the new habit in the bud,'' said Andrew Health, first secretary in the British Embassy. As part of the campaign announced Wednesday, the academy and the National Federation of State High School Associations are distributing a 10-minute video to all public and private high schools. The video outlines the social and health risks of smokeless tobacco use. Most of the 30,000 cases of oral cancers diagnosed in the United States annually are linked to tobacco, said Dr. Roy Sessions, chairman of the department of otolaryngology and head and neck surgery at Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington. About 40 percent of people with oral cancer will die from the disease within five years of such a diagnosis, he said. He also said studies have shown smokeless tobacco is a more difficult habit to kick than smoking.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Opens for Skinheads Accused of Racial Terror
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with early testimony from former group member about synagogue plot, park attack; synagogue member's and black witness's testimony; DELETES outdated prosecution opening statement; other details; quotes. No pickup. ^By JAY JORDEN
DOC.TEXT: Members of a white supremacist group plotted to put poison gas into a synagogue's air conditioning system as part of their hate campaign, a former member of the group testified Wednesday. The allegation came in early testimony during the trial of five ``skinheads,'' so-called because of their closely shaved heads. Members of a faction called the Confederate Hammerskins, they are charged with violating the civil rights of Jews by defacing a synagogue. Three are additionally accused of civil rights violations by allegedly chasing blacks and Hispanics from a Dallas park. On trial are Sean Christian Tarrant, 20, of Dallas; Jon Lance Jordan, 19, of Garland; Michael Lewis Lawrence, 22, of Tulsa, Okla.; Christopher Barry Greer, 25, of Irving, and Daniel Alvis Wood, 20, of Dallas. Greer, Tarrant and Jordan are charged in the park attacks. A former Hammerskin, Gordon Gene Buchanan, testified Wednesday that Wood had discussed putting cyanide gas in the air conditioning system of the Temple Shalom. He said he accompanied Jordan, Tarrant and Wood to the temple on an August night in 1988. He said he saw Jordan and Wood near building's the air conditioning units but could not see what they were doing. Dan L. Kraus of Temple Shalom testified a number of the synagogue's members discussed leaving the congregation after the 1988 vandalism that included spray-painted anti-Semitic graffiti, and gunshots that riddled walls and broke windows. One piece of graffiti said, ``6 million more,'' referring to the Holocaust of Nazi Germany, when millions of Jews were gassed in concentration camps. Another slogan said: ``6 million more, this time we'll do it right.'' Buchanan also testified said that, about July 1988, Tarrant chased and kicked a black man at Robert E. Lee Park while Greer and other youths followed, repeatedly yelling racial slurs. One black man, Alexis Charles Newton of Dallas, testified Wednesday that he was chased from the park by a gang of 12 to 15 white youths, some with closely shaved heads. ``The first reaction was fear. I was scared. I knew what could happen if they caught me,'' he said. Prosecutors have said that the skinheads believed the park, named after a Confederate general, was a symbol of white supremacy that should not have been frequented by non-whites. The group had heard that the NAACP was seeking to have the park renamed in 1988, Buchanan said. To show their disapproval, Greer suggested that the Hammerskins go to the park, put up racial notices, and ``patrol the area,'' Buchanan said. He said he accompanied the group to the park about five times during that summer. But Buchanan said he got into an argument with Wood over a girl and was kicked out of the group in September 1988. Leon Carter, a black attorney representing Jordan, warned jurors not to let emotion overtake them. ``There will be things in this trial that will inflame and excite you. There will be fliers, writings on the wall and other things that will get your emotions up,'' Carter said. ``But once you have ridden that crest of emotion, I ask you to look closely at the case and look to your reason and not emotion.'' Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said after the indictments were issued in September that prosecution of racial hate crimes is a priority of the Justice Department. Each of the federal charges carries up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Wood already has been sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined $5,000 by a state judge after admitting he sprayed swastikas and anti-Semitic slogans at the synagogue. Eleven other Hammerskins associates were charged previously; three out of five adults and four of six juveniles pleaded guilty. Security on the courtroom floor was tighter than usual. Visitors were asked to empty their pockets for inspection.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Sets Talks With Arens; US Considers Transferring Tanks To Egypt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 10-11 to CORRECT style on hyphenation of tank designations and to note recipient would pay only transportation cost
DOC.TEXT: At Israel's request, Secretary of State James A. Baker III will meet Friday with Foreign Minister Moshe Arens in a renewed effort to open Mideast negotiations. The objective is to set up talks between Israel and Palestinian Arabs on an Israeli election plan for the West Bank and Gaza. That has been Baker's goal for several months, but he has made little visible headway. The meeting with Arens, who will come here after a visit to Mexico, was announced Wednesday by Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman. She said Baker had no immediate plan to hold a similar session with Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid. But in response to questions, Ms. Tutwiler said Robert Pelletreau Jr., the U.S. ambassador to Tunisia, met Tuesday with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Ms. Tutwiler declined to provide any details of the conversation. The United States opened talks with the PLO 14 months ago after chairman Yasser Arafat publicly renounced terrorism and said he accepted Israel's existence. With Arens, the spokeswoman said, Baker obviously will be trying to ``move the process forward'' and to set up a three-way subsequent meeting with Meguid. Israel has proposed an election for Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank and Gaza to chose negotiators to work out a formula for limited self-rule in the territories. The PLO opposes Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's plan as a device to block establishment of a Palestinian state on Israeli land. The plan has Baker's support. In another development, spokeswoman Tutwiler said Egypt was ``a leading candidate'' to receive an unspecified number of U.S. M-60A1 tanks that no longer are needed in Western Europe. She said Israel had turned down a similar opportunity. Pentagon officials said 700 tanks were involved. Their value when new was $1.4 million apiece or $980 million in all. The officials said they tanks were being replaced by newer and more powerful M-1 Abrams tanks. Ms. Tutwiler's office said Egypt or whoever gets the tanks will not have to pay for them, but will have to pay transportation costs. Ms. Tutwiler said the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies and Congress would be consulted. It was not immediately clear if Congress would have the power to block transfer of the tanks as it would a military sale. Ms. Tutwiler said Egypt would use the tanks to replacing Soviet-built tanks, with no net increase in its arsenal of the weapons.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf of LOS ANGELES-dated first item to give Page's age.
DOC.TEXT: Singer Patti Page, whose hits include ``I Went to Your Wedding,'' will be going to her own when she marries retired aerospace executive Jerry J. Filiciotto. The two will wed on May 12 at the Solano Beach Presbyterian Church, her publicist, Alan Eichler Associates, said Wednesday. The couple will live in Solano Beach, although Filiciotto owns a 200-acre farm in New Hampshire. The marriage will be the third for Miss Page, 62, whose records have sold more than 100 million copies. Some of Miss page's other hits are ``Tennessee Waltz,'' ``Doggie in the Window,'' ``Allegheny Moon'' and ``Changing Partners.'' She will be seen on PBS stations March 3 as host of the special ``Jukebox Saturday Night II.''

DOC.HEAD: Tough Measures in Store for Desert Poachers In Oman
DOC.TEXT: Conservation officials on Wednesday said they will crack down on desert poachers who smuggle rare animal and bird species out of Oman for sale. ``Offenders will face six-month jail sentences and fines of up to 900 rials for contravening environmental laws,'' conservation department spokesman Yousuf al-Baloushi said. The fine is equivalent to $2,320. He said the action follows the jailing in December of four Omani tribesmen caught trucking Arabian gazelles over the United Arab Emirates border. They were convicted under environmental legislation banning the hunting of endangered species and are serving six-month jail terms, Baloushi said. He added, ``We believe they were part of an organized gang operating in the desert. Investigations are presently under way to find out exactly what has been going on.'' Baloushi said other prime targets included the Nubian ibex and the Houbara bird, known biologically as the MacQueen's Bustard, a resident breeder the size of a goose. Poachers catch them live and export them to neighboring countries, where they fetch a good price, he said. ``It appears there is a ready market for rare species like gazelles, which are said to fetch around 500 rials ($1,300) apiece for private zoos,'' Baloushi said. He said the Arabian white oryx was not threatened. This beast was extinct in the wild until it was reintroduced to the stony Oman central desert preserve at Yalooni in the Jiddat al Harasis. ``The range wardens in the Jiddat are active and the oryx are well guarded and protected. Elsewhere, though, we are bolstering our conservation patrol efforts,'' Baloushi said. ``If we do not act now it will be too late. We are talking here about species of animal and bird that are almost extinct, existing only in Oman. It is a lobal issue in that respect.'' Government notices, published in the local press on the orders of Oman's ruler, Sultan Qaboos, warned that the hunting of rare birds, deer and other wildlife was prohibited. The notices said police would maintain strict border surveillance to apprehend violators.

DOC.HEAD: China Tells Japan It Will Spare Life of Chinese Hijacker: Report
DOC.TEXT: China says it will spare the life of a Chinese hijacker if Japan extradites him to face charges for forcing an Air China jetliner to Japan in December, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The Mainichi Shimbun newspaper said the assurance was made recently to Japanese judicial authorities. Zhang Zhenhai, 35, suffered a broken pelvis during the hijacking on Dec. 16 and is being treated while under detention in Tokyo. No one else was hurt. His three Japanese lawyers said last month that Zhang would face the death penalty if sent back to China. The newspaper said China would try Zhang under Article 107 of its criminal law concerning charges such as demolition or subversion of aircraft, trains, cars and ships. The law stipulates up to 10 years imprisonment, the paper reported. It reported that China also said ``no proof'' existed that Zhang took part in pro-democracy demonstrations in Tienanmen Square last June as he told Japanese officials. Justice Ministry officials refused to comment on the report. Zhang, of Heibei province, hijacked the Chinese airliner with 223 people aboard on a flight from Beijing to New York. The plane flew to Fukuoka, in western Japan, after South Korea refused to let it land. The plane was returned to China the next day with 208 passengers aboard, including Zhang's wife and 13-year-old son. China has told Japan the two will not be tried for criminal activity, officials in Tokyo have said. Zhang said he was seeking political asylum, but Japanese officials have said that even if that were true, hijacking is a serious crime and he will be handed over when China makes its formal request.

DOC.HEAD: Sharp Criticism of China, Cuba, Praise for Soviet Union in Rights Report
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 24th graf: ``Sheldon D.,'' with AJC comment
DOC.TEXT: Crackdowns in China and Cuba drew strong criticism from the State Department in its annual human rights report to Congress on Wednesday in contrast to praise for ``a remarkable opening of the political process'' in the Soviet Union. The human rights situation on the West Bank and in Gaza, where Palestinian Arabs are in the 27th month of an uprising against Israeli control, was described as ``a source of deep concern.'' Assistant Secretary Richard Schifter, the principal compiler of the 1,641-page document, contrasted suppression in China with giant human-rights advances in Eastern Europe. He told a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee that the crackdown on pro-democracy forces in China last year ``put into reverse, in very short order, much of the significant movement toward a more open society which had taken place in China during the last 10 years.'' There was no indication, however, that the Bush administration was about to harden its policy toward China, which several members of Congress have likened to kid-gloves treatment. Schifter said the United States must maintain ties to Beijing in order to bring about improvements. In Cuba, meanwhile, the report said President Fidel Castro ``has taken or fabricated opportunities to harass, detain or imprison'' 50 human rights advocates while the Marxist government ``silenced many of its leading domestic critics.'' The picture in the Soviet Union was brighter. Under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the report said, ``the past year witnessed a remarkable opening up of the political process and improvements in human rights practices.'' Still, the report said, the Soviet Union ``has a considerable distance to go before it will meet the standards set forth in the Helsinki Final Act'' of 1975, a 35-nation pledge to foster human rights, in which Moscow joined. Though the top leadership no longer fosters anti-Semitism and appears embarrassed by it, ``there has been a sharp increase in popular expressions of anti-Semitic attitudes,'' the report said. ``Jews have been increasingly concerned over the danger of violence.'' Schifter, in presenting the worldwide findings, said the ``specter of totalitarianism is at long last disappearing from Europe.'' He added: ``As of today, Albania is the only relic of the age of Hitler and Stalin left intact in Europe.'' And yet, as a whole, the report sketched a gloomy globe. From beheadings and amputations in Saudi Arabia to student detentions in Liberia and to disappearances in El Salvador, the document catalogued man's inhumanity to man in virtually every conceivable way. It said: _Pro-democracy demonstrators were gunned down in the area of Beijing's Tiananmen Square last June, and independent observers were cited as challenging the official toll of 20 executions as unrealistically low. _In Myanmar, formerly Burma, men forced to walk ahead of army troops in mine-infested fields were blown up. _In Iran, prisoners were flogged and suspended from the ceiling, according to eyewitnesses and human rights groups. _In Iraq, effective opposition to government policy was stifled and intelligence services engaged in extensive surveillance. ``The freedoms of speech and press and of assembly and association are virtually nonexistent,'' the report said of Iraq. ``Other important human rights problems include continuing disappearances and arbitrary detentions, lack of fair trial, widespread interference with privacy, excessive use of force against Kurdish civilians and an almost total lack of worker rights.'' Israel, a democracy, came in for little criticism. But there was concern about the occupied West Bank and Gaza. A total of 432 Palestinians were reported killed in 1989 _ 304 by Israeli security forces and settlers and 128 by other Palestinians. While the Israeli defense forces engaged in a severe crackdown, the report cited a significant increase in Palestinian violence against Palestinians, spurred by a growing Islamic fundamentalist Hamas movement. Israeli government guidelines to restrict use of force were violated and prosecution resulted only in a ``relatively small number of such incidents,'' the report said. James Zogby, executive director of the Arab American Institute, called the report a brutal indictment of Israeli occupation, said pro-Israel groups applied pressure to mute the criticism and said Congress should either cut the $3 billion in aid to Israel or make it conditional on an improved record. Sheldon D. Comay, president of the American Jewish Committee, noted that only 21 pages of the report dealt with Israel and said, ``The disproportionate media attention to these pages unwittingly attets to the especially high standards by which Israel is judged.'' In Jerusalem, Moshe Raviv, the deputy director general of the foreign ministry, said U.S. criticism of Israel's handling of Palestinian human rights failed to take into account that Israel was reacting to violence by Palestinians. Rep. Gus Yatron, D-Pa., chairman of the House human rights subcommittee, complimented the State Department for a report that ``pulls no punches in assessing dismal human rights records of such dictatorial regimes as China and Iraq.'' Yatron challenged the Bush administration to match the rhetoric of the annual review with ``a policy which places America's commitment to human rights and democratic institutions above offending ruthless regimes, which the administration is currently seeking to curry favor.'' His statement reflected Congressional criticism of President Bush as imposing only limited sanctions against China. The report found a dramatic deterioration in the human rights climate in China in 1989. Apart form the Beijing crackdown, the army killed scores of Tibetans in March in Lhasa and reports of torture of persons accused of ``counterrevolutionary crimes'' are persistent and consistent, it said. James O'Dea, director of the Washington office of Amnesty International, a worldwide human rights organization, said there were up to 10,000 people in prison, and that secret U.S. missions and private diplomacy had not improved conditions. In Saudi Arabia, capital punishment is meted out for a wide variety of crimes. Beheading is the usual method of execution and, in some cases, it was followed by public crucifixion. In the first 10 months of 1989, at least 13 thieves had their hands severed, including 11 non-Saudis, the report says. Nicaragua's Sandinista government, which faces national elections on Sunday, is sharply criticized for maintaining ``an extensive and repressive internal security apparatus'' that includes surveillance and infiltration of the political opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Stays Waco Man's Execution
DOC.TEXT: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals issued a stay Wednesday to halt the scheduled execution of a man convicted in the slaying of a convenience store clerk whose body was tossed over a cliff. The high court granted the stay of Thursday's execution pending the outcome of a federal case challenging the use of the death sentence against retarded inmates, a spokeswoman in Austin said. Attorneys for Carl Kelly, 30, of Waco contended psychological evidence that could have swayed the jurors was not introduced at his trial. Kelly faced lethal injection for the 1980 robbery, abduction and murder of Steven Pryor, 18, of Waco. Also killed was David Wade Riley, a transient who had been asleep in Pryor's car. Pryor and Riley were taken to Waco's Cameron Park in Pryor's car and shot to death. Their bodies were then tossed over a 60-foot cliff onto the banks of the Bosque River. Kelly's companion, Thomas Graves, then 20, pleaded guilty to both killings, as well as to the slaying of a third man the previous day. Graves, of Waco, received a life prison term. Kelly insisted on a trial, was convicted and received the death sentence. Graves was arrested the morning after the killings driving Pryor's bloodstained car. Kelly's billfold was found in the car. Kelly and Graves got about $30 in the robbery. Kelly has said he was on drugs at the time of the incident. The U.S. Supreme Court last July refused to hear an appeal of Kelly's case. Lawyers for Kelly could ask the court for another hearing. Two other Texas death row inmates, Ronald Keith Allridge and Mikel Derrick, also had executions scheduled for early Thursday that were delayed. The Court of Criminal Appeals earlier this month granted Allridge a stay, and State District Judge Michael McSpadden of Houston reset Derrick's execution for March 22, according to appellate court spokesman Rick Wetzel. Allridge was sentenced to be executed for the March 25, 1985, murder of Carla McMillen Otto during a restaurant robbery in Fort Worth. Derrick was sentenced for the stabbing death of Edward Sonnier at the victim's Houston home on Oct. 11, 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Court Limits OMB's Power to Change Rules
DOC.TEXT: The Office of Management and Budget may not block or change government regulations through its power to reduce paperwork requirements for private businesses, the Supreme Court ruled Wednesday. The decision, a victory for labor unions, means that employers at certain multi-employer job sites must obey rules of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration requiring notice to workers of the dangers of certain consumer products used on the job. The OMB's power over government regulations has been contested by congressional committees and advocacy groups, especially environmentalists, for several years. But the court said it was not ruling on their broad concerns _ only OMB actions under the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1980. On a 7-2 vote, the court held that the act ``does not give OMB the authority to review agency rules mandating disclosure by regulated entities to third parties,'' in the words of the majority opinion by Justice William J. Brennan. Brennan said the court was leaving undecided whether other rules ``might legitimately be subject to OMB review.'' The dissenters, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Byron R. White dissented, said the court should defer to OMB's interpretation of the law. The rules at issue were adopted by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration in 1983 to inform workers about the dangers of being exposed to hazardous materials. The OMB, an arm of the White House, objected four years later, saying the multi-employer rules were unnecessary to protect employees and merely added to employers' paperwork. The United Steelworkers union and others sued over the OMB action, and the Philadelphia-based 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the OMB lacked the power to order a substantive change in another agency's rules. Wednesday's decision upheld the 3rd Circuit ruling. The justices last May refused to hear appeals by the construction and feed grain industries that objected coming under regulations for disclosing information on hazardous materials to workers. The 1983 rules originally were imposed only on manufacturers, but the federal government later was ordered to extend the rules to non-manufacturing businesses. In 1981, President Reagan issued an executive order expanding an earlier order by President Carter giving OMB the power to review agency regulations, which have the force of law. Reagan's order gives OMB, to the extent not forbidden by law or court decisions, the power to hold up regulations until agencies satisfy OMB analysts that what they propose to do will be the most cost-effective course possible. In the Reagan administration, advocacy groups charged the OMB frequently went beyond its mandate in imposing its views.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Prosecutor Acts Against President in Indian ``Genocide''
DOC.TEXT: A federal prosector said Wednesday he will take legal action against President Jose Sarney for allowing gold miners to stay illegally on Yanomami Indian lands and contributing to the ``genocide'' of the tribe. Deputy Attorney General Carlos Mucci told a House session Sarney and five Cabinet ministers were permitting the devastation of the Yanomamis, the world's largest primitive tribe, and so were guilty of ``crimes of responsibility.'' In an interview, Mucci said further, ``The Yanomamis situation is worse that what is reported. The government is contributing to the quasi-genocide.'' Despite protests by environmentalists, Sarney signed a decree on Friday creating the Uraricoera and Catrimani mining areas in the northwestern jungle state of Roraima, near the Venezuelan border. The areas, totaling about 1 million acres, border the mineral-rich Yanomami reserves and are claimed by the tribe. Mucci, head of a Justice Department committee on Indian rights, said Sarney violated the constitution and a judicial order by giving about 40,000 miners two tracts of national park land in exchange for the prospectors' promise to leave the Yanomami reserve. Mucci said only Congress could authorize the location of mining sites and the type of minerals to be extracted on national forest land. He threatened to bring charges against the ministers of justice, health, interior, air force and mines and energy for co-signing the decree. A House vote on the charges is expected this week. Further action would be up to the Senate. When the compromise with the miners was announced last month, Justice Department spokesman Vinicius Becker said, ``This is the peaceful solution to the problem. There will be no shock or confrontation.'' Sarney, a civilian, took office in 1985, ending 21 years of military rule. He will be succeeded by President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello for a five-year term on March 15. ``There is time for the legislature to adopt a position before March 15. It all depends on political will,'' Mucci said. A clandestine gold rush to the Yanomami territory began in 1987, after government studies indicated a wealth of gold, tin, bauxite and diamonds on Yanomami land. Since then, the prospectors have destroyed rain forests, chased off fish and game, polluted rivers with mercury used in gold panning and spread venereal disease and tuberculosis among the peaceful tribe. Brazil's Roman Catholic Church says at least 1,500 Yanomamis of the 9,000-member tribe have died of malnutrition, malaria and venereal diseases since the invasion began. Under international pressure, the government last month announced a $4 million campaign to expel the prospectors, by force if necessary. But shortly after, it offered the miners three tracts of virgin Amazon rain forest near the reserve to avoid a bloodbath with the heavily armed miners. The National Indian Office says it fears the Yanomami tribe, which once claimed 23 million acres of Brazil's northwestern Amazon territory, could be wiped out by further intrusions. Over the years, the government carved up the Yanomamis claim, leaving them 19 scattered reservations totaling 5 million acres. It declared the rest national parks and forests. About 220,000 native Indians are left in Brazil. There were an estimated 5 million when the Portuguese first landed here in 1500. Environmentalists say the miners will spill off into Indian reservations in neighboring Amazon states and decimate other tribes.

DOC.HEAD: Heart-Liver Transplant Patient Returns to Operating Room
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE that operation has ended, quotes from doctor about it, comments from stepfather, further details. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Doctors decided ...'
DOC.TEXT: Doctors for 12-year-old Stormie Jones, the world's first recipient of a heart-liver transplant, spent more than nine hours Wednesday trying to stop internal bleeding that began after her second liver transplant. A team of surgeons reconstructed a connection they made between the donor liver's hepatic artery, one of the main arteries of the liver, and Stormie's hepatic artery. Part of the connection had given way, the doctor said. ``She had bleeding from one of her suture lines, the arterial suture line,'' said Dr. Andreas Tzakis, the surgeon who headed the operation. ``We fixed it by reconstructing the arterial blood supply to the liver.'' Stormie's second operation in two days began about 8:50 a.m. and ended shortly after 6 p.m., hospital officials said. Tzakis said he remained optimistic about Stormie's recovery. ``The liver looks good and we expect her to recover promptly,'' he said. During the procedure, doctors checked all other possible sources of bleeding to try prevent further problems, he said. Internal bleeding occurs in about 10 percent of all patients receiving a second transplant, Tzakis said. Doctors suspected internal bleeding when the girl's blood pressure started dropping about 8 p.m. Tuesday, seven hours after her transplant ended. Stormie had regained consciousness and was listed in critical condition in the hospital's intensive care unit. She did not appear to be distressed at the news she would require more surgery, Tzakis said. ``She's determined to make it no matter what,'' he said. Stormie's stepfather, Alan Purcell, 27, said the girl's attitude has helped other members of the family. ``How can we get down, when she stays up?' he said during a news conference held after Wednesday's surgery. Doctors decided Feb. 13 that Stormie, a resident of the Fort Worth, Texas, suburb of White Settlement, needed a new liver. Her first transplanted liver had been permanently damaged by hepatitis caused by an unknown virus. In White Settlement, Stormie's classmates at Brewer Middle School were praying Wednesday that she would recover, said the principal, Homer Dear. ``The students are thinking: `She's tough, she can handle it, and she's going to come back to us,''' Dear said, adding that the youngsters were trying to raise money to help pay for Stormie's latest surgery. Stormie had asked for a new liver in November because she was tired of problems with her health, according to her mother, Lois ``Suzie'' Purcell, 33. Symptoms of liver inflammation began to appear as early as four months ago, but Stormie became especially ill two weeks ago, suffering from weakness, jaundice and itchiness, her parents said. Her heart remained healthy and was not affected by the hepatitis. Stormie's first transplanted liver had shown some evidence of rejection in November, Tzakis said. The problem, however, seemed to clear up after doctors began administering FK-506, a new, experimental Japanese anti-rejection drug. The girl and her family _ her mother, stepfather and her 16-year-old sister, Misty _ arrived in Pittsburgh for the transplant Monday evening. Stormie received a new heart and liver at Children's on Feb. 14, 1984, to control a condition in which her cholesterol level was 10 times higher than normal. Her cholesterol levels have since decreased to nearly normal, Tzakis said. Dr. Thomas Starzl replaced the girl's heart and liver with those of a 4-year-old girl who had died in a New York car accident. Before the first transplant, Stormie suffered two heart attacks and underwent two triple coronary bypass operations.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Replaced in McMartin Preschool Molestation Retrial
DOC.TEXT: LOS ANGELES _ William Pounders, the judge who presided for three years over the McMartin preschool molestation trial, will not take charge of the retrial of defendant Raymond Buckey, a Superior Court judge ruled Wednesday. Judge Michael R. Hoff ruled that Buckey's retrial on 13 child molestation counts will be assigned to another judge to be identified later. A hearing on the matter was scheduled for Monday. Pounders had scheduled a new trial for March 9. It was not immediately known how his removal would affect that date. Defense attorneys moved for Pounders' dismissal after he gave media interviews following the first trial of Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey. Defense counsel Danny Davis also argued Pounders was biased because he had disallowed some attorneys' fees. But Hoff, in reassigning the case, did not find Pounders was biased toward either side. Instead, Hoff said that Pounders' post-trial interviews could interfere with jury selection for the new proceedings. ``The judge knows what he said and what he meant by his remarks but would be placed in the impossible position of interpreting what the prospective juror thought about those remarks and perhaps the judge himself,'' Hoff said. Pounders said he concurred with the decision. ``I'm finally free after three years and three months,'' Pounders said. ``The only problem is I won't see the case through to its conclusion.'' In legal papers filed Feb. 8, Pounders said he publicly commented on the case so he could defend the judicial system and the jurors. He said he had denied some of Davis' legal fees because they were excessive. Buckey and his mother were found innocent of 52 counts of child molestation and conspiracy. The jury deadlocked on the 13 additional counts involving Buckey.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Attack Soldiers, Four Dead
DOC.TEXT: Maoist guerrillas ambushed an army convoy in the Andes Mountains on Wednesday and two soldiers and two rebels were killed in the ensuing gun battle, officials said. In other violence, police in Lima said six Shining Path rebels shot to death an explosives company executive and his assistant near the company's plant. A military spokesman in Tarma, a highland city 90 miles northeast of Lima, said soldiers captured four rebels who were wounded in the mountain ambush. The battle occurred before dawn Wednesday when a column of Shining Path guerrillas attacked the convoy on a road near the village of Pian, about 10 miles east of Tarma, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Lima police said the two businessmen were killed Tuesday afternoon in an ambush near the Famesa company plant, 20 miles north of Lima. Police said Juan Chacaltana, the company's director of industrial relations, and his assistant Ricardo Cruces were driving away from the plant and had stopped at a store when two men shot them. Police said they did not know the motive for the killing, but that Chacaltana's family said he had received death threats from the guerrillas. The Shining Path began battling Peru's elected governments in 1980. The government says more than 17,500 people have died in the violence, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Bookstore Bows To Students Following Boycott Over Alleged Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: Barnes & Noble College Bookstores agreed Wednesday to remove two branch managers from a store at Brandeis University after more than a week of student boycotts provoked by alleged racial harassment. Alan Kahn, president of the New York-based bookstore chain, agreed to relocate a manager and an assistant manager in the wake of allegations that several black students were unduly scrutinized while shopping at the campus store. Student activist Johnny Williams, a graduate sociology student, said he and other demonstrators would abandon their boycott Wednesday because ``Barnes & Noble has treated our claims with concern and fairness and we applaud them for their sincere response.'' Lawrence Holcomb, also a graduate sociology student, spurred the boycott with a letter published Feb. 6 in the independent campus newspaper, The Justice, in which he charged the store managers had harassed him and his companions and suspected them of theft because they were black. ``We believe that our experiences have been validated by this statement,'' Holcomb said at a news conference Wednesday. ``Until we recognize racial harassment for what it is our society will continue to believe that there is not a problem.'' Students who demonstrated at the bookstore throughout the week have demanded other changes designed to improve race relations at the campus, where 77 of about 3,200 students are black. The list of demands includes establishing a racial harassment policy, recruiting black students and faculty, altering the core curriculum to introduce more courses with a non-European orientation, and developing an intercultural center.

DOC.HEAD: Cab Crushed by Falling Concrete; Driver Killed
DOC.TEXT: Several thousand pounds of wet concrete fell from a construction site onto a downtown street Wednesday, crushing a cab driver to death, authorities said. The cab driver, 55-year-old Choong Soo In of Chicago, was pronounced dead on arrival at Northwestern Memorial Hospital at 1:26 p.m., said Chicago Police Sgt. Norbert Holzinger. Holzinger said a crane operator working at a hotel construction site had trouble while hoisting a bucket filled with about 6,000 pounds of wet concrete to the rooftop of the building. As the crane operator tried to lower the bucket to the floor where it was to be poured, the bucket started going too fast. ``He tried to stop it and reverse it,'' Holzinger said. ``The bucket hit the edge of the lower roof and spilled.'' The cab, which was crushed by the wet concrete, sideswiped three other vehicles before coming to a stop, Holzinger said. The wet concrete covered several vehicles. ``At this time, we're treating it as an accident,'' Holzinger said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Says United States Has Misused Anti-drug Push
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with Cuban criticism of United States; EDITS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Cuba on Wednesday accused the United States of using the anti-drug fight as an excuse for trampling the rights of other nations. Speaking at a special U.N. session on narcotics, Foreign Affairs Minister Isidoro Malmierca of Cuba also said his country supports international efforts to halt the illegal drug trade. However, the offensive must focus on reducing consumption and offering economic aid to poor countries where the narcotics are produced, he said. ``We shall support resolutely the international cooperation to combat drug trafficking and related activities, but at the same time we shall be on the alert and oppose any action or mechanism which could be used to violate the borders of our nations, our sovereignty and territorial integrity,'' Malmierca said. He described the U.S. invasion of Panama in December and the U.S. Coast Guard's firing on a Cuban-chartered freighter on Jan. 31 as ``two criminal acts under the same pretext: the so-called combat against drug trafficking.'' The United States said it invaded Panama to oust military leader Manuel Antonio Noriega and bring him back to the United States to stand trial on drug charges. American officials say the U.S. cutter fired on the freighter when the crew refused to allow a search of the vessel and U.S. authorities suspected it was involved in illegal narcotics trafficking. No one was reported injured. ``The United States does not have to deploy aircraft carriers or paratroopers in other countries in order to combat the cultivation and transport of that drug to the consumer centers,'' Malmierca said. Earlier Wednesday, China's deputy health minister, Gu Yingqi, said world efforts to fight drug trafficking must include safeguards to protect the sovereignty of all nations. Gu said no country should ``threaten other countries with force, even armed invasion, under the excuse of fighting drugs or carrying out international cooperation for drug control.'' He said heightened international efforts to halt the illegal drug trade led to recent violations of the rights of some countries. He was not specific. Britain and Pakistan, two nations facing mounting problems from the illegal drug trade, said regional and global attacks on trafficking and consumption must be coordinated to end the narcotics plague. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd called it ``a problem of nightmare proportions.'' Pakistani representative Kalim Dil Khan said that despite increased efforts to eliminate illegal narcotics production in southern Asia, drug abuse and crimes linked to the illicit trade increased there. Khan, federal secretary of Pakistan's Narcotics Control Ministry, told the session, ``The loss of human lives resulting from drug trafficking and abuse is also increasing. That shows that something has gone wrong somewhere in our global strategy.''

DOC.HEAD: 400 Gather to Mark 25th Anniversary of Malcolm X's Death
DOC.TEXT: About 400 people gathered Wednesday at the site of Malcolm X's assassination to mark the 25th anniversary of his death and to protest the planned demolition of the building. The black leader was shot to death Feb. 21, 1965, while giving a speech in the Audubon Ballroom in upper Manhattan. Under a 1987 agreement by the city, the state and Columbia University, the badly deteriorated structure will be torn down to make way for the university's biotechnology research building. In its heyday in the 1930s and 1940s, the ballroom was a showcase for big bands. ``It is a very historical site for the black community,'' said Colette Pean of the group which organized Wednesday's rally. ``Twenty-five years after Malcolm's death, his message of self-determination for black people is now more important than ever.'' Columbia says it has worked closely with the local community, which is largely Hispanic, in developing the biotechnology project, and consulted with leaders of the black community, including Malcolm X's widow, Dr. Betty Shabazz, about what might be the most fitting memorial. Bernhard Haeckel, Columbia's director of project development, said the conclusion was that a proper show of respect for Malcolm X's legacy ``is one that would be forward-looking rather than nostalgic.'' Columbia hopes the $25 million Audubon Research Building will be a focus for industrial-university cooperation, bringing discoveries in medical research out of the laboratory and into regular use. The school also says an expected 300 permanent new jobs and planned job-training can help the economically distressed neighborhood. Those benefits, in addition to a scholarship fund for minority students in Malcolm X's name at Columbia's nearby medical school, will do more for the black leader's legacy than pouring precious funds into restoring the place of his death, Haeckel said.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Dept. Settles Medicare Fraud Against Two Providers
DOC.TEXT: A New York hospital agreed to pay $1.15 million and a medical provider in Texas will pay $2 million to settle charges they defrauded Medicare of $2.1 million, the Department of Justice announced Wednesday. Prime Medical Services of Dallas, formerly CP Rehab Corp. of Bedminster, N.J., had been billing Medicare for procedures the company said were performed by its doctors when they were actually done by hospital technicians, a statement from the Justice Department said. Victory Memorial Hospital of the New York City borough of Brooklyn and two Manhattan hospitals also submitted claims for reimbursement for the procedures, according to the statement. The double billing was discovered through an investigation by the Department of Health and Human Services Inspector General and the New York Medicaid Fraud Control Unit. The investigation also revealed that Victory Hospital received a 50 percent kickback from CP Rehab for every testing receipt the hospital provided, the Justice Department said. The procedures Medicare was billed for, arterial punctures, are performed to measure arterial blood gases, said Michael Robinson, a spokesman for the Justice Department. Medicare is the federal health care insurance program for people age 65 or over and for the disabled. Robinson would not comment on the status of the investigation into the two Manhattan hospitals involved in the double billing.

DOC.HEAD: New Oil Find Could Delay Beach Reopening
DOC.TEXT: Plans to reopen beaches fouled by 400,000 gallons of crude oil were set back Wednesday when cleanup officials reported that more oil may have seeped into the sand than previously believed. Unusual tides during a Feb. 13 storm may have washed thin layers of oil above the normal high-tide line along 6 miles of beach, British Petroleum America announced. The storm's winds also shifted sands that may have concealed oil deposits, British Petroleum spokesman Jim Marino said. The oil company operates the tanker American Trader and is directing cleanup efforts. Initial findings indicate oil may have seeped between four and six inches into the sand from Huntington Beach Pier to 18th Street in Newport Beach. British Petroleum officials met with Coast Guard officers to discuss a survey of the affected coastline and, if more oil is found, how to recover it, Marino said. ``The worst case scenario would be to prematurely open the beaches and have people go down and get oil on themselves,'' he said. ``We're using an abundance of caution.'' ``It will delay it (reopening beaches), definitely,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer Tim Rowe. However, Newport Beach Fire Capt. Ray Pendleton said surface cleanup had gone so well on another section, from the Newport Pier to 18th Street, that the beachn could be opened Thursday. No date for reopening other beaches closed by the Feb. 7 tanker spill had been set Wednesday. A total of 3{ miles of affected beach were reopened earlier this week after cleanup completion. About 350 people remained on cleanup detail Wednesday. At Bolsa Chica State Beach, crews heated salt water to 140 degrees and washed oil-coated rocks, followed by a salt water rinse at normal temperatures. Workers employed the same technique at the Newport Beach jetties but heated water only to 90 degrees because of concern about marine life. Forty workers scoured sludge from the entrance of the Santa Ana River.

DOC.HEAD: Bonnie Raitt Caps Rough-and-Tumble Decade With Grammy Triumph
LaserPhoto LA17, LaserColor LA29
DOC.TEXT: Bonnie Raitt, a whiskey-voiced redhead who fame eluded in a tough, 20-year career, soared to a stunning comeback Wednesday night with four top Grammy awards. Her ``Nick of Time'' record was named album of the year and won her top female pop and rock vocalist honors. She also shared the traditional blues Grammy with John Lee Hooker for the ``I'm in the Mood'' track on Hooker's ``The Healer'' LP. ``This means so much for the kind of music I do, and means those of us who do rhythm and blues are going to get a chance again,'' Raitt, a four-time nominee during her career, told the 32nd annual Grammy Awards show audience. The 1980s were difficult years for Raitt, 40, who switched record labels and fought drug and alcohol abuse. ``Nick of Time'' chronicles her doubts about love and growing older. Her previous album, ``Nine Lives,'' was ignored by critics and her record label, which refused to release it on compact disc. The daughter of Broadway musical star John Raitt (``Carousel,'' ``Oklahoma'') and his wife and piano accompanist, Marjorie Haydock, Raitt taught herself guitar at the age of 9. Her early influences included bluesman Junior Wells, who played on her first album, ``Bonnie Raitt,'' in 1971. ``Nick of Time'' is her ninth album. One of her best known singles was her 1977 cover of the late Del Shannon's ``Runaway.'' In the interim, her work has been uneven as she fought drug and alcohol abuse. Three years ago, she began psychotherapy and a year later she joined Alcoholics Anonymous. On her recent concert tour, which played to packed houses across the nation, she told audiences that vanity led to her rebirth as an artist. ``I was going to make an album with Prince,'' she said in 1988. ``It's one thing to go on stage if you're a little chunky, it's another to make a video with a guy who's known for looking foxy,'' she said. ``I decided to lose weight, which you can't do if you're drinking all the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested For Threatening Federal Judge
DOC.TEXT: A man was arrested for trying to extort $2,500 from a federal judge when he picked up a package delivered to a park by an FBI agent posing as the judge, authorities said Wednesday. Scott Wolf, 20, was accused of trying to extort money from U.S. District Judge Frank Magill of Fargo, who sits on the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Wolf was arrested Tuesday night after he retrieved a package delivered to a Fargo baseball field by FBI Special Agent Kenneth Aldridge, who was posing as the judge. In a court affidavit released Wednesday, Aldridge said Wolf admitted the extortion attempt. ``Wolf told me that he typed the two Magill extortion letters, and later called the judge and attempted to gain money from the judge,'' Aldridge's affidavit said. ``He further told me that he acted alone and took actions against the judge because he needed money,'' Aldridge said. Magill declined comment Wednesday, said John Garry, one of the judge's law clerks. But the FBI said Wolf may have tried to extort money from the judge because he was acquainted with Magill. ``Mr. Wolf resided at one time in the neighborhood with the Magill family. And there's reason to believe that he has known the Magill family for a number of years,'' FBI Agent Perry Smith told reporters. Wolf appeared Wednesday before U.S. Magistrate Karen Klein, who said he was neither a flight risk nor a danger to the community and released him without bail. Aldridge's affidavit said Magill received the first of two extortion letters on Feb. 4 while attending judicial meetings in Florida. The letter was postmarked Fargo and was addressed to Magill and his wife Mary. The FBI agent said Magill was told in the letter that ``certain fatal and painful actions will be taken against the Magill family'' unless he put $2,500 in a business envelope and placed it on home plate at a baseball diamond. FBI agents delivered a package to the baseball diamond on Feb. 7, but no one picked up the package, Aldridge said. A second letter, which Magill found Saturday, repeated the demand. ``You had better take us serious about this money, because we want it and we want it now,'' the letter said, as summarized in Aldridge's affidavit. Aldridge said McGill also received telephone calls Saturday and Tuesday. The caller hung up when the phone was answered, but the calls later were traced to Wolf's residence.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Speaks to 300,000 Nicaraguans at Rally Ending Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, UPDATING with new quotes, color. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA2
