DOC.HEAD: Apartheid-at-a-Glance: What's Changed, What Remains
With BC-Apartheid Now, b0615-b0616
DOC.TEXT: Here is what has changed in apartheid and what remains in force:

_Blacks allowed to form their own trade unions. _Laws outlawing interracial marriage and sexual relations repealed. _The Pass Laws, which required blacks in ``white'' areas to have a permit, repealed. _Influx control laws, which restricted blacks' freedom to move into urban areas, abolished. _Beaches, theaters, hotels, restaurants and most forms of public transport desegegrated. _Laws reserving for whites certain types of supervisory and technical jobs at mines repealed. _Blacks given a policy-making role in provincial administration. _Central business districts in major cities and towns opened to black traders. _Blacks who previously could only rent homes now can obtain permanent ownership.

_Black majority has no vote in national affairs. DOC.HEAD: Carol Burnett Stars in NBC Comedy Anthology
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Carol Burnett may have come up with something new on television, where recycling the past is usually the wave of the future. In her anthology series for NBC, ``Carol & Company,'' she'll play a different character each week in what essentially are one-act comedies. ``We put up a blank canvas every week and throw on the paint,'' Burnett said. ``Each story is character-driven and focuses on relationships. In essence, it's a pilot every week. If someone said, `Pick the most difficult form of television,' we'd pick this. That's why no one's ever done it before.'' The show will be shot live in front of an audience, featuring a repertory company and, frequently, a guest star, Burnett said. ``Each week, we make a fresh start,'' she said. ``That's the challenge for the actors, the writers, the set designers, everybody. We're even doing a musical.'' NBC has not yet set a premiere date for the show, but has said it will begin in late March. Matt Williams, who created ABC's ``Roseanne,'' is the executive producer and head writer. The repertory company is made up of Terry Kiser, Meagan Fay, Richard Kind, Jeremy Piven and Anita Barone. Burnett, of course, starred for 12 years in ``The Carol Burnett Show.'' But that show, like Fox's ``The Tracey Ullman Show,'' relied on skits. Most anthologies in the past were dramatic. There have been a few comedy anthologies _ 1985's ``George Burns Comedy Week,'' for instance _ but Burns merely introduced a filmed show with a different cast each week. As with her old variety show, Burnett will come out and meet the audience in the theater at the Disney Studio. Then she'll change costumes and join the other actors. The story will be acted out in sequence and, at the end, the actors will make a curtain call. ``It's important that the viewers see the audience,'' she said. ``We don't want anyone to think we're using canned laughter. I've only done a few things for television without an audience. When I started this, I said an audience was important, especially if you're trying to be funny. Our players and guests are used to working before an audience.'' That wasn't always true on her variety series, where some of the guests were movie stars who had worked only before a camera. Gloria Swanson, who asked to take part after seeing Burnett's famous spoof of ``Sunset Boulevard,'' was very nervous and had to be coaxed through her song-and-dance role. Movie spoofs were a hallmark of Burnett's old show, an outgrowth of a childhood filled with countless hours in movie theaters. Recently, she attended the American Cinema Awards. ``I was in heaven,'' Burnett said. ``Every old movie star was there _ Ann Blyth, Huntz Hall, June Allyson, Turhan Bey. It took almost an hour to introduce everybody. People were just dying at seeing these people. ``We haven't done any spoofs yet on our new show,'' she said, ``but we did do a takeoff on the film noir detective films of the 1940s, the Dick Powell kind of thing in `Murder, My Sweet' in which you spat out the dialogue like bullets. We did it mainly to introduce our repertory company. That's as close as we've gotten to a spoof. We're really doing stories.'' In one show, Burnett plays the matriarch of a television soap opera who appears to be a terror until you see her with a security guard played by Robert Guillaume. In another, she's an eccentric woman who shows up on a dock in Gulfport, Miss., where Nell Carter is fishing. Her only concern is that she's going to be abducted by space aliens. Glenda Jackson is a radio pop psychologist in another show in which Burnett shows up at the station to say the psychologist's advice ruined her life. Another spotlights a woman who surprises a few people when she goes to her high school reunion. In yet another, Burnett and Alex Rocco play a romantic couple who continue to work together in a scientific laboratory. Burnett also has her own production company, Kalola Productions, at the Disney Studio, in partnership with former television newswoman Marcia Brandwynne. Kalola is doing an interview show for the Disney Channel called ``A Conversation With ...,'' in which Burnett so far has interviewed Bob Hope, George Burns and Betty White. Kalola has a number of feature and television movies and a TV series in development with various branches of Walt Disney Productions. Anna Phelan Hamilton, who wrote ``Mask'' and ``Gorillas in the Mist,'' is writing a movie based on Burnett's autobiography, ``One More Time.'' A movie musical called ``Rehearsal Club'' is based on Burnett's early life on Broadway, and a movie version of ``Once Upon a Mattress,'' the stage musical that made her a star, is in the works. ``I'm going to be like Alfred Hitchcock and have cameos in all these movies,'' she said. ``In `Once Upon a Mattress,' I'll probably be the queen. We'll have a big talent search for someone to play my old role as Winifred.''

At the Movies: `Hunt for Red October'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Film opens nationwide on March 2.
DOC.TEXT: Tom Clancy's high-tech thrillers have been a phenomenon of the publishing industry. Although jammed with scientific data, his novels have been bought by millions of readers. Despite their immense popularity and tense drama, none has been dramatized on the screen until now. That's understandable. Clancy's labyrinthian plots and dependence on military hardware for suspense require the most deft of treatment on film. ``The Hunt for Red October'' is fortunate in that regard. It is a nail-biter from beginning to end. Like the book, the film requires close attention; the slightest blip on the sonar screen could mean destruction of a nuclear submarine. The casual viewer should stay home. Red October (named for the month of the Russian Revolution in 1917) is the new Soviet submarine, one with fish-like gills that allows it to voyage undetected. Capt. Ramius (Sean Connery) heads the sub west on an unauthorized mission in the pre-Gorbachev era. Both the Soviet and U.S. fleets mobilize to chase Ramius. The Soviets realize he and his officers plan to defect. The Americans, misinformed by Moscow, fear he is a maverick who might launch a nuclear attack on the United States CIA agent Jack Ryan (Alec Baldwin), with experience in analyzing the Soviet navy, is enlisted to track down the Red October. Aiding the pursuit is a Los Angeles-class nuclear sub commanded by Scott Glenn, with a wizard sonar operator, Courtney B. Vance. Larry Ferguson and Donald Stewart did a terrific job of compressing a huge novel into a playable screenplay. John McTiernan proved with ``Die Hard'' that he can stretch suspense almost to the breaking point, and he exceeds himself with ``The Hunt for Red October.'' What a marvel Sean Connery is. His dialogue is laconic, but that great Scottish face reveals everything in his mind. Alec Baldwin makes the leap to stellar status with absolute ease. Kevin Costner, Harrison Ford and Mel Gibson: Make room for the new kid. Outstanding in the virtually all-male cast are Glenn, Vance, James Earl Jones, Sam Neill, Richard Jordan and Peter Firth. Mace Neufeld as producer performed the almost superhuman task in putting together the multitude of details for ``The Hunt for Red October.'' The Paramount Pictures release is rated PG for minor swearing and tension. Running time: 125 minutes.

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.TEXT:
``New York Stories'' (Touchstone. VHS-Beta, $89.95. Rated PG)
``New York Stories'' was a disaster during its theatrical release. But it might play better on the small screen at home because you can always zoom to your favorite vignette and skip the others. It began as an excellent idea: Take three top American filmmakers, set them out on the streets of New York and loop their efforts into one full-length feature to celebrate those collective talents and the city they supposedly enshrined. Unfortunately, the idea doesn't quite gel. The video consists of three vignettes by Martin Scorsese, Frances Coppola and Woody Allen. But only Scorsese's ``Life Lessons'' is worth the $89.95 or cost of rental. It's also the first story in the production so you don't even need to touch the remote. Unless you're an unconditional Woody Allen fan, skip the next two. ``Life Lessons'' is the only vignette that truly mirrors the spirit and attitude of New York _ in this case, the downtown art world. It has a feel, texture and mood, thanks in part to the gritty and witty original screenplay by Bronx-born writer Richard Price, and the sensitive and probing lens of the celebrated cinematographer Nestor Almendros. Star Watch: Costner's Fond Memories of Puerto Vallarta
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Kevin Costner has a special memory about the sunswept seaside resort of Puerto Vallarta. ``I was here about 12 years ago on my honeymoon. At that time I was considering being an actor. On the plane out of Puerto Vallarta, I ran into Richard Burton and thought to talk to him. I had to devise a plan to get at him, because he wanted his privacy _ which I completely understand now,'' Costner said. ``He had blocked out four seats so he could be alone. After we were in the air, I sat down beside him, and I asked him about the job of acting. He was very gracious and helpful. ``My wife and I had saved $20 to take the bus from LAX (Los Angeles International Airport) back to Orange County. But we hadn't counted on the Mexican airport tax of $10 apiece. So when we got off the plane we had about $6 between us. We sat down on our suitcases on one of those islands at LAX, just like the hitchhiking scene from `It Happened One Night.' ``As we were sitting there, a limousine stopped right by us. The window came down, and it was Richard Burton saying `good luck.' He thought to say one last thing to me. The window went up and he drove away. It was kinda nice, just like a scene out of a movie.'' The Costners managed to hitchhike home. When Costner returned to Puerto Vallarta last year, he didn't stay at a tiny hotel near the airport, as he had on his honeymoon. He came with all the perks of a superstar to do location work for the movie ``Revenge,'' the love triangle in which he stars with Anthony Quinn and Madeleine Stowe. As evidence of his new status, Costner also served as executive producer. Costner, 34, returned here for a round of interviews at the elegant Camino Real Hotel to publicize the opening of ``Revenge.'' Normally publicity-shy, he answered questions dutifully though he seemed to be wishing he was back home in La Canada, near Pasadena. The actor chose to make ``Revenge'' before the Academy Award-nominated ``Field of Dreams,'' though filming came afterward. He found the Jim Harrison novel to be ``a fabulous piece of material, a tough-line movie; I move toward that kind of writing.'' e added that he has picked all of his films since ``The Big Chill,'' in which his role as one of the Sixties radicals was reduced to a scene at his own funeral. What does he look for? ``I look for the same thing that a lot of people do: fresh air, originality of concept. Things that surprise me, little things inside a movie that move me. All those things combined hopefully become a satisfying experience. You can't do a movie just because you've always wanted to do a violent one or a comedy. You have to do one that makes sense to you.'' His post as executive producer, he admitted, was ``not the wisest move in a sense, because it's not a very meaningful title. Not to put it down or the people who gave it to me. I've had as much power on other films as to the quality of my arguments or points.'' In ``Revenge,'' Costner faced a legendary actor with great screen presence, Quinn. He was unfazed. ``I've had a lot of experience with those kinds of guys: Gene Hackman (`No Way Out'), Sean Connery (`The Untouchables'), Burt Lancaster (`Field of Dreams'),'' he said. ``One thing is, you don't compete with them, that's for sure. That's a lesson in acting: that you don't compete. These guys are legendary, and the movie is so much better off by their being there. I have plenty of time to get my own share of viewing. As far as I'm concerned, when those guys are on the set, they're the stars of the movie.'' Costner was not only the star of his last movie, ``Dances With Wolves,'' but director and co-producer. The story of a Civil War soldier who moves into the world of the Sioux Indians has been the subject of rumors that he soared over budget and schedule. Costner bristled when asked about the reports. ``The control of that movie is entirely on my shoulders, so its fate I take full responsibility for,'' he said. ``The rumors seem to me kind of silly. There have to be more important things to talk about than me going 2 or 3 percent over my budget. ``Budgets in movies are at best an estimation of things. I went a lot of days over, but the interesting thing is that we went only 3 percent over budget. We managed our money very well. ``When you see the size of the movie, (you'll realize) no one in town could make that movie except us. We made a movie that in a studio concept would be a $30 to $40 million movie. The numbers that are being mentioned are not correct. It's less than $18 million. I'm not going to tell you what it is, because I haven't completed the movie. ``It's convenient to say `Kevin's Gate' (as in `Heaven's Gate' or Watergate). That's kind of cute journalism that I don't really like.'' Kevin Costner is a California boy, son of an electric utility worker who moved the family from town to town. He was a runt in high school, and though he grew to 6-foot-1 in college, he remained shy and dateless. Like many actors, he countered his shyness with drama classes. After graduation from California State University at Fullerton, he married his only date, Cindy Silva, and tried a marketing job for 30 days. He quit in disgust to seek work in Hollywood. For six years he worked by day on crews at Raleigh Studio and studied acting at night. ``The Big Chill'' provided his breakthrough for a major motion picture, but his role of the dead friend was edited down to merely a scene showing him in his coffin. This was followed by his riproaring gunslinger in ``Silverado.'' Costner now faces the instant recognizability that he observed with Richard Burton. Can he maintain any privacy? ``I can,'' he said. ``People are actually very good with me. Sometimes they have strong feelings, and they want to talk to me. I'm still a citizen, I'm a citizen of the world. I can go places. I'm actually treated the way everybody should be treated. My (private) world has closed behind me, but a new one has opened up.''

The Artists: Ambivalent Music for an Ambivalent Age
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Roll over Beethoven, go powder your wig Bach. Meet the newest musical sensation: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. ``I think that nowadays Mozart appeals to more people in more countries on more levels than any other composer who ever lived,'' says musicologist H.C. Robbins Landon, whose ``1791: Mozart's Last Year'' was a best-seller in 1988, and whose new book, ``Mozart: the Golden Years,'' looks at the last decade of Mozart's life. ``It used to be Beethoven and Bach,'' he said. ``Now it is certainly Mozart. Ambivalent music speaks to an ambivalent age. ``With Beethoven, the music starts stormily and ends triumphantly in C major. The message is much more diffuse and cloudy in Mozart. You often don't really know whether the music you're listening to is very happy or unhappy. Maybe it is both. All this appeals emotionally to people nowadays who have begun to think the world is in dreadful danger and all is not straightforward. ``One of the most famous, the `Elvira Madigan' movement, is ambivalent music. Is it happy? People don't know why they love it, but they love it. It obviously has a very special message. ... Nothing becomes a best seller by accident.'' Robbins Landon, who was born in Boston in 1926 and now lives in France, has written 16 books. Most are about Haydn and Mozart. ``My life has been dedicated to music,'' he said. ``The principal thing I've done is to have published Haydn's music _ 21,000 pages of Haydn in score. When I was young, nine-tenths of Haydn wasn't published. Now nine-tenths of Haydn is published. ``That was a great labor of love. You don't live from that. I used to do a lot of TV scripts, mostly for the BBC. I'm doing them again now. At the moment I'm writing a five-part history of music in Venice, a triple production by London, Paris and PBS in this country.'' From studying Mozart's music, Robbins Landon found the composer to have had a split personality. ``He was writing music easily comprehensible to 18th century buffs, and he was writing far-out stuff with extreme violence. Why was of course a mystery. Then I read this theory of Dr. Peter G. Davies that Mozart was manic depressive or had those tendencies. ``Dr. Davies published long, scholarly articles on Mozart's illness. I've quoted them. His ups and downs came in waves. When he had downs, he felt compelled to compose in minor keys which were so far out of their time. When Don Giovanni goes to hell, that's far-out music. He must have known the public wouldn't have known what to do with these things. ``His piano concertos in D minor and C minor began to alienate the public. They began to be the cause of Mozart's concerts in Vienna being less well attended and unattended. From 1787 on, Mozart began to get into debt, because of the fact his far-out music was not comprehensible to the average concertgoer. It wasn't until 1791, the last year of his life, that he began to extricate himself from a mountain of debts.'' Robbins Landon called the Academy Award-winning ``Amadeus'' a great film, which awakened much interest in Mozart. ``What people don't understand is that it's not a biography of Mozart. They never said it was. They said they were producing a film about mediocrity and jealousy and they used Mozart's life as a very successful prop to tell the story.'' The musicologist's new book is based on Johann Pezzl's day-by-day chronicle of Mozart in Vienna from 1786 to 1790. ``Mozart: the Golden Years'' is published here by Schirmer and sells for $29.95. Robbins Landon was given the idea for his life's work by his piano teacher when he was 13. ``He said: `You're never going to be the greatest pianist in the world. You ought to do something for Haydn. All the other composers have their collective works. We don't know how much Haydn wrote. A lot of manuscripts are in private possession.' He said I had to turn myself into a fully trained professional musician,'' Robbins Landon recalled. ``I ended up going to Boston where I conducted and managed an orchestra and formed a chamber orchestra. With some pals I studied counterpoint and harmony. We were happy young people doing music all day long. ``My parents, upper class New Englanders, said, `If we don't help you, you won't make it.' They helped me up to writing a five-volume biography of Haydn, which was published by Indiana University Press. It's a real monster. It did end up making money but you can't live from that. They sent me nice fat checks now and then to keep me going. ``After I'd done what any single person can do for Haydn, then I went to Mozart, always the great love of my life.'' Robbins Landon has been married for 32 years to Austrian historian Else Radant. ``She helps me,'' he said. ``She does a lot of research. We live outside Toulouse with secretaries and assistants. We don't have any cross words with anybody in our house. It's nice to work in an atmosphere like that.'' They all work hard, swim, take five-mile walks, eat garlic, vegetables from their garden, often broil fish and drink the local wine. The secret of a happy life, the musicologist says, ``is not your career or money. If you have a happy marriage, everything else you can work out.'' The Mozarts loved each other, Robbins Landon said. ``He wrote her pornographic letters from Leipsig which I published for the first time in the new book. Nowadays it is nothing. It is sweet.'' If he'd been in Vienna in Mozart's day, Robbins Landon says, ``I would have been a good, routine kapellmeister (music director). I can compose and conduct. If I'd had my wits about me I would have thought Mozart was the greatest thing that ever happened. ... I'm sure he was difficult. ``He couldn't stand mediocrity and was arrogant with non-professionals. I hope I would have been his friend.''

DOC.BYLINE: Music Makers: From Gothic Gloom to Mainstream Rock
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mystic and spiritual are not usually terms associated with a heavy metal band. Neither are introspective and cerebral. But the British band The Cult is an exception. Lead singer Ian Astbury springs from the same mold that produced Jim Morrison, the late lead vocalist of the Doors. With his long, ink-black hair, vaulted cheekbones and penchant for wearing leather and snakeskin, Astbury looks more like an ancient medicine man than a rock singer. His foil, blond guitarist Billy Duffy, grounds Astbury's otherworldliness with a hard rock perspective and balances the singer's brooding seriousness with his own devil-may-care personality. The band is rounded out by bassist-rhythm guitarist Jamie Stewart and drummer Matt Sorum. The Cult's first U.S. release, 1985's ``Love,'' kept them in the college radio spotlight with the meticulously arranged track ``She Sells Sanctuary.'' The album's swirling psychedelic lyrics and jangly, melodic guitar work pigeonholed the band into a genre known as Gothic, a trend started in Britain in the early '80s. By their next album, ``Electric,'' in 1987, the bant released in England and Europe,'' Duffy said. ``We did a lot of our dirty laundry in public. College alternative fans in America liked those recordings. To us, they're very fledgling, kind of experimental. They have their moments, but they're not very relevant to where The Cult is now.'' Part of The Cult's mystique stems from Astbury's interest in American Indian myth and culture. Such songs as ``Brother Wolf, Sister Moon,'' from ``Love,'' and ``American Horse,'' from ``Sonic Temple,'' depict not only the Indian's struggle with the white man, but the folklore he created in trying to determine his own destiny. ``The interest in Indians was more prevalent in the earlier days of the band, in Southern Death Cult,'' Duffy says. ``Ian's interest is still there, but he's matured. He has said, `I'm a white, working-class guy from the northwest of England who happens to personally feel very strongly an affinity for the American Indian.' It's not to the point of a flag-flying exercise. ``Ian's angle is that they do their own thing, they exist, they have their own dignity within themselves. The last thing they need is some two-bob rock n' roll band carrying a flag for them.'' Duffy said the band's philosophy is simple. ``The Cult got together because we had the desire to make music together as individuals,'' Duffy said. ``We all wanted to make a kind of music that no one in Britain seemed to be interested in doing at the time. ``From that, we still maintain that basic desire _ we dig what we do, we're genuinely excited about the records we make and the songs we write. We like to go out and play that to people and share it.'' Duffy doesn't see another style change coming down the line. ``I think that thick sound, that professional sound, will be there, but it will still be very human,'' he said. The band began its current tour of the United States and Canada in San Francisco on Dec. 27.

Books and Authors: The Enduring Navajo and Tony Hillerman
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Judging from Tony Hillerman's books, you might think he's Navajo, and many Navajos are surprised to learn he's not. That's because Hillerman has captured American Indian cultures, particularly Navajo, as no other novelist. In 1987, he was given a ``Special Friend of the Navajo'' award to go with his Edgar Allan Poe Award for best mystery of 1973, ``Dance Hall of the Dead.'' His last two books, ``A Thief of Time'' and ``Talking God,'' have been best sellers, and he now has a $1.25 million contract with Harper & Row. His latest book, ``Coyote Waits,'' is scheduled for June _ just in time to start making his first movie. Hillerman has a three-picture deal with Robert Redford. Filming starts this summer on an adaptation of his 1982 novel, ``The Dark Wind.'' Hillerman serves as consultant. The author, Redford, producers Sarah Pillsbury and Midge Sanford and film executive Bonnie Lee toured the reservation in a rented station wagon with Redford driving, discussing which of Hillerman's Navajo police mysteries should be the first film. ``Dark Wind,'' in which Navajo and Hopi cops solve drug-related murders, was chosen because of its mixture of two Indian cultures. It will be directed by Errol Morris (``The Thin Blue Line''). ``It seemed to me that since so many people who go to movies are the kind of people who think all Indians are alike, it would be good to put two quite different tribes in,'' he said. ``I had taken for granted Redford was going to start with `Thief of Time.' He wants to direct that one himself,'' said Hillerman, leaning back against the antique pigeonhole desk he got from an old hotel office. Above is the ``Friend of the Navajo'' plaque and a framed drawing of Navajo ceremonial masks. On his left, above his word processor, is a map of Indian country _ eastern Arizona, western New Mexico and southern Utah and Colorado _ and a window overlooking a back yard terraced with old railroad ties and bricks. His is a modest brick home in an average Albuquerque neighborhood. Redford, reached while filming in the Dominican Republic, said he likes working with the 64-year-old author. ``He is very unfettered by either success or too much trouble around him,'' Redford said. ``He travels his own route and at his own pace. He's rare in that he has that wonderful sense of structure of storytelling and a very clear eye as to the real nature of the Navajo.'' Born Anthony Grove Hillerman on May 27, 1925, in Sacred Heart, Okla., the son of a storekeeper, young Tony was his high school class historian but never gave much thought to writing. ``I kind of liked to write and I read a lot, but I didn't know real human beings were writers,'' he said. ``I mean writers and writing were not something in the imagination of a kid growing up out there.'' The idea took seed when a wounded Hillerman returned on convalescent furlough from France during World War II. A land mine explosion had shattered his left leg and severely burned his left eye. The leg still bothers him sometimes, and he never regained full use of the eye. Beatrice Stahl, a feature writer for The Daily Oklahoman in Oklahoma City, had done a story based on Hillerman's letters home, and now she wanted to interview him. ``So I went down there and talked to her. She told me I ought to be a writer.'' He took her advice and studied journalism at the University of Oklahoma. He graduated amid a flood of war-delayed students in 1948, and he couldn't find a job on a newspaper. ``So I took a job with an advertising agency writing radio commercials. It was just a try-out job doing ads for Cain's Better Coffee and Purina Pig Chow,'' he said. At Oklahoma he met his wife, Marie. They now have six grown children. He also took a job driving a truck hauling oil field supplies. One stop was the Navajo reservation in New Mexico. On one run, he saw Navajos on horseback in ceremonial attire for the Enemy Way, a soul-cleansing ritual that follows combat. They, too, were returning veterans. ``Of course most of them served in the Pacific,'' he said. Something about them touched him, and he never forgot. From then on, he said, New Mexico was his ultimate destination. When Hillerman got the chance to be bureau manager for United Press International in Santa Fe, he grabbed it. He served as executive editor of The New Mexican in Santa Fe after leaving the wire service. During the Santa Fe stint, he covered a story in which a Jicarilla Apache police officer was shot to death. The investigation showed the fallen officer had coolly shifted his revolver from his wounded arm to his good hand and had shot one of his assailants before dying. The Indian was the model for Navajo detective Lt. Joe Leaphorn, mainstay of Hillerman's novels. Hillerman had sold some non-fiction through a New York agent. When he offered her the manuscript in the late 1960s for his first Leaphorn novel, ``The Blessing Way,'' she told him: ``Just get rid of all the Indian stuff.'' ``Probably it was fairly good advice, but it wasn't what I wanted to do,'' he said. An editor at Harper & Row liked it, Indian stuff and all. It was published in 1970. Navajos tell Hillerman they like his books because they're true to Navajo culture, and the Navajos come out winners. In fact, he said, many Navajos express surprise upon learning he's not a Navajo himself. ``I run into that when I sign books around the reservation,'' he said. Despite the mystery, witchcraft and violence of his books, Hillerman bristles at any suggestion the reservation might be a dangerous place. ``In the Navajo culture, all goals are toward harmony, being peaceful, working together. People who turn against this are the worst kind of people,'' he said when asked to define a Navajo witch. What does he like most about the Navajo? ``I like their emphasis on taking care of the family,'' he said. ``I like the dignity they give their women. I like their attitude about material possessions. They just don't attach any importance to them. There's the idea that if you own too much, you probably aren't taking care of your family. ``I like the emphasis they have on beauty, aesthetics _ so many Navajos seem to have a good eye for the sunset, the pleasing design. ``I like their sense of humor, their stoic endurance of whatever comes down. They endure.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Navajo Culture Central to Hillerman's Books ^With BC-WKD--Hillerman, b0866
DOC.TEXT: For a mystery writer, there's probably nothing more mysterious than Navajo culture. Author Tony Hillerman is fascinated by it, and so, apparently, are his readers. Coming off his second straight New York Times best seller, ``Talking God,'' Hillerman continues to examine Indian cultural themes in ``Coyote Waits,'' due for publication in June. A Navajo shaman is a pivotal figure in ``Coyote Waits.'' In ``The Dark Wind,'' the first of Hillerman's books destined for film, Hopi religion comes into play. In ``Dance Hall of the Dead'' it is Zuni religion. In ``The Blessing Way'' and ``Skinwalkers'' Navajo witchcraft is a central theme. Navajo police Lt. Joe Leaphorn, Hillerman's main character, is a skeptic about witchcraft, but in several books he refers back to one of his early cases in which he failed to take it seriously and several people lost their lives. In a recent interview, Hillerman said witchcraft is real enough and common enough to the Navajo. Navajo acquaintances have given him several anecdotes, but there are many examples in scholarly literature, as well. Hillerman related a story one Navajo once told him about seeing a witch. ``It always takes place in the evening or night,'' Hillerman said. ``It was shearing time, lambing time, and it was one of those copper sunsets. Right on the horizon a quarter-mile or so away, he saw the witch, a skinwalker with the head of a coyote.'' The boy's grandmother told him to run and get his .22-caliber rifle, and the youth took a shot at the witch. ``I asked him, `Did you hit him, Kenneth?' He said, `Nah, it was a Navajo .22.''' Another anecdote involves an elderly weaver who called in a crystal gazer to counteract a witch. A Durango, Colo., businessman and his wife drove the gazer out to the woman's home and watched as he did his ritual, Hillerman said. Staring into the crystal, the gazer claimed the witch was a neighbor and had buried something down the road, presumably to cause her a problem. ``The wife sat next to the crystal gazer and got a real strange look on her face,'' Hillerman said. ``She said, `My God, it was just like watching television.' She saw the same things in the crystal that he was describing.'' Then they went to the spot in the road, and the gazer dug up the thing. ``In the Navajo culture, all goals are toward harmony, being peaceful, working together. People who turn against this are the worst kind of people,'' he said. Hillerman, who says he has learned most of what he knows about Navajos from books, has a framed drawing of Navajo ceremonial masks above his desk. Each mask personifies a yei, or Navajo god. And the ceremonies and masks continually turn up in his books. Kokopelli, the Water Sprinkler, is a key image in ``A Thief of Time.'' A sacred mask of Talking God kept at the Smithsonian Institution becomes a lethal weapon in the 1989 novel, ``Talking God.'' And such rituals as the Blessing Way, the Enemy Way and others give texture and color to Hillerman's stories, which mix gentle Navajo traditions with the jarring intrusion of hard-edged Anglo culture. For the latter, the author said, all he needs to do is read the newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
A Tony Hillerman Bibliography
With BC-WKD--Hillerman, b0866
DOC.TEXT: Many of best-selling novelist Tony Hillerman's characters are scholars _ archaeologists, professors, curators and graduate assistants. His central character, Navajo detective Lt. Joe Leaphorn, has a degree in anthropology. His lateset book, ``Coyote Waits,'' involves a train robbery and a feud between two professors of Western history. Here's a bibilography of Hillerman's previous novels: _``The Blessing Way,'' 1970: Leaphorn and a professor friend pursue a Navajo witch. _``The Fly on the Wall,'' 1971: A novel of legislative intrigue. _``Dance Hall of the Dead,'' 1973: Leaphorn tracks a mysterious Zuni dancer while following a trail of bodies. Hillerman won an Edgar Allen Poe Award from the Mystery Writers of America in 1974. _``Listening Woman,'' 1978: Leaphorn goes up against a militant Indian activist amid more murderous machinations. _``People of Darkness,'' 1980: Introduces officer Jim Chee, a bright young detective who falls in love with a white woman and confronts a coldblooded killer. _``The Boy Who Made Dragonfly,'' 1980: A story for young people. _``The Dark Wind,'' 1982: To become the first of a series of motion pictures based on Hillerman's books. Chee and Hopi deputy sheriff Cowboy Dashee solve some drug-related murders. _``The Ghostway,'' 1985: Starts with murder at a Shiprock car wash and leads Chee to Los Angeles. _``Skinwalkers,'' 1987: Leaphorn and Chee are united on a series of apparently witch-related homicide cases. _``A Thief of Time,'' 1988: The Leaphorn-Chee tandem tackles artifact thievery, an archaeologist's disappearance and, of course, murder during an investigation that leads Leaphorn to the art-auction jungle of New York. _``Talking God,'' 1989: A body dumped near the tracks sends Leaphorn and Chee off in apparently unrelated directions only to find they're working on the same case in Washington. Hillerman also has written or edited non-fiction books, including ``The Great Taos Bank Robbery,'' ``Rio Grande,'' ``New Mexico,'' ``The Spell of New Mexico'' and ``Indian Country.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: Garth Brooks' Songs Are From the Heart
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Rising country music singer Garth Brooks says his songs are ``a piece of my heart.'' The 27-year-old singer-songwriter-guitarist has had two hit records with the first two songs released from his debut album, ``Garth Brooks.'' His ``If Tomorrow Never Comes,'' which was No. 1 on the country music charts in December, is about the need to tell loved ones that you love them. His ``Too Young (to Feel This Damn Old),'' about a rodeo contestant whose only friends are lonely women and bad booze, was a hit record last summer. ``You have to let your heart talk,'' Brooks said in an interview. ``If you just let what's in your heart out, you are true.'' Brooks, a native of Tulsa, Okla., where he was the last of six children, has had a rapid rise since moving to Nashville in June 1987. Prior to that, he was a student at Oklahoma State University where he was a javelin thrower for the school track team. He also sang with the group Santa Fe, a regional band that performed throughout Oklahoma, Texas and New Mexico. After relocating to Nashville, he took a job running a boot store. He was able to earn a living while pushing his music career, an arrangement some other aspiring singers do not have. ``I got the manager's job and got to hire one employee, my wife,'' he said. ``I had a very fortunate start.'' Brooks, whose stocky frame is usually capped off with a spiffy cowboy hat, also began singing on songwriters' demonstration tapes: tapes of new, unrecorded songs that composers play for record companies in hopes of getting them chosen for albums. But his real break came when Capitol Records' executives heard him perform at a Nashville Entertainment Association showcase. Based on this performance, he signed a recording contract with Capitol. Brooks has joined a handful of other young singers who are apparently going to shape the country music sound of the 1990s. ``You just pray that you are going to be one of the chosen ones still around in five, 15, 20 years,'' he said. He senses a change in country music themes, a change that has earned his style of music a growing number of fans. ``Country music isn't `My dad got run over at the truck wash right after my wife left me this morning.' The music is set in a manner that everybody can relate to, not just the guy driving the truck. It's very real and people are turning to it. It's not stereotyped any more,'' he said. ``The music has got to be real. I look for things the common man would say, such as the guy at Wal-Mart. Real people today are going to Wal-Mart.'' The cuts on his first album, many of which he wrote or co-wrote, are touching tunes of emotion and life's roadblocks. The song ``Cowboy Bill'' is about a cowboy storyteller who thrilled kids with stories about his days as a Texas Ranger. Adults doubted his veracity until he was found dead with his badge. The cut ``The Dance'' is about the good times before losing a loved one. In ``Every Time That It Rains,'' Brooks sings about a romantic fling that loses its intensity the second time around. His ``If Tomorrow Never Comes'' was so evocative that he received a letter from a Virginia woman who said she was contemplating suicide until hearing the song and studying its message. ``She said that ever since then, her life has been turned around,'' Brooks said. ``Your songs are your swords, your power. It's amazing the size of the sword you carry. ``I'm looking for beliefs that need to be stated in this day and time. ``I try to let people know that they aren't working for nothing, that what they see when they close their eyes at night doesn't always have to be a dream.''

Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Hoping to keep the film and television industry happy and busy in New York, officials have canceled a plan to charge $1,000 a day to use state parks as scenic backdrops. That charge would have applied to photographers and TV and film crews working on movies, TV shows or advertisements. The plan was unveiled last month as part of Gov. Mario Cuomo's $51.3 billion state budget proposal. Officials from the State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation thought it would have been a good way to raise about $200,000 a year for what Cuomo has said is a cash-starved state treasury. And the fees could have been imposed without legislative approval. Economic Development spokesman Harold Holzer said the filmmaking in New York is important to the state's economy. Such movies as ``Ishtar'' and ``Arthur'' have made use of New York's state parks. Since 1985, the state has been allowing the industry to use its 150 parks and 34 historic sites without charge.

An international array of musicians, dancers, singers and other performing artists will converge in Joensuu, Finland, for a midsummer's festival. ``A Meeting of the Worlds'' is being organized by PAND International (Performers and Artists for Nuclear Disarmament) a peace group founded by Harry Belafonte. Among the groups and performers who will be featured at the festival are the Cleveland Orchestra, the Leningrad Philharmonic, the Japanese drum group Eitetsu Hayashi, the Sakhile Group from South Africa and the Raatikko Dance Theatre of Finland. There will also be rock and jazz concerts, an all-African night and an evening of tangos. Proceeds from the festival, which runs June 19-23, will be donated to UNICEF.

DOC.HEAD: `Granny Bashing' Think Tank Strangled by Founder's Ethics Problems
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger had high hopes for a think tank he founded in 1984, Americans for Generational Equity, to sound an alarm about the bleak future he saw facing his children's generation. The baby boomer lobby group stirred a national debate on such issues as Social Security and housing while enraging advocates of the elderly with claims older Americans were getting an unfair share of federal largesse. But mounting ethics problems that threaten Durenberger's career claimed his brainchild and silenced its voice at a time many people think AGE was just growing up. AGE's blue-ribbon board of directors closed the organization's doors and fired its staff last month after the group ran out of money, facing $40,000 in unpaid bills. An ongoing ethics investigation of Durenberger and charges by the group's former director that the Minnesota Republican used AGE for political purposes made fund raising virtually impossible, board members say. ``I hate to see it just evaporate,'' lamented board member Richard Lamm, the former Colorado governor who harbors hopes of resurrecting the group. AGE never had more than a few hundred members, and in its heyday was run by a staff of four on the cluttered ground floor of a Capitol Hill townhouse. But for good or ill, supporters and detractors alike say AGE brought public attention to ``generational equity.'' Lamm, who once said terminally ill people ``had a duty to die and get out of the way,'' says AGE's writings and conferences raised valid allegations that government policies enriched the elderly to the eventual detriment of children and working-age Americans. ``Fair is fair. ... Money that's desperately needed for children in St. Paul is being transferred to millionaires in St. Petersburg,'' Lamm said. But AGE's detractors, whose ranks include the powerful American Association of Retired Persons and Families USA, accused the group of fomenting generational warfare with ``granny-bashing'' rhetoric. ``The message that came loud and clear is we've got to cut the benefit programs for seniors. I think that's why people responded to them so negatively,''' said Ron Pollack, executive director of Families USA, an advocacy organization for the elderly and their families. ``They sought to divide people up on generational grounds. Most people really think in family terms and they don't think of grandma and grandpa as being evil and young people as being saints.'' Durenberger and the group's acting chairman, Rep. Tim Penny, D-Minn., claim that was not the intention. Durenberger, who declined to be interviewed, formed AGE at a time when Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., was warning that more and more children were growing up poor while the elderly enjoyed the lowest poverty rate of any age group. ``We have entered an era in which the date of one's birth has become the prime determinate of one's prospects for realizing the American dream,'' Durenberger said in a 1987 interview. Besides Lamm, AGE's board included Stanford University President Donald Kennedy and Carla Hills, now the U.S. trade representative. Under the direction of former Durenberger aide Paul Hewitt, AGE issued articles, speeches and reports that raised explosive questions about rising Social Security benefits and other issues. One AGE pamphlet went so far as to suggest the nation was ``raising a generation of young Americans who will live in financial slavery.'' Hewitt says AGE was calling attention to legitimate questions. But the group's rhetoric soon became an embarrassment to Durenberger, who was running for re-election in 1988, and to some other board members. Durenberger fired Hewitt that spring, just as his difficult campaign against Hubert H. ``Skip'' Humphrey III was gearing up. Hewitt's antagonistic style had aliented the elderly and made an enemy of the AARP, Durenberger said recently. The subsequent change in tone moved Boston Globe columnist Bob Kuttner to write late last year that the generational equity issue had ``come, so to speak, of age.'' ``They certainly appeared to be less strident and shrill and immature in their approach,'' said Families USA's Pollack. But the senator's difficulties with Hewitt and AGE were far from over. The Senate Ethics Committee last year began investigating Durenberger's financial conduct, including charges he used a book contract to launder speaking fees, and that drove away the contributors who underwrote AGE's $400,000-a-year budget, says Penny. And in January, the trade magazine Podiatry Today published Hewitt's allegations that Durenberger muzzled the group's staff and tried to divert money to a Minnesota AGE chapter to assist his re-election campaign. ``Nobody wants to support an organization that doesn't have anything to say. It has had nothing to say in the last year,'' Hewitt said. Durenberger, who turned the chairmanship over to fellow Minnesotan Penny in December, denounced Hewitt as a ``liar,'' and other board members say the allegations that AGE was used for political gain were ridiculous and unfounded. But the damage was done. ``With all the controversy involving the senator, which led to a diminished fund-raising capacity, you add to that the allegations made against the senator that were directly tied to his AGE leadership, and it made fund raising virtually impossible,'' said Penny. The $8,000 in donations received after he shut down the operation will go toward paying off bills left over from recent conferences. In the meantime, Lamm has asked the board for time to find someone willing to run the organization with little or no pay so AGE can at least continue sponsoring conferences on generational issues. ``Somebody's got to be the voice of realism,'' said Lamm. ``That's what AGE was. That's not granny bashing.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Tracks Elderly in Florida
DOC.TEXT: Researchers are looking into how well the elderly adjust in the Sun Belt without the support of family and friends they left behind in the North. The Case Western Reserve University study tracks 800 people over 75 who moved from Northern cities to a Clearwater, Fla., retirement community. ``We think the results would help health care professionals to see what the needs of old people are who have relocated and to counsel people as they plan relocation,'' said Eva Kahana, who chairs the sociology department and directs the study. ``It would also help counsel families. It would either help reassure them that the social support networks that people develop in these communities are adequate or what kind of help is available. We would be able to develop guidelines for doctors, social workers and families in having a more realistic picture of what to expect.'' Her study is a spinoff of a 1984 Case Western survey, in which 150 people in their 60s or early 70s who had just moved to Florida were asked how stressful the move was and how they were faring. Researchers followed them for a year. Ms. Kahana said researchers found that the majority were satisfied with their choice, that they didn't miss very much their home communities or the people they had left. ``The question that remains is whether those findings (continue) as they get older,'' she said. For the new study, field workers are interviewing people over 75 in the Clearwater community, which Ms. Kahana would not identify. The 800 interviews should be finished by the end of April. Residents are asked about lifestyle, mental and physical health, and long-distance communication with family and friends. They also are asked to what extent paid helpers or agencies are used to get groceries, clean houses, do yardwork or help them meet appointments or activities. Researchers will keep in touch with the same people for eight years. ``We should not make the inference ... that relocation to the Sun Belt is good for people, period,'' Ms. Kahana said. ``It may be that in the short run it works out very positively, but once they become frail they would be missing the natural supports of the family. ``But one of our hypotheses is that the neighbors and friends (in the new community) take on the role of family members. ``We don't know the extent to which elderly people can make deep friendships late in life. We're going to be looking in depth at that, how friends and neighbors help one another.'' In 1970, about 53,000 Ohioans aged 60 and over left Ohio. That jumped to 86,000 in 1980, the last year for which the Census Bureau has figures, said Charles Longino, associate director of the Center of Adult Development and Aging at the University of Miami at Coral Gables, Fla. In 1980, 44 percent of the 86,000 moved to Florida. Ten years earlier, 36 percent went to Florida. California drew 8 percent in 1980 and 11 percent in 1970. Of the country's 226 million people in 1980, 35.6 million were at least 65, and about 5 percent of that age group moved out of their states, Longino said. Florida drew more of the elderly than any other state, with about 437,000 people in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Project to Help Indian Health Service Meet Needs of Elders
DOC.TEXT: A geriatric leadership project is training health- care workers to meet the special needs of older Indians. ``This is a vast new field that's really new to Indian health care,'' said Bernard Long, who heads the gerontology program at Sioux San Hospital in Rapid City. The Aberdeen Area Indian Health Service, which serves the Dakotas, Nebraska and Iowa, is the only one with a program aimed specifically at the needs of the elderly, Long said. The project includes two seminars this year for nurses, aides and other health-care workers, both Indian and non-Indian. ``What we're trying to do is sensitize service providers, to expand their knowledge about the special needs of Indian elders,'' said Long. ``For example, the way you touch people. You have to be aware of the culture.'' Elders are held in high esteem in the Indian culture, but geriatric health care for Indians has had a low profile, Thomas Stenvig, an IHS program manager in Aberdeen, said. ``The elderly have not received a whole lot of focus as a population in health care,'' he said. ``What we're doing with Indian health care really mirrors what is happening nationally.'' As the percentage of older Americans grows, increasing emphasis will be placed on geriatric health care among all groups of people, Long said, adding that 13 percent of the nation's population is 65 or older. The figure for clients of the IHS, which has 13 offices covering the United States, is 6 percent and growing, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Residents Tackle Issues of Death in `Choice'
DOC.TEXT: When Elizabeth Goucher moved to a retirement community two years ago, she asked herself questions many people would rather not. Should doctors keep her on life-support systems if she became terminally ill? Would she donate her organs after death? Which funeral home should she use? Residents and staff of Duncaster, a residential care center for the elderly, have written a booklet to help people answer some of the disturbing questions about death and terminal illness. ``Choices'' explores issues from arranging a funeral to ``living wills,'' documents that indicates a person's feelings about prolonging life through the use of artificial life-support systems, to setting up a trust and designating power of attorney. A committee of seven Duncaster residents and staff members spent more than a year talking with attorneys and other experts to produce the booklet, which was published last month. Patricia B. Copp, director of resident services at Duncaster, said she thinks planning for death is not as unthinkable as it once was. ``For a long time, this was a no-no, but now, it's a hot topic,'' Copp said. ``These people were making plans for the rest of their lives when they came here and the rest of their lives includes death. They decided they wanted to have strong input in the decision of how things would be handled at and after death.'' Goucher, 67, who helped write ``Choices,'' acknowledges that some older people may not be comfortable planning for their deaths. ``Some people go through life with their heads in the sand because they have someone else to take care of these things. ... But I've seen what can happen when people don't make these provisions,'' said Goucher, a retired social worker in psychiatric hospitals.
Editors: ``Choices'' can be obtained by sending a check or money order for $1.50 to Duncaster, Attention Resident Services, 40 Loeffler Rd., Bloomfield, CT 06002.

DOC.HEAD: Plants Might Like a Little Good Companionship, Too
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: James Walters worked for the AP as a reporter and editor from 1947 until he retired in 1984.

Is it plausible that plants, like people, do better in congenial settings and that insect pests avoid distasteful things? Concede the possibility, and you really should try companion or repellent planting. Does it work? ``I've come to believe in it absolutely,'' says Jim Johnson of Phoenix, president of the Arizona Herb Association. ``I haven't used chemical pesticides in my garden for five years. And I'm convinced plants grow best among their friends.'' Jane Haynes of suburban Fountain Hills, another expert on herbs, says she reacted with enthusiasm when first hearing of the idea 20 or 25 years ago, ``but I'm still not satisfied it happens that way, much as I'd like to.'' One thing is sure: College-trained horticulturists no longer burst into gales of laughter when people say things like they never plant peas near onions or they believe marigolds deter certain pests and basil helps tomatoes grow. Definitive scientific studies are in their infancy, however. In my landscape, I try to avoid chemicals but don't hesitate to use them if natural forces seem to be losing, or if there's no known natural control. And my records over the years seem to show some plants do better or worse near others. The Rodale folks in Emmaus, Pa., publishers of Organic Gardening magazine, began popularizing the companion-repellent theory a couple decades ago. Details are spelled out in The Encyclopedia of Natural Insect and Disease Control, published in 1984 by Rodale Press and available in most bookstores ($24.95 hardcover). Even if you question the concept, this is an excellent reference on how to work with nature and minimize toxic chemicals. Author Roger P. Yepsen Jr. suggests the benefits of companion planting ``may be due to the increased health of vegetables growing near their friends; insects typically pass by healthy plants, preferring to pick on weak or sick plants.'' ``Why are companionate plantings healthier?'' Yepsen continues. ``Perhaps because the plants make complementary demands on the environment. For instance, the compatibility of celery and leek can be traced to the upright-growing leek enjoying the room and light near the bushy celery plant. Or the roots of two friendly plants may occupy different strata of the soil, as do those of Swiss chard and beans.'' The book lists many repellent plantings, such as rosemary vs. snails and slugs; spearmint vs. ants, and garlic vs. aphids. Garlic, it says, ``helps out no matter where you plant it'' and keeps the potato bugs, bean beetles and stem borers from achieving pest status. But Yepsen's main thrust is that a delicate balance of life forms exists in any landscape, and troubles develop when you upset the balance between pests and beneficial forces. To illustrate how the world changes, I recall an incident involving my college professor in agricultural pest control. He was an imposing physical specimen, a former pro football end. One day a little bug invaded his demonstration garden. ``Ohmygod, a bug!'' he cried. He literally shook as he drenched it with DDT, a pesticide outlawed a decade or so later. Johnson believes insects follow smells, ``a cabbage worm is attracted by the scent of cabbage and a tomato worm by the scent of tomatoes, for example.'' So he plants garlic and other members of the onion family throughout his garden and flower beds to confuse insects, and uses various herbs around specific plants. ``While I don't grow a lot of tomatoes, maybe a half-dozen plants, I haven't had a tomato worm in five years. By planting a lot of garlic cloves, the worst that can happen is I'll have a lot of nice garlic,'' he says. Johnson also grows basil next to the tomatoes, reasoning they like each other. What about garlic and roses? ``I think roses like garlic better than garlic likes roses,'' he says. ``But no plants seem to like fennel, although bees seem to love it. Since I want to draw bees for pollination, I grow fennel, but plant it away from everything else.'' Haynes says she has tried to keep track of companion plantings for about 20 years and remains unconvinced. ``There's so many possible variants. I don't see any big differences. Take planting marigolds to deter nematodes. How do you know for sure you have nematodes, or that marigolds did any good?'' She's sure, however, that the moon influences gardening. She propagates her herbs by inserting cuttings in water. ``I get roots more quickly, four to five days quicker, before a full moon than after one, and they seem to be much stronger, too.'' Moon gardening has been around for generations, of course. Many believers will not plant or prune or even turn the soil without checking an almanac. The theory is that the moon's gravitational pull influences fluids in plants, just as it does the ocean tides.

DOC.HEAD: Is Your Home Your Domicile? You Ought to Know
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Paul J. Lochray is an attorney and expert in estate planning for the Denver-based College for Financial Planning.

If you own a second home in another state, for vacation or investment purposes, or if you're thinking about buying one, make certain it's included in your estate planning, experts say. When considering multiple-home ownership in your estate plan, it's important to understand the term ``domicile.'' Essentially, domicile is legalese for primary residence. While it is possible to have more than one residence, a person legally can have only one domicile at a time. If it's not certain at the time an individual dies where his or her domicile is, the intent of the will could be subverted, the heirs may not receive the property rights intended by the decedent, and the tax situation could be greatly complicated. In fact, courts have held an individual's estate to be subject to double taxation under the estate laws of two states because each state considered the dead person to be domiciled there. Consider an individual who has homes in Arizona, a community property state, and Minnesota, a common-law property state. The manner in which property is distributed at death is vastly different under each type of property system. So if the owner dies, and there is confusion as to where his or her domicile is, settlement of the estate can be complicated. What constitutes a domicile may appear obvious at first. It isn't. Traditionally, domicile has been defined as a place where a person establishes his or her permanent residence. But many states have laws that define domicile as a location where a person intends to establish his or her residence for the time being. In today's mobile society, it is not unusual for a person to have homes in several states, conduct business in a multistate area, or move from one state to another beause of a change in health, employment, marital status or retirement. Therefore, the definition of domicile becomes blurred. Although most individuals live most of the year where they are domiciled, the residence does not necessarily determine domicile. Other factors that may be considered: _ How long has the individual lived at the primary residence? _ Where does he or she transact business? _ Where does the individual maintain community or professional affiliations? _ What is the individual's motive for living in particular state? (Evasion of creditors, for example, may negate an individual's claim to domicility.) If you own a vacation home or investment property in a state outside your home state, I suggest you consult an attorney, then consider the following if domicile is unclear: _ If you own residence in more than one state, transfer or sell any unnecessary real estate holdings not located in the same state as your domicile. _ Transfer all tangible personal property (including household furnishings and cars) to the state in which you want to establish domicile. _ Transfer savings, checking accounts, CDs and, if possible, IRAs and other retirement accounts to the domicile state. _ Obtain insurance coverage in the domicile state on personal property, cars and houses. Do not continue insurance coverage through an agent in the state of non-residence. _ If the state you want regarded as your domicile state has a legal form declaring domicility, file one. _ If you do not have a will, execute one in the state in which you want to establish your domicile. Or, if you have a will that does not reflect your current domicile, have a new one executed, including a clause revoking all prior wills in other states. _ Register to vote in the domicile state and vote at the earliest opportunity, thereby reinforcing your intent to establish residency. I do not discourage owning homes in more than one state, but it is important to clarify which state is the domicile, because if there is any question about it, the vacation home that produces so much pleasure now may later cause tremendous inconvenience to you and expense to your heirs.
