DOC.HEAD: Students Make Fast Friends With Elderly Neighbors
DOC.TEXT: When a senior citizens home opened across the street from Carver Middle School, Beth Cordingly saw an opportunity for her sixth-graders that would span generations. So with $360 in ``lunch money'' from the Tulsa Education Fund, she gave it a try. Once a month, pupils walk residents of the Jordan Plaza to the school cafeteria for a meal. ``Senior citizens feel isolated at times, when they can't get out,'' Ms. Cordingly said. ``They have enjoyed the interaction. They have expressed many times that it's like a breath of fresh air.'' But it has been anything but a one-way street. Once friendships were established, pupils went beyond the luncheons by visiting, helping change light bulbs or running errands. ``Most of the residents attended Carver many years ago,'' Ms. Cordingly said. ``The students are intrigued with how life was 50 years ago. They see them growing old, and it causes them to think about their future.'' Sixth-grader Vicki Nelson said her senior friend, John Furch, talks to her ``all the time'' about school and growing up. ``He likes to talk and I like to talk. He likes to eat and I like to eat. We like a lot of things together,'' Vicki said. ``He tells me neat stuff, not really stuff you need for education, but stuff you just learn.'' Taylor Nunley, a resident at Jordan Plaza, said he was surprised how much the children talked. He said most children he has dealt with in the past were ``very reluctant to talk to old people.'' ``There's not as big a generation gap as there used to be in the '60s and '70s,'' Nunley said. ``It seems as though the wall is dwindling down. We need each other.''
DOC.HEAD: ASU Law School Grad 76
DOC.TEXT: Now that he's finished law school, William Shapiro is making a career of volunteer work for the Arizona Senior Citizens Law Project. He knows what he's talking about: Shapiro is 76. Shapiro, who was graduated in December from the Arizona State University College of Law, said he would take the state bar examination at the end of February. A retired chemist and businessman, Shapiro is the oldest student to graduate from the 22-year-old law school in suburban Tempe. Shapiro, a Phoenix resident, has been working as a volunteer at the law project, which serves the low-income elderly in Maricopa County, since 1985. ``I was able to help through my business background,'' Shapiro said. ``But I decided I could do quite a bit more for the people through the study of law.'' John Schlosser, who directs the law project's small staff, said Shapiro's legal skills will help in an office with only two full-time lawyers. Shapiro said he has been involved in landlord-tenant disputes and foreclosures, but plans now to concentrate on disputes involving health benefits. Shapiro was a government chemist during World War II and owned a paint-manufacturing business in South Bend, Ind., for 25 years.
DOC.HEAD: AARP Offers Free Tax Assistance
DOC.TEXT: Free tax assistance for older people is available through April 15 at more than 9,000 sites around the country, the American Association of Retired Persons says. AARP's Tax-Aide Program helps low- and moderate-income older people file federal, state and local tax returns. Trained volunteers offer counseling on specific tax provisions to which older people are entitled, such as those governing pensions, sale of a home and credit for the elderly or disabled, and on special rebate and relief programs available to low-income older people. Tax-Aide sites can be found by calling the local IRS office, under the U.S. Government listings in telephone directories, and asking for the closest Tax Counseling for the Elderly-AARP site. The offices are usually in libraries, senior centers, banks, churches, schools and shopping malls. Special arrangments can be made for people who are unable to visit a Tax-Aide site. Counseling is conducted in more than 20 languages.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday, Feb. 22

DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan expressed ``guarded optimism'' that the country can avoid a recession this year, but his warnings on the dangers of accelerating inflation helped send financial markets into a tailspin. Greenspan said Tuesday the central bank was looking for the economy to grow at a rate far below the one on which the administration based its 1991 budget. Stock and bond prices fell, as Wall Street took Greenspan's inflation warnings and growth forecast as evidence the central bank will follow a tight money policy to battle inflation, dimming hopes for lower interest rates.

Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. agreed to a $5 billion buyout by Georgia-Pacific Corp., dropping its vehement four-month opposition to the deal that would create the nation's largest forest products company. Great Northern, which recently lost two key rounds in the hostile takeover fight, agreed to the deal after Georgia-Pacific sweetened its offer to $65.75 per share from $63, Great Northern spokesman Stephen M. Hill said Tuesday.

Appalachian miners ratified a contract with Pittston Coal Group after striking for nearly 11 months and were credited by labor leaders with helping to rejuvenate the trade union movement. Striking and laid-off United Mine Workers from Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky voted 1,247 to 734 Monday to accept a contract nearly identical to a national UMW agreement that Pittston broke away from in May 1987. The results were announced Tuesday at a union office here.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc.'s leading creditors said they are concerned about their lack of input on the collapsed Wall Street firm's rapid sales of assets. Drexel's brokerage subsidiary has been liquidating billions of dollars worth of securities positions and other assets since the parent company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last week. The brokerage, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., is not included in the filing. But creditors said Tuesday they are concerned about the speed of the breakup of what once was one of Wall Street's most powerful firms.

The Bush administration, under pressure to accelerate the savings and loan cleanup, said it will borrow $11 billion by the end of March for its thrift bailout agency. The new money should start flowing to the Resolution Trust Corp. by the end of this month, William Taylor, chief staff officer of a Treasury-led board overseeing the agency, said Tuesday. Without the money, the RTC had faced a cash crunch, which would have virtually halted the disposal of failed thrifts after this week, said RTC spokesman Stephen J. Katsanos.

US Sprint said the FBI is investigating a former employee's allegations that the long-distance company obtained confidential information about competitors when it bid successfully for part of a $25 billion government contract. Sprint officials said Tuesday the allegations first arose in August during an exit interview for a Sprint salesman in the Washington area, whose job was eliminated during a restructuring. Spokesman Syd Courson in Kansas City, where Sprint is based, said the company investigated the allegations and found no evidence of wrongdoing.

Health Secretary Louis Sullivan said smoking costs the country more than $52 billion annually in health care costs and lost productivity. In testimony Tuesday before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, Sullivan also called on advertising agencies to join anti-smoking efforts by renouncing tobacco ads and said television stations should donate free air time to help educate viewers about the dangers of smoking.

Freeport-McMoran Gold Co., which operates two gold mining operations in Nevada, has agreed to be bought by Minorco SA for about $705 million, officials said. Minorco, a European-based natural resources group with principal interests in mining and processing metals, will commence a tender offer of $17 a share for Freeport-McMoran Gold, which is 61 percent owned by Freeport-McMoran, Inc. of New Orleans. The deal was approved by the Freeport-McMoran Gold board, the companies said Tuesday.

Internal security weaknesses of stock exchange computer systems raise risks of sabotage that ``could literally bring securities trading to a halt,'' even though the systems are well protected against attack by outsiders, a congressional study disclosed. The study released Tuesday by the General Accounting Office found a number of internal control weaknesses at the computer centers of the nation's two major stock exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the over-the-counter market.

The stock market dropped sharply Tuesday, with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials losing 38.74 points to close at 2,596.85. Bond prices plunged following a surge in interest rates overseas. The dollar ended mostly lower, falling to a 10-month low against the British pound. Platinum futures prices surged to new 2{-month highs; copper futures rose; energy futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Creditors Raise Concerns About Asset Sales
With PM-First Boston, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. creditors say they may try to switch the bankruptcy case to a Chapter 7 liquidation to exert greater control over asset sales by the collapsed Wall Street firm. Drexel's brokerage subsidiary has sold off nearly $40 billion worth of securities as well as other assets since the parent company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last week. The brokerage, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., is not included in the filing and creditors legally have no role in its dismantling. But creditors said they are concerned about the speed and method of breaking up what once was one of Wall Street's most powerful firms. ``We're the ones at risk here,'' William Schopf, general counsel of First City Bancorp. of Texas Inc., said Tuesday. ``We're not about to sit back and let someone else play with what is in effect our money.'' First City Houston, the bank's main subsidiary, is the largest U.S.-owned bank on a list of top unsecured creditors included in Drexel's bankruptcy court filing last Tuesday. First City is owed $25 million. Meanwhile, a newspaper reported that Drexel paid as much as $350 million in bonuses to its executives in the weeks before it filed for bankruptcy protection. Some top executives received payments of more than $10 million, The New York Times said in Wednesday's editions. Drexel spokesman Steven Anreder declined to comment on the size of individual bonuses. The payments were determined last year and were part of running the firm's business, the Times quoted Anreder as saying. ``If we didn't have bonuses, we wouldn't have had anybody working for us,'' he said. Representatives of Drexel's creditors plan to examine the bonuses to determine if they could be recovered during bankruptcy proceedings, the Times reported. U.S. Trustee Harold Jones, who is supervising the bankruptcy case, has set an organizational meeting for the creditors for Feb. 27 in New York. The Chapter 11 filing allows Drexel to manage, with the judge's approval, its dismantling. Creditors could seek to force Drexel to liquidate under Chapter 7, where the company's control over its dissolution would be sharply reduced. ``People are going to be considering the pluses and minuses of Chapter 11 vs. Chapter 7,'' said Margaret Shearer, deputy general counsel of AmBase Corp., whose Home Capital Services Inc. subsidiary is the second largest unsecured creditor at $42.7 million. ``That's a major issue.'' Schopf said creditors want to make sure Drexel is receiving fair value for any asset sales and transfers and to determine whether Drexel insiders have benefitted from them. Drexel attorney Alan Miller said the subsidiaries want to get as much as possible from asset sales because unsecured creditors will have priority in the bankruptcy over employees' 54 percent stake in the parent company. ``The people who are here at Drexel who are winding down the business of the subsidiaries have a vital economic interest in the success of the wind-down,'' Miller said. Drexel said Tuesday it had liquidated 82 percent of its securities inventory, selling all but $8.6 billion out of $47.4 billion in holdings. The sales include government, high-grade corporate, mortgage-backed, municipal and junk bonds, as well as equity and convertible securities. ``Our objective was to maximize the asset values for creditors and shareholders, and it could only be done through an effective liquidation accomplished at market prices,'' Drexel said in a statement. In its filing, Drexel listed more than 2,000 total creditors, assets of $3.7 billion and liabilities of $2.89 billion. Drexel last week fired most of its 5,300 employees. Spokesman Steven Anreder said Tuesday about 1,700 workers remained to finish winding down the firm's operations. Employees also are being allowed to use Drexel's offices temporarily to search for new jobs. Creditors may have a difficult time quickly gaining details about the assets of Drexel's parent. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard Buschman III last week gave the company a 90-day extension to file a comprehensive account of assets and liabilities. First City filed motions Tuesday requesting the judge to reconsider the 90-day extension and to compel an examination of Drexel's assets, Schopf said. Buschman scheduled a March 1 hearing to consider the motions, Schopf added. ``It seems to me we should get whatever information is available now rather than having it tied up with a ribbon in 90 days,'' he said. Other creditors said they would seek to interview Drexel executives soon to investigate, among other things, what caused the bankruptcy filing. ``We'll be looking at not only Drexel's current situation but probably the circumstances leading up to the'' bankruptcy filing, said DeWitt Bowman, chief investment officer for California's Public Employees Retirement System, which is owed $25 million.

DOC.HEAD: First Boston May `Exit' Some Businesses
With PM-Drexel
DOC.TEXT: The powerful investment bank First Boston Corp. says it may abandon some businesses as part of a restructuring that provides yet more evidence of the hard times on Wall Street. First Boston said last Friday it was phasing out its fixed-income futures brokerage business in Chicago and laying off 29 employees. In response to reports that further layoffs were expected, the privately held firm said Tuesday it was conducting a ``rolling review'' of its businesses and was considering eliminating other minor operations. First Boston denied that any major cutbacks were imminent, though. ``We will in the future increase our emphasis in certain business areas, and decrease our emphasis in others,'' First Boston president and chief executive John M. Hennessey said in a statement. ``As we did Friday, we may decide to exit certain narrow and discrete business lines.'' The Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday that some executives at First Boston, which has about 5,000 employees, expect the restructuring to cause hundreds of layoffs. Rumors that the firm is on shaky financial ground also have been circulating on Wall Street. Spokesman Fred Garcia said First Boston's financial backing was strong with nearly $2 billion in capital. He said Standard & Poor's Corp. and Moody's Investors Service had reaffirmed the investment bank's credit ratings in recent weeks. Nevertheless, Garcia said the firm was considering selling a bridge loan it had made to Ohio Mattress Co. to help finance a buyout of the company last year. The company scrapped plans to issue $475 million of junk bonds to raise long-term funds last fall because of weakness in the junk bond market. Garcia maintained that First Boston's review included some hirings, such as the recent addition of four top bond traders who had left Salomon Brothers Inc. to form their own firm. ``The strategy is to be very strong in markets where we can add value for our customers,'' he said. ``We don't want to be in low-margin, commoditized businesses.'' The strategy implies the firm will emphasize stronger relationships with fewer clients, Garcia added. First Boston went private last year when it merged with its London-based sister company, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston, in a $1.1 billion deal. The combined entity, CS First Boston Inc., is 45 percent owned by Credit Suisse, the Swiss bank holding company. The investment bank's strengths are in mergers and acquisitions, stock and bond trading and underwriting, and merchant banking. According to Securities Data Co., First Boston was second on Wall Street in merger advising last year, the same as in 1988, posting gains in both the number of deals and their value. Its stock underwriting increased by 26 percent and the firm, moving the firm up a notch to third place on Wall Street. ``Our market share in high-margin businesses such as equity new issues and M&A continues to be strong,'' Hennessy said in the statement. ``Furthermore, our European and Pacific enterprises also started the year strong, both in terms of market share and profitability, following a very good 1989,'' the statement read. Still, analysts said First Boston, like other Wall Street houses, is likely to be hurt by a slowdown in underwriting and mergers, as well as a lingering decline in stock and bond trading following the 1987 stock market crash. Perrin Long of Lipper Analytical Services said more layoffs would not be surprising given the general weak market conditions. First Boston laid off 200 workers last spring. Because of Credit Suisse's strength and its in involvement in the subsidiaries' activities, analysts do not expect First Boston to face the kinds of problems that led the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to seek bankruptcy court protection last week. The filing occurred after Drexel's parent, strapped for cash in part by the drop in value of its holdings of junk bonsd, defaulted on short-term loans. ``From what I can gather, it's a fairly integral part in the strategy of (Credit Suisse) to be in these businesses,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``I would think if they had trouble it would be more ... where the banks have to shore them up if necessary.'' Garcia said he did not know the size of the Ohio Mattress bridge loan First Boston was considering selling, although analysts say it totals at least $450 million. He also said First Boston had set aside provisions last year to cover potential losses on the firm's bridge loan to the U.S. retailing arms of Campeau Corp. and its holdings of bonds issued by those companies. First Boston said last month its exposure to Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., which have filed for bankruptcy reorganization, was $293 million.

DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Agrees to $65.75-A-Share Georgia-Pacific Buyout
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. says it is bolstering its ability to compete in the global market for paper and wood products with its $5 billion takeover over Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. ``Companies are becoming larger through mergers and acquisitions. They're as a result becoming more efficient, lower-cost producers and this is occurring all over the world,'' Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. said in a telephone interview. Hahn spoke Tuesday after his company settled a four-month-long battle and agreed to acquire Great Northern for $65.75 a share. The acquisition will create the nation's largest forest products company, one that will be well positioned to deal with increasing competition from companies in New Zealand, Japan, Canada and Scandinavia, analysts and company officials said. ``Size alone is not enough to help you guarantee your success, but it helps,'' said Clarence Brown, a forest products consultant for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``It's a very capital-intensive, commodity-oriented and cyclical business with an increasingly international flavor and getting more so. And the fellows that aren't willing to compete on a global basis probably won't be around in another 10 years, or won't be growing too fast.'' Great Northern had fought hard to remain independent since Georgia-Pacific launched its first bid of $58 a share on Oct. 31. But its resistance began to waver after the bid was upped to $63, then gave way during negotiations in recent days that produced agreement on the takeover price. ``The time has come for Great Northern Nekoosa to join Georgia-Pacific,'' Nekoosa chairman William R. Laidig said in a statement. ``I encourage our employees to work as enthusiastically with their new associates as they have in the past to make the combined concern the best in the industry.'' Besides paying $65.75 for 57 million common shares outstanding, Georgia-Pacific will take over $1.3 billion in debt. Georgia-Pacific has lined up bank loans to finance the deal. The agreement cancels all litigation between the companies and a March meeting at which shareholders were to consider replacing Great Northern's board with a slate nominated by Georgia-Pacific. Great Northern's stock rose $1.50 a share to $65.37{ on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday. Georgia-Pacific fell $1.37{ to $43.75 a share. Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific had $10 billion in sales last year from its wood products and building materials operations. Great Northern, based in Norwalk, Conn., makes paperboard packaging and uncoated printing paper and has $4 billion in sales. Both companies make newsprint and groundwood paper and have significant timber holdings. The combined company's annual sales will be about 30 percent greater than its closest U.S. competitors, Weyerhaeuser Inc. and International Paper Co. During antitrust hearings in federal court in Bridgeport, Conn., Hahn said the new firm would be able to better adjust its machinery to the types of paper and cardboard being made and would reduce shipping costs by having mills and factories closer to customers. ``The combined company will be an even stronger company, better able to compete in what we're confident will be increasingly competitive global markets,'' Hahn said. Brown of Shearson said the combination would strengthen the companies in a market that increasingly is measured in global terms. Companies like New Zealand's Fletcher Challenge and Japan's Jujo Paper Co. have boosted their presence in North America through acquisitions and joint ventures, he said, while Virginia-based James River Corp. has increased its presence in Europe. ``I think those parties happen to be outstandingly capable and successful paper makers who will probably represent a typical two plus two equals five situation,'' Brown said of Great Northern and Georgia-Pacific. Great Northern's hopes of independence took a dramatic turn for the worse after two recent setbacks. Georgia-Pacific sold off some check paper operations, removing the most serious antitrust question raised in courts in Bridgeport, Conn. Also, a federal judge in Maine struck down some of the company's takeover defenses, ruling that only two-thirds approval was needed for Great Northern shareholders to oust the company's board, rather than three-quarters. Hahn said his company increased its offer to end the protracted court fights. ``The sooner we can get on with combining the operations and gaining the efficiencies, the sooner we get the benefits,'' Hahn said. He reiterated that the company has no plans to sell off mills in Maine, as Great Northern alleged. Georgia-Pacific has agreed to honor contracts with Great Northern's 20,000 union and salaried employees, although some jobs will be cut to eliminate duplication, Hill said. Georgia-Pacific has 40,000 workers.

DOC.HEAD: Families Battle Over Blue Jeans Fortune
DOC.TEXT: The makers of Guess jeans staked their claim to millions in denim profits by alleging that the owners of Jordache bought half of Guess to pick its pockets of designs and boost their own slumping sales. A Superior Court jury will determine whether to award $500 million in damages to the Marciano family, which founded Guess? Inc. in 1981 and now seeks the return of half the firm bought by Nakashe family, which owns Jordache. Marshall Grossman, representing the Marcianos, said in opening statements Tuesday that the Nakashe family breached their trust as part owners after purchasing half of Guess in 1983. ``You will see it was the Nakashes' plan and intention to take information for Jordache and that is exactly what the evidence will show they did,'' Grossman told the jury. Grossman said the Nakashes were supposed to have used trendy Guess patterns for jeans made by a new Guess division, called GM Gasoline Inc., but instead stole the patterns to make jeans for Jordache Enterprises Ltd. The Nakashes were under the gun to develop new designs and were told by the sales department that the situation was critical, Grossman said. An attorney for the Nakashes denied the charges and said experts who compared the jeans sold under the labels of Jordache, Guess and Gasoline would say the designs were not copied. ``The evidence will not show the Nakashes intentionally took designs and copied them, put their label on them and made money,'' lawyer Howard Weitzman said. This marks the second trial on the dispute between the French-born Marciano brothers _ Maurice, Armand, Paul and Georges _ and the Israeli-born Nakashes, Joe, Ralph and Avi. A jury last year found the Nakashes intended to steal Guess designs for the Jordache label. The second trial is to determine whether to award damages to the Marcianos and how much. The Marcianos are seeking more than $500 million in damages plus a return of the Nakashes' half ownership of Guess. The latter part of the decision is up to Superior Court Judge Norman Epstein, who is presiding over the trial. Also at issue is the division of a frozen account containing the Nakashes' accrued share of Guess profits, totalling more than $93 million. The Marcianos also named as defendants a Hong Kong couple, Lee Sec Mon and his wife, who manufactured Jordache products in the British Crown Colony. They allege the Lees were to have manufactured Gasoline designs but diverted materials to Jordache. The Lees are unlikely to appear at trial because of an outstanding warrant for their arrest on customs violations involving garments imports, according to a source close to the case who spoke on condition of anonymity. Founded on an investment of $170,000, Guess last year sold $500 million worth of blue jeans, men's and women's casual wear, swimsuits, shoes, watches, eyeglasses and children's clothing with the distinctive inverted triangle logo. Over the last four years, Guess profits have averaged $45 million a year.

DOC.HEAD: Smoking Critics Blast Tobacco Companies Over Marketing Tactics
DOC.TEXT: The tobacco business is taking a public relations pasting from anti-smoking activists for doing what effective marketers do _ identifying potential customers and giving them what they think they want. ``All companies are looking for market niches,'' said John C. Maxwell Jr., an analyst who follows the tobacco industry for First Wheat Securities in Richmond, Va. `` ... But some people just don't want people to smoke.'' Maxwell was referring Tuesday to the outcry stirred by news reports that the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. had been considering marketing a new cigarette called Dakota to young women with no more than a high school education. The plans were outlined in marketing documents being distributed by The Advocacy Institute, a Washington, D.C.-based smoking opponent which said they were intended for Reynolds. Officials declined to say how they were obtained. Reynolds, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., confirmed that it planned to test Dakota cigarettes in Houston starting in April, but said they were designed for men and women in an effort to compete against Marlboro, the top-selling cigarette from Reynolds' rival Philip Morris USA. The Dakota disclosure comes only a month after Reynolds cancelled plans to test a menthol cigarette called Uptown that was to have been marketed mainly to blacks. Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, secretary of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, and civil rights groups strongly objected to those plans. Critics said tobacco companies are wrong to target the poor, the young and minorities with products that are believed to cause serious health problems. Edward Popper, a marketing professor at Bryant College in Smithfield, R.I., said ``these are the groups that are showing the lowest declines in per capita smoking rates.'' According to the U.S. Office on Smoking and Health, the percentage of the population over age 20 that smokes fell to 29.1 percent in 1987 from 40.7 percent in 1966. Among whites, the percentage of smokers fell 30 percent to 28.3 percent; among blacks, the decline was 22 percent to 33.5 percent. The percentage of men who smoke has fallen much more sharply than women who smoke over the time frame. And among women aged 20-24, the government said the percentage of smokers with some college education dropped 57 percent, while the percentage with no more than high school education dropped about 11 percent. While there have been a number of recent actions to make smoking off-limits in some public places such as restaurants and airplanes, Maxwell said people who criticize the targeting of groups more likely to smoke effectively are ``trying to ban a legal product.'' The cigarette companies argue that their advertising is aimed at persuading people who smoke to switch to their brands. But Dr. Ronald Davis, director of the Office on Smoking and Health, said the tobacco industry is ``pushing a deadly addictive product on the most vulnerable groups in our society.'' The outcry against marketing cigarettes to some groups for comes as tobacco companies post increasing profits despite declining sales volume. Maxwell said cigarette production fell 6 percent to 525 billion units in 1989. He said that number was depressed by a deliberate effort by Reynolds to cut inventories, and estimates that consumption fell by about 2.5 percent to 3 percent last year. Profits are up, however, because cigarette companies have cut costs and introduced more efficient equipment, he said. Leonard Lodish, a marketing professor at Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, said that by targeting groups that smoke more often than others the cigarette companies are no different than other marketers. ``They are finding out what particular market segments want and are delivering products to them,'' he said, adding that ``I'm not sure this is the place to draw the line'' on whether to outlaw tobacco. But Philip Wilbur, director of the health advocacy resource center at The Advocacy Institute, disagreed. ``Standard marketing doesn't involve selling a product that is lethal when used as intended,'' he said. And he said in the wake of the withdrawal of the Uptown cigarette, society may have ``reached a point where they have said `Enough.'''

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Study: Exchanges, Banks Need Tigther Computer Security
DOC.TEXT: Two electronic funds transfer systems that handle more than $1 trillion daily in inter-bank transactions need better security measures to guard against fraud or computer mishap, a congressional study has concluded. The study by the General Accounting Office called for beefed-up security measures for the electronic funds transfer systems used by the Federal Reserve System and most of the nation's banks: FEDWIRE and the Clearing House Interbank Payments System, or CHIPS. A related GAO study noted that internal security weaknesses of stock exchange computer systems raise risks of sabotage that ``could literally bring securities trading to a halt,'' even though the systems are well protected against attack by outsiders. The GAO found a number of internal control weaknesses at the computer centers of the nation's two major stock exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the over-the-counter market. Both studies were requested by Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's subcommittee on finance, which was to conduct a hearing today on computer security in the financial markets. The banking study found that ``there have not been any reported incidents of fraudulent electronic funds transfers over the systems by the employees who operate or oversee them. However, the results of our review of the security measures in place to protect these systems from misuse have not been satisfying.'' The report said it found 17 FEDWIRE control weaknesses at the four Federal Reserve banks investigators visited in New York, Chicago, Dallas and San Francisco. Weaknesses ranged from inadequate surveillance by cameras or motion sensors in critical processing areas to inadequate control of software that allows access to FEDWIRE. FEDWIRE is the primary wholesale electronic funds transfer system used by the banking community to handle the payments banks make to each other within the United States. In 1988, FEDWIRE served over 11,000 depository institutions and government agencies and processed transactions valued at $253 trillion. The computer security report said officials at the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange, the NASD and the Securities Industry Automation Corporation, (SIAC), a jointly-owned subsidiary of both exchanges that operates computerized systems, ``have implemented a wide range of security controls that protect their systems from the external threat of a hacker or virus attack, and as a result, the risk of such a threat is relatively low.'' A hacker is a computer tinkerer who tries to gain access to computer systems without authorization. A virus is a renegade program that, once placed into a computer system, can reproduce and spread among computer systems, disrupting or destroying computer services. But the most significant threat of potential tampering comes from the employees who have access to the exchange and NASD computer systems, said the report. The report recommended the SEC periodically conduct or oversee independent assessments of the exchanges' and NASD's computer security programs, develop written information security plans and policies and conduct periodic risk analyses. In November, the SEC issued a policy statement asking exchanges and the NASD to review their computer systems periodically and conduct studies to assess their capacity and vulnerability. The study found 10 security weaknesses at NASD, including computer center staff performing tasks beyond their normal responsibility. At the SIAC, the study found three security weaknesses, including contingency planning in the event of a computer virus attack. The American Stock Exchange had no immediate comment Tuesday evening. A spokeswoman for the New York Stock Exchange, Sharon Gamsin, said the Big Board had not seen the GAO report and would not comment until it had reviewed it. Charles Justice, vice president for automation at the NASD, said some of the GAO criticisms already had been addressed ``We agreed essentially that steps could be taken and we did take them,'' he said. ``They were taking a federal standard and were trying to apply it to a non-federal operation. We were kind of in technical violation but we simply don't follow that standard. In terms of a substantive violation I don't think there was anything that was serious.'' A Fed spokesman said the agency's comments would come in hearing testimony by Fed Governor Wayne D. Angell.

DOC.HEAD: Company Confirms Technical Problems with New Computer
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp. said it ran into technical problems with its new mainframe computer but said they were minor and would not delay shipments. But The Boston Globe today said two Wall Street analysts said they received reports of troubles that could delay some initial deliveries. Separately, the Wall Street Journal reported today that Digial faces the possibility of the first quarterly loss in its 32-year history and is considering a voluntary severance program to cut its work force by 8,000. The new computers are called VAX 9000s, and Digital planned to begin deliveries with the entry-level Model 210 during its fourth quarter, which begins April 1. Digital said Tuesday it found errors in an add-on product which allows the Model 210 to do vector processing. Dallas Kirk, a company spokesman, said Model 210s with the add-on feature were not scheduled for delivery until the 1991 fiscal year, which begins in July. Analysts said they were concerned about larger problems, that the VAX 9000s were still being assembled in ones and twos, and that concern would remain until product reliability was demonstrated. The new computers will have an average selling price of $1.4 million. Sales of the company's minicomputers have slumped, and earnings dropped 39 percent during the six months ended Dec. 31. Meanwhile, the Journal said Digital's President and founder Kenneth H. Olsen won't rule out a loss in the company's third quarter ending March 31. Slumping sales and rising expenses as Digital makes long-term investments in new products could cause the loss, the newspaper said. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., is the world's second-largest computer maker after International Business Machines Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Huntsman Gives Up Attempt to Acquire Aristech
DOC.TEXT: A consortium formed by a Japanese company and top management of Aristech Chemical Corp. has outbid a Utah industrialist who dropped his yearlong quest to buy the company. Jon M. Huntsman said in a statement Tuesday that after two weeks of studying Aristech, he decided not to top the $27 per share offer made by Mitsubishi Corp. and the managers. The $992 million bid has been endorsed by a special committee of directors. Huntsman had said he would offer more than $27 per share unless he found some materially negative information during his review. He said in a statement he may make another offer if the Mitsubishi bid falls through. No other parties have expressed interest in making a bid for Aristech. Huntsman started his quest for Aristech by buying nearly 9 percent of its stock last year. He intially proprosed a friendly buyout of the company or just its polypropylene division. Both offers were rebuffed by Chairman Thomas Marshall, who said neither the company nor the polypropylene business were for sale. Huntsman then made a formal $25-per-share bid in October, only to see it rejected as inadequate. Shortly thereafter, Aristech's managers began working with Mitsubishi on an alternative bid. They submitted an initial offer of $26 per share in January, then bumped it up to $27 after a committee of non-management Aristech directors set up an auction to determine the winning bidder. Under the offer, Aristech's managers would receive $6.5 million in cash and 29.9 percent of the company's stock. Huntsman did not participate in the auction. He complained the company had unfairly denied him access to non-public information about the company and criticized management for inviting a Japanese bidder while rejecting an American suitor. However, the Aristech board allowed Huntsman to begin an in-depth review shortly after the auction and promised to leave the company open to a new bid. Huntsman's company owns half of Donora-based Polycom Huntsman Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Daimler-Benz Chief: Move Slowly in E. Europe
DOC.TEXT: U.S. automakers should move quickly but cautiously into Eastern Europe as the region liberalizes economically, the head of West Germany's Daimler-Benz says. Edzard Reuter, chairman of the board of management for Daimler-Benz AG, the maker of Mercedes-Benz automobiles, said Tuesday he saw little chance of growth in the company's automobile sales in Eastern Europe, but truck sales could benefit. He said any move by Daimler-Benz into Eastern Europe carries economic and political overtones. Automakers currently are faced with risks in Eastern European investment because most of the currencies there are not convertible into West German marks, French francs or U.S. dollars. Reuter said Western businesses must ``do everything they can to engage themselves in Eastern Europe as quickly as possible.'' General Motors Corp. last month announced it would begin building cars in a joint venture with the Hungarian truckmaker RABA in 1992. GM executives have said that Czechoslovakia is the next most-likely place for Eastern European investment by the world's largest automaker. Politically, there is a risk for any West German company as debate over reunification of the split nation heats up, Reuter said. ``We must be careful in trying to avoid these risks of a revival of nationalism in Germany,'' Reuter said at a news conference before addressing the Economic Club of Detroit. ``We must try to supersede military security by some kind of economic partnership.'' He said his company has begun talks with East German companies about joint ventures in vehicle manufacture, railroad systems, microelectronics and household goods. Many of those things, with the exception of railroads, are being discussed with Japanese companies, he said. Daimler-Benz has a marketing agreement with Mitsubishi Motors Corp. of Japan which Reuter hopes will boost sales of Mercedes-Benz automobiles in Japan. Reuter said his company has doubled sales to 60,000 cars a year in Japan, and would like more dealerships. Last year, Mercedes sold 74,851 cars in the United States. Reuter said even though he would like to see an expanded role for Daimler-Benz in Japan, the company should move slowly because of Japanese economic protectionist policies. Nevertheless, he said, ``We have no problem cooperating with them. We should probably try to include the Japanese in the global competition. We will not hesitate to do so.'' The U.S. market is one place where Mercedes-Benz automobiles compete with Japanese luxury cars _ Toyota's Lexus and Nissan's Infiniti. But Reuter discounted the competition, mainly because of price differences. ``Even if this sounds a little arrogant, we never were frightened by Lexus or Infiniti,'' he said. ``What we offer, even with a higher price, is a far better deal than anybody can offer. ``We are not going to reduce our prices on our models to face our competition.'' Base versions of Mercedes automobiles range in price between $32,500 and $83,500. The most expensive versions of Lexus and Infiniti cars sell for about $40,000. For the 1990 model year, BMW and Volkswagen, both West German, cut prices and eliminated rebates on many of the cars they sell in the United States. Several times during the news conference, Reuter said flatly there would be no price reduction for Mercedes-Benz cars.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Approves Administrators For Sock Shop
DOC.TEXT: A High Court judge on Wednesday approved the appointment of administrators to run troubled retailer Sock Shop International PLC. Granting the administration order under Britain's Insolvency Act, the judge, Sir Jean-Pierre Warner, said: ``I hope it comes off.'' Filing for administrators is a way of holding off creditors while a company sorts out its financial problems. Company founders and co-managing directors Sophie Mirman and Richard Ross had asked for the appointment of administrators with the support of the company's bank Barclays Bank, ``to ensure the survival of the company as a going concern.'' Miss Mirman and her husband Ross now will lose control of the company to the accountants Peter Du Buisson and Phillip Sykes. Sock Shop, which has the equivalent of about $27 million in debts, said in a statement, ``The company continues to trade, and talks on refinancing are being pursued.'' On Tuesday, the company asked for a temporary suspension of trading in its shares on London's Stock Exchange pending a further announcement. The stock was trading at 58 cents a share when trading was stopped, unchanged from Monday's close. Miss Mirman said: ``We believe the best way of ensuring our financing discussions are productive is the appointment of administrators. ``I am confident the Sock Shop concept will survive. We have an exciting new series of products for the 1990s and enjoy strong consumer support.'' Sock Shop has been seeking financial rescue for weeks. The group is expected to announce a new cash-raising exercise or a new partner. Sock Shop announced earlier this month a $4.9 million loss for the first six months of its fiscal year, blaming London's 14-week transportation strikes last summer. Thirty of the retailer's socks and hosiery stores are in or near London's subway stations, and the company was forced to close them during the walkouts. The company closed its 17 U.S. stores, most of them in New York, in December after high security costs put a dent into operating profit. Sock Shop operates 109 outlets in Britain and 16 elsewhere in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: GM Unloads Lumber Property
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. will transfer more than 57,138 acres of Louisiana farmland, wetland and hardwood timberland to two conservation groups. GM has owned the land through its Fisher Lumber Corp. subsidiary since 1926, when wood was used extensively in automobile assembly. The land involved in the deal is all the property Fisher Lumber controls. Spokesman John Mueller said today that most of the land would be swapped for smaller tracts elsewhere for automotive-related uses, including dealerships. Mueller declined to give the number, size or who currently owns the smaller parcels. About 46,000 acres will be handed over to Muirfield-Pitts, which will maintain the property as a wildlife habitat and recreation area. The rest will be transferred to The Nature Conservancy, an international organization that has protected millions of acres of wildlife habitat in the United States. No money is involved in the agreement, Mueller said, which is expected to be completed in a year. Fisher Lumber will be dissolved at that time.

DOC.HEAD: Advanced Mirco Devices Sells Texas Plant To Sony
DOC.TEXT: Advanced Mirco Devices says it is selling a semiconductor plant in San Antonio, Texas to Sony Corp. for $55 million and a close look at how the Japanese company manages chip factories. Experts said the deal announced Tuesday is one of the first in which Japanese technological expertise will flow into the United States rather than vice versa. The deal also would give Sony its first U.S. chip-making outpost. Under the agreement, Sony will take over two Advanced Micro Devices factories in San Antonio and hire about 650 AMD workers. The Tokyo-based company plans to refurbish one now-idle production line and use it to make advanced memory chips known as static random access memory chips, or SRAMs. Meanwhile, AMD will continue receiving the chip output of the other plant, and its engineers will study how Sony runs the refurbished factory. ``You cannot succeed in this business if you are not in control of your production processes,'' said Jerry Sanders, AMD's chief executive. AMD, with $1.1 billion in sales, is the nation's fifth-largest semiconductor maker about equal in size to Sony's chip business. For the past five years, the two companies have collaborated on the development of new SRAM products. The new agreement is not aimed so much at learning manufacturing technology but at learning how Japanese companies use it, Sanders said. Those companies are able to get more chips with fewer defects from plants similar to those used in the United States. AMD has sent engineers to Japan to study Sony's techniques, but the company said it expects to learn more by applying those methods alongside Sony's engineers. Sony will benefit from the deal by acquiring the work force and management at the San Antonio plans while AMD will receive both cash and manufacturing expertise, said David Angel, vice president of semiconductor research at Dataquest Inc. in San Jose. Others said that while the agreement means the sale of another American asset to the Japanese, AMD saved U.S. jobs and probably will improve its profitability. Sanders also expected the two companies to complete an additional agreement to develop a new complementary metal-oxide semiconductor process that he said could double the number of circuits that can be put on a piece of silicon.

DOC.HEAD: EC to Aid Polish Farmers
DOC.TEXT: The European Community will provide Polish farmers with $61 million worth of insecticides and herbicides as part of its aid package to Poland and Hungary. Nico Wegter, an EC spokesman for foreign affairs, said the chemicals should help private Polish farmers save an estimated $366 million of crops that otherwise would be spoiled.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Minister To Seek U.S., IMF Financial Aid
DOC.TEXT: Economy Minister Antonio Gonzalez will travel to Washington within the next two weeks to lobby the Bush administration and creditor banks for fresh loans to support recently announced economic reforms, government officials said Wednesday. Gonzalez plans to hold talks with senior officials at the U.S. Treasury, International Monetary Fund and World Bank, the officials said. The economic reforms unveiled by Gonzalez last Sunday aim to reduce inflation of 8,314 percent during the past 12 months, and its prime cause, a fiscal deficit equivalent to about 14 percent of Argentina's approximately $75 billion gross domestic product. President Carlos Menem's government hopes the measures _ which include new taxes, the sale of state companies to private investors and a committment to deregulate the banking system _ will convince the IMF to resume loan disbursement. The IMF last month suspended a second $230 million payment from a $1.4 billion, citing Argentina's failure to comply with economic targets including inflation, tax collections and the fiscal deficit. The IMF decision prompted the U.S. Treasury, World Bank and private commercial banks to either postpone disbursement of existing credits, or defer consideration of new ones.

Stock prices declined broadly in early trading today in response to a steep drop on the Tokyo Stock Exchange that was echoed in London. The U.S. markets also were pressured by government figures showing a jump in inflation. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 21.85 points to 2,575.00 in the first half hour of trading. The decline was led by blue chip stocks, including American Telephone & Telegraph, which lost { to 38{, and General Electric, down | to 60\. Losers outnumbered gainers by nearly 8 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 129 up, 1,017 down and 316 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 28.88 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. In Tokyo, the key Nikkei Index plunged 1,200 points, or 3.15 percent, to 35,734.33. The index was pushed down primarily by computerized selling of stocks in the last half hour of trading by foreign brokerage firms. This morning, the Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index for January rose 1.1 percent, the biggest rise in 7{ years. However, the department said, seasonal factors such as an increase in food and energy costs accounted for about 60 percent of the jump. Analysts interpreted the figures to mean the Federal Reserve would not consider pressing interest rates lower anytime soon. Higher interest rates tend to discourage investments in stock. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 1.59 to 179.78. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.62 at 352.26. On Tuesday, The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 38.74 points to close at 2,596.85 as traders worried about increases in interest rates worldwide. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 327 up, 1,257 down and 388 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 147.30 million shares, down from 166.84 million in Friday's session. The market was closed Monday for Presidents Day.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Again Drops on Interest Rate Worries
DOC.TEXT: Prices fell broadly in early trading on Wall Street today following sharp declines earlier on the Tokyo and London stock markets and another negative report from Washington on inflation. Rising interest rates, which have spooked financial markets since the beginning of the year, were again the primary unsettling influence today. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 16.90 to 2,579.95 as of 10:30 a.m. EST today after falling nearly 30 points earlier. The broader market also slumped. Declining issues had a margin of nearly 8 to 1 over advancers on the New York Stock Exchange, with 129 stocks rising, 1,017 falling and 316 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 28.88 million shares after the first half-hour. Trading was active, but orderly. ``It's busier than it's been, but nothing like in the mid-80s,'' said Thomas Jacobson, a specialist with A.C. Partners on the floor of the NYSE. Prices fell after the Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index for January rose 1.1 percent, the biggest rise in 7{ years. The department said seasonal factors such as an increase in food and energy costs accounted for about 60 percent of the jump. The CPI figure was the latest in what has become a series of negative reports on inflation. It led analysts to again conclude that the Federal Reserve _ which has kept interest rates higher in an attempt to keep inflation in check _ would not move rates lower anytime soon. Wall Street got some support from bond prices, which despite the inflation report were holding steady. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was up 1-16 point, and its interest rate was unchanged at 8.66 percent. Some analysts said government bonds were being seen as a relatively safe haven for investors right now. Interest rates also unnerved the stock market in Tokyo, where the Nikkei Stock Average, the Japanese market's major index, fell more than 3 percent, its third biggest single-day dive ever and worst since the worldwide stock market crash in October 1987. The average, which reflects the performance of 225 selected issues, fell 1,161.19 points, or 3.15 percent, closing at 35,734.33 after having fallen nearly 565 points over the previous two trading days. Analysts attributed the market's weakness to increasing speculation that the Bank of Japan would raise its official discount rate, the interest it charges for loans to commercial banks. Market watchers also blamed heavy computer programmed selling for the decline but said there was no panic-selling. In London, prices fell sharply in response to the drop in Tokyo but volume was so light one trader described it as ``feeble.'' The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index, the London market's main barometer, was 24.9 points, or 1.1 percent, lower at 2,252.1 in mid-afternoon trading. Traders there also cited interest rates as the cause for the decline.

DOC.HEAD: First Direct Broadcast Satellite Service Launched
DOC.TEXT: Four media companies today announced they are banding together to launch the first direct-to-home TV satellite service that will beam High Definition Television and digital sound on low-cost ``napkin-sized'' dishes. Cablevision Systems Corp., National Broadcasting Co., News Corp. Ltd. and Hughes Communications Inc. signed a memorandum of understanding to create the first high power Direct Broadcast Satellite service in 1993. The companies plan to invest about $1 billion in the joint venture, including up to one-third in equity and $325 million in non-recourse debt. The service, called ``Sky Cable,'' will use the most powerful space transmitter ever launched for commercial communications, the companies said in a written statement. The high-power satellite system will make as many as 108 new channels available through the use of digital video delivery; beam High Definition Television and standard video signals and deliver digital quality audio. Reception will be made by a flat, napkin-sized dish that can be mounted on a windowsill or rooftop and purchased for about $300 at consumer electronics stores, the companies said. A conventional 10-foot backyard satellite dish costs approximately $2,000 to $3,000. ``The new service will give Americans a taste of the next century's boundless range of video choices, sharply enhanced picture reception and more realistic sound,'' said Stephen J. Petrucci, president and chief operating officer of General Motors Corp.'s Hughes Communications unit, which will provide the satellite system. The companies said the new satellite venture likely would be the first to introduce HDTV to the United States on a broad consumer scale. Under the agreement, the equity will be divided evenly among the partners and will be paid into the venture in equal amounts over the next four years. The remaining funds will be financed as working capital. Charles F. Dolan, chairman of Cablevision Systems Corp., said Sky Cable will give viewers in areas not served by cable ``many of whom don't have the space or funds for old-fashioned satellite dishes'' a less cumbersome and more economical way to get high-quality reception and a variety of programming. Australia's News Corp., owned by media magnate Rupert Murdoch, currently uses direct broadcast satellite technology in its Sky Television system. ``We expect to apply our experience to the development of Sky Cable,'' Murdoch said. Bob Wright, president of General Electric Co.'s NBC unit, said that while free, over-the-air broadcasting will remain ``the heart of NBC,'' the venture will help further the company's programming and HDTV goals. ``This system capitalizes on our substantial investment in the development of an American High Definition Television system, as it will provide an important means of delivering advanced TV to the home,'' Wright said. Local cable operators will be able to market Sky Cable's services along with their own, the companies said. Sky Cable will provide subscribers with a choice of multi-channel packages, a la carte subscription channels and pay-per-view programming. Sky Cable's programming also will be packaged for non-cable homes and as a supplement for homes with wired cable.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Prices Jump 1.1 Percent in January
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS December's record cold weather to December's frigid weather in lead; SUBS 10th graf bgng `Overall, energy' to include food index; SUBS 11th graf bgng `However, prices' to include historical data; INSERTS 3 grafs after 20th graf bgng `Before taking' to include real earnings report. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Consumer prices shot up 1.1 percent last month, the biggest gain in 7{ years, the Labor Department said today in a report that reflected sharp increases in fuel and food costs lingering from December's frigid weather. The seasonally adjusted increase in the Consumer Price Index, the government's primary gauge of inflation at the retail level, was the largest since a similar 1.1 percent gain in June 1982. The steepest gain last year was a 0.7 percent rise in April. The increase represented an annual rate of 14.1 percent. The jump, following 0.4 percent advances in both November and December, was foreshadowed by a 1.8 percent surge in wholesale prices in January. But analysts said the spurts should be short-lived and inflation should return to more moderate levels in following months. ``Increases in food and energy prices accounted for over 60 percent of the January advance,'' the Labor Department said. ``Record monthly increases were recorded in the indexes for fuel oil and fruits and vegetables _ up 26.3 and 10.2 percent, respectively _ and gasoline prices rose 7.7 percent.'' Fuel oil prices rose only 0.2 percent in December. Natural gas and electricity costs increased 0.3 percent in January following a 1.5 percent hike a month earlier. Dairy prices, however, were up 2.4 percent after increases of 2.2 percent in December, 1.7 percent in November and 1.4 percent in October. Analysts said the price hikes were due to last year's drought, which caused many farmers to slaughter milk cows. Gasoline costs, which fell 2.1 percent in December, rose 7.7 percent last month as refineries switched to greater production of fuel oil. Overall, energy prices were up 5.1 percent and food, 1.8 percent. However, prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, considered a better gauge of underlying inflationary pressures, were up 0.6 percent after rising 0.3 percent in December. It was the largest increase since a similar 0.6 percent gain in January 1989. The previous high was 0.7 percent in January 1984. ``A small residual influence from the winter also should keep food and energy prices up in February,'' said Donald Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University. ``However, our projections indicate that price moderation in these areas is likely later this year.'' Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan _ in congressional testimony Tuesday that sent financial markets into a tailspin _ also said January's consumer price increase was temporary and that a reversal ``is apparently under way.'' Greenspan termed the January price spurt ``horrendous'' and said the risks of higher inflation in the present circumstances were ``larger than we should be willing to tolerate.'' Analysts interpreted Greenspan's comments as a signal that the Federal Reserve is intent on pursuing a tight-money policy in an effort to restrain inflation and thus will not move anytime soon to push interest rates lower. ``The message is that interest rates will stay high and perhaps go higher as the central bank keeps the economy throttled back to bring down inflation,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. Greenspan said the Fed had lowered its overall inflation estimate for 1990 to between 4 percent and 4.5 percent, down from a June forecast of 4.5 percent to 5 percent. Nevertheless, he emphasized that inflationary pressures remain too high and he indicated the Fed would continue its tight-credit and high-interest policies. The Bush administration is forecasting a 1990 inflation rate of 4.1 percent. Before taking into account normal seasonal changes, the Consumer Price Index stood at 127.4 in January. That meant that a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period would have cost $127.40 last month, up from $121.10 a year earlier. In a separate report, the Labor Department said Americans' average weekly earnings, after adjusting for inflation, fell 0.7 percent in January. The decrease stemmed from a 1.1 percent increase in prices as measured by a special index for urban wage earners, which was partially offset by a 0.1 percent increase in average hourly earnings and a 0.3 percent increase in average weekly hours. Average weekly earnings in January before adjusting for inflation were $338.24, up 2.8 percent from a year earlier. Taking the 5.2 percent inflation rate for urban workers into account over the 12-month period, real weekly earnings were down 2.3 percent. The Labor Department offered these other details of price changes in January: _Reflecting the overall food price increase, grocery store foods advanced 2.9 percent, their largest increase since a 7.1 percent rise in August 1973. Nearly two-thirds of the gain was due to fruits and vegetables. Fresh vegetables were up 22.6 percent, including a 75.6 percent jump in the cost of tomatoes. Meat, poultry, fish and egg prices rose 1.9 percent, including jumps of 2 percent for beef, 1.3 percent for pork and 1 percent for fish. Poultry prices were up 0.6 percent and eggs advanced 9.1 percent. _Apparel prices were unchanged in January. _Entertainment costs rose 0.6 percent. _Housing expenses advanced 0.7 percent, half of which was attributed to a 2 percent increase for fuel and other utilities. _Medical care also was up 0.6 percent to a level 8.4 percent above a year ago. _Transportation costs jumped 2.1 percent. Public transportation rose 1.9 percent, reflecting increases of 1.3 percent in airline fares and 3.9 percent in intracity public transportation.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 420.05 down 3.78 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Olin Chairman Dies
DOC.TEXT: John M. Henske, former chairman of Olin Corp. and the Chemical Manufacturers Association, died at his home after a long illness. He was 66. Henske, who died Tuesday, began his career with Stamford-based Olin in 1969 as vice president of the Chemicals Group. He was elected president in 1973 and named to the additional post of chairman in 1980. He retired July 1, 1988. The Omaha, Neb., native came to Olin from Dow Chemical Co., where he had served on the board of directors and as a vice president.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `In Tokyo ...,' to CORRECT Nikkei loss to 1,161.19, sted 1,200.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices slid this morning in response to a steep drop on the Tokyo Stock Exchange that was echoed in London. The U.S. markets also reacted to government figures showing a jump in inflation. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 16.44 points to 2,580.41 in the first hour and a half of trading. Earlier, the Dow was down by as much as 30 points. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 312 up, 996 down and 445 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 61.89 million shares as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. In Tokyo, the key Nikkei Index plunged 1,161.19 points, or 3.15 percent, to 35,734.33. The index was pushed down primarily by computerized selling of stocks by foreign brokerage firms in the last half hour of trading. This morning, the Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index for January rose 1.1 percent, the biggest jump in 7{ years. However, the department said, hikes in food and energy prices, which are subject to seasonal increases, accounted for about 60 percent of the increase. Analysts interpreted the figures to mean the Federal Reserve would not consider pressing interest rates lower anytime soon to stimulate the economy. Higher interest rates tend to discourage investments in stock. Edward Collins III, head of institutional trading at Daiwa Securities America, said the market may have overreacted to the consumer price figure at the start of trading. ``This may just be an aberration that just occurred for one month,'' he said. Among blue chip stocks, American Telephone & Telegraph lost | to 38], Philip Morris was down { to 37\, American Express dropped \ to 28 and General Electric was down ] to 60{. Prices of U.S. Treasury bonds rose slightly this morning after a sharp drop in government bond prices Tuesday that sent interest rates upward. The higher interest rates in the United States and abroad caused stock prices to slide sharply, with the Dow Jones average losing 38.74 points. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 0.92 to 180.45. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.00 at 352.88.

DOC.HEAD: Law Upheld Allowing Abandoned Rail Lines to Be Used for Nature Trails
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 6-12, In other action ..., with other cases. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today upheld a federal law that allows abandoned rail lines to be used for nature trails. The court, in a case from Vermont, unanimously rejected arguments that the 1983 law, known as the ``rails-to-trails'' act, unconstitutionally deprives property owners of use of their land without just compensation. Justice William J. Brennan, writing for the court, said a separate federal law permits property owners to file a claim against the government to determine whether they are entitled to compensation. Brennan also said the rails-to-trails law is a legitimate exercise of congressional power aimed at ``encouraging the development of additional recreational trails.'' The ruling could affect a large number of property owners. Some 10,000 miles of railroad rights-of-way have been abandoned in the United States since 1985. In other action, the court: _ Limited the Office of Management and Budget's power to order changes in federal job-safety rules. The court ruled 7-2 that the OMB, in trying to reduce paperwork for private businesses, may not block or change rules made by other government agencies. _ Upheld federal regulations aimed at saving the government time and money when it mistakenly overpays some Social Security recipients. The justices, voting 5-4 in a case from Colorado, said the rules are a reasonable interpretation of the Social Security Act. The court rejected arguments that needy recipients could suffer undue hardship. _ Reinstated a $6.1 million award against the Arthur Young & Co. accounting firm won by investors in the Farmer's Cooperative of Arkansas and Oklahoma. The justices, by a 5-4 vote, ruled that the financial notes held by the co-op's investors are ``securities'' as defined by federal law. A federal appeals court had thrown out the award after ruling that the notes were not securities. Today's decision reversed that ruling. The rails-to-trails law was challenged by J. Paul and Patricia Preseault, who claim they own land on a right-of-way abandoned by Vermont Railroad Inc. That claim is disputed by Vermont officials who say the state owns the land. The railroad discontinued service in 1975 over a 1.7-mile stretch of its North Burlington branch rail line in Chittenden County, Vt. If the Preseaults own the disputed property, they have a right under Vermont law to use the land once rail service is discontinued and the railway's easement automatically expires. But the federal law _ an amended version of the earlier National Trails System Act _ allows for railroad rights-of-way to be maintained for possible future railroad use while the land is converted at least temporarily to nature trails. This practice, known as rail banking, is at the heart of the case decided today. Vermont entered into a lease with the city of Burlington that allows the city to maintain the right-of-way as a trail while preserving it for possible rail use. Citing the state-city agreement, the Interstate Comerce Commission rejected the Preseaults' bid to have the rail line declared officially abandoned. The Preseaults said the rail-banking provisions are a sham aimed at disguising the true purpose of the federal law _ preventing reversion of rights-of-way to property owners after abandonment. The couple said the rail-banking procedure is intended to disguise the fact that the rail lines have been abandoned. Brennan rejected that argument. The law is not invalid ``merely because more Draconian measures _ such as a program of mandatory conversions or a prohibition of all abandonments _ might advance more completely the rail-banking purpose,'' he said. ``The history of congressional attempts to address the problem of rail abanondonments provides sufficient reason to defer'' to Congress, he added. The Preseaults said the 1983 law violates the Constitution's Fifth Amendment, which bars the taking of private property without just compensation, and also said it interferes unlawfully with interstate commerce. The case is Preseault vs. ICC, 88-1076.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Higher After Lower Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, turning higher after a lower opening linked to fears of a continued decline in stock prices. Tuesday's 39-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrials average prompted corresponding sell-offs in the wheat and soybean markets. Crop futures opened slightly lower today in anticipation of further weakness in the stock market but stock prices appeared to be recovering after an opening plunge. Adding to this morning's bullish mood was Tuesday's weekly Agriculture Department export inspections report, which indicated better-than-expected foreign demand for U.S. soybeans and wheat. Strength in the wheat market was limited, though, by reports of improved soil moisture in the winter wheat fields of the Southern Plains. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.81} a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1\ cents higher with March at $2.42 a bushel; oat futures were { cent lower to 1\ cents higher with March at $1.35{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 2\ cents higher with March at $5.67{ a bushel. Cattle futures were lower while pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. DOC.HEAD: High Court Reinstates Award Against Arthur Young
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today reinstated a $6.1 million award against the Arthur Young & Co. accounting firm won by investors in the Farmer's Cooperative of Arkansas and Oklahoma. The justices, by a 5-4 vote, ruled that the promissory notes held by the co-op's investors are ``securities'' as defined by federal law. A federal appeals court had thrown out the award after ruling that the notes were not securities. Sold for many years by the co-op to thousands of farmers, the notes were uninsured, payable on demand and yielded only interest. When the co-op filed for bankruptcy protection in 1984, about 1,600 of its 23,000 members held notes they had purchased for more than $10 million. Among other legal actions, investors filed a ``class action'' lawsuit against Arthur Young & Co., which had audited the co-op's 1981 and 1982 financial statements and issued reports on those statements. The suit alleged that the accounting firm fraudulently had misled investors about the co-op's financial strength, in violation of a federal security law's anti-fraud provisions. A federal jury awarded the investors about $6.1 million in compensatory damages, but the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals threw out the award when ruling that the notes were not securities. In disagreeing with the 8th Circuit court, Justice Thurgood Marshall noted ``Congress' broader purpose ... of ensuring that investments of all descriptions be regulated to prevent fraud and abuse.'' He was joined by Justices William J. Brennan, Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens and Anthony M. Kennedy. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia dissented. The case is Reves vs. Ernst and Young, 88-1480.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Computer Maker Trims Workforce by 3 percent
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. said today it would cut its work force by 3 percent, eliminating 400 jobs because of sagging profits and falling sales. The layoffs for Apple Computer _ the world's No. 2 personal computer maker with sales of $5.3 billion last year _ become effective in two months, the company said. Reductions will be made in the marketing and distribution departments of Apple's domestic division and in personnel, finance and customer service divisions throughout the company. About 280 of the jobs eliminated will be at Apple's headquarters. The Cupertino-based company will continue hiring workers for research and development and for its domestic sales force. Hirings also will continue in Apple's European and Southeast Asian divisions. Chairman John Sculley blamed the layoffs on the slowing growth of the U.S. personal computer industry. Analysts, however, have been criticizing the company for neglecting _ and even alienating _ some of its traditional customers. ``We expect that the cost reduction steps we have identified will help ensure long-term profitability and will enable Apple to continue to prosper in the 1990s,'' Sculley said in a prepared statement. ``Most everybody left at the company is making a big sigh of relief, but Apple will still have the problem of low morale in its product developing division that remains to be corrected,'' said Abigail Christopher of International Data Co., a market researcher in Framingham, Mass. ``So this will add some stability, but they've got a way to go,'' she said in a telephone interview today. On Jan. 15, Apple said it planned to make an undetermined number of layoffs. At the time, it also froze the salaries of some employees for at least six months, eliminated automobiles for U.S.-based executives and cut back its profit-sharing plan. Analysts have criticized Apple for neglecting its low-end products, particularly Apple II and the bottom-of-the-line Macintoshes. Apple has been stressing more powerful, more expensive models for corporate use, and as a result its sales of the other models have plummeted in the past year, analysts said. The layoffs also follow a major restructuring that reportedly will see the departure of Jean-Louis Gassee, Apple's new products developer. Allan Loren, who had been president of Apple's domestic division, left the company because of sagging sales of its U.S. division. Gassee was criticized for failing to introduce new low-priced models of the Macintosh and for the company's portable computer, which many of the company's legions of stalwart users complain is bulky, slow, expensive and difficult to read. The company's largest number of layoffs occurred in 1985, when it cut its workforce by 20 percent because of the recession in the personal computer industry. In that cutback, 1,200 jobs were lost.
