DOC.HEAD: For AMs Thursday Feb. 22
Another Oil Shortage?
DOC.TEXT: Into that already stuffed file of ``lessons we should have learned but didn't'' you may drop the latest data on oil imports, which in January reached the highest level in 12 years. Not only are imports rising, domestic production also is falling, and is now lower than it was two decades ago. Petroleum imports in January reached 9.1 million barrels a day, or more than half what is consumed in the United States, a nation that has enormous fuel reserves available. At the same time, domestic crude oil production dropped in January to just 7.4 million barrels a day, more than 5 percent lower than a year earlier and 20 percent lower than levels of about four years ago. Foreign oil sources are being relied upon more each year, domestic sources less each year, a remarkable trend in terms of history, geography, economics and national security. Among them: _The economic destruction in the form of inflation, soaring interest rates and reduced domestic output that resulted from the oil embargo of the 1970s. _A vow by Americans in all walks of life, from the individual car owner and homeowner to the White House, never again to be caught short of oil because of foreign limitations on supply. _The balance of payments problem. Oil imports probably account for as much as $50 billion of the gap between imports and exports. _A successful conservation effort by the American people, one that seemingly could have been maintained almost effortlessly. _An assured market for domestic production, made possible by the long-term growth of the American economy. _The demonstrated ingenuity of Americans in developing more fuel-efficient products, to say nothing about alternative sources of energy. Incredibly, there is little observable effort being made to rectify the situation by the federal government. Little mention of the situation is made in the detailed forecasts of economists. On the edge of crisis, the oil problem is discussed like the weather, the assumption being that tomorrow, no matter what anyone does, there will be oil to burn as surely as there will be a sky up above. The attitude is similar to that which preceded the crises of the 1970s. America, suggests economist Edward Yardeni, one of a relative few economists who include the problem in their analyses, is as vulnerable now as then. The impact of any increase in the price of oil, or shortage in supplies, is almost instantaneous, and the reminder is as recent as now, when oil prices still reflect the unexpectedly severe cold of December. You cannot run factories, homes, schools or churches without fuel. You cannot distribute food. You cannot draw water in high buildings; in fact, without fuel you cannot even breath in some. You cannot see in the night. It is one of the more awesome items in the file of ``lessons we should have learned but didn't,'' because in these modern times we couldn't live a day without it. More awesome, is that the problem can be ignored by so many at so many levels of society.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv AMs Thursday Feb. 22.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Broadly Lower But Above Worst Levels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with closing quotes.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices ended lower on London's Stock Exchange today amid nervousness over sharp falls on overseas equity markets. Wall Street's early weakness, coming on the heels of Tokyo's third-worst sell-off earlier, and a sharp fall in New York Tuesday, unsettled London investors. The declines came on fears of hikes in interest rates, and worries about the bond markets. But Wall Street's ability to recover some lost ground by the end of the European day gave investors some encouragement. ``The Dow is bouncing back which is probably the best news to happen in a long while,'' one equity strategist said. ``It probably isn't going to encourage people to buy any new stocks, but it will likely staunch the selling flow.'' Said Geoffrey Lewis of the investment firm Smith New Court PLC: ``The market really behaved reasonably well considering the overnight falls both on Wall Street and Tokyo. The market took the falls in its stride.'' But Lewis added, ``It's obviously nervous to see how Tokyo will react tonight.'' The Dow Jones industrial average was off 17.79 points at 2,579.05 as London trading ended. At the London close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 17.3 points, or 0.8 percent, at 2,259.7. It finished just below its session high of 2,261.7 points and better than the minimum of 2,246.0. The Financial Times 30-share index was 15.2 points lower at 1,783.8 points at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 11.08 points to close at 1,228.19. Volume was a relatively active 427.8 million shares, compared with 377.4 million shares Tuesday. With Sunday's Japanese general election now out of the way, many analysts are convinced that Japan's central bank will raise its key interest rate soon. Recent rises in West Germany's money market rates also have increased fears that the West German central bank might raise its key interest rates soon too. ``One is keeping an eye worldwide on interest rates, certainly in Japan and over in Germany,'' Lewis said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Electronics Giant Buys San Antonio Microchip Plant
DOC.TEXT: For the first time Sony Corp. will produce semiconductor chips outside Japan at a plant Sony's U.S. subsidiary bought from Advanced Micro Devices Inc. As part of the deal Advanced Micro Devices gets a look at how Sony makes semiconductors. ``This is more than a sale of the plant,'' said David Frink, spokesman for Advanced Micro Devices. ``It's a partnership with an agreement providing for the transfer of state-of-the-art manufacturing for semiconductors.'' Sony said Tuesday it paid $55 million for the San Antonio plant owned by Sunnyvale, Calif.,-based AMD. Sony also hired the plant's 650 employees, and officials said more workers may be hired this year. ``We plan to make a tremendous capital investment in San Antonio,'' Sony spokesman Jason Farrow said by telephone from New York. He said this marks the first time Tokyo-based Sony will produce chips outside its home country. Sony Microelectronics Corp., a new subsidiary of Sony USA, will manage the semiconductor plant. The agreement also calls for AMD to continue using a section of the plant at least until 1994. AMD engineers will observe Sony's manufacturing methods. The plant currently makes programmable logic devices, known as microchips or semiconductors, for use in such devices as CAT scanners and facsimile machines, Frink said. Sony will make statistic random access memory devices _ SRAMS or memory chips _ used in a variety of computer devices, he said. Advanced Micro Devices' other Texas plant, located in Austin and employing 2,200 workers, is not part of the Sony deal. AMD chairman W.J. Sanders has criticized Japanese trade practices, but in a statement Tuesday hinted that his criticism was part of the past. ``This agreement between AMD and Sony, Japan's first commercial semiconductor manufacturer, may be a model for international cooperation in high technology,'' he said. Sanders added that access to Sony's manufacturing know-how will improve his company's global competitiveness. Ownership of the San Antonio plant gives Sony a foothold in the United States as a domestic producer. Sony customers have complained of price increases accompanying the strengthening of the yen, analysts said. Sony's semiconductor production is expected to exceed $1 billion in the fiscal year ending March 31. ``What this does is bring in Sony, which has been quite healthy, to AMD, which hasn't been so healthy,'' said analyst Jay Samstag of Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: TV Station Sale Boosts Pulitzer Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Pulitzer Publishing Co. said Wednesday that the sale of a television station in Indiana helped more than double its fourth quarter earnings over a year ago. The publishing company said net income totaled $18.2 million, or $1.74 per share, on revenue of $110 million. That compared with earnings of $7.7 million, or 73 cents, and $106 million in revenue in 1988. Pulitzer said it had a one-time gain of $12.7 million from the sale of WPTA-TV in Fort Wayne, Ind. Without that, quarterly earnings would have dropped by 29 percent to $5.5 million, or 52 cents a share, reflecting lower profits at the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, it said. The company said it suffered a 7.7 percent drop in full-run advertising at the newspaper because of generally soft business conditions and expanded competition from the September start-up of the St. Louis Sun daily newspaper. It also said promotion and early-retirement expenses increased. Chairman Joseph Pulitzer Jr. said, ``Fourth-quarter results demonstrate the necessity of reducing our operating expenses. We are addressing this critical issue in our current labor negotiations, as well as with our ongoing program aimed at operating efficiencies.'' For the year, Pulitzer earned $31.4 million, or $3 per share, on sales of $402 million. That compared with earnings of $19.6 million, or $1.88, and $391 million in revenue, in 1988. Besides the Post-Dispatch, Putlizer publishes the Arizona Daily Star in Tucson, and newspapers and shoppers in the Chicago area. The company also owns seven network-affiliated television stations and two radio stations.

DOC.HEAD: Litton Quarterly Earnings Up 3 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Litton Industries Inc. on Wednesday said its second-quarter profit rose 3 percent on a 5 percent sales gain. The conglomerate, which makes defense and electronics systems, builds ships and automated factory lines and provides data for energy exploration, said it earned $44.6 million, or $1.78 a share, in the November-January quarter. That was up from $43.5 million, or $1.71 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales grew to $1.27 billion in the latest quarter from $1.2 billion the prior year. For the first six months of fiscal 1990, Litton's profit edged up 1 percent, to $88.1 million, or $3.51 a share, from $87 million, or $3.40 a share. Sales were up 2 percent for the half-year, from $2.43 billion to $2.48 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rise on Soy Strength
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed moderately higher Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, led by a surge in soybean oil futures sparked by a burst of buying on the cash market. Soybeans for March delivery traded up to $5.74 a bushel, their highest level in five weeks, and March soybean oil spiked to a three-month high of 20.52 cents a pound before profit-taking trimmed the gains near the close of trading. Analysts said the initial spurt of buying boosted prices to levels that triggered pre-set buy stops, bringing successive waves of buyers into the market. ``We hit a slug of them,'' said William Biedermann, director of research for Allendale Inc., a futures brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. Corn and wheat futures mostly followed the soybean market higher, analysts said. DOC.HEAD: Retail Prices Spurt Most in 7{ Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to provide new detail on core inflation rate; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `The Labor...
DOC.TEXT: Retail prices rose 1.1 percent last month, the most in 7{ years, as consumers suffered from high food and fuel costs brought on by December's frigid weather, the government said Wednesday. Leaving food and energy aside, prices rose by 0.6 percent in January, the steepest increase in a year and double the December pace. The White House called the news disappointing and private analysts also expressed concern. ``Unfortunately, this increase was not all food and energy,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at The Boston Co. ``This indicates an entrenched inflation that will not easily recede.'' The Labor Department said the increase in its seasonally adjusted Consumer Price Index was the largest since a 1.1 percent gain in June 1982. The department said that 60 percent of the January increase came in food and energy prices. The frigid weather a month earlier _ it was the fourth coldest December since records were first kept 96 years ago _ drove down fuel stocks and damaged fresh fruits and vegetables, driving prices up. Analysts said food and energy prices should ease by March. ``In fact, we're already beginning to see food and energy prices come down,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser for the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``Certainly, starting with the March CPI number, we'll see much smaller increases.'' Nevertheless, there was concern that the so-called core inflation _ prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors _ rose 0.6 percent last month, double December's increase and the largest since an identical 0.6 percent jump in January 1989. At the White House, presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater called the jump ``disappointing news'' but said the administration expects the core rate to decline steadily over the year. ``We are hopeful that this is a bulge that will be temporary in nature, but inflation requires eternal vigilance and we remain on a policy of wanting steady growth with low inflation,'' he said. John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, noted that in addition to food and energy, all other categories posted increases except apparel, which was unchanged. ``The surprising breadth of the increases ... suggests that core inflation is 4.5 to 5 percent,'' he said. ``If we're stuck there, that means the Fed is stuck.'' Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told Congress on Tuesday that a reversal of the ``horrendous'' January consumer price rise was under way but added that inflationary pressures remain too high and indicated the Fed would continue its tight-credit and high-interest policies. Greenspan also said the Fed had lowered its overall inflation estimate for 1990 to 4 percent to 4.5 percent, down from a June forecast of 4.5 percent to 5 percent. The Bush administration is forecasting a 4.1 percent inflation rate. Overall, food prices advanced 1.8 percent while energy costs increased 5.1 percent, including a record 26.3 percent rise for fuel oil. Gasoline prices rose 7.7 percent rise while natural gas and electricity costs combined increased 0.3 percent. Prices of fruits and vegetables also posted a record increase in January, up 10.2 percent. Tomato prices rose 75.6 percent. Grocery store prices overall were up 2.9 percent, their largest increase since a 7.1 percent rise in August 1973. Meat, poultry, fish and egg prices combined were up 1.9 percent. Dairy prices continued their upward spiral, rising 2.4 percent after increases of 2.2 percent in December, 1.7 percent in November and 1.4 percent in October. Analysts attributed the hikes to last year's drought, which caused many farmers to slaughter milk cows. Economist Silvia found a 0.7 percent increase in new car prices surprising in view of the sales incentives that were being offered in January. ``Given that we supposedly had rebates, and prices rose about the same as during the prior month, it suggest that rebates were being cut back or that price increases are sticking,'' he said. Other categories showing price increases included entertainment costs, 0.6 percent; housing expenses, 0.7 percent, half of which was attributed to a 2 percent increase for fuel and other utilities; medical care, 0.6 percent, and transportation costs, 2.1 percent. Before taking into account normal seasonal changes, the Consumer Price Index stood at 127.4 in January. That meant that a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period would have cost $127.40 last month, up from $121.10 a year earlier. In a separate report, the Labor Department said Americans' average weekly earnings, after adjusting for inflation, fell 0.7 percent in January. The decrease stemmed from a 1.1 percent increase in prices as measured by an index for urban wage earners, but that was partially offset by a 0.1 percent increase in average hourly earnings and a 0.3 percent increase in average weekly hours. Average weekly earnings in January, before adjusting for inflation, were $338.24, up 2.8 percent from a year earlier. Taking the 5.2 percent inflation rate for urban workers into account over the 12-month period, real weekly earnings were down 2.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Two-Year Treasury Notes Up
DOC.TEXT: Yields on two-year Treasury notes rose in Wednesday's auction to the highest level since last May. The average yield was 8.50 percent, up from 8.21 percent at the last auction on Jan. 24. It was the highest rate since two-year notes averaged 8.84 percent on May 24, 1989. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8.5 percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $10,000. A total of $10 billion in notes were sold out of bids totaling $26.3 billion.
