DOC.HEAD: Avon Selling Stake in Japanese Company
DOC.TEXT: Avon Products Inc. said Wednesday it plans to sell its remaining 60 percent stake in Avon Japan to a private Japanese mail order company and its president in a cash deal valued at $450 million. The big beauty products company decided to withdraw from Japan after concluding that it would be too costly to try to prosper there, an intensely competitive environment in which Avon has had little success expanding its market share. Friends of Freesia Co. Ltd. and Freesia President Veji Sasaki will pay $408 million in cash at the closing _ $338 million plus $70 million in advance royalties. Another $42 million in advance royalties will be paid 18 months later, Avon said. The proposed deal, which must be approved by Avon's board of directors, provides for Avon to receive 5 percent in royalties on all Avon products sold by Avon Japan for the first 18 months after completion of the deal. After a year and a half, Avon will receive 3 percent in royalties. Avon, which started the Japan subsidiary about 20 years ago, sold 40 percent of the company, or 27.1 million shares, on the open market in 1987 for $220 million. Avon Chairman James E. Preston said proceeds from the sale of its remaining interest will be used to reduce its $600 million debt. Avon last year reduced its $1.1 billion debt by $500 million, he said. John Cox, Avon's spokesman, said the company decided it would be too costly to continue trying to succeed in a highly competitive market where it has only about a 4 percent market share. Cox said Avon's assets could be put to better use in other Pacific Rim countries. ``Japan has a mature cosmetics market with strong competition,'' Cox said. ``To grow would involve heavy investing in advertising, marketing, plant and equipment.'' Avon Japan earned $15.3 million in fiscal 1989 on sales of $285 million. The subsidiary employs 2,000 workers and has 350,000 independent sales representatives. About 25 percent of its sales are by direct mail. Freesia, a private company with sales of about $180 million, will retain current Avon management and operate the company as a subsidiary. Avon will give Freesia exclusive use of its ``trademark, intellectual property rights and product technology'' for 10 years. Avon also will retain two seats on the board of Avon Japan and will provide consulting and product research and development services. Avon's board will consider the planned transaction at the next regular meeting, scheduled for March 1. Securities analysts endorsed the sale plan and said it would improve the bottom line of the New York-based direct sales company. Andrew Shore of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. estimated the sale will contribute about 15 cents a share to Avon's 1990 earnings. ``It will go a long way to restoring the health of the balance sheet.'' The company's financial performance has been scrutinized over the past year or so by several investors contemplating possible takeovers. Avon rejected outright acquisition proposals of $2.1 billion from rival direct sales company Amway Corp. of Ada, Mich., and of $2.85 billion from Minneapolis-based investor Irwin Jacobs. It also fended off takeover feelers from Mary Kay Cosmetics, another leading direct seller of beauty products. A limited partnership including a subsidiary of Mary Kay Corp., the Dallas-based privately held parent of the cosmetics marketer, also has been building a stake in Avon stock. Chartwell Associates announced in late December that it had increased its holding to 8.7 percent. Avon last week said it earned $54.6 million, or 34 cents a share, in 1989 compared with a deficit of $404.5 million, or $6.79 a share, in 1988. The 1988 results reflected $546 million in losses from discontinued operations. Sales in 1989 rose 8 percent to $3.3 billion from 1988's $3.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Plan To Challenge Drexel Bonus Payments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf pvs, `Schopf said... to UPDATE with congressional look at bonuses; SUBS 10th graf pvs to CORRECT attribution on amount of bonuses; PICKS UP 11th graf pvs, `He said...
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert creditors said Wednesday they will seek a bankruptcy court investigation of up to $350 million in year-end bonuses paid shortly before the firm's collapse. A Drexel spokesman said the payments were set in December and were not made with any knowledge the firm would go out of business. Drexel's parent company filed for bankruptcy court protection last week. ``We're talking about bonus payments so large they arguably put Drexel into bankruptcy,'' said William G. Schopf Jr., general counsel of First City Bancorp. of Texas Inc., which is owed $25 million. ``If that's true, it would be something we would seek to reverse if possible.'' Schopf and other creditors said they would seek details about the payments from Drexel executives during bankruptcy court proceedings. Also, Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's finance subcomittee, said the panel planned to look into the bonus payments in the coming weeks. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard Buschman late Tuesday granted First City a hearing on its motion seeking to force Drexel to detail asset sales made in the liquidation of the brokerage subsidiary, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Drexel has sold nearly $40 billion in securities positions as well as other assets in its dismantling. The firm still is trying to liquidate about 18 percent of its portfolio and sell equipment, furniture and other assets. The creditors could face difficulties because the securities subsidiary is not covered by the bankruptcy filing. But they said they would seek to investigate the payments because of their size and timing. ``It gives rise to concern, as does any large transfer made shortly prior to the bankruptcy filing,'' said Wayne Davis, an attorney with a New York law firm representing several large creditors. Creditors may seek to recover payments made outside the normal course of business for up to 90 days before a bankruptcy filing. The period stretches to one year for payments to company insiders. Sources said the bonuses totaled between $300 million and $350 million. But Drexel spokesman Steven Anreder said the size of most of the cash payouts was determined in December, before the firm's financial problems became critical. He said one executive chose to take his entire bonus in Drexel stock _ the value of which was wiped out by the firm's demise. ``There was no sense of foreboding here at all,'' Anreder said. ``It was only in the last week and a half that things were difficult, but even then no one thought'' the firm would go under. Anreder said the bonuses were paid in December and early January. The size of some of the payments was determined in early 1989, he said. ``We did what we believed we had to do competitively, and it was within both the norms of what the longstanding practice had been at the firm and within the norms of the industry,'' Anreder said. Drexel insiders said some individual bonuses exceeded $10 million, with reports being circulated of payouts approaching $20 million. They contended the firm could have slashed its bonuses _ long regarded as among the industry's most excessive _ to save money. The firm lost about $40 million in 1989. They also said the payouts raised questions about management's handling of the firm's deteriorating financial condition in the months leading up to the bankruptcy filing. Anreder said Drexel reduced 1989 bonuses, but he did not specify by how much. Most Wall Street firms cut the payouts by up to 20 percent last year because of a severe securities industry business slowdown. Drexel's parent sought bankruptcy protection Feb. 13 after it defaulted on $100 million in short-term loans and banks refused to extend credit. The firm had relied on such loans to sustain its capital base. Anreder said Drexel, aware of its financial problems, late last year moved to shore up its standing through employee payments, requiring executives making more that $200,000 a year to take up to 18 percent of their salary in company securities.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Gold Lower
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mostly higher in thin, nervous trading Wednesday following a mixed performance overseas. Gold prices rose in New York and Hong Kong but slipped in Europe. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $418 a troy ounce, down $1.90 from late Tuesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $417.80 an ounce, off $2.10. The dollar started out higher in Japan, but fell back in Europe as dealers became unnerved by sharply falling stock prices in Tokyo and a bond market rally in West Germany. Those worries, however, failed to have a major impact on traders in New York. ``I don't think there's any incentive to buy or sell,'' said Earl I. Johnson, of Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago. ``The market needs more information on the U.S. economy. ``There's (also) a lot of uncertainty about a (proposed) monetary union in Germany, and nervousness about firmer interest rates abroad.'' The dollar had little reaction to a government report showing an unexpectedly high 1.1 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index in January _ even though increased inflation lessens prospects for lower interest rates, which would depress the dollar, dealers said. They said the market already had anticipated higher inflation when Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan testified before Congress on Tuesday. The dollar was quoted at 1.6645 West German marks in London, down from 1.6748 marks, and 1.6725 marks in New York, up from 1.66835 marks Tuesday. But the dollar weakened against the British pound, largely due to comparatively higher interest rates in Britain. Sterling bought $1.7145 in London, up from $1.7040 late Tuesday, and $1.7125 in New York, up from $1.7115. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.4795 Swiss francs, up from 1.4785; 5.6730 French francs, up from 5.6670; 1,238.00 Italian lire, up from 1,237.50; and 1.19825 Canadian dollars, down from 1.20075. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Tuesday: 1.4735 Swiss francs, down from 1.4865; 5.6500 French francs, down from 5.6875; 1.8780 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8845; 1,242.00 Italian lire, down from 1,243.00; and 1.2008 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2014. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.57 yen to a closing 145.15 yen. The dollar traded at 145.30 yen in London, and at 145.50 yen in New York, up from 145.155 yen. Meanwhile, gold fell in London to a late bid price of $418.85 an ounce from $419.75 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to $419.50 an ounce from $419.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.18 to close at $419.68 an ounce. Silver prices slipped. Silver bullion for current delivery closed at $5.272 a troy ounce, down from $5.332 Tuesday. Silver fell 2 cents in London to $5.33 an ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Iacocca Unveils Ad Saying U.S. Cars Match Japanese
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca said Wednesday that Japan should be stripped of the ``Teflon kimono'' image that implies its cars are better made than American autos, but said Chrysler's new ad campaign along those lines didn't amount to Japan-bashing. ``For the life of me, I don't know why there seems to be this national inferiority complex,'' Iacocca told reporters on the first leg of a six-city tour to showcase Chrysler products and its new advertising campaign. He spoke in a hotel ballroom before a display of Chrysler autos ranging from the minivan and Jeep to sports and luxury cars. ``Every time I pick up the paper, I seem to read another story that reinforces the idea that anything made overseas, including Europe, is somehow better than anything made in America,'' he said. ``We're not going to let that kind of crap go unchallenged any more.'' The nation's third-largest automaker, which last week reported a $664 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1989 and a 65.8 percent drop in profits for the year, is preparing a major advertising blitz with the theme ``Advantage Chrysler.'' The message is that Chrysler quality has improved sharply since the early 1980s and equals or surpasses its Japanese counterparts. The centerpiece is a 60-second spot in which Iacocca gives a boardroom pep talk to other Chrysler Motors chairman Bennett E. Bidwell, Chrysler Corp. Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald, and other company executives seated around a table. ``Americans just don't understand the quality of our cars. We've gotta get people to wake up to the truth,'' Iacocca says in an impassioned tone. ``The truth is we've got advantages over the Japanese in every car we make, but nobody knows it. And that's gonna change.'' He insisted the campaign was not Japan-bashing, but complained about media reports portraying Japanese cars as superior and criticized as inadequate U.S. government efforts to open Japanese markets to American cars. ``Japan today is wrapped in a Teflon kimono, especially when it comes to cars,'' he said. ``Maybe it's time to just start peeling back the kimono a little bit.'' The campaign will have failed if consumers' primary reaction is ``there's Iacocca Japan-bashing,'' Greenwald said. ``We're not angry at anybody; we're simply saying ... go look at the products.'' Iacocca said the initial commercial will hit the airwaves in early March. Chrysler is trying to cut costs by $1.5 billion this year through reorganization and layoffs. It has closed its Jefferson Avenue plant in Detroit and plans to close a St. Louis facility by mid-September. Iacocca said it was too early to say whether further cutbacks would be needed. ``It's an ongoing thing,'' he said. ``When we get to a billion and a half, we're going to keep looking.''

DOC.HEAD: Pharmaceutical Company Combines Research, Medical Departments
DOC.TEXT: Upjohn Co. said Wednesday it was consolidating its drug research, testing and treatment divisions into a new corporate entity, Upjohn Laboratories. The consolidation is to be completed by April 1, Upjohn said. Upjohn said the change was designed to direct research toward areas where developments are most in demand, such as cardiovascular disease, cancer and viral diseases including acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Upjohn Laboratories is to have facilities in Kalamazoo; Tsukuba, Japan; and Crawley, England. It also is to oversee research efforts in Sweden, France, England and West Germany funded through Upjohn's European Discovery Center program. Dr. Jerry R. Mitchell, formerly vice president for pharmaceutical research, will be president of Upjohn Laboratories, the company said. Upjohn employs 20,000 people worldwide. The company develops and manufactures human health care products, animal health products and agricultural products such as vegetable seed and specialty chemicals. Upjohn reported 1989 earnings of $176 million on net sales of $2.91 billion.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices closed moderately lower Wednesday, rebounding somewhat from an early plunge caused by sharply lower prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and a government report indicating a jump in inflation. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed down 13.29 points to 2,583.56. In the first few minutes of the session it was down by as much as 30 points before regaining ground on buying by bargain hunters, analysts said. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 577 up, 963 down and 455 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 159.24 million shares, up from 147.30 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 190.68 million shares. In Tokyo, the key Nikkei Index plunged 1,161.19 points, or 3.15 percent, to 35,734.33, its third-worst drop ever. The index was pushed down primarily by computerized stock selling by foreign brokerages in the last half hour of trading. Other overseas exchanges echoed the decline. Before the U.S. markets opened, the Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index for January rose 1.1 percent, its biggest jump in 7{ years. However, the department said, hikes in food and energy prices, which are subject to seasonal increases, accounted for about 60 percent of the rise. Analysts interpreted the figures to mean the Federal Reserve would not consider pressing interest rates lower anytime soon to stimulate the economy. Higher interest rates tend to discourage investments in stock. Edward Collins III, the head of institutional trading at Daiwa Securities America, said the market may have overreacted to the consumer price figure at the start of trading. ``This may just be an aberration that just occurred for one month,'' he said. Philip Puccio, a managing director of equity trading at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the market was spared a sharp decline by cash-rich institutional investors who saw buying opportunities, especially among blue chips, after Tuesday's 38.74-point drop in the Dow. Before that buying materialized, he said, ``Everybody was worried we were going to see something close to a Black Monday or October 13.'' Puccio said traders also were encouraged by a rebound in U.S. Treasury bond prices. On Tuesday, a sharp drop in government bond prices sent interest rates upward, helping depress stocks. Among blue chip issues Wednesday, American Telephone & Telegraph lost \ to close at 38}, American Express was down \ at 28, IBM was up 2 to 104~, General Motors was up 1 at 43} and General Electric was down ] to 60{. Philip Morris was the most active issue on the NYSE, losing [ to close at 37| in consolidated trading. The tobacco industry has been criticized in recent days for marketing campaigns that target specific groups of the population. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $7.401 billion, or 0.23 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 0.30 to 181.07. Standard & Poor's industrial index lost 0.52 to 378.14, and S&P's 500-stock composite index lost 0.32 to 327.67. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market lost 2.31 to 421.52. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 1.93 to 352.95.

DOC.HEAD: Petroleum Futures End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices closed mixed Wednesday as wintry weather in many parts of the United States gave heating oil prices a boost. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for No. 2 heating oil rose 0.15 cent to 57.53 cents a gallon. April heating oil edged up 0.05 cent to 56.75 cents while contracts for later delivery declined. All crude oil futures contracts finished lower. The April contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude, fell 40 cents to $21.74 a 42-gallon barrel. May WTI dropped 33 cents to $21.60 and June ended at $21.40 a barrel, down 30 cents. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for March delivery lost 0.79 cent to 59.41 cents a gallon; April lost 0.69 cent to 60.20 cents a gallon and May dropped 0.79 cent to 64.08 cents. ``Cold weather helped keep heating oil firm,'' said Peter Beutel, oil analyst and broker at Elders Futures Inc. Expectations of lower demand for crude oil during the annual refinery maintenance period in March and April continued to depress crude prices, analysts said. Randall Rothenberg, an energy trader for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the price weakness started in the London market, where warm weather has dampened demand expectations for crude as well as refined products. Analysts said the market also was under pressure ahead of the weekly American Petroleum Institute inventory report, released after the close of trading. The API, the trade group representing large oil refiners, reported a 3.7 million barrel drop in crude oil stocks to 344.9 million barrels for the week ended Feb. 16. Gasoline stocks rose 2.1 million barrels to 240 million barrels and distillate inventories increased 2.6 million barrels to 119.3 million barrels, the API reported.

DOC.HEAD: Cattle Futures Plummet in Delayed Reaction to Report
DOC.TEXT: Live cattle futures plummeted the permitted daily limit Wednesday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in a delayed reaction to last week's government report showing a larger-than-expected number of cattle being fed for slaughter. On other commodity markets, feeder cattle futures also fell sharply while pork futures advanced; coffee futures rose sharply; grains and soybeans were higher; precious metals retreated; and energy futures were mixed. Live cattle futures settled .43 cent to 1.5 cents lower with the contract for delivery in April down the 1.5-cent limit at 75.62 cents a pound. Feeder cattle finished .20 cent to 1.22 cents lower with March at 80.25 cents a pound; live hogs were .13 cent to .35 cent higher with April at 47.92 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .02 cent to .57 cent higher with March at 52.15 cents a pound. Analysts attributed the sell-off in cattle futures to sluggish beef sales and bearish interpretations of the Agriculture Department's monthly cattle-on-feed report, which was released Friday. The report showed an 11 percent increase over the previous year in cattle placements onto feedlots during January in the seven largest cattle-producing states. Thomas Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp. in Arlington Heights, Ill., said the January feedlot placements were the largest since 1974 and 25 percent above the 10-year average. The report initially was construed as extremely bearish and some analysts were surprised that cattle futures fell less than 1 cent on Tuesday, the first trading day after the report's release. The decline came Wednesday after some trading advisers finished analyzing the report and added more urgency to their recommendation to sell. ``It's becoming more and more apparent that we're going to have a lot of cattle April through June,'' Morgan said. Coffee futures rose strongly on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange amid growing optimism that coffee producing and consuming countries are moving toward reinstatement of export quotas to support prices. The International Coffee Organization lifted export quotas in July because the 74-nation cartel was unable to resolve U.S. demands for more high-quality beans and an end to sales of coffee at discount prices to non-member countries. After the quotas were lifted, coffee futures plunged from about $1.20 a pound to 14-year lows of less than 70 cents. Analysts said a meeting of U.S., Colombian, Mexican and Central American trade representatives next week in Guatemala is perceived as a step toward eventual reinstatment of coffee export quotas. Coffee futures settled 1.25 cents to 2.73 cents higher with March at 89.64 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade, led by a surge in soybean oil futures sparked by a burst of buying on the cash market. Wheat futures settled 2 cents to 3} cents higher with March at $3.84{ a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 2 cents higher with March at $2.43 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1{ cents higher with March at $1.36\ a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 5\ cents higher with March at $5.71 a bushel. Precious metals futures retreated on New York's Commodity Exchange as the stock market rebounded from a steep opening decline. Gold futures settled $1.90 to $2 lower with February at $418 a troy ounce; silver was 6 cents to 6.4 cents lower with March at $5.28 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures finished mostly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventory report. The report, released after the close, showed an unexpected 2.6-million-barrel decline in U.S. stocks of petroleum distillates, which include heating oil. The API also reported an increase of 2.1 million barrels of gasoline, as expected, and a decline of 3.8 million barrels of crude oil, which was somewhat below expectations. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures finished 9 cents to 40 cents lower with April at $21.74 a barrel; heating oil futures were .43 cent lower to .15 cent higher with March at 57.53 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .69 cent to .82 cent lower with March at 59.41 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Billionaire Plans to Run a Slate for Lockheed Board
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire investor Harold C. Simmons, who has been battling with the management of Lockheed Corp., said Wednesday he plans to nominate his own slate of candidates for the defense contractor's board. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Simmons said he will nominate a slate for election to the Lockheed board of directors at the company's annual shareholders meeting March 29. A spokesman for Calabasas, Calif.-based Lockheed said the company had no comment on Simmons' filing. But the spokesman, Ron Meder, repeated a statement Lockheed Chairman Daniel M. Tellep made Feb. 2 after Simmons indicated he might launch a proxy fight for shareholders' votes to oust board members. Tellep's statement said in part that Simmons offered no plans or proposals for Lockheed and ``provided no basis whatsoever for us to determine his intentions with respect to the company or whether his interests would be consistent with those of Lockheed and its other shareholders.'' Meder said Simmons had until Feb. 26 to present his slate before the meeting. Under the company's by-laws, shareholders have 10 days from when the annual meeting's date is publiclly announced to submit a slate. In recent months, Simmons steadily has increased his holdings in Lockheed, developer of the Stealth jet fighter plane, from 6.25 percent last fall to 18.9 percent two weeks ago.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation Into Title Agency Owned By Las Vegas CEO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7 pvs `Chelsea title... to CORRECT by deleting reference to Perlman partnership with Grossman in Chelsea Title, and ADD information that authorities searching for board of directors list; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, `McCarthy said...
DOC.TEXT: A title agency formed by the chief executive officer of a Las Vegas casino is under investigation for how it appropriated employee salaries and deductions, state officials confirmed Wednesday. The Press of Atlantic City reported in its editions Wednesday that former workers at Chelsea Title Agency claim the company failed to put money deducted from their paychecks toward health-and life-insurance premiums, state unemployment insurance, state and federal taxes, and credit union accounts. The Northfield-based title agency was bought in July 1988 by Clifford Perlman and the estate of his late brother Stuart for $1.3 million. Perlman is the chief executive officer of the MGM Grand Casino Hotel and Theme Park, which is being built by Kirk Kerkorian in Las Vegas. Calls Wednesday to Perlman's Los Angeles office were not immediately returned. Chelsea Title went out of business Jan. 11 and its assets have been placed under court protection. Michael McCarthy, enforcement head of the state Labor Department's division of workplace standards, said authorities have been unable to determine who sits on the title agency's board of directors. Board members could be held liable for any discrepencies, he said. McCarthy said the department has been unable to find anyone to serve with a subpoena. ``The problem is not getting a subpoena, but who to serve it on,'' he said. ``That's the mystery.'' Beyond the question of funds, the investigation is also looking into claims from about 20 of the company's 55 employees, who say they were not paid in the two weeks before the company closed. Insurance Department spokesman Len Karp said Wednesday that the department's investigation could take several months, but he would not comment further. Atlantic County Prosecutor Jeffrey Blitz also would not comment beyond that his office also is investigating. The New Jersey Casino Control Commission denied the Perlmans gaming licenses in 1980 after the Division of Gaming Enforcement said the two allowed corporate and personal business dealings with two Florida businessman allegedly linked to reputed mob figure Meyer Lansky. They were forced to sell their interest in Caesars World Inc., the parent company of Caesars Hotel Casino in Atlantic City.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Dutch-Shell Posts 45-percent Profit Jump
DOC.TEXT: The Royal Dutch-Shell Group of Cos. Wednesday reported a 45 percent jump in fourth-quarter profit, as higher crude oil prices offset a decline in chemical earnings. The Anglo-Dutch oil giant said its net income for the three months ended Dec. 31 rose to 1.02 billion pounds, or $1.6 billion according to average exchange rates for the period, from 702 million pounds, or $1.3 billion, in the same period a year earlier. Earnings for Shell Transport and Trading Co. PLC, the British arm which controls 40 percent of the group, increased to 11.3 pence a share, or $1.08, from 7.8 pence a share, or 83 cents. Earnings per share for Royal Dutch Petroleum Co., the Dutch arm which controls 60 percent of the company, rose to 3.63 Dutch guilders, or $1.78, from 3.10 guilders, or $1.56. The company's financial statements are based on British accounting methods and cannot be directly compared to those of most American companies. Inventories are valued on the basis of first in first out (FIFO), or on a historic cost basis, instead of the typical American system of last in first out (LIFO), or on a current cost basis. On a current cost basis, net income rose 17 percent to 892 million pounds from 765 million pounds. Sales for the three months advanced 28 percent to 18.2 billion pounds, or $29 billion, from 14.2 billion pounds, or $25.5 billion, a year ago. Net income for the year jumped 34 percent to 3.95 billion pounds, or $6.5 billion, from 2.94 billion pounds, or $5.2 billion, in 1988. British earnings per share rose to 44 pence from 32.4 pence. Dutch earnings per share came to 15.98 guilders vs. 12.35 guilders. On a current cost basis, net income rose 13 percent to 3.58 billion pounds from 3.17 billion pounds. Annual sales gained 16 percent to 64.8 billion pounds, or $106.1 billion, from 55.8 billion pounds, or $99.4 billion. Royal Dutch-Shell, which is based in The Hague, the Netherlands, and London, said that along with improved results from all areas of operation, save chemicals, the company was helped by an improvement in exchange rates, interest and other corporate items. Manufacturing, marine and marketing, which include Shell's oil refining businesses, reported higher earnings on a decline in sales. The earnings rise, however, was attributed chiefly to inventory gains. U.S. refining operations were particularly depressed in the latest year. Analysts say the company was hurt by low margins in the U.S. gasoline market and a missed opportunity in U.S. heating oil sales, where prices turned sharply higher at year end just as the company began a planned withdrawal from the market.

DOC.HEAD: Brake, Cruise-Control Problems Prompt Widespread Recall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New info, editing throughout
DOC.TEXT: Jaguar PLC, the luxury British automaker dogged by an image of slipshod quality, is recalling nearly two-thirds of the cars it has sold in the United States since 1988 because of potential brake problems. The 38,315 models affected contain a high-pressure hose that could rupture and spurt hot brake fluid onto an engine, causing smoke, fire and loss of braking power, the automaker said. The brake recall also affects 56,000 Jaguars sold in other countries. In addition, Jaguar said it is recalling 38,385 cars sold in this country dating to 1979 for defects that could cause the automatic cruise control device to jam, raising the risk of crashes. The company said it is unaware of any accidents or injuries that may have resulted from these defects, which will be repaired free of charge. Owners will be notified by mail. The recalls come at a particularly awkward time for Jaguar, which is suffering from a protracted slide in sales in its most important foreign market, the United States, just as Japanese and German competitors are becoming more aggressive about selling luxury cars in this country. The British company, which recently agreed to be acquired by Ford Motor Co., has long been tainted by reputation for inconsistent quality, temperamental cars and customer complaints about service. In the brake recall, dealerships will check the brake systems of all XJ6, Vanden Plas and Majestic cars sold in the United States for potential leaks. The cruise control recall affects 1979 model XJ12 sedans and 1982 to 1990 model XJ-S cars.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of Canada Sues Campeau Chairman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All figures are in Canadian dollars
DOC.TEXT: The National Bank of Canada is suing Campeau Corp. Chairman Robert Campeau for $50 million to reclaim losses from an unpaid personal debt. In papers filed last week in the Supreme Court of Ontario, the bank said it was seeking funds from the Toronto entrepreneur to recover some of its losses on a $150 million loan Campeau defaulted on last month. The National Bank is the third Canadian bank to sue Campeau, whose Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. retailing divisions sought Chapter 11 protection from creditors in U.S. Bankruptcy Court last month. Campeau acquired both retailers in buyouts that depended heavily on junk bonds, and the companies have been unable to generate enough cash to pay Campeau's $7.5 billion in debt. The other banks suing Campeau are the Bank of Nova Scotia and the Bank of Montreal. The National Bank loan was borrowed by a company controlled by Campeau to buy securities in Toronto-based Campeau Corp. Campeau agreed to personally guarantee up to $50 million of the loan. The bank already has taken possession of securities pledged against the loan, but the market value of the securities has dropped to less than half the $150 million owed on the loan. In January, the National Bank stripped Campeau's voting control of the company he founded in the 1940s when it took possession of Campeau shares that had been pledged as collateral for the $150 million loan. When Campeau's troubles came to light last September, the news devastated the junk bond market and brought the takeover business to a near halt. The drop in junk bonds also contributed to last week's Chapter 11 filing by Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Resorts Gets Two-Year License Renewal
DOC.TEXT: Resorts International Inc. received a two-year casino license extension Wednesday, but the gaming company was ordered to report monthly on its troubled finances. The Casino Control Commission said it granted the license renewal to Resorts International, the parent company of Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, despite its bankruptcy proceedings. ``The mere filing of a Chapter 11 action does not in and of itself warrant a conclusion that a company lacks financial stability,'' acting commission chairwoman Valerie Armstrong said. ``The bankruptcy action is but one, albeit significant, factor.'' She said Resorts had shown during commission hearings last week it could become financially stable within the two-year license period under a ``flat growth'' scenario. Resorts filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors in federal court in Camden last November. It is seeking approval for a reorganization plan from creditors and a federal bankruptcy judge. Resorts last month ``won'' $14.3 million from gamblers, an 11 percent drop from the $16.1 million registered in January 1989, according to commission figures. The casino's win for all of 1989 dropped 6.4 percent to $227.4 million compared to the previous year. Win is the amount of money gamblers lose, and does not take into account expenses. It is not profit. Under the flat growth forecast, Resorts will post a $500,000 cash deficit at the end of 1990 because of an extensive refurbishing program, the commission said in its unanimous ruling. The commission imposed conditions recommended by the Division of Gaming Enforcement that Resorts file monthly balance sheets, income statements and statements of cash flow and working capital. Resorts officials also must advise regulators on a monthly basis of significant deviations from financial projections and from prior financial performance. But the commission stopped short of requiring the casino to report daily or weekly or to set a specific cash balance that would trigger the imposition of restricted accounts to ensure that wages, taxes and progressive jackpots are paid. Resorts President David C. Hanlon said he was pleased with the decision and confident the opening April 2 of the neighboring Taj Mahal casino would reverse the decline of the first gaming hall to open on the Atlantic City boardwalk in 1978. The Taj Mahal, originally owned by Resorts, led to some of its financial problems as construction costs since 1983 until its sale to real estate developer Donald Trump in 1988 diverted money from Resorts and its capital expenditures. Resorts reorganization plan seeks to shed about $400 million of $927 million that Griffin assumed to finance his November 1988 purchase of the property from Trump. Griffin sold Trump the Taj Mahal in return.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Federated Exec Comes Back to Old Digs For Rescue Operation
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: For Allen I. Questrom, it's almost like going back home again to rescue the family from crisis. Questrom spent 23 years with Federated Department Stores but quit when it was acquired by Campeau Corp. of Canada nearly two years ago with billions of dollars in borrowed money. At the time, he feared such an enormous amount of debt would force Federated to drastically change its philosophy, away from quality and more toward high-volume selling and price-slashing promotions _ not his way of running a retailer profitably. Now Questrom is in charge of resurrecting Federated and another of Campeau's multibillion dollar debt-financed acquisitions, Allied Stores Corp., which both sought protection from creditors last month in the biggest retailing bankruptcy filing in history. Questrom has minimized his contact with the press since he took over Feb. 2 as chairman and chief executive of Federated and Allied. But at a news conference to announce his new job, he laughed when asked whether he thought the task ahead would be the biggest of his career. ``Yes, I think that's safe to say,'' he said. His new boss, Federated Stores Inc. chairman and chief executive officer G. William Miller, was more direct. ``If you hadn't said that, I would have gotten out of here,'' said Miller, a former U.S. treasury secretary. Questrom, 49, was hired away from Neiman-Marcus, a 22-store specialty chain based in Dallas. As an added inducement to help lead the rescue, he will be paid $1.2 million a year _ although Questrom has insisted that's not the reason he came back. Widely respected in the retail business, Questrom is known as a believer in old-fashioned fundamentals _ clean stores, quality service, merchandise appropriate to a shopper's income level. In his view, a store that sells $700 women's dresses, for example, should not be peddling $19 shoes. Questrom clearly faces an enormous problem, because he will have to combine his philosophy with a strategy that produces more revenue, cuts costs, satisfies the bankruptcy court and appeases anxious creditors. The Massachusetts native began his tenure with Federated in 1965 as an executive trainee at the Abraham & Straus chain, and by 1973 had become a merchandise manager. Later he ran both Rich's and Bullock's, two of Federated's best-known subsidiaries (Bullock's was subsequently sold), and advanced to executive vice president then vice chairman of the company. In May 1988 when Campeau bought Federated for about $6.6 billion, Questrom turned down the new owner's offer to make him chairman and moved to Neiman-Marcus. When he was approached about coming back to Federated after the bankruptcy filing in January he originally rejected the idea, but evidently changed his mind because many acquaintances in the company pleaded with him to reconsider, including a daughter of the company's founder. Questrom returns to work with Federated-Allied president James Zimmerman. Both insist that the sister retailers, with 260 stores and 100,000 employees in 28 states, can be healthy and profitable. Questrom, Zimmerman and Miller said the biggest obstacle is the crushing debt burden of $7.7 billion that Federated and Allied assumed when Campeau purchased the companies. Miller said some of that debt likely will never be repaid. The most vulnerable creditors may be the holders of ``junk bonds'' that were used to help finance the Campeau acquisitions. Questrom said he would concentrate at first on rebuilding confidence of merchandise suppliers to ensure that Federated and Allied can maintain their market positions in the spring season. Zimmerman said sales were off in the first two months of this year. The challenge of competing against financially healthy retailers is a problem that Questrom readily acknowledged. ``Obviously, in the short term, that's a key issue. But I think we're working very aggressively with our vendors to be sure that we do get deliveries on schedule,'' he said. ``Ninety-eight percent of the vendors want Federated to be successful. They're working towards that aim. We all get the same benefit out of being successful.'' Questrom said Federated and Allied were streamlined prior to filing for reorganization to concentrate more on their core businesses. ``We are a department store company now. We were, before, a kind of a broad-based retail company. I believe the talents of the organization now are much more focused,'' Questrom said. ``Really, it's for Jim and I and the company to really just put the priorities in order and to focus our attention on running the business to benefit our customers. And I think we can do it,'' he said. Questrom said the reorganizations under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws give Federated and Allied one advantage in luring merchandise suppliers. The supervision of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court means companies that deal with Federated and Allied now receive first priority for payment _ over creditors who dealt with Federated and Allied before their Jan. 15 filings. ``From a retail point of view or a vendor point of view, this is the safest company to ship to today. This is the place to be shipping in terms of making sure you get your payments,'' Questrom said. A more natural advantage the company has is its geographical reach in some of the most important U.S. metropolitan markets. ``We own the major properties in each of those cities,'' he said. ``I think our competitive position will, in fact, come back to normal in the next 30 to 45 days.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday, Feb. 22

DOC.HEAD: New York Official Calls for Shuttle Fare Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: The state's consumer protection chief called Wednesday for federal inquiries into rising fares for air shuttle flights in the Northeast, which he said have soared by as much as 102 percent in four years. Richard Kessel, director of the Consumer Protection Board, charged at a news conference that the Trump and Pan Am shuttles were gouging captive passengers on their flights linking New York with Boston and Washington. ``As far as air fares, the sky's the limit for the shuttle flights out of New York,'' Kessel said. ``It's probably becoming cheaper to send customers to the moon than to Boston or Washington.'' On Jan. 3, he noted, Trump Shuttle raised its one-way weekday fares by 20 percent, from $99 to $119, and Pan Am followed suit. Moreover, since the Pan Am Shuttle started in 1986 its New York-Boston fares have risen by 83 percent and its New York-Washington fares by 59 percent, Kessel said. Fares on the Trump Shuttle, which billionaire developer Donald Trump bought from Eastern Airlines last spring, have increased by 102 percent to Boston and 72 percent to Washington, Kessel said. In the same period, he said, the consumer price index measuring retail inflation rose 14.3 percent. Officials for both shuttle services noted that jet fuel prices have jumped recently and, more generally, said their fares reflected their expenses. ``We believe today's fares are justified based on the costs that are incurred in operating a shuttle service,'' said Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon. Trump Shuttle President Bruce Nobles said, ``We charge a fair price in relationship to our cost. ... ``This gentleman does not understand the economics of our business,'' he said, referring to Kessel. Kessel said the root problem was deregulation of the nation's airline industry in 1978, which he said stripped protection from business travelers who have no practical alternative to the shuttles. He called for investigations of the shuttle fares by Congress and the U.S. Department of Transportation.

DOC.HEAD: Business Week Magazine Plans Russian-Language Edition
DOC.TEXT: McGraw-Hill Inc.'s Business Week magazine said Wednesday it has agreed to publish a Russian-language edition in the Soviet Union, saying that it will be the first major Western business news magazine published there. Business Week Publisher John W. Patten said the magazine signed a letter of intent on publishing the Russian edition with Kniga Publishers, a unit of Goskompechat, the State Committee for Publishing, Printing and Book Trade, based in Moscow. A pilot issue of Business Week-USSR will be printed in Minsk in May, and will contain editorial material translated from Business Week and Business Week International, the English-language version of Business Week distributed overseas, he said. Bimonthly issues will be published in September and November, and monthly publication will begin in 1991. Initial circulation is expected to be 50,000. Business Week-USSR would be Business Week's third foreign language edition. It began Business Week-China in 1986 and plans to publish Business Week-Hungary starting in May.

DOC.HEAD: Settle Lawsuit By Ex Member of Leveraged Buyout Giant
DOC.TEXT: A former general partner of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. who sued the co-founders of the leveraged buyout firm in a high-stakes dispute over money has settled out of court for an undisclosed amount. A document filed in a New York State Supreme Court Feb. 7 shows Jerome Kohlberg's claims against the company and the other partners, Henry R. Kravis and George B. Roberts, have been discontinued `with prejudice and without cost to either party.'' The phrase ``with prejudice'' means those claims cannot be raised in any future lawsuit. Nonetheless, the document's language suggests Kohlberg could bring claims that may arise from the future conduct of the defendants. The terms of the settlement evidently also require both sides not to talk about the matter publicly. They declined to comment or even confirm a settlement had been reached. The quiet resolution of this legal brawl came less than six months after Kohlberg, a pioneer in the business of debt-financed takeovers known as leveraged buyouts, slapped his ex-partners with the lawsuit. He claimed the firm reduced his stake in several companies acquired while he was one of KKR's general partners. Kohlberg claims that violated an agreement he made with the firm when he left its management in 1987. The defendants denied the claim. KKR is the leader in arranging leveraged buyouts, in which companies are acquired with borrowed money repaid with their earnings, sale of assets or a combination of both. KKR holds the record for the biggest takeover in history, the $25 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. The firm's operations, a mystery to the public, have made its partners enormously wealthy but some of the most recent deals have run into trouble because of difficulties in repaying or renegotiating debt. Kohlberg, Kravis and Roberts formed their partnership in 1976, with each serving as general partners who managed the firm and directed its acquisitions and investments. Kohlberg remained a general partner until 1987, when after a falling-out with Kravis and Roberts over the firm's strategy he became a limited partner, sharing in Kohlberg Kravis' profits but not in its management. Among the deals undertaken while Kohlberg was a general partner were the 1986 leveraged buyouts of consumer products company Beatrice Cos. for $6.1 billion and the grocery chain Safeway Stores Inc. for $4.2 billion.

DOC.NOTE: $adv25
For release Sunday, Feb. 25
DOC.HEAD: Horizontal Drilling Improves Chances Of Finding Some Oil
With BC-Texas Oil
DOC.TEXT: Oil companies have brought a technology learned offshore to the plains of South Texas, turning ``Heartbreak Field'' into a gusher of activity. Horizontal drilling _ a modern term for ``slant hole drilling,'' once an illegal way of draining your neighbor's oil _ has resulted in record-setting flow rates from wells drilled in the Pearsall Field of the Austin Chalk, a geological formation running northeast through Texas from the Mexican border to Carthage into Louisiana and beyond. Oil in the Pearsall Field is contained in narrow, vertical deposits that make vertical wells more chancy that usual. Even successful wells have low flow rates, extending the time it takes to recover investment. With horizontal drilling, however, several deposits can be linked, increasing both the chances of finding oil and the production once it is found. The technique, first used in undersea drilling for oil, costs about twice much as an onshore vertical well but flow rates can be four to five times higher. The Pearsall Field, which covers parts of five counties southwest of San Antonio, is only one place where experts say the technology could be used. Meridian Oil Co. has been using horizontal drilling in the Bakken Formation of North Dakota since 1987. Other, older Texas fields _ including parts of the mammoth Permian Basin of West Texas and eastern New Mexico _ are considered likely candidates, as are some shallow California fields where so much gas has escaped there is nothing to carry the oil to the surface. ``There are a lot of places in the United States where (horizontal drilling) will fit, any place where you have a reservoir that's not continuous,'' said Jim Roberts, production vice president for Oryx Energy Co., credited with pioneering the technique in South Texas. Oryx already has begun drilling horizontal wells in the Bakken Formation and the Ellenburger area of the Permian Basin. The Texas Railroad Commission, which regulates oil production in the state, is considering expanding to the rest of the state new rules it put in place for the Pearsall Field. A report from the Bureau of Economic Geology at the University of Texas says horizontal drilling ``holds significant promise'' and could add 11 billion barrels of easily recoverable oil to Texas reserves, an increase of more than 31 percent over current estimates. While most of the attention has been focused on horizontal drilling, other technologies also are enhancing discovery and recovery of oil at the same time concern again is growing about U.S. dependence on foreign supply. There is little chance that a major oil deposit remains to be found in the United States, experts believe, so explorers are returning to familiar fields, using new technology to pump more oil out of old discoveries. ``Ninety percent of everything we get added (to reserves) is from existing fields,'' said William Fisher, head of the Bureau of Economic Geology, who estimates U.S. reserves of easily recoverable oil at about 100 billion barrels. Enhanced recovery can get 230 billion more barrels, he said, but only if the price reaches about $25 per 42-gallon barrel. The price now hovers around $22, and analysts don't foresee $25 for several years. The technologies range from using a mixture of molasses and microbes to raise pressure in sagging wells to re-evaluating seismic data to find missed oil deposits. One company, Western Resource Technologies Inc., is pushing five methods it says it can use to turn dry holes and abandoned wells into new gushers. ``We like to think of ourselves as the Mel Fisher of the oil patch,'' said Western Chairman Steven S. McGuire, referring to the celebrated undersea treasure hunter.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday Feb. 25

DOC.BYLINE: Georgia-Pacific Lists $200 Million in Takeover Fees
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. expects to pay some $200 million in fees and expenses to finalize its $3.8 billion acquisition of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp., the company disclosed in documents Wednesday. Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific disclosed the anticipated fees in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission updating its $65.75-a-share takeover offer. The filing, however, did not disclose any individuals or companies that would be getting those fees. During their protracted legal battles over the last four months, Georgia-Pacific was advised by the investment banking firm of Wasserstein Perella & Co. while Goldman, Sachs & Co. advised Great Northern. Neither firm's fees were disclosed in the SEC filing. In its filing, Georgia-Pacific said it estimates the total amount of funds required to close the deal, announced Tuesday, for Great Northern's 57 million outstanding shares ``is approximately $3.8 billion, with another approximately $200 million being required to pay related fees and expenses expected to be incurred.''

DOC.HEAD: More Losses for Northrop, Which Blames Fixed-Price Development Pacts
DOC.TEXT: Northrop Corp., the builder of the B-2 bomber, said it lost $16.6 million in the fourth quarter and $63.5 million in 1989, largely because of high costs on fixed-price research and development contracts with the government. The fixed-price accords have been costly for many aerospace giants. McDonnell Douglas Corp., whose fourth-quarter profits fell 58 percent, has run behind schedule in developing the C-17 cargo plane and T-45 Navy training jet. And Lockheed Corp. showed about $300 million in pretax fourth-quarter losses because of unforeseen changes on a new submarine-hunting plane. Northrop took a total of $240 million in writeoffs for such development losses in 1989, with $28 million of that in the fourth quarter. About $81 million of the writeoffs were on development of radar-jamming equipment, and another $159 million on classified programs in Northrop's missiles and unmanned vehicles segment. Since early 1988, Northrop has refused to accept fixed-price development contracts. Lockheed and Rockwell International Corp. also refuse to do so, saying the risk of unforeseen expenses is too great during the initial development of complicated programs for the military. For the October-December quarter, Northrop lost $16.6 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with a loss of $86.1 million, $1.83 a share, in the same period of 1988. Sales plunged 23.2 percent to $1.33 billion from $1.73 billion. For the full year, Northrop lost $63.5 million, or $1.35 a share, compared with earnings of $104.2 million, or $2.22 a share, in 1988. The 1988 profit figure included a favorable one-time tax adjustment of $135.1 million. Sales fell 9.5 percent last year to $5.25 billion from $5.8 billion in 1988. Separately, Northrop said it had completed the previously announced sale of twin office towers in Century City that house its headquarters, for $218 million in cash. Northrop, whose total debt had been $1.2 billion, used the proceeds to reduce its short-term debt to $424 million. The company is leasing back its headquarters space. The sale yielded a pretax gain of $136 million, of which $102 million will be recognized in 1990 and the rest spread over the next 10 years. After-tax earnings for the first quarter of 1990 will benefit by $67 million, or $1.42 a share, the company said. Fourth-quarter revenues fell in the aircraft segment as development work on the B-2 wound down and fewer main body assemblies were delivered for the FA-18 fighter. Sales also fell in the electronics segment, where deliveries of guidance systems for the MX missile fell, and in the missiles and unmanned vehicles segment. The latter decline stemmed from an accounting change for work on a classified contract, causing a $120 million reduction in quarterly sales. For the full year, the effect of the fourth-quarter charges was partially offset by higher revenues from startup of B-2 production and increased delivery of parts for the Boeing 747 jetliner. Northrop said its business backlog stood at $5.6 billion at the end of 1989, compared with $4.9 billion at the end of 1988. Kent Kresa, the company chairman, has predicted 1990 sales will stay at about the same level as in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Some State Environmental Officials Complain About Clean Air Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS last graf with two grafs of Fitzwater comment on Sununu. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: State environmental officials complained Wednesday that Senate and White House negotiations are weakening a proposed clean air bill so much that many urban areas would not be able to meet the air quality standards. The officials, from 13 states, many of which are plagued with some of the worst urban smog problems in the country, criticized the closed-door deal-making and urged Senate leaders to bring the measure to the Senate floor where it can be openly debated. Among the state officials who accused the Senate and administration negotiators of weakening the Senate bill were those responsible for air pollution controls in Southern California and the New York City area, two regions facing the most serious smog problems. Under the compromises already tentatively agreed to in the private Senate negotiations ``we would not be able to obtain healthy air in Southern California,'' said Norton Younglove, chairman of the South Coast Air Quality Management District in California. Thomas Joring, New York state commissioner of environmental conservation, said some of the provisions worked out in the private talks would make the new air pollution control law weaker than current law, especially as it applies to curbing urban smog. The criticism came as Senate leaders and the Bush adminstration continued the closed-door discussions for a third week in hopes of crafting a bill that would have enough support to avoid a contentuous debate and possible filibuster on the Senate floor. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said he hoped to conclude by the end of the week the private discussions on the bill, which would revise federal air pollution controls for the first time in 13 years. Mitchell said he expects ``plenty of debate on the Senate floor'' once the private discussions are completed. While the talks have reached tentative agreements on some parts of the bill such as curbs on acid rain, major differences remained over how to reduce pollution for automobiles. The Senate bill calls for a second round of tailpipe controls, while the administration says that's too expensive and favors using cleaner motor fuels in the most polluted areas of the country such as Los Angeles and the Northeast. But the state pollution control officials focused their criticism on areas where the negotiators already have reached agreement. Among the areas of concern were compromises that would: no longer require the federal government to impose a smog cleanup plan if local officials are unwilling or unable to do so; that would exempt small industrial polluters from urban smog controls; reduce the geographic areas that would be covered under urban air cleanup programs. ``The pollution cleanup program envisioned by this (Senate-Bush administration) deal will not work in practice,'' the state officials said in a statement. The group included air pollution control officials from the states of California, Oregon, Washington, Nevada, Colorado, Delaware, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Vermont and Maine. Meanwhile, a group of environmental organizations blamed White House Chief of Staff John Sununu for the administration's stand on the clean air bill, claiming that Sununu was undercutting the president's environmental policies. The groups, including the National Wildlife Federation, National Audubon Society and the Natural Resources Defense Council, asked to meet with Bush to discuss their environmental concerns, including those involving the clean air bill negotiations. Marlin Fitzwater, the president's spokesman, said Sununu ``ensures that all points of view are heard and that is a role that he has played with regard to environmental policies.'' ``And the president has made the decisions on environmental policies; they represent his point of view and his priorities,'' Fitzwater continued. ``And environmnental groups, by the same token, represent interest groups and pressure groups and it is their job to keep the pressure on. They're doing it. The governor's doing his job. I don't see any real difficulty here.''

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rate Concerns Send Stock Prices Skidding
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `The retreat ...' to UPDATE with index down 405 points at end of morning session.
DOC.TEXT: The specter of rising worldwide interest rates rattled major global stock markets Wednesday, sending prices down in New York and London after they skidded lower in the Tokyo market's third-worst drop ever. On Wall Street, stocks declined sharply at the opening in response to the wave of selling overseas and the release in Washington of a report showing high January inflation that could push interest rates even higher. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped more than 40 points in the early going before regaining some ground. The widely watched index closed down 13.29 at 2,583.56, giving it a two-day loss of 52 points. Broader market indicators also dropped, with declining issues outnumbering gainers by a margin of about 5 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange and the Wilshire Associates index of more than 5,000 stocks losing $7.4 billion in value. Stock prices fell on Wall Street after the Labor Department reported food and energy price hikes helped push its Consumer Price Index for January up 1.1 percent, the biggest jump in 7{ years. The report prompted renewed speculation that the Federal Reserve _ which has kept interest rates relatively high in an attempt to curb inflation _ would not move rates lower anytime soon. Similar worries sparked the Wednesday selloff in Tokyo, where the Nikkei Stock Average, the Japanese market's major index, fell more than 3 percent. That was the market's third biggest dive ever and worst since the worldwide stock market crash in October 1987. The Nikkei average reflecting the performance of 225 selected issues fell 1,161.19 points, or 3.15 percent, to 35,734.33, after having fallen nearly 565 points in the previous two trading days. The retreat continued Thursday as the Nikkei average fell another 405.97 points, or 1.13 percent, to 35,328.36 in morning trading. Analysts attributed the Tokyo market's weakness to increasing speculation that the Bank of Japan would raise its official discount rate, the interest it charges for loans to commercial banks. Later in London, stock prices fell as traders watched interest rates rise on the British bond markets and reacted to the overnight selloff in Tokyo and early weakness on Wall Street. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 issues, down 31 points early in the session, closed down 17.3 points, or 0.8 percent, at 2,259.7 Inflation has spooked the financial markets since the start of the year. Wall Street began 1990 with the Dow Jones industrial average hitting a new high in the first session of the year. But the market since has been stymied by the prospect of higher interest rates, which can depress corporate profits. Wall Street analysts said the Dow industrials' partial recovery from Wednesday's early lows represented bargain-hunting more than an endorsement of the equity market. ``You have institutions waiting for the opportunity to buy,'' said Peter VandenBerg, a market analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. The stock market also was aided by firmer prices and lower yields on the Treasury bond market. Late Wednesday, the government's bellwether 30-year bond was up $2.50 per $1,000 in face value, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, edged down to 8.64 percent from 8.66 percent late Tuesday. Bonds had also fallen on the CPI report, compounding sharp losses in the credit markets on Tuesday, but analysts said Wedneday's declines were more than offset by bargain hunting and by the decline on Wall Street, which prompted some investors to switch funds out of stocks and into bonds. Similarly, such blue chips as International Business Machines Corp., which are seen as better long-term bets, did relatively better. IBM was up $2 to $104.87{ a share Wednesday, outdistancing the rest of the market. Ralph Acampora, a stock market analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Co., said the stock market has been in a ``two-tier'' system since August, with stocks in the Dow industrial average outperforming the rest of the market. ``It's not horrendous for the blue chips, it's horrendous for everything else,'' Acampora said.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon's Biggest S&L Taken Over
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede to make ``Benjamin'' into ``Benj.,'' as the company does it; INSERTS grafs 9-11: ``Kevin Sheilds,'' with spokesman quotes. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Oregon's largest thrift institution, Benj. Franklin Federal Savings and Loan Association, was seized Wednesday by regulators who said it failed to meet the stringent financial standards of the new savings and loan law. The Resolution Trust Corp., created last August to dispose of failed S&Ls, took control of the Portland institution, which has about $5 billion in assets, after the Office of Thrift Supervision said Franklin was operating in an unsafe and unsound condition. Franklin, largely because of the new capital standards, $106 million in the red at the end of November, according to Ed Headlund, deputy district director of the thrift office's Seattle office. That was after an accounting break of about $280 million, known as supervisory goodwill, was removed from its books. It had booked most of the goodwill as a result of its 1982 acquisition of Equitable Savings and Loan, which it took over at regulators' request. Goodwill is usually the difference between the purchase price of an asset and its real value. The S&L bill last August revoked the accounting break for Franklin and scores of other S&Ls. The law now requires institutions to hold tangible capital of $1.50 for every $100 of assets, and does not permit them to count good will in the $1.50. Also, Franklin suffered from problems in the Oregon real estate market that surfaced several years earlier, according to Headlund. In an attempt to pull out of its problems, Franklin in October announced a cost-cutting program that included layoffs and the sale of its commercial lending operation. Kevin Shields, a Portland-based spokesman for the Resolution Trust Corp., said the corporation will try to sell Franklin to or merge it with another savings and loan. ``But that won't happen quickly,'' he said, estimating it would take six months before buyers might be sought. Franklin Chief Executive Officer G. Dale Weight will be on paid leave, he said. Unlike many failed S&Ls, it did not invest heavily in commercial real estate or in securities such as junk bonds. About 80 percent of its holdings were residential mortgages. Franklin is the largest of Oregon's 12 thrifts. At the end of September, it was the 41st largest S&L in the nation, according Sheshunoff Information Services Inc., an Austin, Texas, consulting firm. In addition to Oregon, it operated branches in Idaho and Washington state. Regulators said Franklin would maintain normal business hours and stressed that all deposits up to the $100,000 insurance limit are guaranteed. It had $3.2 billion in deposits in 448,612 accounts. Its takeover brings the number of S&Ls under government management to 320.

DOC.HEAD: Division Reorganization Announced
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT to Lynne sted Lunne.
DOC.TEXT: The Federated and Allied department store chains said they are reorganizing their merchandising services and dropping store labels in men's suits and slacks, women's shoes and women's accessories. The changes in the retailers' New York-based Federated@Allied Merchandising Services will eliminate 25 of the division's 280 jobs, spokeswoman Carol Sanger said Tuesday. ``This is just refocusing the private label for the brands,'' Ms. Sanger said. ``It's getting out of a couple of areas the private labels have been in and getting into areas that are more profitable.'' The company said merchandising division would concentrate on women's ready-to-wear, men's home furnishings and children's clothing. Under the reorganization, Lynne Jergensen has been promoted to the new position of executive vice president for product development. Ms. Jergensen, who joined Federated Merchandising Services in 1973, has been a senior vice president for women's and children's clothing.

DOC.HEAD: Firm Reportedly Paid Out Millions in Bonuses Weeks Before Bankruptcy Filing
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. paid bonuses totalling hundreds of millions of dollars to its executives just weeks before its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection, a newspaper reported. The payments totalled as much as $350 million since December, The New York Times said in Wednesday's editions, citing Wall Street executives. Year-end bonuses are standard practice on Wall Street, although Drexel has been known for paying huge bonuses, the newspaper said. Several people inside the firm said some top executives received bonuses of more than $10 million two to three weeks before Drexel's collapse, the Times reported. Drexel spokesman Steven Anreder declined to comment on the size of individual bonuses. The bonuses were determined last year and were part of running the firm's business, the Times quoted Anreder as saying. ``If we didn't have bonuses, we wouldn't have had anybody working for us,'' he said. Representatives of Drexel's creditors told the Times they would examine the bonus payments to determine if they could be recovered as part of the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. Creditors may face a hurdle in trying to recover any bonuses because Drexel's securities subsidiary, which paid the bonuses, wasn't covered by the parent firm's bankruptcy filing. Federal regulations prevent securities firms from filing for bankruptcy. Nevertheless, Drexel's securities arm already has sold most of its nearly $50 billion in securities and the operationg will be liquidated as a result of the parent company's bankruptcy filing, officials at the firm have said.
